notes: On 22 January 2025, members of the Free Trade Union, family members, civil society representatives, and trade unions gathered at the Chea Vichea statue in Chroy Changvar (Phnom Penh) to commemorate the 21st anniversary of the assassination of Chea Vichea, the former president of the Cambodian Free Trade Union. The protesters demanded the government deliver long-overdue justice and called for proper investigations into all slain unionists.

On 21 January 2025, hundreds of farmers in Bati district staged a protest and blocked National Road 2 in Bati, Trapeang Sab (Takeo) to demand government intervention to address severe water shortages threatening their rice crops. Protesters used loudspeakers to call on the government to act immediately, warning of future protests if the issue remained unresolved.

On 20 January 2025, about 300 workers staged a protest at a garbage collection company 800Super-GAEA in Preaek Phnov, Praek Pnov (Phnom Penh), demanding the reinstatement of union president, vice president, secretary, and treasurer, who were suspended for joining the union.

On 18 January 2025, hundreds of workers staged a protest in front of the Glory Knitwear factory in Angk Snuol, Peuk, Angk Snuol (Kandal) to demand unpaid severance pay for 2024 and blocked National Road 4. Workers accused the factory of exploiting long-term employees and failing to honor promises to provide fair compensation upon closure.

On 13 January 2025, about 60 farmers, mostly women, from Kok Thlok village, staged a protest in Moung Ruessei, Kear, Moung Ruessei (Battambang) against the sharp drop in rice prices and blocked National Road No. 5 with a tractor loaded with rice sacks and banners demanding action. The farmers called for government intervention to raise prices above 1,000 riels per kilogram to ensure profitability.

On 18 December 2024, nearly 100 dismissed workers of NagaWorld staged a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to mark the third anniversary of their ongoing protest against alleged union discrimination by the casino's owner, demanding the reinstatement of dismissed union members, an end to union interference, and respect for workers' rights.

On 10 December 2024, a group of young people and relatives of imprisoned activists, dressed in white shirts, staged a protest outside the Royal Palace in Chey Chummeah, Doun Penh (Phnom Penh). They carried banners calling for the release of prisoners of conscience and were blocked by Daun Penh district authorities from traveling to the Dangkere statue to burn incense and honor patriotic heroes on International Human Rights Day.

assoc_actor_1: LICADHO: Cambodian League for the Promotion and Defense of Human Rights; Students (Cambodia)
notes: On 6 December 2024, approximately 50 youth, students, and members of LICADHO, the Cambodian Human Rights Coalition (CHRAC), and other civil society organizations marched from Kampot to Srah Chak, Doun Penh (Phnom Penh) to commemorate Human Rights Day on December 10, calling for respect for human rights and the release of prisoners of conscience.

On 30 November 2024, workers, unions, and members of NagaWorld staged a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) demanding labor law compliance and reinstatement, while unions warned that the EU's potential withdrawal of 80% of Cambodia's 'Everything But Arms' trade benefits over human rights concerns could devastate garment workers and exports.

On 26 November 2024, more than 100 members of the International Campaign to Ban Landmines (ICBL), including landmine victims, staged a protest in front of the venue of the Ottawa Treaty Review Conference, Sokha Siem Reap Resort & Convention Center, in Sla Kram, Siem Reap (Siemreap) against the U.S. decision to supply antipersonnel mines to Ukraine, demanding the U.S. to revoke this decision and advocating for the global abolition of landmines.

On 7 November 2024, around 30 community members representing 252 families from Kratie's Sambor district staged a protest outside the Ministry of Land Management, Urban Planning and Construction in Svay Pak, Russey Keo (Phnom Penh) to call on authorities to resolve a land dispute with Kasekam Youveakchun Svay Rieng Co. Ltd, which began clearing their land and crops in June 2024.

On 2 November 2024, about 100 members of Kuy ethnic group staged a protest in Chhaeb, Chhaeb Pir (Preah Vihear) to protect their rice fields and awaited a promised meeting with provincial authorities and representatives of the Chinese company Hengfu Group Sugar Industry to resolve ongoing land disputes. The protesters demanded authorities to urgently address the issue.

On 19 October 2024, about 30 members of NagaWorld staged a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the Cambodian government to resolve their labor dispute, which has remained stalled for nearly three years. Wearing white shirts symbolizing union protection, they displayed banners with demands, including the reinstatement of union leaders and an end to exploitative practices.

On 8 October 2024, over 100 families from Koh Khnhe commune in Kratie province's Sambo district gathered in front of Kratie Provincial Court in Kracheh, Kracheh (Kratie) to support their representatives who were summoned in a land dispute with the Vietnamese company Kamdhenu Ventures Cambodia and Svay Rieng Youth Agriculture Company and to protest against the companies for destroying crops and burning homes, facing allegations of illegally occupying state property and using violence.

On 3 October 2024, more than 100 Bunong people from four villages in Busra commune staged a protest at Busra commune hall in Busra, Bu Sra, Pech Chreada (Mondul Kiri) to demand the return of burial land and a community worship area, which they claim was encroached upon by traders in collaboration with corrupt authorities to obtain title deeds.

On 31 August 2024, about 30 members of NagaWorld staged a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding a resolution to their labor dispute, which has been ongoing for over three years.

On 16 August 2024, about 10 members of NagaWorld staged a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding respect for labor rights, their reinstatement, and the release of the union president. The protesters, holding banners reading 'We need a solution from NagaWorld,' emphasized that their demonstration was about labor rights, not politics.

On 7 August 2024, more than 400 villagers from six villages in Prek Narin commune, Battambang province, staged a protest at Aek Phnum District Hall in Preaek Norint, Aek Phnum (Battambang), demanding an explanation from the district governor regarding the division of their long-held land concessions into two areas. These lands, initially allocated to families for farming after the Khmer Rouge regime, have been under dispute due to recent government demarcation efforts aimed at reclaiming flooded forest areas around Tonle Sap Lake.

On 2 August 2024, about 200 indigenous people protested at Pech Chreada district office in Busra, Pech Chreada (Mondul Kiri), demanding expedited issuance of communal land titles after environmental rangers destroyed over 500 rubber trees in their village, claiming the land was within the protected Sre Pok Nam Lear wildlife sanctuary. The protest dissolved when the district governor promised to halt the destruction and compensate for the trees.

On 19 July 2024, about 30 members of NagaWorld staged a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) calling for the casino management and the Ministry of Labor to resolve ongoing labor disputes, enabling workers to earn a living. They displayed an orange cloth with the message 'We need justice' and an image of the scales of justice, symbolizing their appeal to the courts.

On 15 July 2024, over 150 villagers from Prek Samrong and Achm Kok villages in Kampong Samnang commune, Takhmao city staged a protest in front of Kandal Provincial Hall in Doeum Mien, Krong Ta Khmau (Kandal) to demand the provincial governor to hold a public forum to address the adverse impacts they faced due to the canal rehabilitation project. The villagers also called for the authorities to thoroughly study the project's impact and propose fair solutions.

assoc_actor_1: Buddhist Group (Cambodia); Mother Nature; NPP: National Power Party; Students (Cambodia)
source: Cambodia Daily; LICADHO; Radio Free Asia
notes: On 10 July 2024, about 150 members of Mother Nature, Students Association, Buddhist monks, Youth, and National Power Party staged a protest at the Caltex Bokor gas station in Boeng Keng Kang Ti Bei, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to commemorate the 8th anniversary of the assassination of political analyst Kem Ley who was fatally shot on 10 July 2016. The protesters demanded justice for Kem Ley and the release of the detained student movement and environmental activists.

On 10 July 2024, 20 residents of Samrong Tbong Community in Boeung Ta Mok staged a protest in Samrong Tbong village, Samraong, Prek Pnov (Phnom Penh) against forced eviction and relocation. They demanded authorities to cease threats of forced eviction and demolition of their homes.

On 29 June 2024, more than 20 members of NagaWorld staged a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) calling for the casino management and the Ministry of Labor to resolve ongoing labor disputes, enabling workers to earn a living.

On 27 June 2024, more than 100 land dispute victims from Kandok commune, Kandal Stung district, and Kampong Samnang commune, Takhmao city staged a protest outside the Ministry of Land Management, Urban Planning and Construction in Svay Pak, Russey Keo (Phnom Penh) to demand the Ministry to resolve their land issues. The National Forces Party had submitted a letter to Prime Minister Hun Manet the previous day, requesting intervention and compensation for 453 families affected by the construction of a new airport in Kandal Steung district. Rong Chhun, an adviser to the National Power Party, emphasized the need for government attention and appropriate compensation.

On 20 June 2024, more than 20 members of Buddhist monks and Mother Nature, dressed as ghosts, staged a protest outside the Ministry of Environment in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh). They demanded the designation of Koh Kong Krao as a marine national park, citing the ministry's persistent failure to protect the area despite promises made by the Minister.

On 19 June 2024, about 60 community members from Kratie province staged a protest outside the Ministry of Interior in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to demand the government halt the land clearing under an Economic Land Concession (ELC) granted to a Singaporean company in 2009. The protesters also submitted petitions to the Ministry of Interior, Prime Minister's Cabinet, and the Land Management Ministry.

On 16 June 2024, about 300 activists, members of the National Power Party (NPP), and detainees' families from various provinces gathered outside the party headquarters in Tuek Lak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk (Phnom Penh) to demand civil liberties and the release of political prisoners. The protesters holding banners and photos of imprisoned individuals called for the release of the National Power Party President and other detained activists and leaders.

On 14 June 2024, 70 members of union federations and unions staged a protest outside the Center for Alliance of Labor and Human Rights (CENTRAL) office in Boeng Tumpun, Mean Chey (Phnom Penh), accusing the organization of publishing a report that they claim unfairly restricted union representatives' freedom of association. The protesters submitted a petition to CENTRAL and the Ministry of Interior, denouncing the report as baseless and not reflective of the true conditions faced by unions in Cambodia.

On 12 June 2024, 25 Shengbo Garment factory workers protested outside Kampong Speu Provincial Court in Svay Kravan, Chbar Mon (Kampong Speu), demanding the reinstatement of their union leader, Roeun Kolap, who they say was unfairly dismissed for forming a union in June 2023. The protest coincided with a postponed court hearing for Kolap's case.

assoc_actor_1: CATU: Cambodian Alliance of Trade Unions; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 29 May 2024, around 30 to 40 members of the Cambodian Confederation of Trade Unions (CATU) staged a protest outside Kampong Speu Provincial Court in Svay Kravan, Chbar Mon (Kampong Speu) to demand the release of the union leader at Wing Star Shoes Co Ltd, who was arrested in February and charged with conspiracy to commit theft related to an alleged incident from two years prior.

On 27 May 2024, more than 20 young people cycled from Boeung Ta Mok (Prek Pnov, Phnom Penh) to the National Assembly in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to petition for a fair resolution to the forced evictions impacting their community. They demanded the 7th legislature to actively represent the people and resolve these issues, particularly focusing on land and environmental injustices.

On 24 May 2024, about 20 members of NagaWorld staged a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) calling for the casino management and the Ministry of Labor to resolve ongoing labor disputes, enabling workers to earn a living.

On 21 May 2024, more than 200 members of Bunong ethnic group from five villages in Mondulkiri province staged a protest at the community forest in Sre Thom village, Sokh Sant, Kaoh Nheaek (Mondul Kiri) against the authorities' complete confiscation of their farmland and land. They demanded that authorities assess the cultivated land's actual condition and return it to the community for present and future sustenance.

On 20 May 2024, around 300 Telugu youths from Visakhapatnam, India staged a protest in Sihanoukville, Buon (Preah Sihanouk) against forced work in cybercrime syndicates after a trafficking racket involving local agents was busted. They were detained by police officers following the protest, prompting efforts for their safe return by local authorities and ministries. The youths were promised jobs but coerced into cybercrimes upon arrival.

On 16 May 2024, nearly 50 residents of Damnak Sangke village protested in front of Phnom Penh City Hall in Srah Chak, Doun Penh (Phnom Penh), demanding resolution to a land dispute involving 2 hectares in Khan Dangkor. They held banners highlighting the critical importance of the land to their lives and called for legal title deeds, having only soft title deeds recognized by authorities.

On 10 May 2024, about 60 Samrong Tbong community members residing near Boeng Tamok lake attempted to march to the Prek Pnov district hall but police and district security guards obstructed in Samrong Tbong, Praek Pnov (Phnom Penh), preventing the residents from proceeding to the Praek Pnov district hall to discuss eviction orders.

On 6 May 2024, about 80 residents from the Daun Ov community in Choeung-Ek commune, Dangkor district staged a protest outside Phnom Penh City Hall in Srah Chak, Doun Penh (Phnom Penh) to demand land titles amidst threats from a company dumping sand into a nearby lake since 2020. The villagers sought resolution after years of unsuccessful attempts, including numerous petitions and direct visits to government agencies.

On 1 May 2024, International Workers' Day, nearly 1,000 workers and members of Cambodian Labor Confederation (CLC) marched from National Assembly (Chamkar Mon, Phnom Penh) to the Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training in Tuek Lak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk (Phnom Penh), demanding higher wages for garment workers and the restoration of union rights. They also called on the government to address their concerns and improve working conditions.

On 30 April 2024, Members of the Cambodian Alliance of Trade Unions (CATU) gathered in front of Kampong Speu Provincial Court in Svay Kravan, Chbar Mon (Kampong Speu), demanding the dropping of criminal charges against the president of Wing Star Shoes' union.

On 26 April 2024, about 60 members of NagaWorld staged a protest outside gathered in front of the Supreme Court in Voat Phnum, Doun Penh (Phnom Penh) to petition the Supreme Court to drop charges and secure the release of their leader, ahead of the court's ruling on May 3.

On 25 April 2024, about 400 workers at ML INTIMATE APPAREL staged a protest outside the factory in Nimitt, Paoy Paet (Banteay Meanchey) to demand payment from the factory owner due to the irregular wage payments and past violations of workers' rights by factory owners.

On 25 April 2024, about 50 employees of Cambodiana Hotel and Sofitel Phnom Penh staged a protest and submitted a letter to the Minister of Labor at the Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training in Tuek Lak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk (Phnom Penh) to demand intervention from both employers and the Ministry of Labor to address employment issues.

On 25 April 2024, about 20 activists of Mother Nature and monks gathered at Ministry of Justice in Chakto Mukh, Doun Penh (Phnom Penh) to commemorate the 11th anniversary of environmental activist Chut Wutty's murder and called for justice for him as well as a reinvestigation into his murder.

On 24 April 2024, more than 100 monks and members of the Khmer Kampuchea Krom Association staged a protest in Samaky Reangsey Pagoda (Wat Khmer Kampuchea Krom) in Stueng Mean Chey, Mean Chey (Phnom Penh) to demand an end to the persecution and discrimination faced by Khmer Krom citizens and monks. They also petitioned the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to intervene with the Vietnamese government regarding the decapitation of monks and detention of Khmer Krom activists.

On 22 April 2024, activists and members of the National Power Party gathered outside the party headquarters in Tuek Lak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk (Phnom Penh) to protest the government's suppression of democracy and demand the release of political detainees.

On 20 April 2024, members of NagaWorld staged a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) calling for government intervention to address labor disputes and the release of their union leader held in Prey Sar Prison.

On 19 April 2024, about 40 members of the Samrong Tbong Community in Boeung Ta Mok staged a protest in Samrong Tbong village, Samraong, Prek Pnov (Phnom Penh) against forced eviction and relocation. They demanded an end to authorities' threats of violence and called on the government to peacefully resolve the land issue.

On 10 April 2024, about 40 villagers from Prek Kampoes commune in Dangkor district gathered in front of Phnom Penh City Hall in Srah Chak, Doun Penh (Phnom Penh) to seek intervention regarding overlapping land titles with Eco Megapolis Development Cooperation. The villagers were concerned about potential eviction among the 50 affected families.

On 6 April 2024, members of Khmer Intellectual Students Union Association gathered in front of the Phnom Penh Municipal Police in Chrang Chamreh Ti Pir, Chrang Chamreh Ti Pir, Russey Keo (Phnom Penh), demanding the release of the President of the Khmer Intellectual Students Association, who was sent to court for questioning following his arrest on April 5.

On 6 April 2024, members of the Samrong Tbong Community in Boeung Ta Mok staged a protest in Samrong Tbong village, Samraong, Prek Pnov (Phnom Penh) against forced eviction and relocation. The residents confronted Prek Pnov district authorities regarding excavations behind their homes, resulting in a clash and minor injuries to two residents.

On 5 April 2024, homebuyers of New World Borey staged a protest at the New World Borey office in Phnom Penh Thmei, Phnom Penh Thmei, Saensokh (Phnom Penh) to call for a solution after the company's lawyer sent warning letters to all customers, threatening house confiscation if payment wasn't made as per notice.

On 1 April 2024, about 200 residents from Kandal Steung district and Takhmao town gathered at the Ministry of Land Management, Urban Planning and Construction in Svay Pak, Russey Keo (Phnom Penh) to submit a petition to the Minister, demanding to exclude their land from the Techo Takhmao International Airport project, issue land titles, and allow them to build on-site.

On 29 March 2024, members of the Bunong ethnic group staged a protest at the community forest in Sre Thom village, Sokh Sant, Kaoh Nheaek (Mondul Kiri) to demand Mondulkiri Provincial Governor Thong Savun allow them to plant farms in collective land communities. The protesters submitted a petition demanding authorities recognize their right to traditional farming, emphasizing their dependence on collective lands and the impact of economic land concessions.

On 23 March 2024, workers held a protest at RG Footwear Factory (Cambodia) in Baek Chan, Angk Snuol (Kandal), demanding wages and other benefits from the company following layoffs and promises of re-employment at the company after a fire.

On 22 March 2024, about 500 of workers at the Y&W Garment Factory continued staging a protest for the third consecutive day in front of the factory and blocking the road at the Baku traffic light in Spean Thma, Dangkao (Phnom Penh) to demand expedited solutions to pay their salaries and benefits after employers fled the factory without paying wages and other entitlements. The protest concluded after the protesters agreed to receive wages arranged by the Ministry of Labor.

On 21 March 2024, about 500 of workers at the Y&W Garment Factory continued staging a protest for the second consecutive day in front of the factory and blocking the road at the Baku traffic light in Spean Thma, Dangkao (Phnom Penh) as the Ministry of Labor failed to confirm additional benefits they were expecting. They demanded expedited solutions to pay their salaries and benefits after employers fled the factory without paying wages and other entitlements.

On 20 March 2024, hundreds of workers at the Y&W Garment Factory staged a protest in front of the factory and blocked the road at the Baku traffic light in Spean Thma, Dangkao (Phnom Penh) to demand expedited solutions to pay their salaries and benefits after employers fled the factory without paying wages and other entitlements.

On 18 March 2024, about 40 members of the Samrong Tbong Community marched from Night Market to the Royal Palace in Chey Chummeah, Doun Penh (Phnom Penh) to urge King Norodom Sihamoni to intervene in the Boeung Tamok development, which has adversely impacted their homes and livelihoods. However, the officials emphasized that the Royal Palace couldn't accept their petition as it doesn't handle such matters, advising the villagers to seek assistance from city authorities or government ministries instead.

On 12 March 2024, about 500 workers at the Y&W Garment Factory staged a peaceful strike and protest in front of the factory in Spean Thma, Dangkao (Phnom Penh) to demand a resolution to labor disputes after employers fled the factory without paying wages and other entitlements.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Forestry Officials
source: Camboja News; LICADHO; Radio Free Asia
notes: On 6 March 2024, over 100 members of the Samrong Tbong Community staged a protest in Samrong Tbong village, Samraong, Prek Pnov (Phnom Penh) against forced eviction and relocation. The residents faced eviction as the Boeng Tamok lake area underwent privatization for new development projects. The protest was met with tear gas and gunfire as authorities, including police officers and forestry administration officials, fired weapons and arrested approximately 40 residents.

On 5 March 2024, around 60 members of NagaWorld and the Labor Rights Supported Union of Khmer Employees (LRSU) staged a protest outside the Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training in Tuek Lak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk (Phnom Penh) to submit a letter to the Ministry of Labor, demanding intervention in their prolonged labor dispute, a fair resolution, and the release of NagaWorld union leader.

On 5 March 2024, over 100 members of Samrong Tbong Community held a protest at Samrong Tbong village in Samraong, Praek Pnov (Phnom Penh) against the eviction and relocation after the residents faced the eviction as the Boeng Tamok lake area was privatized and used for new development projects. The protesters raised banners to protest the forced removal and to demand the authorities to cease using violence against the people and to halt land confiscation.

On 29 February 2024, over 30 members of Kuy ethnic group staged a protest outside Tbaeng Mean Chey District Hall in Prame, Tbaeng Mean Chey (Preah Vihear) to demand a resolution to the ongoing land dispute. The protesters accused local authorities of unlawfully seizing and selling their land.

On 29 February 2024, around 100 members of Samrong Tbong Community continued holding a protest at Samrong Tbong village in Samraong, Praek Pnov (Phnom Penh) against the eviction and relocation after the residents faced the eviction as the Boeng Tamok lake area was privatized and used for new development projects. The protesters raised banners to protest the forced removal and to demand the authorities to cease using violence against the people and to halt land confiscation.

On 28 February 2024, around 100 members of Samrong Tbong Community held a protest at Samrong Tbong village in Samraong, Praek Pnov (Phnom Penh) against the eviction and relocation after the residents faced the eviction as the Boeng Tamok lake area was privatized and used for new development projects. The protesters raised banners to protest the forced removal and to demand the authorities to cease using violence against the people and to halt land confiscation.

On 27 February 2024, around 100 members of Samrong Tbong Community held a protest at Samrong Tbong village in Samraong, Praek Pnov (Phnom Penh) against the eviction and relocation after the residents faced the eviction as the Boeng Tamok lake area was privatized and used for new development projects. They stated that persecution by authorities is disrupting their livelihoods. Police, excavators and security guards attempted to clear the community's land, knocked out villagers resulting in injuries, including a child and two women, one of whom is pregnant.

source: Cambodia Daily; Cambodia News Gazette; Cambodianess; Camboja News; Khmer Times; Radio Free Asia
notes: Elections/referendum: On 25 February 2024, the Senate election took place in Cambodia (coded to Phnom Penh). The ruling Cambodian People's Party (CPP) secured a landslide victory, winning 55 seats out of the total 58.

On 22 February 2024, more than 100 members of Bunong ethnic group gathered at the community forest in Sre Thom village, Sokh Sant, Kaoh Nheaek (Mondul Kiri) to demand a resolution to a land dispute with cadastral officials after land titles were issued for over 2,000 acres of land, including community forest land. The protesters conducted a traditional ceremony, Sen Prey Phnom Demon, to pray for the protection of their community forest and cultural heritage.

On 22 February 2024, about 30 members of NagaWorld staged a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) demanding the Prime Minister to address two-year-long labor disputes at NagaWorld. The protesters also called for the release of their union leader.

On 14 February 2024, about 100 homebuyers of New World Borey from various provinces attempted to march to former Prime Minister Hun Sen's residence in Phnom Penh to seek intervention. The protesters were stopped by Kambol district security authorities, blocking their route in Kamboul, Pur SenChey (Cambodia). The protesters planned to continue seeking intervention and filing a petition at the Prime Minister's Office.

On 12 February 2024, about 200 homebuyers from various provinces gathered in front of the Borey Brilliant City office in Sla Kram, Siem Reap (Siemreap) to protest and demand repayment from Tycoon Leng Channa's Brilliant City. The protesters, who had invested in the company's house and land sales, claim that monthly interest payments were not paid.

On 12 February 2024, about 20 monks and students marched from Wat Botumvati (Phnom Penh, Daun Penh) to the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sport in Boeng Proluet, Prampir Meakkakra (Phnom Penh), demanding justice for a former pedagogical student removed from the National Institute of Physical Education and Sports league in December 2021. Holding banners and using white paper to symbolize freedom, the group demanded the Minister of Education to address the issue.

On 3 February 2024, more than 100 garment workers staged a protest in front of Shengbo Garment Factory in Preah Srae, Odongk (Kampong Speu), demanding the reinstatement of two recently elected union leaders who were fired by the Chinese-owned factory.

On 31 January 2024, more than 150 staged a protest outside Preah Vihear Provincial Court in Pal Hal, Preah Vihear (Preah Vihear) to follow the case of four community representatives facing charges filed by environmental officials. The protesters sought justice for the representatives and called for the protection of over 3,000 hectares of forest. Additionally, they demanded provincial authorities to ensure a transparent and fair resolution, prioritizing the community's rights to natural resources.
On 28 January 2024, members of NagaWorld staged a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) demanding the Prime Minister to address labor disputes at NagaWorld.

On 26 January 2024, about 800 Run Ta Ek residents staged a protest at Run Ta Ek Commune Hall in Run Ta Aek, Banteay Srei (Siemreap) in response to the government's decision to cut equity cards, resulting in deductions ranging from 20,000 to 300,000 riels per family. The protesters demanded the government to reconsider the deductions and seek a resolution to prevent further financial hardships.

On 22 January 2024, members of the Free Trade Union, family members, civil society representatives, and trade unions gathered at the Chea Vichea statue in Chroy Changvar (Phnom Penh) to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the assassination of Chea Vichea, the former president of the Cambodian Free Trade Union. The protesters demand justice as the real killer has not been identified by the government, despite two decades passing since the tragic event.

On 15 January 2024, more than 600 people in Khnat commune carrying banners staged a protest outside Siem Reap provincial hall in Sla Kram, Siemreap (Siem Reap) demanding the national government and UNESCO to halt newly enforced restrictions on buildings and repairs imposed by the APSARA Authority, responsible for overseeing the Angkor Archaeological Park.

On 7 January 2024, 13 youth and environmental activists staged a protest outside Hun Sen's Cabinet in Chakto Mukh, Doun Penh (Phnom Penh) demanding the Cambodian government to safeguard Koh Kong Krao island off the coast of Koh Kong province, which is earmarked for development, including a special economic zone. All protesters were detained and questioned by police officers before being released.

On 29 December 2023, more than 200 people living in seven villages in Kratie held a protest at Bos Leav, Chetr Borei (Kratie) demanding that provincial authorities allow them to occupy the land and cease forced evictions. The protest followed a survey by Kratie provincial authorities and officials who decided to allocate the land equally among families.

On 26 December 2023, about 50 members of NagaWorld gathered at Prey Sar Prison in Prey Veaeng, Dangkao (Phnom Penh) to demand the release of the NagaWorld Union President. The protest aimed to commemorate his birthday and denounce her year-long detention without charges, alleging persecution of independent unions. The protesters called for an end to discrimination, the release of her, and sincere efforts to resolve labor disputes.

On 25 December 2023, more than 200 people living in seven villages in Kratie held a protest at Bos Leav, Chetr Borei (Kratie) demanding that provincial authorities allow them to occupy the land and cease forced evictions. The protest followed a survey by Kratie provincial authorities and officials who decided to allocate the land equally among families.

On 23 December 2023, about 20 residents living near Boeng Tamok lake held a protest at Samrong Tbong village in Samraong, Praek Pnov (Phnom Penh) against the eviction and relocation after the residents faced the eviction as the Boeng Tamok lake area was privatized and used for new development projects. They stated that persecution by authorities is disrupting their livelihoods.

On 19 December 2023, more than 200 people from Phnom Penh, Kampong Speu, Pursat, and other provinces staged a protest at the Plot Office in Khsem Khsant, Odongk (Kampong Speu) to demand the owner of a land parcel in Udong district, Kampong Speu province, to fulfill the terms of the real estate purchase/sale contract after buyers from various provinces complained of not receiving title deeds despite payments.

On 18 December 2023, about 500 members of Candlelight Party gathered at the party headquarters in Veal Sbov, Chbar Ampov (Phnom Penh) to protest against the party leadership's removal of grassroots-level members, which they argued contradicted the party's statutes. Banners were raised by party members from various provinces, including Kampong Thom, Siem Reap, Tbong Khmum, and Phnom Penh, demanding an end to unjust dismissals and the reinstatement of ousted grassroots members.

On 10 December 2023, about 3,000 youth groups, monks, and civil society officials gathered at Freedom Park in Tuol Sangke, Russey Keo (Phnom Penh) to commemorate the 75th International Human Rights Day and demand government to create space for freedom of expression, support independent media, release political prisoners, and cease accusations against those advocating for justice and national reconciliation.

On 8 December 2023, about 50 union leaders from 12 institutions gathered at the Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training in Tuek Lak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk (Phnom Penh) to submit a letter requesting a meeting with the Minister and demanding a review of various concerns, including restrictions on trade union freedom, violations of labor rights, and threats against union leaders.

On 8 December 2023, more than 40 representatives of land communities in Boeung Pram area staged a protest in Boeung Pram, Boeung Pram, Bavel (Battambang) before the 75th International Human Rights Day to demand swift resolution of chronic land disputes and the legalization of their land titles, citing over 10 years of conspiracy involving influential individuals and local officials.

On 7 December 2023, over 30 Buddhist monks and youths marched from Kampong Thom province to Odongk, Kampong Speu to call upon the government to ensure dignity, freedom, and justice for all citizens. The group planned to join a large-scale International Human Rights Day gathering in Phnom Penh on December 10.

On 24 November 2023, about 30 members of NagaWorld staged a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government release the NagaWorld union leader, respect human rights, resolve the labor disputes, and stop discrimination in the workplace. Covered in paper and with their mouths symbolically restricted, the demonstrators highlighted their perception of unjust treatment by the government.

On 21 November 2023, about 40 members of NagaWorld staged a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government release the NagaWorld union leader, respect human rights, resolve the labor disputes, and stop discrimination in the workplace. They wore blue shirts representing the NagaWorld Union and red shirts representing NagaWorld.

On 17 November 2023, 14 members of Friday Women, women who were family members of detained activists, in solidarity with Candlelight activists marched from Stung Meanchey Bridge (in Stueng Mean Chey) to O'Russey Market in Boeng Proluet, Prampir Meakkakra (Phnom Penh) demanding the Cambodian government to release their imprisoned family members and stop using the judiciary to suppress social and political activists.

On 16 November 2023, 25 environmental activists rode a bike from Freedom Park (in Tuol Sangke) to the Ministry of Environment in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to submit a petition, demanding the government to revoke export licenses of Angkor Plywood Co., Ltd., to prevent deforestation in Cambodia.

On 10 November 2023, members of NagaWorld staged a protest by dressing in rubbish to convey a message to their employers outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government release the NagaWorld union leader, respect human rights, resolve the labor disputes, and stop discrimination in the workplace. They held banners made from plastic, water bottles, and straws, highlighting injustices. The protest took place after NagaWorld coerced 12 unionized employees into terminating their contracts without providing any reasons a few days ago.

On 5 November 2023, about 30 members of NagaWorld staged a protest by dressing in rubbish to convey a message to their employers outside the NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government release the NagaWorld union leader, respect human rights, resolve the labor disputes, and stop discrimination in the workplace. They held banners made from plastic, water bottles, and straws, highlighting injustices.

On 31 October 2023, nearly 20 environmental activists marched from the night market to the Ministry of Environment in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to submit a proposal to increase import duties on plastic bags. The district authorities, in civilian uniforms, blocked and accused the youths of disrupting public order. They removed banners from the group and used inappropriate language and physical force.

On 28 October 2023, nearly 200 residents in Phnom Penh who had purchased houses through the Borey Piphop Thmey Company staged a protest for the second consecutive day in front of New World office in Kamboul, Pur SenChey (Phnom Penh) to demand the release of Tycoon Hong Piv and the return of 50% of their money after the company repossessed their homes due to payment difficulties. The protesters held banners and shouted at the office demanding the company find a solution.

On 27 October 2023, nearly 200 residents in Phnom Penh who had purchased houses through the Borey Piphop Thmey Company staged a protest in front of New World office in Kamboul, Pur SenChey (Phnom Penh) to demand the release of Tycoon Hong Piv and the return of 50% of their money after the company repossessed their homes due to payment difficulties.

On 27 October 2023, members of Friday Women, women who were family members of detained activists, in solidarity with Candlelight Party activists protested in front of the US Embassy in Voat Phnum, Voat Phnum (Phnom Penh) to demand the US Ambassador to intervene and request the release of their imprisoned family members and political activists held for political reasons. The group called upon the Cambodian government to release prisoners and stop using the judiciary to suppress social and political activists.

On 25 October 2023, hundreds of residents gathered at Doun Num village in Mean Chey, Prasat Bakong (Siemreap) to protest against the APSARA Authority for demolishing their homes by the APSARA authority forces. They called for fair resolution and reasonable compensation.

On 5 October 2023, over 100 members of unions and organizations including the Cambodian Independent Teachers Association (CITA) gathered at Freedom Park in Tuol Sangke, Russey Keo (Phnom Penh) to celebrate World Teachers' Day. They also called for the elimination of corruption in Cambodia's education system, freedom of association for teachers, and an increase in teachers' salaries and benefits.

On 1 October 2023, about 30 members of NagaWorld staged a protest and held banners outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government release the NagaWorld union leader, respect human rights, resolve the labor disputes, and stop discrimination in the workplace.

On 27 September 2023, more than 300 members of Bunong ethnic group staged a protest for a sixth consecutive day at Dak Dam Commune Hall in Dak Dam, Ou Reang (Mondul Kiri), demanding a resolution to a land dispute with cadastral officials. They were concerned about the loss of their ancestral land, homes, and farming areas due to land titles issued for over 2,000 acres of land, including community forest land.

On 26 September 2023, more than 300 members of Bunong ethnic group staged a protest for a fifth consecutive day at Dak Dam Commune Hall in Dak Dam, Ou Reang (Mondul Kiri), demanding a resolution to a land dispute with cadastral officials. They were concerned about the loss of their ancestral land, homes, and farming areas due to land titles issued for over 2,000 acres of land, including community forest land.

They were concerned about the loss of their ancestral land, homes, and farming areas due to land titles issued for over 2,000 acres of land, including community forest land.

They were concerned about the loss of their ancestral land, homes, and farming areas due to land titles issued for over 2,000 acres of land, including community forest land.

On 23 September 2023, more than 300 members of Bunong ethnic group staged a protest for a second consecutive day at Dak Dam Commune Hall in Dak Dam, Ou Reang (Mondul Kiri), demanding a resolution to a land dispute with cadastral officials. They were concerned about the loss of their ancestral land, homes, and farming areas due to land titles issued for over 2,000 acres of land, including community forest land.

On 22 September 2023, more than 300 members of Bunong ethnic group staged a protest at Dak Dam Commune Hall in Dak Dam, Ou Reang (Mondul Kiri), demanding a resolution to a land dispute with cadastral officials. They were concerned about the loss of their ancestral land, homes, and farming areas due to land titles issued for over 2,000 acres of land, including community forest land.

On 16 September 2023, about 30 members of NagaWorld staged a protest and held banners outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government release the NagaWorld union leader, respect human rights, and resolve the labor disputes.

On 16 September 2023, about 10 employees of Giant Ibis Transportation staged a protest and held banners outside the company in Doun Penh (Phnom Penh; coded as Voat Phnum) to demand the resolution of a labor dispute that has persisted for over three years. They are calling on their employers to comply with labor laws and provide compensation as required.

On 12 September 2023, a social media activist and his wife were attacked by unknown assailants possibly in retaliation to his social media posts critical of the government in Preaek Pra, Chbar Ampov (Phnom Penh). A group of men in black uniforms and helmets deliberately collided with them and beat him severely. Both of them were injured.

On 11 September 2023, a former student of the National Institute of Physical Education and Sports, along with other activists staged a protest in front of the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sport in Boeng Proluet, Prampir Meakkakra (Phnom Penh), demanding justice and seeking clarification from the Ministry regarding their removal from the school in December 2021. During the protest, one of the protesters symbolically displayed the suppression of freedom of expression by wearing a mask with a black cross.

On 8 September 2023, workers staged a protest and held banners at Nyan Kids in Kamboul, Pur SenChey (Phnom Penh) to call for a minimum wage of $ 215 from 2024 as they could not accept the proposed wage increase in the third round. They argued for a minimum wage that aligns with current living costs and economic needs.

On 31 August 2023, about 50 members of NagaWorld staged a protest and held placards outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government release the NagaWorld union leader, respect human rights, and resolve the labor disputes.

On 29 August 2023, members of NagaWorld staged a protest and held placards outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government release the NagaWorld union leader, respect human rights, and resolve the labor disputes.

On 31 July 2023, about 20 members of NagaWorld staged a protest and held placards outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government release the NagaWorld union leader and resolve the labor disputes.

source: Cambodia Daily; Cambodia News Gazette; Cambodianess; Khmer Times; Radio Free Asia; VOA
notes: Elections/referendum: On 23 July 2023, the general election took place in Cambodia nationwide (coded to Phnom Penh). The ruling Cambodian People's Party (CPP) of Prime Minister Hun Sen declared victory.

On 11 July 2023, nearly 100 family members of Koh Kong land activists staged a protest in front of Koh Kong Provincial Court in Krong Khemara Phoumin, Stueng Veaeng, Khemara Phoumin (Koh Kong) to demand the court release and drop the charges against nine activists involved in the land dispute.

On 7 July 2023, eight members of Friday Women and women who were family members of detained activists marched from Malaysian Embassy (in Chamkar Mon, Phnom Penh) to Indonesia Embassy in Chakto Mukh, Doun Penh (Phnom Penh) to follow up on past petitions calling for actions against the persecution of political prisoners.

source: Radio Free Asia; VN Express International; VOA
notes: On 28 June 2023, about 40 members of NagaWorld wearing orange scarves staged a protest and held placards outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government release the union leader and resolve the labor disputes.

On 13 June 2023, about 30 members of NagaWorld held a protest fro the second day outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government release the union leader and resolve the labor disputes. The protesters held a banner and blue umbrellas with a phrase 'SAVELRSU', meaning 'save NagaWorld.'

On 12 June 2023, about 30 members of NagaWorld held a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government release the union leader and resolve the labor disputes. The protesters held a banner and blue umbrellas with a phrase 'SAVELRSU', meaning 'save NagaWorld.'

On 4 June 2023, 20 youths, activists, and monks marched from Mekong Gardens complex (in Chroy Changvar) to Royal Thai Embassy in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to commemorate the three-year anniversary of the disappearance of a Thai political activist who was in exile in Cambodia. The protesters called upon the Thai and Cambodian government to expedite the investigation of the case. Some protesters meditated in front of the Thai Embassy.

On 28 May 2023, 30 environmentalists rode a bike from Freedom Park (in Tuol Sangke) to the Ministry of Environment in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to call upon the government to protect natural resources and raise awareness about environment protection.

On 28 May 2023, nearly 40 members of NagaWorld held a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government release the union leader and resolve the labor disputes. The protesters wore orange prison jumpsuits and a black robe covering their eyes and mouth, symbolizing the suppressed freedom of expression.

On 26 May 2023, about 100 farmers and activists held a protest outside Ministry of Interior in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to support the president of Coalition of Cambodian Farmer Community and two colleagues who were charged with plotting against the state and planning to provoke a peasant revolution, and demand their release from pre-trial detention.

On 25 May 2023, about 100 farmers and activists held a protest outside Ministry of Interior in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to support the president of Coalition of Cambodian Farmer Community and two colleagues who were charged with plotting against the state and planning to provoke a peasant revolution, and demand their release from pre-trial detention.

On 24 May 2023, more than 300 farmers and activists held a protest outside Ministry of Interior in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to support the president of Coalition of Cambodian Farmer Community and two colleagues who were charged with plotting against the state and planning to provoke a peasant revolution, and demand their release from pre-trial detention.

source: Camboja News; Radio Free Asia; VOA
notes: On 22 May 2023, more than 200 farmers and activists held a protest outside Ministry of Interior in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to support the president of Coalition of Cambodian Farmer Community and his colleagues who were charged with plotting against the state and planning to provoke a peasant revolution, and demand their release from pre-trial detention.

On 19 May 2023, more than 100 community members and land rights activists staged a protest outside the Ministry of Interior in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to demand the release of three Coalition of Cambodian Farmer Community (CCFC) staffers who were arrested the previous day.

source: Cambodia Daily; Cambodianess; Camboja News; Khmer Times; Nikkei Asian Review; Radio Free Asia; VOA
notes: Other: On 15 May 2023, the National Election Committee (NEC) officially disqualified the main opposition Candlelight Party from contesting upcoming elections in July as the party failed to submit proper registration documents (coded to Phnom Penh).

On 12 May 2023, about 50 members of NagaWorld held a protest outside NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh). The protesters held banners demanding the government release the union leader and resolve the labor dispute, as well as calling upon the Malaysian owners to restore the employment.

On 11 May 2023, more than 30 union representatives held a protest in front of Adidas store in Boeng Keng Kang Ti Muoy, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to demand the company pay compensation to workers as the factory was suspended during the coronavirus pandemic.

On 10 May 2023, about 150 residents living near Boeng Tamok lake held a protest at Samrong Tbong village in Samraong, Praek Pnov (Phnom Penh) to call upon the Prek Pnov district authorities to stop dismantling community bridges and address land conflicts.

On 1 May 2023, about 2,000 workers, unionists, and members of civil society gathered outside the National Assembly in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to celebrate International Labour Day and call for respect of labor rights and an end to the harassment of unionists. Petitions were submitted to representatives from the National Assembly, Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training, and Phnom Penh Capital Hall.

On 26 April 2023, around 25 members of Mother Nature marched from Botumvatey Pagoda (Chey Chummeah, Doun Penh) to Ministry of Justice in Chakto Mukh, Doun Penh (Phnom Penh) to commemorate the 11th anniversary of environmental activist Chut Wutty's murder and called for justice for him. The protesters displayed photographs of Wutty and dressed as him to symbolize the continuation of his mission to protect the environment.

On 22 April 2023, nearly 10 employees of Giant Ibis Transportation held a protest outside the company in Voat Phnum, Doun Penh (Phnom Penh) to demand the company stop discriminating against unions and workers, as well as restore employment.

On 7 April 2023, about 100 members of Sam Rainsy (Candlelight) Party gathered at the party headquarter in Preaek Pra, Chbar Ampov (Phnom Penh) to call for the release of the candlelight party officials.

On 3 April 2023, about 40 members of NagaWorld held a protest outside Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Prampir Makara, Prampir, Ou Ruessei Ti Pir, Prampir Meakkakra (Phnom Penh) to support their representatives who attended the court hearing. The protesters demanded the government release the leader and resolve the labor dispute.

On 31 March 2023, nearly 20 youths gathered at the Ministry of Information in Voat Phnum, Doun Penh (Phnom Penh) to submit a petition asking for re-granting a license to Voice of Democracy (VOD) after being previously revoked by the Prime Minister.

On 15 March 2023, more than 400 people affected by the land grab in Sre Ambel and Botum Sakor district held a protest outside Koh Kong Provincial Hall in Krong Khemara Phoumin (Koh Kong), demanding Koh Kong provincial authorities address land disputes and drop the charges on their representatives involved in the land dispute.

On 15 March 2023, about 40 members of NagaWorld held a protest in front of the Supreme Court in Boeung Raing, Daun Penh (Phnom Penh) to support a Cambodian woman human rights defender and union leader who was sent to the court. The protesters demanded the government release the leader and resolve the labor dispute.

On 10 March 2023, about 20 women who were family members of detained activists staged a protest at the Delegation of the European Union in Boeung Raing, Daun Penh, Voat Phnum (Phnom Penh) to call upon the EU member states to take action against the persecution of political prisoners.

On 8 March 2023, about 20 young activists gathered on International Women's Day in front of the Thai Embassy in Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to demand Thai authorities drop the lese-majeste charges against two women protesters.

On 7 March 2023, about 50 members of NagaWorld held a protest in front of Court of Appeal in Boeung Raing, Daun Penh (Phnom Penh) to support a Cambodian woman human rights defender and union leader who was sent to the court. The protesters demanded the government release the leader and resolve the labor dispute.

On 1 March 2023, a monk along with supporters marched from Freedom Park in Phnom Penh to Ta Khmau (Kandal) as a part of a long march to the Thai border, calling for social morality and a halt to the persecution of social workers.

On 18 February 2023, 14 members of Khmer Thavrak, human rights activists, and Friday Women staged a protest at Freedom Park in Tuol Sangke (Russey Keo, Phnom Penh) to demand the government grant a license to Voice of Democracy (VOD) as the Prime Minister previously revoked its, causing the VOD to shut down.

On 15 February 2023, about 60 members of NagaWorld held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh). The protesters demanded the government release the union leader and resolve the labor dispute.

source: Cambodia Daily; Camboja News; Radio Free Asia
notes: On 13 February 2023, about 50 members of Khmer Thavrak, human rights activists, and NagaWorld staged a protest in front of Voice of Democracy (VOD) office in Boeng Keng Kang Ti Bei, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh) to demand the government not shut down VOD as the Prime Minister previously revoked the license of VOD.

On 9 February 2023, about 300 workers staged a protest in front of Zhen Tai Garment in Kakab, Pur SenChey (Phnom Penh) to demand a reasonable amount of wage after workers' salary was suspended for two months.

On 8 February 2023, more than 300 workers staged a protest at CAMBO HANDSOME in Chaom Chau, Pur SenChey (Phnom Penh) to demand the Ministry of Labor address the labor disputes and to call upon the employer to settle the compensation.

On 25 January 2023, about 1,000 workers staged a protest outside Smart Shirt Garments Manufacturing in Srang, Kong Pisei (Kampong Speu) against the salary cut after some workers took a day off to celebrate the Lunar New Year. The protesters blocked National Road 41 but later were intervened by police.

On 24 January 2023, about 50 members of NagaWorld held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh). The protesters demanded the government release the union leader and resolve the labor dispute.

On 22 January 2023, about 100 relatives and leaders of independent unions gathered at Vichea's statue in Chroy Changvar (Phnom Penh) to commemorate Chea Vichea, the former president of the Cambodian Free Trade Union, who was assassinated. The event marked the 19th anniversary of the murder. The protesters called for justice and demanded the government identify the murderers.

On 18 January 2023, about 150 residents of Battambang province gathered in front of Battambang Provincial Court in Svay Por, Battambang (Battambang) to testify in the case in which they accused the director of the Department of Agriculture of violating the public property rights. The authorities attempted to block the protesters.
On 16 January 2023, 152 workers staged a protest outside the Canterver Empire in Chaom Chau, Pur SenChey (Phnom Penh), demanding employers pay benefits according to the labor law.

On 14 January 2023, about 100 members of NagaWorld held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh). The protesters demanded the government release the union leader and resolve the labor dispute.

On 12 January 2023, 104 residents living near Boeng Tamok lake held a protest at Ministry of Land Management, Urban Planning and Construction in Svay Pak, Russey Keo (Phnom Penh) to file a petition demanding the government resolve land disputes after residents faced eviction as the Boeng Tamok lake area was privatized and used for new development projects.

On 10 January 2023, about 50 members of NagaWorld gathered in front of Prey Sa Prison in Prey Sar, Dangkao (Phnom Penh) to unleash balloons into the sky and call for the release on bail of the union leader.

On 8 January 2023, nearly 100 members of NagaWorld held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh). The protesters demanded the government release the union leader and resolve the labor dispute.

On 30 December 2022, about 100 members of Cambodian Independent Teachers' Association (CITA) marched from Freedom Park to Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Prampir Makara, Prampir, Ou Ruessei Ti Pir, Prampir Meakkakra (Phnom Penh) to file a petition calling for the release of teachers and prisoners of conscience.

On 25 December 2022, almost 30 activists and students staged a protest at Royal University of Phnom Penh in Tuek Lak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk (Phnom Penh) to demand the Ministry of Education stop issuing permanent residency permits to illegal immigrant and ban Vietnamese courses taught at the university.

On 25 December 2022, more than 200 residents staged a protest in front of Kandal Provincial Hall in Doeum Mien, Krong Ta Khmau (Kandal), demanding the government resolve the land disputes and set a deadline for residents to demolish their houses due to the construction of the new airport in Kampong Talong village.

On 25 December 2022, about 100 children representing families living near Boeng Tamok lake gathered at Samrong Tbong village in Samraong, Praek Pnov (Phnom Penh) to demand the government resolve the land disputes as local residents faced the eviction.

On 24 December 2022, members of NagaWorld held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh). The protesters demanded the government release the union leader and resolve the labor dispute.

On 18 December 2022, members of NagaWorld held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), marking the one-year anniversary of the December 18 strike outside NagaWorld. The protesters demanded the government release the union leader and resolve the labor dispute.

On 15 December 2022, a bomb went off in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh). It was hidden in a cake and placed outside NagaWorld casino. There were no injuries or fatalities. The suspect and motive were still unknown.

On 12 December 2022, about 100 members of NagaWorld wearing orange prison jumpsuits held a protest in front of Prey Sa Prison in Prey Sar, Dangkao (Phnom Penh) to call for the release on bail of the union leader.

On 9 December 2022, nearly ten women gathered in front of the Delegation of the European Union in Daun Penh, Voat Phnum (Phnom Penh) ahead of the EU-ASEAN Commemorative Summit. The protesters called upon the governments of all EU member states to take action against the persecution of political prisoners who were their family members.

On 6 December 2022, more than 100 members of NagaWorld held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government solve the labor disputes and calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts, and the release on bail of the union leader.

On 5 December 2022, dozens of NagaWorld members wearing orange prison jumpsuits staged a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the release on bail of the union leader.

On 27 November 2022, more than 300 members of NagaWorld and civil society workers gathered at Freedom Park in Tuol Sangke (Russey Keo, Phnom Penh) to call for the release of the union leader and equal rights for women and girls.

On 17 November 2022, about 300 residents of Tbong Khmum's Dambe and Memot districts, Svay Rieng's Romeas Hek district and Kandal's Kandal Stung district gathered at Ministry of Land Management, Urban Planning and Construction in Svay Pak, Russey Keo (Phnom Penh) to submit a petitions to the Prime Minister and Ministers demanding the government expedite the land dispute resolution process.

source: Radio Free Asia; Voice of Democracy (Cambodia)
notes: On 10 November 2022, six members of Khmer Thavrak staged a hunger strike for the fourth consecutive day at Freedom Park in Tuol Sangke (Russey Keo, Phnom Penh) to demand the government and court release Seng Theary as well as other arrested political activists. One of the protesters fainted and was later hospitalized. Police officials intervened and attempted to dismantle their tents.

source: Radio Free Asia; Voice of Democracy (Cambodia)
notes: On 9 November 2022, six members of Khmer Thavrak staged a hunger strike for the third consecutive day at Freedom Park in Tuol Sangke (Russey Keo, Phnom Penh) to demand the government and court release Seng Theary as well as other arrested political activists.

source: Radio Free Asia; Voice of Democracy (Cambodia)
notes: On 8 November 2022, six members of Khmer Thavrak staged a hunger strike for the second consecutive day in a forest in Preah Vihear (Preah Vihear) to demand the government and court release Seng Theary as well as other arrested political activists.

source: Radio Free Asia; Voice of Democracy (Cambodia)
notes: On 7 November 2022, six members of Khmer Thavrak staged a hunger strike in a forest in Preah Vihear (Preah Vihear) to demand the government and court release Seng Theary as well as other arrested political activists.

On 6 November 2022, about 100 members of NagaWorld held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the government solve the labor disputes and calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts, and freedom of expression in the workplace.

On 5 November 2022, a group of women gathered in front of the US Embassy in Daun Penh, Voat Phnum (Phnom Penh), ahead of the US President's arrival in Cambodia on 12 November to attend the US - ASEAN Summit. They called for justice for their arrested family members and the release of their husbands who were mostly opposition political activists.

On 4 November 2022, almost 20 women gathered in front of the US Embassy in Daun Penh, Voat Phnum (Phnom Penh), ahead of the US President's arrival in Cambodia on 12 November to attend the US - ASEAN Summit. They requested that the embassy give them the opportunity to meet with US President Joe Biden and called for justice for their arrested family members and the release of their husbands who were mostly opposition political activists. Police officers attempted to block and dispersed the demonstration.
