On 26 January 2022, around 1000 members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the 40th consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts. The protesters demanded the government release their eight representatives.

On 25 January 2022, members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the 39th consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts. The protesters demanded the government release their eight representatives.

On 24 January 2022, members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the 38th consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts. The protesters demanded the government release their eight representatives.

On 23 January 2022, members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the 37th consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts. The protesters demanded the government release their eight representatives.

On 22 January 2022, around 100 people staged a demonstration at Vichea's statue in Chroy Changvar (Chraoy Chongvar, Phnom Penh) to commemorate Chea Vichea, the former president of the Cambodian Free Trade Union, who was assassinated. The event marked the 18th anniversary of the murder. The protesters called for justice and demanded the government identify the murderers.

On 18 January 2022, members of NagaWorld union held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts. The protesters demanded the government release their eight representatives.

On 17 January 2022, members of NagaWorld union held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts. The protesters demanded the government release their eight representatives and submitted a petition to several Embassies asking for their intervention.

On 16 January 2022, members of NagaWorld union held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts.

On 15 January 2022, members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the 28th consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts.

On 12 January 2022, members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the 25th consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts.

On 11 January 2022, members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the 24th consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts. The protesters also submitted a petition to several Embassies asking for intervention.

On 10 January 2022, around 300 members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the 23th consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts. The protesters also submitted a letter to the Ministry of Labor asking for government's aid.

On 9 January 2022, around 300 members of NagaWorld union held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts. The protesters demanded the Ministry of Labor and NagaWorld release their eight representatives.

On 7 January 2022, around 300 members of NagaWorld union held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts. The protesters demanded the Ministry of Labor and NagaWorld release their eight representatives.

On 6 January 2022, around 400 members of NagaWorld union held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), demanding the release of their arrested unionists. The protesters also called for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, Cambodia's largest casino and luxury resort, and compensation for pay cuts.

On 5 January 2022, around 400 members of NagaWorld union held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, compensation for pay cuts, and the release of their representatives.

On 4 January 2022, members of NagaWorld union held a protest in front of the Australian embassy in Chamkar Mon, Boeng Keng Kang Ti Muoy (Phnom Penh), demanding the release of their arrested unionists. The protesters also called for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, Cambodia's largest casino and luxury resort, and compensation for pay cuts. The union leaders were arrested at the scene.

On 31 December 2021, around 1000 members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the 14th consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, Cambodia's largest casino and luxury resort, and compensation for pay cuts.

On 29 December 2021, around 1000 members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the 12th consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, Cambodia's largest casino and luxury resort, and compensation for pay cuts.

On 27 December 2021, 1000 members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the tenth consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, Cambodia's largest casino and luxury resort, and compensation for pay cuts. The protesters insisted on taking strike action until the proposal is accepted by the company. The protesters attempted to relocate to the nearby park but without success due to the intervention by police.

On 23 December 2021, members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the sixth consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, Cambodia's largest casino and luxury resort, and compensation for pay cuts. The protesters insisted on taking strike action until the proposal is accepted by the company.

On 21 December 2021, around 2000 members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the fourth consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, Cambodia's largest casino and luxury resort, and compensation for pay cuts.

On 20 December 2021, around 2000 members of NagaWorld union held a protest for the third consecutive day in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, Cambodia's largest casino and luxury resort, and compensation for pay cuts.

On 18 December 2021, 1000 members of NagaWorld union held a protest in front of NagaWorld hotel in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon (Phnom Penh), calling for the restoration of employment at the NagaWorld hotel, Cambodia's largest casino and luxury resort, and compensation for pay cuts.

On 10 December 2021, around 200 rights advocates staged a protest at Freedom Park in Tuol Sangke (Russey Keo, Phnom Penh) calling for the government to bring back human rights and democracy in the country. The protest marked the 73rd anniversary of International Human Rights Day.

On 22 October 2021, Cambodian police interrupted the protest held by 20 Friday Women protesters in front of the French Embassy in Daun Penh district (Voat Phnum, Doun Penh, Phnom Penh) to demand that France pressure Prime Minister Hun Sen and his administration to comply with the Paris Peace Accords. The police seized banners and pushed some of the protesters to the ground, causing several injuries.

Explosive remnants of war: On 8 October 2021, a mortar round exploded in Sala Visai commune, Prasat Balang district (Kampong Thom province), killing a boy and injuring two other children. The children found pieces of unexploded ordinance (UXO) when they went care for their cow, and they played with it, effectively triggering the explosion.

assoc_actor_2: Former Government of Cambodia (1993-); CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party
notes: On 29 September 2021, Lak Keang, a commune chief of Preah Sihanouk province's Bit Traing and member of the now-dissolved opposition Cambodia National Rescue Party, was arrested in Preah Sihanouk and was brought to Phnom Penh for questioning by police. This is the latest in a series of arrests, judicial harassment and attacks against officials of CNRP. The banned opposition party known for its vocal critics of Prime Minister Hun Sen. Location coded as Sihanoukville.

assoc_actor_2: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Former Government of Cambodia (1993-)
notes: On 29 September 2021,Tum Bunthorn, a former commune councilor for the banned Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP) was arrested in Phnom Penh for his reporting on corruption and land grabs. This is the latest in a series of arrests, judicial harassment and attacks against officials of CNRP, the banned opposition party known for its vocal critics of Prime Minister Hun Sen. Location coded as Prampir Makara.

On 19 September 2021, around 400 farmers gathered to block National Road 5 in Baribour district (Kampong Chhnang) to protest over the ongoing land dispute, which saw their farmland in Pursat province fenced off for years, preventing them from farming on the land the claimed to own.

source: Khmer Times; Voice of Democracy (Cambodia); Cambodianess
notes: On 12 September 2021, clashes erupted between more than 100 farmers and police during a protest over the land dispute related to the development of Phnom Penh's new international airport in Boeng Khyang commune, Kandal Stueng district (Kandal). Protesters blocked the road with a tractor and bonfires, and threw rocks and bottles at police and security officers, who responded with tear gas and water canons. The protesters were unsatisfied with the compensation for their farmlands that were expropriated for the development of the new airport. Thirty people were arrested, 21 of which were later released. Thirteen officers were injured.

On 10 September 2021, police dispersed a demonstration held by about 7 to 10 Friday Women protesters outside the US Embassy in Voat Phnum Commune, Doun Penh District (Phnom Penh) who were calling for the release of their family members that were jailed for their political stance and activism. Use of physical contact without crowd suppression weapons was reported.

On 7 September 2021, more than 50 villagers and farmers gathered to block National Road 2 in Kandal province in protest of the development of Phnom Penh's new international airport in Kandal Stueng district (Kandal) as they were unsatisfied with the compensation for their farmlands that were expropriated for the development of the new airport. More than 100 security officers were present, but did not intervene. No violent incidents reported.

On 31 August 2021, about 70 villagers protested in front of the Banteay Meanchey Provincial Court in Ou Ambel commune, Serei Saophoan district (Banteay Meanchey) calling for the resolution of in their ongoing dispute over a 193-hectar plot of land in Tharm Puok and Phoum Thmei communes in Thmar Puok district with a private firm. The protest came after representatives of around 170 families involved in the land dispute were questioned at court over accusations that they trespassed the firm's private property.

On 4 August 2021, about 30 people gathered outside the Commune Hall in Svay Chrum district (Svay Rieng) to express their anger after three farmers were summoned to the Commune Hall for breaking the coronavirus social distancing measures during their land dispute protest earlier in the week.

Around 2 August 2021 (as reported), more than 120 of farmers and their families held a protest on their rice fields in Svay Rieng against provincial authorities, as they refused accept the compensation for their farm lands which had been expropriated by authorites to build a reservoir.

On 2 August 2021, about 300 villagers and farmers held a demonstration at the construction site of the new Phnom Penh Airport in Kandal Stueng district (Kandal) as they claimed the airport's construction sent bulldozers to close an entry road to their farmlands that were located inside the construction project, which the farmers had not agreed to sell. During the demonstration, clashes erupted between the demonstrators and airport security guards. Minor injuries were reported. Police were also deployed at the site but did not intervene.

Security measures: On 29 July 2021, the Cambodian government [coded to Phnom Penh] imposed the national lockdown coming into effect from 29 July 2021 to 12 August 2021 to curb the spread of coronavirus. The measures include a nation-wide curfew between 9pm to 3am, a ban of gatherings of more than 10 people and the closure of schools, entertainment venues, and non-essential businesses.

On 23 July 2021, more than 80 people protested in front of the Siem Reap International Airport in Tuek Vil commune, Siem Reap district, (Siemreap) to demand full severance entitlements of the 130 workers who were laid off in April 2020.

assoc_actor_2: Former CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Former Government of Cambodia (1993-)
notes: On 23 July 2021, an activist and former Treng Trayoeng commune council chief from now-dissolved opposition Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP) was arrested at a grocery store in Traeng Trayueng commune (Kampong Speu) on charges of incitement related to her 2019 online posts supporting the return of CNRP leader Sam Rainsy, who had gone in self-imposed exile in Paris, to Cambodia. The activist fled to Thailand after a court summoned her for the posts. She was arrested and jailed after returning to the country, following Prime Minister Hun Sen's promise on granting exiled CNRP activists amnesty upon their return. Her arrest was the latest in a series of legal crackdown by the ruling Cambodia People's Party on political opposition figures and activists in the country.

On 14 July 2021, about 400 workers of garbage collecting company CINTRI held a protest at the company's headquarters in Tonle Basak commune, Chamkar Mon district (Cambodia) to demand severance payments after being laid off by the company.

On 5 July 2021, about 50 farmers and villagers from Kandal province held a protest at the Ministry of Justice in Daun Penh, Voat Phnum commune, Doun Penh district (Phnom Penh), demanding the release of their three fellow villagers. The 3 villagers had been arrested on 2 July and charged with incitement and occupying private lands after being invited by authorities to negotiations over their land dispute in Kandal. According to villagers, a private buyer had claimed over 170 hectares of the land located in Prasat commune, Sa'ang district (Kandal) where villagers had been cultivating since the 1980s.

On 2 July 2021, protesters demonstrated outside Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Prampir Makara district (Phnom Penh), to oppose the persecution of activists who held a demonstration on the anniversary of the Paris Peace Agreement, whose goal was to bring multiparty democracy to the country.

On 22 June 2021, almost 40 villagers continued their protest, which started in May, with a makeshift camp blocking a road in Boeng Khyang commune (Kandal Stueng district, Kandal) to protest against the unfair land expropriation for the creation of the new Phnom Penh Airport.

On 22 June 2021, market vendors staged a protest in front of Tuol Sangke Market in Tuol Sangke sub-district (Roussey Keo district, Phnom Penh), demanding the authorities lift the closure order imposed due to the coronavirus pandemic and demanding not to pay the full rent of the stalls during the closure of the market.

On 10 June 2021, villagers gathered in Kandal province to protest against the construction of a new airport and demanded fair compensation for the land that is being expropriated by the government. Location coded at the capital of the province, Ta Khmau.

On 8 June 2021, representative of NagaWorld casino employees demonstrated and filed a petition to the Ministry of Labour in Tuek Lak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk district (Phnom Penh) to demand government intervention and to protest against the unlawful lay-off of 1,300 staff of the casino.

On 4 June 2021, ten wives of jailed CNRP activists, also called the Friday Women, demonstrated at the United Nations Office in Chamkar Mon district (Phnom Penh), and filed a competition asking for the release of their husbands. As seven protesters rallied outside, they were dispersed by 30-40 security forces, presumed to be the police. Some were allegedly shoved to the ground. There were no injuries.

On 3 June 2021, around 300 farmers staged a protest and blocked a road in Tuol Prech commune (Ang Snoul district, Kandal) to oppose a military operation to clear and take over land which they claimed to belong to the state but have been farmed by local villagers. A squad of around 60 soldiers were deployed and live bullets were used in an attempt to disperse the crowd. A villager was shot and wounded by a soldier.
On 31 May 2021, around 60 people protested in Tuol Kouk district (Phnom Penh), demanding their money back from an investment company they accused of fraud.

On 30 May 2021, villagers blocked a road in Banteay Dek commune (Kien Svay district, Kandal), in a protest related to a long-held land dispute with neighboring villages. The protesters claimed they have been forcefully stopped from cultivating their land, which had been allocated to them by government. The blockade lasted until 31 May 2021.

Around 28 May 2021 (weekend of), around 2,000 factory workers blocked a road in Kampong Cham province to protest, demanding to be given rapid test for coronavirus infection, ability to quarantine at their home and to be paid half of their wages.

On 28 May 2021, seven wives of jailed CNRP members demonstrated at the US Embassy in Daun Penh district (Phnom Penh), to file a petition to the embassy demanding them to intervene and help secure the release of their husbands, amidst the coronavirus outbreak in prisons.

Explosive remnants of war: On 27 May 2021, a farmer was killed and another seriously wounded after having driven their vehicle over an anti-tank landmine in Sung commune (Samlout district, Battambang). The mine is a remnant of the Cambodia Civil War.
On 26 May 2021, more than 40 taxi drivers demonstrated in Phnom Penh to protest the fine imposed against them for having violated the coronavirus lockdown ban and transported passengers.

On 20 May 2021, around 300 factory workers blocked a road in Pur Senchey district (Phnom Penh), demanding their employers to pay half of their April salary as announced by the government, despite not having worked due to the coronavirus lockdown measures imposed.

On 14 May 2021, for at least a week, villagers blocked a road in Kandal province, protesting against the developing of a disputed land they clamed belong to the community. About 50 people were on stand-by at the disputed land during the daytime, while at night, ten people stand guard to protect the land. Location coded to the site of the development in Kandal Stueng district.

On 13 May 2021, around 300 villagers gathered at a red-zone barricade in Stung Mean Chey II commune, Mean Chey district (Phnom Penh), protesting and calling for themselves to be allowed outside the area to run essential errands and receive vaccination, as they have been in a strict lockdown due to the spread of the coronavirus.
On 12 May 2021, four unknown assailants beat a CNRP member with metal bars and pipes at Chroy Chungvar market in Phnom Penh. He was hospitalized and had fractured skull.

On 11 May 2021, around 300 villagers blocked a road in Krakor district (Pursat), over a land dispute with the authorities. The villagers claimed the authorities had destroyed their rice fields and confiscated the land for redistribution.

On 10 May 2021, around 100 villagers gathered on Veng Sreng road in Phnom Penh, demanding reduced rent as they have been prevented from working and earning wages due to the strict coronavirus lockdown measures.

On 7 May 2021, factory workers demonstrated in Pur Senchey district (Phnom Penh), demanding the authority for documentation related to the coronavirus vaccination which they need to be allowed back to work.

actor1: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Prison Guards
notes: On 3 May 2021, a prisoner was reportedly killed while in custody in Battambang province for theft. The official cause of death was reported by the authorities to be pneumonia but signs of physical assault were found on the corpse of the victim.

On 30 April 2021, hundreds of villagers and factory workers staged a protest in Phneat village, Stueng Mean Chey II commune (Mean Chey district, Phnom Penh), demanding for food supplies from the government as they are prohibited from leaving the house, even to buy food, as the lockdown measures put in place to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

On 29 April 2021, villagers and factory workers staged a protest in Phneat village, Stueng Mean Chey II commune (Mean Chey district, Phnom Penh), demanding for food supplies from the government as they are prohibited from leaving the house, even to buy food, as the lockdown measures put in place to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

On 27 April 2021, two unknown men on a motorbike attacked a CNRP member and her son while traveling in Phnom Penh. The son who has autism was hit in the head with a brick, resulting in the fracture of skull. It is believed that the assailants were targeting the mother who is a part of the Friday Wives group who hold weekly protests to demand the release of their jailed CNRP husbands.
On 3 April 2021, a prisoner died while in police custody in a local detention center in Battambang province. Bruises on his body suggested he might have been tortured by the police.

On 15 March 2021, around 60 villagers scuffled with around 100 private security guards in Chhuk district (Kampot) as the guards bulldozed the farmland which has been the subject of dispute between the villagers and a business tycoon since 2014. Two villagers were wounded and one security guard was arrested.

Property destruction: On 15 March 2021, unknown assailants set fire and burned down more than 50,000 saplings which had been planted in a ceremony presided by the PM at Techo Sen Russey Treb National Park in Chhaeb district (Preah Vihear). The authorities believed this incident was intentional and reflect hostilities towards the government. No injuries reported.

On 14 March 2021, two men, presumed to be illegal loggers, attacked a journalist while he was asleep in Svey Leu district (Siem Reap). The victim claimed that the attack was premeditated and he was targeted due to his coverage of the crime. He required stitches and had two teeth broken.

On 20 February 2021, at least 2 villagers were arrested by the police while they were demonstrating against the demolition of their houses in Siem Reap City (Siem Reap), which the authorities claimed to be built on state land.

On 18 February 2021, around 40 former CNRP activists demonstrated in front of the Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Prampir Makara district (Phnom Penh), demanding charges of CNRP activists to be dropped. They were dispersed by the local authorities shortly after, though no physical interaction was reported.

assoc_actor_2: Former CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Former Government of Cambodia (1993-)
notes: On 16 February 2021, a CNRP member, who was a former Kamboul commune councilor was attacked by two unknown men on a motorbike in Prampir Makara district (Phnom Penh). He was hit from behind with a rock, resulting in broken teeth.

Explosive remnants of war: On 13 February 2021, a man and a child were badly wounded as a war remnant exploded while they were clearing land in Lumtong Commune, (Anlong Veang district, Oddar Meanchey). The remnant is believed to be left from the Cambodian Civil War.
On 12 February 2021, sixty members of civil society groups and labour unions demonstrated in front of the Myanmar Embassy in Phnom Penh, opposing the coup d'etat in Myanmar on February 1.

On 11 February 2021, the father of a jailed CNRP activist was knocked unconscious by 2 unknown men in Kandal province. He was a frequent participant of the weekly Friday Wives protests. Location coded at the capital of the province, Ta Khmau.

source: Radio Free Asia; Voice of Democracy (Cambodia)
notes: On 4 February 2021, wives and family members of 21 CNRP activists on trial demonstrated in front of Phnom Penh municipal court in Prampir Makara district (Phnom Penh), demanding their release. The demonstrators were prevented by the authorities from entering the court and three were arrested.

On 24 January 2021, around 40 villagers from Boeng Tamok area staged a protest in Phnom Penh, demanding to be granted land titles to their houses as lands in the area have been increasingly granted to state institutions and private developmers.

On 22 January 2021, around 100 airport staff demonstrated at the provincial labor department in Siem Reap to demand that their entitlements be paid in full having been laid-off because of the coronavirus pandemic.

On 21 January 2021, around 6,000 garment factory workers blocked the road in front of Y&W company factory in Spean Thma commune, Dangkao district (Phnom Penh), demanding the employer at a Chinese-owned factory for their owed seniority payment. The demonstrators threw bottles, batons and stones at the police who tried to disperse the crowd. Two policemen sustained minor injuries.

On 20 January 2021, thousands of garment factory workers blocked the road in front of Y&W company factory in Spean Thma commune, Dangkao district (Phnom Penh), demanding the employer at a Chinese-owned factory for their owed seniority payment. One man was detained following a scuffle with the police.

On 18 January 2021, the police beat an elderly Vietnamese woman who was protesting in a land dispute between a Vietnamese community, Cambodian villagers, and the state in Sangkat Kbal Kaoh (Chbar Ampov district, Phnom Penh). The district governor later apologized to the woman.
On 15 January 2021, protesters demonstrated in Phnom Penh, calling for the release of an activist and union leader, Rong Chhun who was being trialed for incitement.

On 6 January 2021, around 20 Buddhist monks and nuns demonstrated in Thormatrey temple in Prey Sar commune, Dangkao district (Phnom Penh), to oppose construction work being done on a plot of land that the court ruled to belong to private owners, and not the temple.

On 29 December 2020, relatives and wives of CNRP members protested at the Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Prampir Makara district (Phnom Penh), during the mass trial of CNRP officials. Two were arrested by the police.
On 21 December 2020, around 100 CNRP supporters held a demonstration near a court in Phnom Penh as the authorities began the trials of 5 detained CNRP activists.
On 20 December 2020, a scuffle took place in Prey Nob district (Preah Sihanouk) over a land dispute, leading to several injuries. Residents also reported hearing two gunshots.

On 18 December 2020, fifteen wives of jailed CNRP members protested in front of Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Prampir Makara district (Phnom Penh), demanding the release of their husbands. The protesters attempted to march to the EU Delegation but were blocked by the police.

On 17 December 2020, around 100 villagers demonstrated at Pailin Provincial Court in Pailin City, Pailin province, protesting against the court summons of 3 community representatives for illegally occupying the land which had been sold to a private developer.

On 12 December 2020, the son of a CNRP member was struck with a stick by three unknown assailants in Boribour district (Kampong Chhnang) and was seriously wounded. The attack is believed to be motivated by the victim's affiliation with the CNRP.
On 12 December 2020, four unknown assailants attacked a CNRP member by striking him as he travelled on a tuk-tuk in Phnom Penh.

On 4 December 2020, wives of arrested CNRP members demonstrated in Phnom Penh, demanding their releases. The demonstrators also voiced concerns over the health of the detainees as they have been continuously refused visits.

On 20 November 2020, fifty security personnel violently dispersed the demonstration of a dozen wives and relatives of jailed CNRP activists who gathered in front of the Royal Palace in Daun Penh district (Phnom Penh), demanding the king's intervention for the release of the jailed CNRP members. One woman was kicked by the guard, leaving her unable to walk. The protesters attempted to rally to the British Embassy but were chased off by the authorities.
tags: crowd size=a dozen; women targeted: protesters; women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons

notes: On 18 November 2020, armed villagers clashed with security guards of a company who had been given land concession in Trapaing Phlaing commune (Chhuk district, Kampot), resulting in one death and another injury. Both parties are involved in a dispute over a piece of land, which had been occupied by the villagers, given to the company by the government.
On 18 November 2020, a group of about 40 villagers lynched to death a fisher accused of stealing bananas, in Setbou commune (Takhmau City, Kandal).

On 18 November 2020, around 200 protesters gathered in front of Koh Kong Provincial Court in Koh Kong province, during the hearing of the of a case involving land activists and a sugar plantation. Location coded at the capital of the province, Krong Khemara Phoumin.

On 17 November 2020, around 20 former employees of Sofitel Phnom Penh, who had been laid off due to the effects of the coronavirus pandemic, demonstrated in front of the Labor Ministry in Phnom Penh, claiming that the hotel had not compensated them fairly.

Explosive remnants of war: On 13 November 2020, a police officer stepped on an anti-personnel land mine and was seriously injured near a temple in Kantuot commune (Choam Khsant district, Preah Vihear). The explosive is believed to have been planted during the Thai-Cambodian border dispute in 2007.

On 13 November 2020, a group of wives of arrested CNRP members marched to file a petition to the king at the royal palace in Daun Penh district (Phnom Penh), demanding release of the CNRP members. They were pushed back by security guards and a palace representative met with the protesters and denied to receive the petition.

On 6 November 2020, family members of arrested CNRP activists gathered in front of the Royal Palace in Daun Penh district (Phnom Penh) to demonstrate and to file a petition to the king, demanding the release of jailed CNRP activists and those arrested for protesting in front of the Chinese Embassy a few weeks ago. The protesters were dispersed by security guards.

On 3 November 2020, three unknown men drove a motorcycle into the wife of a CNRP activist who was riding her own motorcycle in Phnom Penh, and seriously wounded her. The victim claimed that this is a staged accident by the Cambodian authorities in an attempt to stop her for campaigning for her husband's release.
tags: women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons

notes: On 26 October 2020, nearly 100 construction workers demonstrated in Tuol Kouk district (Phnom Penh), protesting against a mall developer who owed their wages.

On 23 October 2020, sixty to a hundred CNRP members and land rights activists demonstrated in front of the Chinese Embassy in Phnom Penh, where up to 300 policemen were deployed, calling China and Cambodia to respect the Paris Peace Agreements. Six protesters were dragged away from the area by the officers, three others were arrested and the remaining were marched away by the guards. The protesters then demonstrated in front of the US and French Embassies without further incidents.

On 20 October 2020, timber smugglers smashed the vehicle and attempted to assault 2 journalists reporting on illegal timber trade near Sekong bridge in Steung Treng commune, (Steung Treng, Stung Treng). One journalist suffered a slight injury.

On 19 October 2020, a secretary general of the CNRP's executive committee was hit in the head with a rock by 2 assailants on a motorcycle in Phnom Penh. He lost consciousness and was hospitalized. It is believed that the attack was politically motivated.

On 12 October 2020, workers who had been on strike to demand compensation from the Cambodian Cultural Village staged a protest in front of the village in Siem Reap, following the company's announcement to permanently close the business.

On 8 October 2020, around 30 protesters gathered in front of the residence of the Prime Minister in Phnom Penh, demanding assistance in obtaining the titles for their lands. After their petition was handed to the PM's representative, the protesters were pushed to demonstrate at a nearby temple.
On 5 October 2020, a group of teachers from the Cambodian Independent Teachers Association demonstrated at Freedom Park in Phnom Penh, demanding a pay increase.

On 1 October 2020, family members and wives of detained CNRP activists demonstrated in front of the Supreme Court in Phnom Penh, demanding their release. Forty security officers, presumably the police, were deployed to disperse the demonstration, resulting in the injuries of 2 protesters. The protesters also rallied to the US Embassy to call for an intervention from the international community.

On 30 September 2020, dozens of officers, presumed to be the police, dispersed the group of 60 protesters who had been demonstrating and camping outside Koh Kong Provincial Hall in Krong Khemara Phoumin (Koh Kong). Protesters were calling on the local administration for assistance in a land dispute with a private company that had evicted more than 1,500 households to build a resort. Four protesters were arrested and were released on the same day.

On 28 September 2020, five to six unknown assailants attacked two journalists who were on a trip to investigate the illegal timber trade in Memot district (Tbong Khmum). The assailants beat the journalists with sticks and threw an axe at their car. At least one journalist suffered an injury on his back. It is believed that the attack was motivated by the victims' reporting of forestry crimes.

On 28 September 2020, around 60 villagers started camping out outside Koh Kong Provincial Hall in Krong Khemara Phoumin (Koh Kong), calling the local administration for assistance in their land dispute with a private company who had evicted more than 1,500 households to build a resort.

On 25 September 2020, more than 25 wives of arrested CNRP members staged their weekly demonstration in front of the Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Prampir Makara district (Phnom Penh), demanding the release of their husbands.

On 22 September 2020, dozens of local CNRP supporters gathered and demonstrated in front of Tbong Khmum Provincial Court in Tbong Khmum, during the sentence hearing of 5 former CNRP members. Location coded at the capital of the province, Suong.

On 21 September 2020, villagers from Koh Kong, Preah Sihanouk, Svay Rieng and Tbong Khmum gathered and blocked the road in front of the Land Management Ministry in Tonle Basak sub-district (Chamkar Mon district, Phnom Penh), demanding government's assistance in solving land disputes and land-related issues. Sources estimated there to be 400 to 1100 participants. Security forces were present at the scene.

On 11 September 2020, around 250 garment factory workers protested outside the Labour Ministry in Tuol Kouk district (Phnom Penh), demanding assistance as the owner of the company left without paying the workers' wages.

On 10 September 2020, around 30 vendors with shops in Thailand staged a protest in Banteay Meanchey province, calling for the border's re-opening. Vendors and cart-pushers have not been allowed to cross the border due to coronavirus concerns. Location coded at the capital of the province, Serei Saophoan.
On 10 September 2020, more than 4,000 Y&W Garment factory workers blocked a street in Dangkao district (Phnom Penh), protesting and demanding time-off over Pchum Ben holidays.

On 9 September 2020, almost 900 textile factory workers protested in Takeo province, demanding their overdue payment following the suspension of all operations by the factory. Location coded at the capital of the province, Doun Kaev.

source: Phnom Penh Post; Radio Free Asia
notes: On 7 September 2020, the police barred around 50 people who had gathered to stage a demonstration, demanding the release of the jailed union leader at Freedom Park in Phnom Penh (Cambodia). Following the failed attempt of demonstration, three members, including the vice-president of the Khmer Thavrak group, were arrested.

On 4 September 2020, police officers violently dispersed the Friday Women protest held by wives and family members of the arrested CNRP activists in front of the Phnom Penh Criminal Court in Prampir Makara district (Phnom Penh). The demonstrators demanded the release of jailed CNRP members. One woman was slammed to the ground by the security forces, causing her to lose consciousness and was later hospitalized. Several other women were also hurt.
tags: crowd size=no report; women targeted: protesters; women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons

notes: On 1 September 2020, around 400 garment factory workers who were on strike protested in front of the factory in Siem Reap, demanding the reinstatement of the 2 union leaders and the compensation for workers who had been laid off due to the economic impact of the coronavirus. The workers began striking late last month.

On 1 September 2020, around 50 protesters rallied to the Japanese and German embassies in Chamkar Mon district (Phnom Penh), to file a petition demanding their intervention to secure the release of a union leader who had been jailed for his comment on the border issue between Cambodia and Vietnam. Police officers tried to block the rally.

On 26 August 2020, a group of around 100 protesters demonstrated in front of the Appeal Court in Phnom Penh, demanding the release of an activist jailed for his comment on the Cambodian-Vietnamese border issue.

On 25 August 2020, around 50 villagers from Kandal and Takeo province, whose lands fall within the planned site for the construction of the new international airport, gathered to demonstrate and to submit a petition at the residence of the Prime Minister at Ta Khmau city (Kandal), demanding a bigger payout from the airport developer. After submitting the petition, the protesters were told to disperse by the security guards.

source: Radio Free Asia; Voice of Democracy (Cambodia)
notes: On 24 August 2020, 20-30 union member protesters rallied in front of the Office of the UN OHCHR in Chamkar Mon district (Phnom Penh), filing a petition calling for the help in securing the release of the union leader activist jailed for his comment on the border issue between Cambodia and Vietnam. They were prevented by police officers from marching to the Embassy of Japan. However, another group of protesters managed to file another petition there.

On 23 August 2020, a group of workers who had been on strike since August 14 demonstrated in front of the Cambodian Cultural Village in Siem Reap city (Siem Reap) demanding the payment of their monthly wages and other benefits which have been cut since April due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on tourism.
Explosive remnants of war: On 13 August 2020, an unexploded war remnant exploded in Veal Veaeng district of Pursat, Cambodia, seriously wounding 4 civilians.

On 13 August 2020, at least 6 activists, including members of the Khmer Thavrak group, staged a protest in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, calling for the release of a jailed activist who had made a comment about Cambodia's loss of land to Vietnam.

On 13 August 2020, police officers arrested 5 members of the Khmer Thavrak youth group and another activist in Prampir Makara and Pur Senchey districts (Phnom Penh), for having staged a protest demanding the release of Rong Chhun, a political activist and union leader earlier on the same day. During one of the arrests, the officers reportedly dragged a female Khmer Thavrak member into a car by her hair and beat her.
tags: women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders

notes: On 13 August 2020, around 30 villagers gathered in front of the Ministry of Land Management, Urban Planning and Construction in Boeung Trabek district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to protest and to submit a petition following the incident in which 21 villagers accused of occupying and cultivating on land belonging to a private company were arrested by the police.

On 10 August 2020, a teacher's union leader, who had led protests calling for the release of an activist jailed over his comment on the loss of Cambodian land to Vietnam, was attacked by two unknown men who pushed her to the ground as she was on a motorbike in Kandal province, Cambodia. She was knocked unconscious for a while and had to receive stitches to her hand. Location coded at the capital of the province, Ta Khmau.

On 7 August 2020, around 20 staff of Le Meridien hotel held a banner in front of the Labor Department in Siem Reap, Cambodia, protesting over the reduction of their wages and the firing of 3 union activists. They also demanded the labour department's intervention in the dispute. In the afternoon, they moved to protest at Le Meridien hotel in Siem Reap, where they were joined by about 30 more workers.

On 7 August 2020, family members of arrested CNRP activists continued their weekly protest in front of Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Prampir Makara district of Phnom Penh, demanding the release of the political prisoners.

On 5 August 2020, protesters demonstrated at Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Prampir Makara district of Phnom Penh, demanding the release of an activist jailed over his comment on Cambodia' territory loss to Vietnam.

On 5 August 2020, a group of around 20 protesters demonstrated outside Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Prampir Makara district, Phnom Penh, to demand the release of an activist jailed over his comment on the loss of Cambodian territory to Vietnam. In an attempt to disperse the protesters, a group of 10 security guards surrounded the protesters, pushed, kicked and dragged them. Two protesters sustained minor injuries.

Explosive remnants of war: On 3 August 2020, two farmers were killed by the explosion of a UXO believed to be a leftover from the Cambodian civil war in a plantation in Anlong Reab commune, Veal Veng district of Pursat, Cambodia.

On 3 August 2020, seventy security officers set up a barricade in front of Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Prampir Makara district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, as around 30 protesters rallied, demanding the release of an activist jailed for his comment on the loss of border territory to Vietnam. The security guards got into a scuffle with three protesters who tried to break the barricade, no injuries reported. The protesters later marched to the Justice Ministry, where they were also blocked, before regrouping at Wat Botum Park.

On 1 August 2020, around 100 supporters of an activist, who had been jailed for his remark that the government allowed Vietnam to encroach on their farmland, gathered in protest at the Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Prampir Makara district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, demanding his release.

On 31 July 2020, family members of jailed CNRP activists protesting for their releases at the Municipal Court in Prampir Makara district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, were stopped by the police from marching to the French Embassy to follow up on the petition they had previously submitted.

On 27 July 2020, around 30 villagers demonstrated in front of Wat Botum pagoda park, near the Prime Minister's cabinet office in Chakto Mukh, Daun Penh district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to protest against the court complaint of a land broker against them over lands that had been given to them by the Phnom Penh City Hall.

On 24 July 2020, wives and family members of jailed CNRP activists protested for the 6th time in front of the Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Prampir Makara district, Phnom Penh, to demand the release of the political activists. Around 30 security personnel, presumably the police, violently dispersed the crowd by aggressively dragging them from the building, injuring at least 5 protesters. A woman was pulled so violently that she could barely walk thereafter. The protesters later marched to the British Embassy to file a petition.

On 23 July 2020, around 100 garment factory workers from Violet Apparel factory submitted a petition to the Labour Ministry, then rallied toward the residence of the Prime Minister, demanding government intervention in regards to the closure of their factory, as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. The protesters were stopped by around 50 police officers in Phsar Depou Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia.

On 17 July 2020, the police suppressed a demonstration by 25 family members of jailed CNRP activists who were protesting for the fifth time at Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. The protesters demanded the release of the political prisoners.

Explosive remnants of war: On 13 July 2020, an intoxicated civilian found a UXO in Pursat province of Cambodia. As he attempted to throw it into the river, it exploded and wounded him. Location coded at the capital of the province, Pursat. The UXO is believed to be a leftover from the Cambodian War.

On 10 July 2020, the 4th anniversary of the murder of a well-known political commentator and activist, around 100 activists who rallied to the commemoration ceremony were met with roadblocks set up by the police in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, in an attempt to stop them.

On 10 July 2020, family members of jailed CNRP activists protested in front of the Municipal Court in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand release of jailed political prisoners. At least one female protester reported that she was assaulted and strangled by the court guards. She sustained bruises and was unable to work as a result.

On 9 July 2020, to commemorate the fourth anniversary of the murder of a political activist, around 20 youth activists marched from his hometown in Leay Bour commune, Tram Kak district in Takeo province to Daun Keo city. They were stopped on 4 occasions by police officers to intended to block the procession.

On 8 July 2020, an environmental activist was punched and beaten by a group of villagers during a public forum in Seda commune (Lumphat district, Ratanak Kiri), shortly after he made an accusation that local authorities conspired with local villagers in the destruction of a community forest land in the area in 2017. He was taken to the hospital on the next day.

On 8 July 2020, police dispersed a group of 7 activists and 12 monks who gathered in Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh province, Cambodia to hold a Buddhist ceremony and at the spot where a well-known political activist was murdered in 2016. A participant said that the commemoration was held to 'strengthen the national spirit'. A protester was briefly detained. After they were dispersed, they gathered on a nearby street to hold the Buddhist ceremony and then walked to neighbouring Takeo province.

On 8 July 2020, almost 50 to more than 100 garment factory workers from Hana (Cambodia) 1 Inc gathered in front of the Prime Minister's residence in Daun Penh district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand intervention after they failed to negotiate with their employer regarding owed payments following the factory closure.

On 1 July 2020, around 300 garment factory worker of Hana (Cambodia) I Inc protested in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to oppose the closure of the factory due to the coronavirus pandemic. Later, more than 50 started marching toward the residence of the Prime Minister to demand government intervention, but they were met with police officers who stopped the rally.

On 29 June 2020, more than 50 garment factory workers of New Best Global Textile company protested at the Labour Ministry in Tuek L'ak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, demanding their owed wages.

On 26 June 2020, ten wives of arrested CNRP affiliates gathered at the Municipal Court in Veal Vong, Prampir Makara district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia. They protested the arrests and demand their release. They were intimidated by the police who seized their cardboard signs and demanded they stop chanting.

On 26 June 2020, family members of jailed activists and CNRP members petitioned at the US Embassy in Voat Phnum, Daun Penh district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, demanding the US's assistance to secure the activists' release.

On 25 June 2020, more than 40 female entertainment workers gathered in front of the Ministry of Labour, Ministry of Women's Affairs and the Council of Ministers in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand the government to extend the financial aid package to cover workers in the entertainment sector as they have been affected by the closure of entertainment venues as a part of the measures to curb the spread of the coronavirus.

On 19 June 2020, around 600 residents and monks blocked a road in Preaek Anhchanh commune, Mukh Kampul district of Kandal, Cambodia, in a demonstration against a sand dredging activity on a piece of land which they claimed to belong to the Ratanak Bopharam Pagoda.

On 19 June 2020, around 20 family members of arrested CNRP activists demonstrated in front of Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Veal Vong, Prampir Makara district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, demanding immediate and unconditional release of the prisoners.

Around 17 June 2020 (as reported), more than 200 NagaWorld casino workers demonstrated and submitted a petition to the Ministry of Labour in Tuek Lak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, demanding financial assistance as entertainment venues remained close as per the government's coronavirus prevention measures.
Around 16 June 2020 (from 15 - 16 June), more than 60 construction workers protested in Tuol Kouk district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand their missing 3-month wages.

Explosive remnants of war: On 10 June 2020, a man was killed and another seriously injured after having stepped on a landmine in Chhnal Moan commune, Koas Krala district of Battambang, Cambodia. The landmine is believed to be leftover from previous conflicts.

On 10 June 2020, more than 20 representatives of entertainment workers gathered at the Ministry of Labour in Tuek L'ak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to protest and submit a petition demanding a similar allowance as that given to garment factory and tourism workers who are affected by business closures due to the coronavirus pandemic.

Explosive remnants of war: On 8 June 2020, a woman accidentally burned an unexploded ordinance which was hidden among rubbish, causing an explosion that resulted in her death in Snuol district of Kratie, Cambodia. The explosive is believed to be from the Cambodian War.
On 4 June 2020, unidentified armed men abducted a Thai pro-democracy activist exiled in Cambodia in front of his apartment in Chroy Changvar district of Phnom Penh.

On 3 June 2020, eighteen activists were stopped and their bicycles were confiscated by the local authorities in Koh Kong, Cambodia during their bicycle rally to highlight environmental concerns in Koh Kong Krav island. The rally started on June 2, and was planned to head toward Phnom Penh. Location coded at the capital of the province, Krong Khemara Phoumin.

On 2 June 2020, 700 garment factory workers of TY Fashion Cambodia protested in Ponhea Lueu district of Kandal, Cambodia, demanding their payment allowance from the government and employer as they had been suspended from work due to the coronavirus pandemic.

On 2 June 2020, hundreds of garment factory workers who are suspended gathered and blocked the road in Kandal province of Cambodia to protest and demand the payment of the government-promised financial assistance amid the economic downturn during the coronavirus pandemic. Location coded at the capital of the province, Ta Khmau.

On 1 June 2020, around 1,000 Cambodian traders gathered at the border check point in Paoy Paet, Banteay Meanchey province of Cambodia, to protest against the prolonged border closure due to the coronavirus pandemic, and to demand Thai authorities allow them to cross into Thailand to do business. The local authorities intervened and the crowd was dispersed.
On 31 May 2020, around 150 construction workers protested in Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand unpaid wages.

Around 28 May 2020 (as reported), around 50 parents and guardians of students gathered to protest in front of a school in Sen Sok district, Phnom Penh, Cambodia, demanding a reduction of the tuition fee as students have been taking online classes due to the coronavirus pandemic.
Explosive remnants of war: On 27 May 2020, two men drove a tractor over an unexploded old war remnant in Huy Tbong village, Pailin province of Cambodia. Both were wounded.

On 26 May 2020, more than 600 textile factory workers protested in front of the factory in Chaom Chau, Pur Senchey district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand their unpaid wages which had not been paid due to the financial crisis faced by the employer as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.

actor1: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Prison Guards
notes: On 20 May 2020, a female prisoner died while in state custody at a prison in Ratanak Kiri province, Cambodia. The family suspected the prisoner had been beaten and tortured, presumably by prison guards, as several bruises were found on the body. GP coded 3 at the province's capital, Banlung.
Explosive remnants of war: Around 20 May 2020 (week of), an old war remnant exploded in Ta Taok commune, Samlout district of Battambang, Cambodia. A civilian was seriously wounded.
On 13 May 2020, around 1,600 garment factory workers gathered in front of the factory in Ta Khmau of Kandal, Cambodia, to demand their unpaid wages.

assoc_actor_2: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 11 May 2020, a female activist from CNRP party was hit until she lost consciousness by an unknown male assailant in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. The victim had recently posted a video criticizing the government.
On 11 May 2020, more than 600 garment factory workers protested in front of the factory in Pur Senchey district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand their unpaid wages.

On 9 May 2020, sixteen people protested outside a microfinance institution in Battambang province, Cambodia, to demand institutions and banks suspend all loan repayments amidst the economic hardship caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Six protesters were arrested by the police.

assoc_actor_1: Bunong Ethnic Group (Cambodia); Kuoy Ethnic Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 5 May 2020, more than 200 people of Bunong and Kuy ethnicity gathered at Keav Seima District Hall in Keav Seima district of Mondul Kiri to protest against the government banning their access to land inside a wildlife sanctuary.

Explosive remnants of war: On 5 May 2020, villagers accidentally stepped on a landmine in Ta Tork commune of Samlout district, Battambang, Cambodia. The explosion killed one and injured 3 others. The landmine exploded in an area where fighting occurred in the 1980s.

Explosive remnants of war: On 5 May 2020, a villager sustained a serious injury after having accidentally stepped on a landmine in Sangkum Thmei village, Veal Veaeng district of Pursat province, Cambodia. The landmine exploded in an area where fighting occurred in the 1980s.
On 5 May 2020, around 400 footwear factory workers protested in Dangkao district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand missing wages and seniority pay after the company suspended its operations.

actor1: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Prison Guards
notes: On 30 April 2020, a prisoner was pronounced dead after having been held at Battambang Provincial Correction Center in Battambang city of Battambang province of Cambodia. A relative claimed that he was tortured to death by prison guards.

Explosive remnants of war: On 29 April 2020, a woman was killed and three others were injured after a rocket, believed to be leftover from the civil war, exploded in Kandal village, Samraong commune, Ou Chrov district of Banteay Meanchey, Cambodia.
On 27 April 2020, more than 100 parents gathered in front of a school in Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand a reduction of the tuition fee amid the coronavirus pandemic.

On 23 April 2020, more than 300 garment factory workers gathered in Chaom Chau commune, Pur Senchey district, Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand reinstatement after the factory suspended its operations two months ago, but claimed that the workers resigned.
Reported on 7 April 2020, more than 100 construction workers demonstrated in Preah Sihanouk district of Sihanoukville, Cambodia, to demand unpaid wages.

On 3 April 2020, around 50 former employees of the Grand Duke hotel protested at the Ministry of Labour in Tuek L'ak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand compensation after the hotel closed down.
On 26 March 2020, shoe factory workers protested in Kampong Speu, Cambodia, after having been laid off, due to the economic slowdown and coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, without financial relief.

On 25 March 2020, nearly 1,000 garment factory workers protested in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand the owed wages that their employer failed to pay due to the economic slowdown and the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic.

On 24 March 2020, nearly a hundred hotel and casino workers protested in Pir, Preah Sihanouk of Sihanoukville, Cambodia, demanding their unpaid wages. The casino had cut wages and not paid workers due to a decline in business as a result of COVID-19 (Coronavirus).

On 22 March 2020, nearly a hundred casino workers protested in Buon, Preah Sihanouk of Sihanoukville, Cambodia, demanding their unpaid wages. The casino had cut wages and not paid workers due to a decline in business as a result of COVID-19 (Coronavirus).

Security measures: On 17 March 2020, the Cambodian government [coded to Phnom Penh] imposed the restrictions coming into effect from 17 March 2020 to 16 April 2020 to curb the spread of coronavirus. The measures include a ban on religious gatherings and international travel as well as travels in and out, and between districts of Phnom Penh and other provinces.

On 13 March 2020, four environmental activists from Prey Lang Community Network were held by private security guards from Think Biotech over their investigation into illegal logging allegations in Sombour district, Kratie, Cambodia. One of the activists was reportedly assaulted, before all were taken by the police on the following day. The police released the activists on 16 March, but the four are still under investigation.

On 11 March 2020, around 800 garment factory workers protested in Kampong Speu province, Cambodia, after their employer failed to pay their wages and other bonuses. Location coded at Chbar Mon, capital of the province.

On 9 March 2020, at least 300 garment factory workers protested in Kamboul, Pur Senchey district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, and demanded their employer to reinstate 3 union representatives who had been fired without any explanation.

On 5 March 2020, more than 800 factory workers again protested in Vihear Suork commune, Khsach Kandal district of Kandal, Cambodia, after their employer reversed a previous agreement. Instead of giving the workers their lay-off benefits, the employee suspended the worker's jobs for two months.

On 4 March 2020, more than 800 factory workers protested in Vihear Suork commune, Khsach Kandal district of Kandal, Cambodia, after their employer reversed a previous agreement. Instead of giving the workers their lay-off benefits, the employee suspended the worker's jobs for two months.
On 14 February 2020, a military officer died after having stepped on a landmine that had been planted in Choam Ksant district of Preah Vihear, Cambodia, near the border with Thailand.
On 10 February 2020, several residents protested in Buon commune of Preah Sihanouk, Preah Sihanouk province of Cambodia, after the government demolished their illegally built residences.

On 7 February 2020, more than 1,000 garment workers protested against their employer in Serei Saophoan, Banteay Meanchey, Cambodia, after the working conditions reportedly imposed by the employer violated their human rights.
On 7 February 2020, a military officer was seriously injured after having stepped on a landmine in Preah Vihear province of Cambodia.

On 3 February 2020, around 100 protesters gathered at Koh Kong Provincial Hall in Smach Mean Chey district in Khemarak Phoumin city of Koh Kong, Cambodia, demanding government intervention in their land disputes. .
Explosive remnants of war: On 30 January 2020, a man was killed by an explosion after having attempted to dismantle an unexploded war remnant, in Memot district of Tboung Khmum, Cambodia.

On 27 January 2020, more than 50 construction workers protested in front of the construction site in Otdam Soriya commune of Tram Kak district, Takeo province, Cambodia, after the employer failed to pay their wages.

assoc_actor_2: Former CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Former Government of Cambodia (1993-)
notes: On 20 January 2020, two unidentified assailants attacked a former CNRP councilor with a blunt object in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.
On 20 January 2020, around 100 former hotel staff protested in front of the Great Duke hotel in Tumnob Tuek, Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand unpaid wages and severance pay.

On 15 January 2020, military police officers who were dismantling illegally-built residences in Ream National Park were attacked again by villagers armed with machetes and sticks in the national park in Ream, Prey Nob district, Sihanoukville, Cambodia. The clash resulted in the injury of 3 officials, and 7 rioters were later arrested.

On 13 January 2020, almost one thousand villagers from Koh Kong, Kompong Speu, Preah Vihea, and Oddar Meanchey protested in front of the Ministry of Land Management in Boeung Trabek, Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, demanding the government to intervene in long-running land disputes with a foreign company.
On 9 January 2020, around 3,000 employees of a hotel and casino demonstrated in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh, to demand wage increase and better working conditions.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Forestry Officials
notes: In early January 2020, around 100 residents of Ream National Park used petrol bombs and other objects to attack forest rangers and police officers who were dismantling illegally-built residences in Ream National Park in Prey Nob district, Preah Sihanouk province of Cambodia. Five officers were injured.

On 8 January 2020, stall vendors protested near Otres beach in Buon, Sihanoukville municipality, Sihanoukville province, Cambodia, and demanded other solutions after the authorities ordered the dismantling of the stalls in order to improve the surrounding atmosphere of the beach.

On 8 January 2020, nearly 100 villagers marched and gathered in front of the Ministry of Justice, the Ministry of Agriculture and the Ministry of Interior in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand resolutions to land disputes and to demand the authority to drop charges against local activists over land dispute cases.

On 2 January 2020, almost 100 rickshaw drivers protested in front of Paoy Paet City Hall in Paoy Paet, Banteay Meanchey province of Cambodia, demanding a casino to allow them to pick up passengers from inside the premises.

On 2 January 2020, more than 100 former employees protested in front of the waste collection service company in Tonle Basak in Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, demanding the company pay their unpaid wages. The protest continued until at least 31 January 2020.

On 31 December 2019, hundreds of villagers gathered in front of the Land Management Ministry in Boeung Trabaek, Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, demanding government intervention to find a solution to their land disputes.

actor1: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Prison Guards
notes: Around 29 December 2019 (between 28 December - 31 December), during the detention of 6 villagers who had been detained by the military police in Banteay Meanchey Provincial Prison in Tuek Thla district of Serei Saophoan, Banteay Meanchey, Cambodia, following a land-rights protest, at least 2 of the detainees were beaten by the officers and inmates. As a result, one detainee died on January, 1st 2020.

On 25 December 2019, more than 100 villagers gathered in front of the Ministry of Land Management in Boeung Trabaek, Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, urging the Ministry to intervene in a land dispute between the villagers and a foreign sugar company.

On 23 December 2019, a convoy of nearly 500 protesting garment factory workers moving toward Phnom Penh to file a petition regarding their unpaid wages was stopped in Mukh Kampul district of Kandal, Cambodia by local authorities who did not allow them to proceed toward the capital.

On 23 December 2019, more than 500 garment factory workers protested in front of the factory in Khsach Kandal district of Kandal, Cambodia. They attempted to file a petition to the Prime Minister demanding he solve the issues with their employer after the factory had been closed down.

On 18 December 2019, an unidentified group of men attacked and beat garment factory protesters demonstrating for compensation and benefits from their employer in Khsach Kandal district of Kandal, Cambodia. Three protesters were injured.

Reported on 16 December 2019, nearly 200 garment factory workers have been protesting and camping in front of a factory in Mean Chey district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, demanding unpaid wages and missing benefits after the factory announced their closure.

Since 14 December 2019, around 500 workers of a garment factory have been protesting daily in Khsach Kandal district of Kandal, Cambodia, after their factory was sold and operations were ceased. The protesters demanded compensations and benefits from their former employer.
Explosive remnants of war: On 13 December 2019, a farmer was seriously injured after driving over an old anti-tank mine planted in the field in Phnom Proek district of Battambang, Cambodia.
On 6 December 2019, a former CNRP member was beaten by 2 unknown assailants in Orussey III commune, Prampir Makara district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia.

On 4 December 2019, more than 100 workers from a textile company went on strike and gathered in front of the factory in S'ang district of Kandal, Cambodia, after their employer failed to pay their wages and social security dues.

On 2 December 2019, more than 100 villagers gathered to block the digging operations of a company which has claimed ownership of the land and cleared some of the villagers' farmland in Trapeang Pring, Dambae district of Tbong Khmum, Cambodia.

On 25 and 26 November 2019, around 100 villagers protested in front of Koh Kong provincial court in Krong Khemara Phoumin, Koh Kong province of Cambodia, to demand the release of a security guard who had threatened a provincial deputy governor, over the road construction on a disputed land.

On 25 November 2019, around 100 villagers protested in front of Koh Kong provincial court in Krong Khemara Phoumin, Koh Kong province of Cambodia, to demand the release of a security guard who had threatened a provincial deputy governor, over the road construction on a disputed land.

On 22 November 2019, nearly 300 garment factory workers demonstrated at and filed a petition to the Ministry of Labour in Tuek L'ak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, protesting the dismissal of the unionists and other employees.

On 14 and 15 November 2019, about 800 workers of a textile factory demonstrated and went on strike in Kampong Speu, Cambodia, after the employers fired two workers, likely due to their union activities.

source: Khmer Times; Phnom Penh Post; Radio Free Asia; Voice of Democracy (Cambodia)
notes: As of 10 November 2019, at least 65 CNRP activists have been arrested in an ongoing crackdown by the Cambodian government. Arrests have been made in Phnom Penh, Chbar Mon (Kampong Speu), Kampong Cham, Paoy Paet (Banteay Meanchey), Batheay (Kampong Cham), Banlung (Ratanak Kiri), Kandal, Kampot and Keo Siema (Mondulkiri). Seventeen CNRP activists have been released on bail.
On 4 November 2019, more than 100 hotel workers protested in Tumnob Tuek, Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand their unpaid wages.
On 23 October 2019, 700 to 800 factory workers gathered in Paoy Paet, Banteay Meanchey province of Cambodia to protest against their company over unpaid wages and working conditions.

On 17 and 18 October 2019, dozens of people gathered in Tbong Khmum province of Cambodia to protest against the arrests of 2 villagers over an alleged crime, suspecting the arrests to be related to the villagers' political activities (and possible affiliation with CNRP).

On 17 October 2019, dozens of people gathered in Tbong Khmum province of Cambodia to protest against the arrests of 2 villagers over an alleged crime, suspecting the arrests to be related to the villagers' political activities (and possible affiliation with CNRP).
On 15 October 2019, a group of 10 monks and activists started their 9-day march from Phnom Penh, Cambodia, toward Sihanoukville to demand the demolition of a casino.
On 8 October 2019, about 50 garment workers protested at the Ministry of Labour in Tuek L'ak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, against their factory owner over unpaid wages.
On 7 October 2019, Cambodian Prime Minister ordered and authorized the military to carry out any necessary measures to attack and prevent the entry of CNRP leaders to Cambodia.
