notes: On 22 September 2019, a bodyguard of the CNRP leader was attacked by two unknown assailants in Chak Angrae Leu, Mean Chey district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia.

On 18 September 2019, about 100 villagers gathered in front of Koh Kong Provincial Court in Koh Kong province of Cambodia (coded at Khemarak Phoumin, the capital), in support of community members who were questioned over a land dispute.

On 11 September 2019, more than 150 students protested at the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sport in Boeung Raing, Daun Penh district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to demand a revision of their national examination results.

For 3 days in the week of 5 September 2019, more than 300 Cambodian villagers protested at Paoy Paet City Hall in Phum Kilou Lekh Buon, Paoy Paet, Banteay Meanchey, Cambodia, demanding the authorities return their land title documents which had previously been collected.
On 3 September 2019, more than 150 employees demonstrated at a hotel in Tumnob Tuek, Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, demanding the hotel pay the outstanding salaries to the staff.
On 31 August 2019, Cambodian and Laos military forces both withdrew from the disputed undemarcated Mom Bei area in Chhaeb district of Preah Vihear, Cambodia. Tensions had been rising since August 14.

Around 15 August 2019 (month of), a Vietnamese drug detainee was physically assaulted by other detainees appointed as the cell's 'security chief' in Prey Speu prison in Chaom Chau district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia. He was beaten at least once with a wooden stick and the beatings occurred reportedly twice per day

On 26 July 2019, 200 Cambodian garment factory workers protested in front of their factory in Pur Senchey district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, demanding better working conditions and adequate overtime compensation.

On 24 July 2019, 40 protesters gathered at the Ministry of Interior in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia. The protesters filed a petition demanding state intervention in a land dispute between the locals and Preah Vihear Authority.

On 22 July 2019, more than 300 protesters gathered and marched to several government institutions in Phnom Penh, Cambodia to protest and submit a petition demanding government intervention and settlements to their land disputes with private companies and individuals. The Cambodian authorities later halted the demonstration citing public disturbance.
On 19 July 2019, two Cambodian journalists were arrested by Cambodian police force while live-streaming a land protest in Bei commune, Krong Preah Sihanouk, Preah Sihanouk province of Cambodia.

On 15 July 2019, approximately 100 members of tourism and agriculture workers' federations demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Labour in Tuek L'ak Ti Muoy, Tuol Kouk district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia yesterday. The protesters demanded better working conditions and workplace safety.
On 13 July 2019, more than 100 workers of a casino went on a strike and protested to demand better working conditions in Sihanoukville of Preah Sihanouk, Cambodia.

On 10 July 2019, activists and students gathered at a gas station in Phnom Penh where a political commentator had been murdered. They were met by the police who prevented the protesters from paying respect. A Cambodian activist was arrested.

On 8 July 2019, thousands of Cambodian garment factory workers went on strike and protested to demand better working conditions and the re-recruitment of their Union leader in Angk Snuol district of Kandal province, Cambodia.

source: Cambodia News Gazette; Radio Free Asia
notes: On 8 July 2019, a group of 100 protesters demonstrated in front of the offices of the Ministry of Land Management in Tonle Basak, Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, as a result of a land dispute with a Cambodian business man.

source: Cambodia News Gazette; Radio Free Asia
notes: On 8 July 2019, 20 protesters demonstrated in front of the Chinese Embassy in Tumpung Ti Pir, Chamkar Mon district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia to demonstrate against the delay in providing compensation following a land dispute with the Chinese-backed Union Development Group (UDG) .
On 28 June 2019, a Cambodian activist from the banned Cambodian opposition party was severely beaten when attacked by unidentified men in Kampong Thom province, Cambodia.

On 21 June 2019, around 200 Cambodian villagers blocked the road to prevent Cambodian military officers who had patrolled the forest from getting out of the area in Koh Kong province, Cambodia. The rioters demanded the release of an arrested villager and threw stones at the officers who then fired shots into the air to disperse the riot. No fatality was reported.
On 17 June 2019, more than 100 unexploded ordinances were found in Khna Krao village, Kantout commune, Svay Leu district of Siem Reap province, Cambodia.

Weapons seizure: On 16 June 2019, police seized four rocket-propelled grenades (RPGs), DK-75 and four B40 RPGs, which was planted behind the Rout Chambei village middle school in Ou Smach commune, Samrongm (Oddar Meanchey) and arrested a suspected former Cambodian soldier. The man is under investigation.
On 12 June 2019, about 1,562 Cambodian garment factory workers demonstrated and went on strike to demand better working conditions in Bavet city, Svay Rieng province of Cambodia.
Explosive remnants of war: On 2 June 2019, a mine (unexploded ordinance) in Choam Ksant commune, Choam Ksant district of Preah Vihear province, Cambodia, exploded and injured a Cambodian civilian.

Explosive remnants of war: On 1 June 2019, a mine (unexploded ordinance) in Anlong Romiet commune, Kandal Stueng district of Kandal province, Cambodia, exploded, injuring two Cambodian civilians. The unexploded ordinance went off while the two were clearing a forest.

On 27 May 2019, approximately 20 protesters demonstrated in front of the Chinese embassy in Tuol Tumpung Ti Pir, Chamkarmon district, Phnom Penh, Cambodia, to urge the embassy to resolve the land dispute between the locals and a Chinese company.

Reported on 22 May 2019, more than 200 villagers protested in front of Preah Sihanouk Provincial Hall in Sihanoukville, Cambodia. The protesters demonstrated against the land disputes and the delay in issuing state land titles.
On 20 May 2019, 1 Cambodian national was killed and another one injured in an attack carried out in a school in Preaek kak, Stueng Traeng district of Kampong Cham province, Cambodia.
Reported on May 7, 2019, more than 40 Cambodian protesters demonstrated against the eviction of a monk and removal of the O'Damrey pagoda in Sihanoukville.
On 2 May 2019, after a road dispute, a Cambodian general fired at the car of two civilians on a road in Phsar Daeum Kor commune, Tuol Kork district in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.
On 1 May 2019, hundreds of Cambodian workers marched in Phnom Penh to mark International Labour Day, calling for protection of labour rights and gender equality.
On 29 April 2019, more than 50 Cambodian villagers protested against the use of their village as a dumpsite in Phloeung Chhes Rotes commune, Pur Senchey district in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.
On 21 April 2019, hundreds of Cambodian garment factory workers protested against the rent increase in Chaom Chau I commune, Pur Senchey district in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.

On 19 April 2019, approximately 100 villagers demonstrated against their eviction by the police in Sihanoukville, Preah Sihanouk, Cambodia. The rioters blocked a main road, threw stones at the police and damaged police cars. Eight rioters were arrested and six policemen were injured.

actor1: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Prison Guards
notes: On 18 April 2019, the son of a Cambodian activist died while in police custody in Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. The police reported the cause of death to be from a fall but the injuries on the body suggest that he could have been killed by prison guards. First reported on 6 May 2019.

On 4 April 2019, almost 700 people from different communities in Kampong Speu province staged a demonstration in front of the Ministry of Land Management, Urban Planning and Construction in Phnom Penh to petition the Ministry to speed up the settlement for 1,500 families across Kamping Speu province that were evicted in 2010 by three sugar companies from land they'd farmed for 31 years.

actor1: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Forestry Officials
notes: On 19 March 2019, five environmental rangers were patrolling protected biodiversity in O'Doeum Thkov in Kraya commune, Santuk district, Kampong Thom, when they came upon men clearing the forest for farmland with a machete. The men fled. When the rangers caught up, the men attacked one of them with a machete, severely injuring one. The men then escaped.

On 8 March 2019, 400 people, mostly women, gathered at the National Olympic Stadium in central Phnom Penh city with the intention of staging a demonstration march to the Office of the Council for Ministers. They were blocked and prevented from leaving the stadium by Cambodian authorities. They were gathered to mark International Women's Day and to demand measures to prevent and end violence against women. Despite some commotion, there were no injuries.

On 6 March 2019, 100 Cambodian women with disabilities and the Cambodian Disabled People's Organization staged a demonstration in Phnom Penh to call for better training to enable them to become fully independent.

On 28 February 2019, nearly a thousand garment factory workers staged a demonstration march towards the home of the PM in Phnom Penh to demand the W&D garment factory they work for rehire all the workers that were fired after they protested previously. Hundreds of security forces stopped them near Independence Monument from marching any further.

On 27 February 2019, nearly a thousand garment factory workers staged a demonstration march towards the Labour Ministry in Phnom Penh to demand the W&D garment factory they work for rehire all the workers that were fired after they protested previously.

On 25 February 2019, more than 100 workers from the W&D garment factory staged a demonstration in front of the Municipal Court in Phnom Penh city, Phnom Penh district, Phnom Penh province to show support for six representatives there to appeal the ruling over the 1,200 workers dismissal from the factory the previous month following protests demanding improved conditions.

Reported on 21 February 2019, a group of forestry activists and Buddhist monks clothed trees in traditional Buddhist garb in Prey Lang forest, coded at Stoung city (Stoung, Khampon Thong), the capital of one of the provinces that border the forest, to preserve the forest from deforestation by illegal loggers. They said the ceremony was aimed at praying for the forest's future existence.

On the weekend of 16 February 2019, a Buddhist monk led a group of villagers to patrol the area of Prey Lang forest coded at Stoung city (Stoung, Khampon Thong), the capital of one of the provinces that border the forest, to preserve the forest from deforestation by illegal loggers. On the patrol they confiscated abandoned wood, chainsaws and even detained a group of loggers they found. The loggers were set free after being advised not to further engage in illegal logging.
On 14 February 2019, in Phnom Penh, over 100 former garment workers from the W&D factory staged a demonstration to demand their reinstatement after they were sacked for inciting a strike.
Defusal: On 10 Feb 2019, in Paoy Paet, Paoy Paet district, Banateay Meanchey province, a bomb found in a casino was destroyed by the police without causing any injuries.
In the week of 6 Feb 2019, in Pir Thnou commune, Snuol district, Kratie province, a local journalist was ambushed and beaten to death by three locals.
On 6 February 2019, in Phnom Penh, protesters gathered in front of the Embassy of the Russian Federation demanding the release of the imprisoned filmmaker Rath Rott Mony.
On 31 January 2019, in Trapaing Phlaing commune, Chhuk district, Kampot province, six men killed a farmer over a land dispute. The six were arrested a couple of days later.

On 31 Jan 2019, in Phnom Penh, around 200 villagers from Preah Vihear province staged a protest in front of the PM Hun Sen's residence seeking a resolution to their long-running land dispute. The protesters also demanded the release of 13 residents who were arrested on 19 January 2019 for allegedly grabbing state land.

notes: On 29 January 2019, in Sre Pok protected area, Nang Khylik commune, Kaoh Nhek district, Mondul Kiri province, a shooting took place between suspected wildlife poachers and a joint patrol comprising rangers, military police, police officers and two community activists. One of the park rangers was shot and seriously wounded.

source: Phnom Penh Post; Radio Free Asia
notes: On 24 January 2019, in Koki village, Bit Traing commune, Prey Nob district, Sihanoukville province, almost 300 villagers clashed with 200 policemen during a demonstration against the forcible eviction of residents. The demonstrators tried to prevent authorities from entering the area by throwing stones and burning car tyres. The police opened fire, injuring one man. One 10-year-old was beaten and suffered light injuries. Six men were arrested.
On 22 January 2019, in Phnom Penh's Russey Keo district, over 400 garment workers from Long Victory International staged a protest over fears that the company plans to close.

On 21 January 2019, in Kbal Chhay area, Preah Sihanouk, residents staged a protest against the demarcation of land. Two people were arrested for allegedly attempting to discourage the authorities from demarcating the land. One protester heard gun shots, and it was later reported that the police shot one land dispute demonstrator while other villagers were beaten up. No fatalities reported.

On 21 January 2019, a man who was the main community representative in an ongoing land conflict between hundreds of families and a company granted a land concession was last seen in the environment office of the Kulen Promtep Wildlife Sanctuary in Choam Ksant district, Preah Vihear province after he was arrested with his son by soldiers the day before.

On 20 January 2019, a man who was the main community representative in an ongoing land conflict between hundreds of families and a company granted a land concession and his son were beaten and arrested by soldiers guarding the concession granted to Metrei Pheap Kase Ousahakam company. They were taken to be detained overnight at the environment office of Kulen Promtep Wildlife Sanctuary in Choam Ksant district, Preah Vihear province.
On 18 January 2019, in Phnom Penh, over 400 family representatives protested at the Land Management Ministry regarding a land dispute with Memot Rubber Plantation Company in Kratie province.

From 13-16 Jan 2019, in Bavet town, Svay Rieng province, 2,000 workers from King Maker Footwear Co protested for four days demanding 50 per cent of their salary after they were suspended for a month due to a lack of orders.

On 16 January 2019, in Meanchey district of Phnom Penh, seventeen families protested after they had been designated as Vietnamese immigrants by the authorities. The protesters claim that they are Cambodians by birth and have lived in the area for two decades.

On 15 January 2019, in Bavet town, Svay Rieng province, 2,000 workers from King Maker Footwear Co protested for four days demanding 50 per cent of their salary after they were suspended for a month due to a lack of orders.

On 14 January 2019, in Trapaing Srotoap village, Trapaing Chor commune, Kampong Speu province, 80 people demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Land Management demanding a solution to their decade-long land dispute with HLH Company and Ly Yong Phat Sugar Company.

On 9 January 2019, in GIGA special economic zone, in Svay Teap district's Kandieng Reay commune (Svay Rieng province), about 500 workers from Bai Hong factory protested demanding the reinstatement of three representatives who intended to form a trade union.

On 9 January 2019, in Phnom Penh, over 10 people staged a protest outside the Embassy of the Russian Federation calling for the release of the filmmaker Rath Rott Mony who was detained for allegedly producing a documentary about human trafficking in Thailand.
On 8 January 2019, in Phnom Penh, 1,200 garment workers from W&D factory protested in front of the factory after they had been fired the previous week for striking.
On 7 January 2019, in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk), 106 families from Mittapheap district were protesting, demanding land rights to build houses on the property where they are living.

On 7 January 2019, in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk), after a meeting aimed to resolve a land dispute involving 106 families from Mittapheap district, the two groups violently confronted each other. A 60-year-old woman was kicked. Both sides have filed complaints.

On 5 January 2019, in Phnom Penh, 1,200 garment workers from W&D factory were protesting for seniority indemnity and severance benefits. The protesters blocked Street 217 in Mean Chey district's Stung Meanchey 3 commune.
On 3 January 2019, in Phnom Penh, hundreds of garment workers from a Prestige factory in Kandal protested demanding better working conditions.

On 2 January 2019, in Phnom Penh, 11 people staged a protest outside the Embassy of the Russian Federation calling for the release of the filmmaker Rath Rott Mony who was detained for allegedly producing a documentary about human trafficking in Thailand.

On 1 January 2019, in Kandal Stung, Kandal province, around 1,000 people demonstrated at Boeng Kyang Commune Hall. The protesters were demanding compensation for their land that was allegedly sold to Heng Development Company.

From 27 to 31 Dec 2018, in Dangkao (Phnom Penh), striking garment workers from Seduno Investment Cambo Fashion demonstrated in front of the factory demanding their seniority indemnity and severance pay.

The tractors, together with two chainsaws and 2.7 cubic metres of timber, had been confiscated by the rangers two days earlier.

On 26 and 27 Dec 2018, in Phnom Penh, about 500 workers of the refuse collection firm Cintri staged protests after negotiations over a wage increase and improved working conditions were delayed.

Weapons seizure: On 19 Dec 2018, Ra village, Thipakdei commune (Koas Krala, Battambang), the police seized more than 300 AK 47 bullets that were found by a villager while digging her land.

On 18 December 2018, Phnom Penh, more than 500 garment workers from City Spark Cambodian Co Ltd held a protest outside the factor demanding better working conditions and for the allowance to form a union. Ten unknowns allegedly hired by the company attacked the protesters with sticks and hoes to break up the protest. Some workers were slightly injured.
On 14 December 2018, in Phnom Penh, more than 1,000 workers of a footwear factory demonstrated after failed negotiations over the amount of severance pay. The demonstrators blocked a road.
Arrests: On 11 Dec 2018, Paoy Paet, Banteay Meanchey district, the police arrested 55 Malaysian and Chinese nationals suspecting them of running an illegal gambling operation online.
On 10 December 2018, Samrong commune, Phnum Kravanh district, about 200 villagers blocked a road for more than two hours after authorities confiscated rice tractors loaded with luxury timber.

On 7 December 2018, in Phnom Penh, hundreds of pharmaceutical agents from BHIP Global Cambodia staged a protest in front of the home of the prime minister, demanding solutions and the removal of the company's current management team after their boss was fired. Security forces and district officials intercepted and redirected the protesters away from the prime minister's house.

At the end of Nov 2018, in Pursat Province, a small mob attacked a couple, accusing them of killing someone's daughter with sorcery. The accused woman was shot in the leg and the man was beaten to death. 1 fatality.

Arrests: Around 29 Nov 2018, the police's Counter Terrorism and Cross Border Crime Department arrested 232 Chinese nationals over online scams in Bati district (Takeo) and Tram Kak district (Takeo). They were deported to China on the 6 Dec.

Arrests: Around 29 Nov 2018, the police's Counter Terrorism and Cross Border Crime Department arrested 232 Chinese nationals over online scams in Bati district (Takeo) and Tram Kak district (Takeo). They were deported to China on the 6 Dec.

On 26 November 2018, at least 10 ethnic Phnong villagers staged a demonstration in the Busra commune in Mondul Kiri province to demand an end to a sand dredging operation carried out in a wildlife sanctuary. They also earlier seized dredging machines used in the operation.

Around 12 November 2018, more than 2,000 garment workers from Quantum Clothing Ltd in Por Senchey district in Phnom Penh have been demonstrating for nearly a week outside the factory following a change in ownership. They are seeking better labour benefits.

On 7 November 2018, more than 300 demonstrators gathered and threw Molotov cocktails at the car of local authorities and conservation organisers in the Ta Tai Wildlife Sanctuary near Ta Tai village in Koh Kong district after they allegedly destroyed their cash crops in the newly established sanctuary. No on was injured in the altercation.

On 6 November 2018, hundreds of villagers from Sihanoukville, Svay Rieng, and Tboung Khmum and Kandal provinces were blocked by police when they attempted to demonstrate at the government offices and the residence of the PM in Phnom Penh, calling for a resolution to land disputes.

On 6 November 2018, in a separate protest, 11 ethnic Kuoy families representing 300 other ethnic families from Preah Vihear province were stopped from delivering petitions at the home of Hun Sen by police, who asked them instead to submit their complaints to local authorities.

On 5 November 2018, more than 30 demonstrators from different communities in Phnom Penh and Koh Kong province staged a demonstration in front of the PM's house in Phnom Penh city to seek his intervention in long-running land disputes. Three activists were arrested by police.

On 16 October 2018, police officers in plain clothes and uniforms fired gunshots during an anti-drug raid in Prek Pra commune, Chbar Ampov district, Phnom Penh. An altercation between police and local residents occurred during the raid. Two women fainted and were sent to hospital.

On 3 October 2018, some 300 villagers staged a demonstration outside the Preah Sihanouk provincial court in Sihanoukville demanding charges be dropped against four villagers being tried inside the court for using violence against a property owner. The case is part of an ongoing land dispute between the villagers of Otres commune in Stung Hav district and two businessmen.

On 27 September 2018, some 300 villagers staged a demonstration outside the Preah Sihanouk provincial court in Sihanoukville in demand for the charges to be dropped against the four representatives who were being tried inside the court during the demonstration for using violence against the owner of an immovable private property. This is part of an ongoing land dispute between the villagers of Otres commune in Stung Hav district and two businessmen.
On 17 September 2018, a group of 500 people including Buddhist monks staged a protest in Lvea Aem district against 6 teachers who allegedly sold temple land to a rich businessman.
In September 2018, a mob beat and killed a man after a road accident in Svay Rieng province of Cambodia.

On 14 September 2018, more than 400 villagers from 13 communities in Sihanoukville staged a demonstration in the southwest of Sihanoukville province demanding that charges be dropped against four locals detained by authorities for 'violently occupying' disputed property.
On 12 September 2018, 59 families from the Slor Kram commune staged a demonstration in Siem Reap city to urge authorities to fast track the process of giving them land deeds.

On 23 August 2018, around 300 villagers from Snuol district in Kratie province staged a protest outside the land management ministry in Phnom Penh (PM, PP) demanding a solution to their land dispute with a rubber plantation in their province.

Within in the week of 17 August 2018, more than 40 workers at a garment factory staged a protest in Prey Pring Tbong village in Chaom Chau commune as the owner of the factory was withholding their salaries.

From Aug 7, 2018 to at least Aug. 10, 2018, about 1,400 TY factory garment workers have been staging a protest in the streets of Kandieng Reay commune against their employer for deducting two days wages after they took leave to cast votes in national elections.

As reported on 10 August 2018, residents of Borei Keila have accused Suy Sophan, the owner of the Phan Imex Company who they have disputed with since 2012, of releasing dogs on protesters in an attempt to evict them from the land. The dogs reportedly attacked at least one woman.

From Aug 7, 2018 to at least Aug. 10, 2018, about 1,400 TY factory garment workers have been staging a protest in the streets of Kandieng Reay commune against their employer for deducting two days wages after they took leave to cast votes in national elections.

On 8 August 2018, around 170 workers staged a protest and blocked the road in front of their factory in S'ang Phnum commune demanding the wages the owner of the factory had failed to pay.

As reported on Aug 9, 2018, 100 garment workers staged a protest the week before in Pur Senchey's Kakab commune after their factory ceased operations on Aug 1 without warning and without distribution of pay.

On 31 July 2018, around 100 villagers staged a protest in Svay Rieng province seeking intervention from the authorities to expedite a court case against a man imprisoned for murdering a girl the year before.

On 27 July 2018, in Phnom Penh, several parties held rallies prior to the general elections on Sunday. The largest rally was attended by around 250,000 people supporting the Cambodian People's Party who then marched across the city. LDP also held a 10,000 person rally, while the Funcinpec Party and Khmer National United Party both held smaller events, all in Phnom Penh.

Defusal: On July 10, Pailin provincial police recovered a dozen explosive devices under a bridge in Pailin town. Suspected that bombs were placed to create chaos during upcoming elections.

On 3 July 2018, seventy construction workers in Svay Rieng province's Bavet staged a protest after the labour agency that found them jobs failed to pay their salaries.

On 27 June 2018, protestors from Koh Kong province were prevented from protesting outside the Prime Ministers house in Phnom Penh. They are protesting about a land dispute with the Koh Kong Sugar Industry Co Ltd.

In the week of June 20, villagers from Koh Kong province's Kiri Sakor district staged a protest in Phnom Penh city after their petition over a land dispute with the Chinese Union Development Group went unanswered.

On 28 March 2018, in Kompong Speu province, around 70 people gathered outside Phnom Penh Sugar Company's factory to protest, demanding compensation for a land dispute.
On 27 March 2018, in Banteay Meanchey province, around 80 villagers protested outside the provincial court over a land dispute and the detention of a community representative earlier in the week.

Detonation: On 15-March-2018, a land mine exploded accidentally during a clearance training at a military base in western Cambodia's Kampong Speu province, killing two people, including an Australian trainer, and injuring three others.
On 13 March 2018, around 30 protesters from Laoka village staged a demonstration at the town hall assumed at Sen Monorom town (Mondulkiri) over the illegal selling of forestland.
On 12 March 2018, in Phnom Penh, farmers from 37 communities joined a protest and submitted petitions to the government concerning several land disputes.
On 11 March 2018, in Phnom Penh, a mob beat a professor from the University of Cambodia after he was involved in a hit-and-run. One of the members of the mob was a former Daun Penh security guard.
Property destruction: On 9 March2018, in 2 Thnou commune (Pir Thnou), Snuol district, Kratie security forces flattened and razed homes, threatening to kill villagers who did not leave.

On 8 March 2018, in 2 Thnou commune (Pir Thnou), Kratie, Snuol district, land rights protestors blocked the National Road 76A. The military and police fired on the protesters in order to disperse the crowd. At least 8 fatalities reported.

actor2: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Forestry Officials
notes: On 30 January 2018, soldiers attacked and killed a forest protection ranger, a military police officer and a conservation worker in the Keo Seima wildlife conservation in Srae Preah township, Kaev Seima district, Mondul Kiri. This area experiences unrest with illicit logging and smuggling and the soldiers actions were apparently in retaliation for the victims' seizure of equipment from illegal loggers.
Around 5 January 2018, 200 garment workers gathered in Phnom Penh to protest compensation from the government because their factory of employment had been abandoned without notice.
On 2 January 2018, 30 families gathered in Poipet to demand intervention from authorities to resolve a land dispute.
On 26 December 2017, roughly 100 garment workers protested against a shoe factory over the factory's decision to hire soldiers to act as security guards for the company.

Around 15 December 2017 (month of), a drug detainee was beaten to death by a detainee appointed as the 'security chief' of the cell along with 19 others detainees. The beating took place in Prey Speu prison in Chaom Chau district of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, and lasted around 6 hours.

On 2 December 2017, hundreds of teachers and students protested outside Kampong Thom High School to demand a police commander publicly apologize for insulting the school's teachers and threatening to jail them.

assoc_actor_1: ADHOC: Cambodian Human Rights and Development Association
notes: Some time during the week of October 30, 2017, roughly 700 villagers gathered to protest against a Canadian gold mining company whom they say is taking their land.
On 19 October 2017, workers from a garment factory gathered in Phnom Penh to protest against shortened contract extensions.

On 13 September 2017, a small gathering of CNRP lawmakers were prevented from conducting a ceremony for the victims of a grenade attack in 1997 at Wat Botum Park in Phnom Penh by about 100 security personnel.

On 1 September 2017, villagers protested against a land rights NGO and the EU for allegedly dividing their communities. The protesters then delivered a petition to the Interior Ministry to shut down the organization.

On 22 August 2017, about 100 rioters clashed with security forces after blocking the street in front of the Land Management Ministry in Phnom Penh to protest a land dispute with a sugar company. A scuffle broke out when security guards began to push the rioters off the road.

On the weekend of August 20, 2017, a group of villagers protested against another group of activists who had filed a suit against local officials regarding logging in the area. The protesters accused the activist group of working on behalf of an opposition party.
On 12 August 2017, about 1,000 garment workers protested at their factory in Phnom Penh, saying the company had hired a police officer to intimidate workers.

A long-running land dispute turned violent as villagers in Kampot province's Decho Aphivat commune clashed with representatives of an agricultural company that had been ordered to tear down their homes. The company's representatives were tearing down half-built homes when villagers pulled a worker off of his motorbike and beat him, and also broke the windshield of a company car.

On 6 August 2017, 200 monks and members of a youth political group congregated at Phnom Penh's Wat Chbar Ampov to sign a petition against the leader of the League for Democracy Party. Their anger with him stemmed from comments he made referring to monks as greedy 'bag thieves' constantly seeking donations.
On 2 August 2017, about 200 people gathered at the Siem Reap provincial hall to demand that authorities intervene to remove a fence blocking a road.

On 28 July 2017, in Po commune, Tbeng Meanchey province, a mob of villagers attacked environmental officials following a logging bust. About 300-400 villagers were present during the skirmish. It was unclear whether the officials who were attacked were members of a security force or civilian government workers.

On 23 July 2017, authorities stopped a group of activists in Sesan district, Stung Treng province. The activists were headed toward a village (Kbal Romeas) affected by a nearby hydropower dam to show their support for the families there.

On 19 July 2017, hundreds of gold miners protested to call for an end to a firm's operations on the land they were using. They protested outside the Chung Phlas Commune office in Mondulkiri's Keo Seima district.
On July 17 and 18, 2017, around 2,000 A&J (Cambodia) bicycle factory workers protested in Bavet after the factory's owners proposed eliminating their bonuses.

On 18 July 2017, in Phnom Penh, protesters burned tires in the road to protest the construction of a commuter rail service. The protesters were angry that they had not been notified about the project.
On July 17 and 18, 2017, around 2,000 A&J (Cambodia) bicycle factory workers protested in Bavet after the factory's owners proposed eliminating their bonuses.

On 15 July 2017, farmers in Phnom Proek and Kamrieng districts, Battambang province shut down major roads in protest of low corn prices. The protesters drove tractors onto national roads 59B and 57, demanding authorities help negotiate a better price.
In July 2017, a boy who was accused of stealing was beaten by a mob in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, and was left to die in a pond.

On 14 July 2017, farmers in Phnom Proek and Kamrieng districts, Battambang province shut down major roads in protest of low corn prices. The protesters drove tractors onto national roads 59B and 57, demanding authorities help negotiate a better price.

On 28 June 2017, in Kbal Romea commune, Stung Treng province, around 200 villagers from six villages gathered at Sre Pok Bridge to protest against the government's plan to dismantle the bridge. Some authorities were still able to dismantle parts of the bridge.

On 26 June 2017, in Phnom Penh, protesters were confronted by police at the Wat Chas pagoda as they were preparing to march to the National Assembly to demand a national holiday to mark territorial losses to Vietnam. The police were armed and blocked the road, making it impossible for the protesters to continue their march.
On 25 June 2017, protesters in Kratie town blocked a road, using ten vans to prevent trucks from transporting sand. Their goal was to demand a halt to sand dredging in Krakor commune.
On 23 June 2017, several hundred protesters gathered near Siem Reap airport to protest authorities' removal of a home recently built inside an archaeological park.

On 22 June 2017, about 50 monks gathered in front of the Battambang Provincial Court to demand the release of a fellow monk, claiming he had been falsely accused of illegal possession of a weapon and arrested for his political activism.

On 22 June 2017, about 100 protesters gathered in Phnom Penh after a member of their community savings group, whom they say owed them a large sum of money, was released on bail after being charged with fraud.

On 21 and 22 June 2017, garment workers protested in Veng Sreng boulevard in Phnom Penh against the dismissal of a union leader at a factory, claiming the leader was fired for pushing the owners to respect a recent labor arbitration decision.

On 21 and 22 June 2017, garment workers protested in Veng Sreng boulevard in Phnom Penh against the dismissal of a union leader at a factory, claiming the leader was fired for pushing the owners to respect a recent labor arbitration decision.
On 20 June 2017, about 50 journalists gathered in Phnom Penh to protest the arrest of four journalists.

On 18 June 2017, the Venerable Meas Vichet, a well-known monk went missing in Krabei Riel commune (SR, SR) and a priest who was with him before his disappearance claimed that security officials detained them, forcibly removed their clothes, beat them, and tried to get information from them on the murder of Kem Ley.

On 11 June 2017, in Koh Kor village, Sa'ang district, Kandal province, two environmental activists staged a protest to demand that authorities halt sand dredging operations. The activists were allegedly harassed by local police for coordinating the protest.

assoc_actor_1: BWTUC: Building Woodworkers Trade Union of Cambodia
notes: On 11 June 2017, around 100 union members and representatives from the Building Woodworkers Trade Union of Cambodia called for greater enforcement of safety standards on building sites in Kandal province's Kandal Stung district.
An unidentified assailant used an axe to attack the top elections official of O'Taki in Battambang province, also setting fire to election documents. He also attacked the official's wife.

On 08 June 2017, in Phnom Penh, about a thousand workers from a garment factory protested outside the Ministry of Labour to demand intervention from the authorities to force their company to reinstate 10 unionists suspended from work after a strike began earlier in the week.
On 28 May 2017, thousands of opposition supporters gathered in Phnom Penh to march in a CNRP parade.

On 26 May 2017, in Samraong City, Oddar Meanchey province, four activist monks were arrested after attending an opposition rally with police confiscating their mobile phones and deleting videos and photographs taken during the event, one monk said, though the account was disputed by authorities.
On 22 May 2017, 2017 about 30 protesters were halted by authorities in Phnom Penh as they attempted to march to the National Assembly to deliver a petition requesting intervention in a land dispute.

On 18 May 2017, a group of protesters traveling to Phnom Penh to petition the prime minister over land disputes were halted along the road by authorities and were not able to continue on their protest.
On 17 May 2017, more than 1,000 garment workers blocked a public road in Ta Khmau City, Kandal province to protest over unpaid wages.
On 12, 13, 14 and 17 May 2017, around 300 garment factory workers blocked National Road 21 in Phnom Penh. They are demanding their April salaries from a garment factory.
On 12, 13, 14 and 17 May 2017, around 300 garment factory workers blocked National Road 21 in Phnom Penh. They are demanding their April salaries from a garment factory.

On 13 May 2017, around 250 activists gathered in Koh Kapi commune, Koh Sralao, Koh Kong, to highlight environmental issues. The group was barred from holding further protests by a local commune chief and by police.
On 12, 13, 14 and 17 May 2017, around 300 garment factory workers blocked National Road 21 in Phnom Penh. They are demanding their April salaries from a garment factory.
On 12, 13, 14 and 17 May 2017, around 300 garment factory workers blocked National Road 21 in Phnom Penh. They are demanding their April salaries from a garment factory.

On 1 May 2017, police intervened to stop more than 1,000 protesters from conducting a march to celebrate International Workers' Day in Phnom Penh. The workers, from different industries, were eventually allowed to proceed with a shorter march, with around 100 riot police standing by.

On 26 April 2017, protesters marked the fifth anniversary of an environmental activist's death in Phnom Penh by gathering for a brief prayer session. Security guards were deployed to the scene and pushed and pulled a few of the protesters.
On 26 April 2017, in Phnom Penh, district security guards briefly arrested eight women outside the World Bank headquarters during a peaceful demonstration for Phnom Penh's Boeung Kak community.

A 16-year-old boy was shot and seriously injured by a joint force of military police, soldiers, fisheries officials and provincial police officers. He was shot on his boat while authorities were conducting a raid.

On 07 April 2017, in Kratie province, villagers in O'Krieng commune's O'Kandie village prevented soldiers from building a fence around disputed land that the army plans to use as training ground. Ten soldiers arrived to build the fence but were stopped by at least one villager standing in front of their tractor.
On 4 April 2017, dozens of farmers traveled from Battambang province to Phnom Penh to fight for land they say they have farmed for decades after a court ruled it should be handed over to soldiers.

On 30 March 2017, in Phnom Penh, CNRP officials, supporters, victims and their families gathered to mark the 20th anniversary of a grenade attack on a rally that killed 16. They gathered at Wat Botum Park.
On 28 March 2017, about 30 villagers protested outside Phnom Penh's city hall to demand an update on a planned railway that could lead to many land evictions.
On 27 March 2017, roughly 12 activists gathered in Phnom Penh to call for the release of political prisoners. Police arrested two of the protesters.

A dispute over road construction in Samaki Meanchey village led to violence when rioters who claimed to own the land where the road was being built attacked the workers who were paving the road with scythes and sticks.

Property destruction: On 17 March 2017, dozens of masked farmers stormed a forestry monitoring office in Mondulkiri province in the Keo Seima wildlife preserve and burned it to the ground in retaliation for being prevented from growing cassava in a protected area.
In March 2017, protesters blocked the clearing of a forest in Stung Treng province.
In March 2017, hundreds of angry villagers gathered at the residence of a man accused to be a sorcerer in Kampong Speu province of Cambodia. He was rescued safely by the police.

On 10 and 11 Mar 2017, in Phnom Penh, more than 600 garment workers from a fashion factory protested outside their factory for two days in a row after the factory's management failed to pay them their wages.

On 10 and 11 Mar 2017, in Phnom Penh, more than 600 garment workers from a fashion factory protested outside their factory for two days in a row after the factory's management failed to pay them their wages.

On 3 March 2017, nearly 50 sex workers gathered in Phnom Penh to protest discrimination against sex workers, celebrate the memory of a sex worker who drowned while fleeing security guards, and strengthen solidarity among sex workers.
On 28 February 2017, about 50 fishers protested at Kampot's provincial hall to seek protection from Vietnamese fishers, who they say threatened them in Cambodian waters.

Between 9 and 15 Feb 2017, in Phnom Penh, garment workers protested steadily for one week at Phnom Penh Tower, claiming a retail giant was complicit in withholding workers' salaries.

On 14 February 2017, protesters headed toward the Prime Minister's mansion in Phnom Penh to seek intervention in a land dispute, but were beaten and pushed to the ground by security guards before they could complete their peaceful march.

On 13 February 2017, workers from a garment factory protested outside the factory in Kampong Speu province's Chbar Mon town after their employer vanished without paying a month of their salaries. About 300 workers joined the protest.

On 13 February 2017, a mob of angry customers surrounded a tour agency office in Phnom Penh to confront its owner after being swindled out of thousands of dollars meant to be used to purchase airline tickets. No violence was reported, but the article did say that the rioters wanted to beat the owner.

On 13 February 2017, about 40 villagers from Phnom Penh gathered at the district governor's house, requesting that he help them obtain compensation for land taken for a government project to build a satellite city on a peninsula.

On 30 January 2017, in Phnom Penh, more than 200 workers from two garment factories blocked National Road 1 for an hour as part of a protest seeking government intervention in claiming back pay.

From 20 to 27 Jan 2017, in in Tbong Khmum province, around 300 protesters from seven villages protested against a local company's ongoing attempts to clear farmland they say belongs to them, claiming the government tricked them out of their land decades ago. The villagers built camps on the 500 hectares of disputed land.

On 27 January 2107, in Koh Nhek district, Mondulkiri province, two hundred ethnic Phnong villagers launched a protest after the deputy district governor and an armed escort seized timber from their homes, before allegedly attempting to extort a bribe for its return.

In the week of 26 January 2017, in Mondul Kiri province, some 50 villagers protested two days in a row against the provincial land department's decision to list parts of a wildlife sanctuary as private state land, paving the way for a company to clear it.

On 16 January 2016, in Battambang town, Battambang, dozens of villagers protested after the provincial court upheld a ruling granting ownership of a disputed plot of land to an anti-drug police officer.
One British employee of a demining organization died and another was injured after an antipersonnel mine exploded while they were attempting to remove it.
On 13 January 2016, a deminer working for the NGO Halo Trust was killed and another injured in Bar Yakha commune, Pailin province, after a mine was detonated.

On 10 January 2017, in Phnom Penh, about 20 protesters gathered at City Hall to demand a halt to the construction of a railway line that would affect their communities. The protesters requested that the government provide them with additional details about the project, including compensation and relocation issues.
On 9 January 2017, 20 activists staged a protest in Phnom Penh to call for the release of several activists from jail.
On 9 January 2017, thirty residents gathered in Phnom Penh to request long-delated land titles for their homes.
A man was injured after stepping on an anti-personnel mine while hunting in the jungle near the border between Cambodia and Thailand. He lost one of his legs.

On 12 December 2016, at Boeung Kak in Phnom Penh, fifty activists gathered to continue Black Monday protests, this time to demand the release of human rights officials and political prisoners from jail.

On 11 August 2016, in Phnom Penh, more than 100 people protested outside the offices of an NGO that had been representing them in a land dispute. The protest was formed to fulfill a stipulation in the settlement of the dispute.

On 10 August 2016, in Phnom Penh, police and security guards clashed with about 70 protesters, shoving and pushing them as they tried to make their way to the Ministry of Land Management. The villagers were attempting to follow up on a petition asking for intervention in a feud with a sugar company. Police formed a human chain to block the protesters when the shoving match ensued.
A man was severely injured after stepping on a landmine in a stretch of undemarcated borderland between Cambodia and Thailand.
On 8 August 2016, 60 workers protested in Phnom Penh against a recent transfer, saying they were given little information about the company they had been transferred to.

On 8 August 2016, in Phnom Penh, about 20 'Black Monday' protesters were marching to an appeals court when district police stopped them and snatched away the banner they were carrying, which showed the image of a slain political activist. After a small scuffle, the protest leader was taken away in a police truck.
On 8 August 2016, in Phnom Penh, more than 100 factory workers gathered to protest their employer, who they say has not paid their final salaries after the factory went bankrupt.

An angry mob of 20 beat a man to death following a dispute over cigarettes. The victim had declined to give someone a cigarette, leading to a physical altercation. In retaliation, a mob formed and beat the victim to death with wooden sticks, machetes, and other weapons. The mob retreated when the police were called.

From July 28 through August 3, more than 1,000 workers across 15 factories protested during their lunch breaks. The workers were calling on a CNRP leader to retract a suggestion that garment exports be used to leverage better human rights in Cambodia. The locations of the protests were not named.

From July 28 through August 3, more than 1,000 workers across 15 factories protested during their lunch breaks. The workers were calling on a CNRP leader to retract a suggestion that garment exports be used to leverage better human rights in Cambodia.

On 3 August 2016, an angry mob stormed a military police compound in Sorb commune, Prek Prasap, Kratie province, to retrieve two trucks loaded with wood that had been confiscated for not having proper licenses.

Timber smugglers who mounted a raid on a police station to reclaim impounded wood claim they were beaten during the initial seizure. They said the policemen hit the drivers of the vans loaded with timber, vandalized the vehicles, and used violence on women. Six people were injured.

On 27 July 2016, in Phnom Penh, 40 members of the 'SOS' airport community gathered in front of the Anti-Corruption Unit headquarters to demand an investigation into a district governor who has forbidden community members from building new houses or altering land ownership in disputed areas.
On 26 July 2016, about 10 residents of Phnom Penh blocked an excavator from knocking down an uninhabited building.
On 24 July 2016, in Phnom Penh, around 100 garment workers protested in Freedom Park a CNRP leader's pitch to the EU to put pressure on the Cambodian garment industry imports to effect change.
On 22 July 2016, more than 30 former garment workers protested in Phnom Penh to demand an injunction that would allow them to sell equipment from a defunct factory they used to work for.

On 19 July 2016, in Phnom Penh, more than 300 workers from an electronics factory in Kampong Speu brought a week-long protest to the doorstep of the Ministry of Labour to demand the government force their employer to re-hire a dismissed unionist and improve working conditions.
On 18 July 2016, in Kampong Speu province, more than 300 workers from an electronics factory protested for a week demanding an improvement to their working conditions.
On 18 July 2016, activists clashed with police in Phnom Penh after police blocked them from marching in support of an arrested election official.
On 17 July 2016, in Kampong Speu province, more than 300 workers from an electronics factory protested for a week demanding an improvement to their working conditions.
On 16 July 2016, in Kampong Speu province, more than 300 workers from an electronics factory protested for a week demanding an improvement to their working conditions.
On 15 July 2016, in Kampong Speu province, more than 300 workers from an electronics factory protested for a week demanding an improvement to their working conditions.
On 14 July 2016, in Kampong Speu province, more than 300 workers from an electronics factory protested for a week demanding an improvement to their working conditions.
On 14 July 2016, 100 villagers protested outside Preah Sihanouk provincial hall to demand that authorities resolve their disputes and provide them with land titles.
On 14 July 2016, in Phnom Penh, about 100 people from nine communities along a discontinued railway line due to be turned into a road went to City Hall to protest the plan.
On 13 July 2016, in Kampong Speu province, more than 300 workers from an electronics factory protested for a week demanding an improvement to their working conditions.

On 12 July 2016, in Phnom Penh, thirty people representing 540 families affected by the development of a new satellite city at a lake in Phnom Penh gathered in front of City Hall to demand a solution to their concerns, such as being evicted from their land.

On 11 July 2016, in Battambang city, Battambang province, more than 300 workers from a footwear factory gathered in front of Battambang city hall to seek intervention after an 11-day strike failed to resolve their demands, such as receiving monthly allowances.

On 11 July 2016, scuffles broke out between rioters and police in Phnom Penh when the police tried to block activists who were attempting to pay their respects to a government critic who had been killed.
Two children died and another was seriously injured by a landmine explosion.
On 10 July 2016, in Phnom Penh, a large crowd of protesters gathered at the scene of the killing of a vocal activist.

On 10 July 2016, a prominent political activist of the GDP was shot dead in broad daylight, sparking public outrage among those who believe this was the latest act of government intimidation ahead of elections next year. An eyewitness said two men walked into the shop where the activist was sitting and shot him in the head repeatedly at point blank range.

On 4 July 2016, a group of 50 Boeung Kak activists protested against the arrest of human rights activists. They were prevented from continuing the protest by about 20 security. As the guards attempted to take away the posters and cage, a brawl ensued in which three protesters sustained minor injuries.
A man stepped on a landmine, damaging one of his legs so severely it had to be amputated.

On 30 June 2016, in Phnom Penh, a group of 50 vendors operating out of Kampon Speu bus station protested and gathered to deliver a petition to the Ministry of Urban Planning asking that plans to relocate the bus station be reconsidered.
On 27 June 2016, in Kampot, Kampot province, more than 400 factory workers protested outside the firm they work for, demanding that 21 workers be rehired after their contracts expired.
On 27 June 2016, in Phnom Penh, twenty land activists dressed in black and protested near their homes by the airport outside of Phnom Penh.
On 23 June 2016, nearly 100 villagers protested the construction of an irrigation dam in Stung Treng.
On 21 June 2016, in Siem Reap town, Siem Reap province, a group of 81 soldiers protested against their former commander, alleging that he was guilty of land-grabbing.

On 20 June 2016, in Sihanoukville Special Economy Zone, Sihanoukville city, Preah Sihanouk province, around 600 garment workers protested outside the RCI garment factory because they had not been paid since May.
On 20 June 2016, five activists protested in Phnom Penh to demand the release of four human rights officials and an election officer. Four of the protesters were arrested.
On 14 June 2016, in Phnom Penh, hundreds of CNRP supporters congregated near the CNRP headquarters in anticipation of an attempt to arrest CNRP acting president Kem Sokha.

On 14 June 2016, Phnom Penh, more than 200 current and former employees of a garment factory burned tires and garbage in front of the factory facility to demand severance pay as the company nears closure.
On 6 June 2016, seven activists in Phnom Penh were arrested for demonstrating against the arrests of four human rights workers and an election official.

On 1 June 2016, in Touch village, Bar Kaev district, Ratanak Kiri province, district police officers broke up a gathering (not a protest) of 50 ethic Jarai Christians because they had not sought permission from authorities to meet.

On 30 May 2016, in Busra commune, Pechr Chenda district, Mondul Kiri province, 20 Bunong ethnic minority villagers from Poulo village engaged in a violent altercation with a coffee company operating on their land. The rioters forcibly stopped the coffee workers from planting, and a physical argument broke out.

Around 30 May 2016, in Sre Chhouk commune, Keo Seima district, Mondul Kiri province, around 50 Bunong ethnic villagers delivered a protest request that 300 hectares of land be titled as community forest by provincial authorities.
On 30 May 2016, in Phnom Penh, land rights activists marching in protest to call for the release of imprisoned human rights workers were halted by authorities.
On 30 May 2016, in Phnom Penh, twenty-three cars carrying more than two dozen opposition lawmakers delivered a mass petition to the Royal Palace calling for an end to Cambodia's political crisis.

On 23 May 2016, in Ba Phnom district's Boeung Preah commune, Prey Veng province, police shut down a gathering of 30 people in a private home, saying the event organizers had failed to notify the district governor of the gathering beforehand. The event was a outing to discuss farmers' rights, quality of life and political empowerment.

On 23 May 2016, in Phnom Penh, land activists held a protest of around 100 people, which turned into a riot when around 100 police officers arrived on the scene. Scuffles emerged and at least one person ended up in the hospital.
On 23 May 2016, Phnom Penh, twenty protesters from a community that faces eviction from their land near Phnom Penh airport demonstrated to demand land rights.

On 16 May 2016, in Phnom Penh, a group of 30 activists held a protest that was heavily monitored by a police contingent, which prevented the group from leaving the vicinity. The group was demanding the release of imprisoned civil society members. Five further land activists were arrested.
On 10 May 2016, a group of activists attempting to submit a petition against a dam being built in Laos were confronted by police officers in Phnom Penh and threatened with arrest.
On 10 May 2016, in Phnom penh, nearly 600 garment workers protested in front of the Labour Ministry, claiming they hadn't been paid bonuses after the factory changed their contracts.
On 7, 8 and 9 May 2016, in Phnom Penh, about 300 workers at the Lian Hao garment factory protested for three days in a row over the sacking of 14 workers, allegedly for forming a union.

On 9 May 2016, in Phnom penh, eight protesters, among them a German and a Swedish national, were arrested while they were protesting against the jailing of a group of human rights workers and an election official. Anti-riot officers carrying batons and shields set up roadblocks to prevent about 40 people total from taking part in the protest outside the prison holding those jailed.
On 7, 8 and 9 May 2016, in Phnom Penh, about 300 workers at the Lian Hao garment factory protested for three days in a row over the sacking of 14 workers, allegedly for forming a union.
On 7, 8 and 9 May 2016, in Phnom Penh, about 300 workers at the Lian Hao garment factory protested for three days in a row over the sacking of 14 workers, allegedly for forming a union.
On 6 May 2016, a group of university students clashed with CNRP supporters at CNRP headquarters in Kompong Thom province. No injuries resulted.

On 3 and 4 May 2016, in Kandal province, nearly 500 New Archid garment factory workers protested for two days in a row, demanding that the company they work for reinstate three worker representatives they claim were fired without cause.
On 3 May 2016, in Svay Rieng and in Prey Veng provinces, citizens in two communes gathered to protest their high power bills after a local electric company failed to lower its prices.
On 3 May 2016, in Svay Rieng and in Prey Veng provinces, citizens in two communes gathered to protest their high power bills after a local electric company failed to lower its prices.

On 3 and 4 May 2016, in Kandal province, nearly 500 New Archid garment factory workers protested for two days in a row, demanding that the company they work for reinstate three worker representatives they claim were fired without cause.
On 1 May 2016, about 2,000 workers in Phnom Penh marched to the National Assembly to call for higher wages and changes to a new trade union law.

On 27 April 2016, several hundred protesters representing some 4,000 families from Tbong Khmum's Memot and Dambe districts arrived in Phnom Penh to submit petitions against several different companies and local officials the protesters say are encroaching on their land.

On 25 April 2016, in Hanchey commune, Chhlong district, Kratie province, around 200 high school students and 30 teachers protested at Metey Keat Chhon High School to demand the removal of their principal for allegedly being rude to female teachers, spending school funds without transparency, and not giving them time off.

On 23 and 24 April 2016, in Phnom Penh, a group of former Capitol bus drivers who say they were fired after trying to form a union resumed demonstrations outside of Capitol's headquarters, asking for their jobs back and for government intervention.

On 23 and 24 April 2016, in Phnom Penh, a group of former Capitol bus drivers who say they were fired after trying to form a union resumed demonstrations outside of Capitol's headquarters, asking for their jobs back and for government intervention.

On 19 April 2016, in Tbeng Meanchey district, Preah Vihear province, more than 200 protesters were blocked by police while en route to deliver a petition against a Chinese-owned sugar company with which they are locked in an ongoing land dispute. While marching to attempt to meet with the Prime Minister, the police stopped the demonstrators, who went on to shout their demands from the sides of the road instead.

On 18 April 2016, in Phnom Penh, more than 400 workers at a South Korean-owned garment factory protested to demand their unpaid salaries after the factory's owner disappeared. The protesters said they had not been paid since March.
On 4 April 2016, security guards attempted to clear out protesters who were protesting the new union law in Phnom Penh. There were allegations that the guards acted aggressively.
On 30 March 2016, about 300 factory employees traveled to Phnom Penh to ask the Prime Minister for help securing money they believed they are owed per their contracts.

On 28 March 2016, in Kampot, Preah Sihanouk, Kandal provinces and Phnom Penh, independent unions and NGOs staged demonstrations at 100 factories and union offices in opposition to the draft trade union law.

On 28 March 2016, in Kampot, Preah Sihanouk, Kandal provinces and Phnom Penh, independent unions and NGOs staged demonstrations at 100 factories and union offices in opposition to the draft trade union law.

On 28 March 2016, in Kampot, Preah Sihanouk, Kandal provinces and Phnom Penh, independent unions and NGOs staged demonstrations at 100 factories and union offices in opposition to the draft trade union law.

On 28 March 2016, in Kampot, Preah Sihanouk, Kandal provinces and Phnom Penh, independent unions and NGOs staged demonstrations at 100 factories and union offices in opposition to the draft trade union law.

On 25 March 2016, in Koh Kong province, representatives of 526 Koh Kong families rode motorcycles to deliver petitions to their district town halls, calling for the return of land taken from them by a 2006 land concession.
On 14 March 2016, amusement park employees protested outside an amusement park in Phnom Penh to demand outstanding salary they believe they were owed.
Around 13 March 2016, representatives of 104 families from Kratie province arrived in Phnom Penh to protest the provincial authority's attempts to forcibly evict them.
On 10 March 2016, about 50 protesters demonstrated in Phnom Penh against the privatization of land they are living on for a development project.

On 8 March 2016, more than 200 activists attempted to cycle from the Ministry of Women's Affairs to the National Assembly in Phnom Penh to mark International Women's Day. They were eventually halted by authorities.
On 8 March 2016, around 100 Phnom Penh residents protested at the Ministry of Public Works against a planned expressway leading from the airport to the city center.
On 7 March 2016, in Kampot, Kampot province, 130 construction workers protested over allowances and annual leave, resulting in their employer conceding to most of their demands.
On 6 March 2016, more than 80 truck drivers used their vehicles to temporarily block a highway in Strung Treng City after authorities stopped their vehicles for being overloaded.
On 4 March 2016, students protested in Phnom Penh to call on a politician to come clean about leaked audio clips that recorded him speaking with a mistress.
On 3 March 2016, a soldier was killed in Samlot district, Battambang province, after driving over an old anti-tank mine in a tractor.

On 2 March 2016, in Chey Sen and Chheb districts, Preah Vihear province, about 200 residents of six villages obstructed a road used by a sugar company they were protesting for allegedly stealing some of the villagers' land.

On 1 March 2016, in Chey Sen and Chheb districts, Preah Vihear province, about 200 residents of six villages obstructed a road used by a sugar company they were protesting for allegedly stealing some of the villagers' land.

On 29 February 2016, in Prey Kuy village, Ampil commune, Siem Reap province, about 70 residents submitted a petition to provincial officials requesting that the authority of their commune not be changed to that of a different commune.
On February 27 and 28, 2016, hundreds of protesters in Phnom Penh gathered to voice opposition to a chief monk's plans to sell a local pond to an unknown developer.
On February 27 and 28, 2016, hundreds of protesters in Phnom Penh gathered to voice opposition to a chief monk's plans to sell a local pond to an unknown developer.
On 26 February 2016, 50 people gathered in Phnom Penh to protest the construction of a controversial hydropower dam.

On 23 February 2016, about 500 people gathered in Phnom Penh to demand the release of a former bus driver and a labour activist who were arrested for participating in a demonstration against a bus company.

On 16 February 2016, in Phnom Penh, more than 150 office workers from a Japanese quality-control company protested outside their office at the Cambodiana Hotel and threatened to continue if the company refused to negotiate. The protesters demanded paid vacation days, monthly bonuses and the end of anti-union discrimination.

On 15 February 2016, in Phnom Penh, about 50 workers from a garment subcontractor protested at the Ministry of Labour, calling for the factory's owner to pay their wages after he apparently disappeared with a massive amount of money that he owed them.

On 6 February 2016, in Phnom Penh, a group of former bus drivers, protesting what they claim are cases of unfair dismissal, clashed with a group of motorbike taxi drivers demanding an end to a protest they say is losing them passengers. More than 20 rioters were injured.
Protesting bus drivers and their supporters were attacked by a rival association armed with sticks, metal bars and hammers. Police arrested two protesters, but none of the attackers.
Members of a tuk-tuk drivers' association accused of working with a bus company beat a group of bus drivers who were protesting the company after a mass firing.

On 2 February 2016, protesters in Phnom Tbeng Meachey district, Preah Vihear province, surrounded a group of Forestry Administration officers in order to protect a pile of valuable logs from being seized. The standoff ended peacefully when police intervened.

On 1 February 2016, Khsach Kandal, Kandal province, striking garment workers were attacked by the factory's security guards. Eight workers and unionists were slightly injured and one more seriously injured. Despite the violence, the workers managed to complete their protest march. No arrests were made following the violence.

On 1 February 2016, in Prek Khsach commune, Kiri Sakor district, Koh Kong, roughly 30 villagers locked in a land dispute with a sugar company protested at a construction site where they say the company was attempting to erect a concrete barrier on disputed land.

On 1 February 2016, in Samrong Tong district, Kampong Speu province, garment workers at the Chinese-owned Cerie (Cambodia) factory protested against the firing of three unionists who tried to organise workers at the factory. Two union officials were arrested shortly after taking part in the protest.

On 1 February 2016, more than 100 students, joined by several teachers from a high school in Phnom Penh, protested in front of their school, accusing the school's director of corruption and demanding the reinstatement of three teachers that had been transferred to another school.

On 1 February 2016, in Phnom Penh, fired Capitol City Bus Company drivers resumed protests in front of their former employer's office after a City Hall-brokered truce failed to bring forth a resolution to their dispute. The 40 drivers say they were fired for trying to start a union. According to the protesters, the bus company had ignored the city's request to consider re-hiring the fired drivers.

On 1 February 2016, villagers evicted by the development of a Boeung Kak lake took their protest to the World Bank headquarters in Phnom Penh. They demanded to meet with the bank's Cambodia country manager, and pelted the building with eggs when their request was ignored.
On 27 January 2016, about 150 employees of a quality control firm protested outside the company's head office in Phnom Penh against the scrapping of bonuses.
Former Capitol Bus Company drivers who have been protesting in front of the company's office since last month decided to halt demonstrations temporarily after city hall intervened in the dispute.
On 26 January 2016, some 50 people gathered at Takeo Provincial Hall to ask authorities to assist them in recouping money they had invested in a collapsed savings scheme.

On 26 January 2016, in Siem Reap, Siem Reap province, about 80 protesters gathered in front of a local shrine to pray for the provincial court to cancel an injunction ordering them to stop demonstrating at a hotel's entrance. The workers have been protesting what they say is the unfair dismissal of 17 employees.
On 25 January 2016, on Chroy Changvar peninsula in Phnom Penh, several families burned tires to protest the bulldozing of their land. Security forces observed but did not interfere.
On 24 January 2016, about 50 protesters gathered in Phnom Penh to rally against a planned road that would encroach on their land.

On 20 January 2016, Botum Sakor districts, Koh Kong province, about 100 villagers representing more than 500 families delivered petitions to commune halls appealing for action on a decades-long land dispute with two sugar companies.

On 20 January 2016, in Sre Ambel district, Koh Kong province, about 100 villagers representing more than 500 families delivered petitions to commune halls appealing for action on a decades-long land dispute with two sugar companies.
On 20 January 2016, about 300 market vendors protested in front of a Phnom Penh municipal court to demand that two of their colleagues who had been arrested be released.
On 19 January 2016, 150 protesters gathered in Serei Saophoan City, Banteay Meanchey province, to demand land titles for disputed territory.
On 17 January 2016, in Phnom Penh, more than 20 beer promoters protested in front of their company's headquarters to demand better working conditions.
On 14 January 2016, about 200 garment factory workers traveled to Phnom Penh from Kompon Speu to petition the government to release five union officials who had been arrested earlier in the week.
On 14 January 2016, around 100 protesters marched in Phnom Penh to demand an intervention in their long-running land dispute.

On 13 January 2016, in Chbar Mon, Kampong Speu province, hundreds of protesters from the Agile Sweater garment factory gathered in front of the Kampong Speu provincial court to ask authorities to release five unionists arrested at the factory earlier in the week.

On 11 January 2016, in Phnom Penh, nearly 100 workers from the CERIE Garment factory in Kampong Speu protested at the Labour Ministry to urge officials to implement a decision made by the Arbitration Council to reinstate three workers fired for trying to create a union.

From 31 Dec 2015 to 7 Jan 2016, in Phnom Penh, dozens of former Capitol Bus Company drivers protested in front of their ex-employer's office for eight days straight, claiming they were unduly fired. Dozens of policemen were stationed outside of the office, but no interaction between the police and protesters was reported.

From 31 Dec 2015 to 7 Jan 2016, in Phnom Penh, dozens of former Capitol Bus Company drivers protested in front of their ex-employer's office for eight days straight, claiming they were unduly fired. Dozens of policemen were stationed outside of the office, but no interaction between the police and protesters was reported.

From 29 Dec 2015 to 6 Jan 2016, workers of a high-end hotel in in Siem Reap protested for nine days. The protesters demanded to reinstate 17 employees fired in 2015 following union elections. On 6 Jan, 90 staff gathered in front of the hotel.

Dozens of policemen were stationed outside of the office, but no interaction between the police and protesters was reported.
