From 31 Dec 2015 to 7 Jan 2016, in Phnom Penh, dozens of former Capitol Bus Company drivers protested in front of their ex-employer's office for eight days straight, claiming they were unduly fired. Dozens of policemen were stationed outside of the office, but no interaction between the police and protesters was reported.

From 29 Dec 2015 to 6 Jan 2016, workers of a high-end hotel in in Siem Reap protested for nine days. The protesters demanded to reinstate 17 employees fired in 2015 following union elections. On 6 Jan, 90 staff gathered in front of the hotel.

From 31 Dec 2015 to 7 Jan 2016, in Phnom Penh, dozens of former Capitol Bus Company drivers protested in front of their ex-employer's office for eight days straight, claiming they were unduly fired. Dozens of policemen were stationed outside of the office, but no interaction between the police and protesters was reported.

From 29 Dec 2015 to 6 Jan 2016, workers of a high-end hotel in in Siem Reap protested for nine days. The protesters demanded to reinstate 17 employees fired in 2015 following union elections. On 6 Jan, 90 staff gathered in front of the hotel.

From December 29 to 31, 2015, 80 villagers protested outside Preah Vihear's provincial in Tbaeng Meanchey hall against a Chinese-owned sugarcane plantation they accuse of encroaching on their farmland.

From 31 Dec 2015 to 7 Jan 2016, in Phnom Penh, dozens of former Capitol Bus Company drivers protested in front of their ex-employer's office for eight days straight, claiming they were unduly fired. Dozens of policemen were stationed outside of the office, but no interaction between the police and protesters was reported.

From 29 Dec 2015 to 6 Jan 2016, workers of a high-end hotel in in Siem Reap protested for nine days. The protesters demanded to reinstate 17 employees fired in 2015 following union elections. On 6 Jan, 90 staff gathered in front of the hotel.

From December 29 to 31, 2015, 80 villagers protested outside Preah Vihear's provincial in Tbaeng Meanchey hall against a Chinese-owned sugarcane plantation they accuse of encroaching on their farmland.
On 30 December 2015, Fifty recently-fired bus drivers protested in front of the office of their former employer, claiming they had been unfairly fired.

From 29 Dec 2015 to 6 Jan 2016, workers of a high-end hotel in in Siem Reap protested for nine days. The protesters demanded to reinstate 17 employees fired in 2015 following union elections. On 6 Jan, 90 staff gathered in front of the hotel.

From December 29 to 31, 2015, 80 villagers protested outside Preah Vihear's provincial in Tbaeng Meanchey hall against a Chinese-owned sugarcane plantation they accuse of encroaching on their farmland.

From 29 Dec 2015 to 6 Jan 2016, workers of a high-end hotel in in Siem Reap protested for nine days. The protesters demanded to reinstate 17 employees fired in 2015 following union elections. On 6 Jan, 90 staff gathered in front of the hotel.
On 24 December 2015, authorities in Phnom Penh blocked villagers from marching to protest a long-running land dispute in Preah Vihear province.
On 23 December 2015, a group of 100 protesters initiated a march in Phnom Penh to call for justice in their long-running land dispute.
On 23 December 2015, more than 400 truck drivers blocked busy Phnom Penh roads to protest restrictions on the kinds of vehicles they are allowed to drive.
A woman was killed and three of her family members injured following the explosion of a decades-old grenade.

On 21 December 2015, about 200 garment workers (other sources say as many as 5000) walked off their jobs at a factory in the Tai Seng Special Economic Zone in Bavet city. They headed to an area to protest but were detained by riot police. Some of the rioters were armed with sticks and clubs, and at least 2 military police were allegedly injured in stone throwing. The police dispersed the riot with a water canon, but no arrests were made.

On 16 December 2015, a dispute over new streetlights in a Phnom Penh neighborhood escalated into a violent incident when an Interior Ministry official gunned down a village chief and his relatives. Three were killed.

On 15 December 2015, in Serei Saop, Banteay Meanchey province, about 100 people gathered outside the Banteay Meanchey Provincial Court to demand authorities release from custody the organizer of a protest.

On 14 December 2015, in Paoy Paet, Banteay Meanchey province, about 50 protesters marched through the town dragging a dummy painted in fake blood with the words 'corrupt officials abuse citizens and create injustice.' The protesters face eviction from their homes to make way for a railway project. The organizer of the protest was detained.
On 14 December 2015, in Chbar Mon, Kampong Speu, about 200 villagers in Kampong Speu protested against a land dispute.

On 10 December 2015, in Phnom Penh, close to 2,000 protesters marched peacefully to the Ministry of Justice in recognition of Human Rights Day. The police set up barricades, but the march proceeded without major confrontations or violence.
On 8 December 2015, rallies were held to celebrate International Human Rights Day in five provinces - Koh Kong, Siem Reap, Takeo, Kratie and Svay Rieng.
On 8 December 2015, rallies were held to celebrate International Human Rights Day in five provinces - Koh Kong, Siem Reap, Takeo, Kratie and Svay Rieng.
On 8 December 2015, rallies were held to celebrate International Human Rights Day in five provinces - Koh Kong, Siem Reap, Takeo, Kratie and Svay Rieng.
On 8 December 2015, rallies were held to celebrate International Human Rights Day in five provinces - Koh Kong, Siem Reap, Takeo, Kratie and Svay Rieng.

On 8 December 2015, rallies were held to celebrate International Human Rights Day in five provinces - Koh Kong, Siem Reap, Takeo, Kratie and Svay Rieng. Authorities in Siem Reap blocked the march to keep public order and avoid traffic congestion
On 8 December 2015, in Phnom Penh, hundreds of garment workers burned car tires in protest of labor conditions.

On 8 December 2015, in Kandal province, hundreds of garment workers from Winnie Fashion Co Ltd burned car tires in protest of poor physical working conditions and the company's hostile attitude towards unions.

On 5 December 2015, dozens of activist monks rallied at Wat Stung Meanchey in Phnom Penh to protest a monk's defrocking for throwing Buddha statues into a pond, claiming he was framed because he is a known supporter of land activists.
On 4 December 2015, around 100 people protested the installation of a new electricity transmission tower to demand a halt in the placement of the towers, or suitable compensation.

On 3 December 2015, a women's protest group gathered outside the World Bank office in Phnom Penh to call on it to freeze lending to Cambodia. Police were present at the protest and allegedly pushed and pulled some of the women in an attempt to move them away from the protest site.
On 3 December 2015, in Phnom Penh, a coalition of 23 union groups gathered in front of the National Assembly, demanding changes to a controversial law governing the trade union sector.

On 2 December 2015, in Banlung, Ratanak Kiri, about 150 villagers destroyed the gates of Ratanakkiri Provincial Court in protest of the conviction and imprisonment of three of their community representatives. Provincial military police intervened after about half an hour of protesting, but no villagers were arrested and no injuries were reported.

On 29 November 2015, in Siem Reap, Siem Reap province, more than 70 workers from a Korean-owned massage center protested in front of their workplace to demand a basic wage increase with a yearly health bonus. They are also on strike.
On 27 November 2015, a village chief in Phnom Penh was doused with battery acid by two unidentified assailants.
One villager was killed and two more injured when their tractor rolled over a land mine.
On 19 November 2015, a group of several dozen marchers in Poipet were blocked by police. They were marching to protest their evictions.

On 16 November 2015, in Prey Tralach, Battambang, protesters demonstrated against the eviction from their houses in Prey Tralach community forest, which local authorities claim was illegally inhabited and deforested by villagers.

On 16 November 2015, about 100 villagers in Rokha Kiri district, Battambang province, blocked the road to their district office to demand the removal of a local official accused of pillaging a community forest.

On 16 November 2015, about 300 market vendors protested outside a municipal court in Phnom Penh as one of their representatives was questioned over a complaint that he had led the sellers in defying an order approving a change in market management.
On 16 November 2015, two families burned tires in protest regarding a land dispute in Phnom Penh before being dispersed by a small team of military police and district security guards.

A soldier was shot and killed as he slept in his home (assumed unarmed at the time). Earlier that day, he had been investigating a piece of disputed land. According to authorities, his death may have been related to his investigation.

On 11 November 2015, in Phnom Penh, more than 300 garment workers from Takeo province protested in front of the Ministry of Labour following two weeks of strikes over working conditions. Their demands included lunch money, a transportation allowance and conforming to wage laws.
Two law enforcement officers were killed and another wounded in a gun ambush by unknown attackers. Police suspect the attack was in retaliation for a raid on an illegal logging site the night before.
On 2 November 2015, more than 400 truck owners and drivers gathered in Phnom Penh to demand tax breaks and authorization to drive their illegal right-handed drive vehicles.
On 30 October 2015, 700 Jarai ethnic villagers protested a mining firm in Ratanakkiri at the Pate Commune Hall.
On 28 October 2015, 80 truck drivers rallied in Phnom Penh to demand tax breaks and for certain kinds of vehicles to be legalized.

On 27 October 2015, truck drivers surrounded a group of custom officials in Kandal province's Takhmao City to protest a tax dispute. The custom officials had stopped two trucks that had not paid taxes on their vehicles when they were surrounded.

Two opposition lawmakers from the CNRP were beaten outside parliament during a demonstration in support of the ruling party. The two victims were attacked in their vehicles as they tried to leave the national assembly, where hundreds of protesters were gathered to demand the resignation of the legislature's deptuy president.

On 22 October 2015, 600 Agile Sweater factory garment workers protested outside the provincial court in Chbar Mon City, Kampong Speu province to call for the release of two workers who had been jailed after attempting to start a new union.

On 19 October 2015, in Chbar Mon Town, Kampong Speu province, around 250 villagers protested outside the Kampong Speu Provincial Hall to demand compensation for land concessions in an ongoing dispute with a Chinese company.
On 18 October 2015, a farmer was injured when an old bomb exploded near his home in Sala Krao district, Pailin province.
On 16 October 2015, 15 villagers burned a sign bearing the CNRP logo in protest against the party. The protest was in Samraong City, Oddar Meanchey province.
On 5 October 2015, more than 1,000 demonstrators gathered in Phnom Penh to protest widespread land and housing evictions, but their march was blocked by municipal authorities.
On 5 October 2015, more than 100 teachers rallied in Phnom Penh to call on the government to increase wages.
On 2 October 2015, 250 protesters demonstrated in front of Banteay Meanchey's provincial hall to implore local officials to resolve land disputes.
On 1 October 2015, about 100 people protested outside Poipet's city government offices against the looming threat of eviction from their homes and other problems.

On 25 September 2015, in Phnom Penh, more than 200 employees of a Japanese-owned quality control firm protested to demand the dismissal of the firm's general manager, who they said was critical and condescending.
On 22 September 2015, a group of 90 workers protested outside of a recruitment company in a Phnom Penh district office, saying the company had cheated them out of hundreds of dollars.

On 18 September 2015, in Poy Chorpun, Koh Kong province, over 200 protesters gathered to block a Chinese firm from accessing a road in order to pressure authorities into resolving an ongoing land dispute with the firm. About 50 policemen armed with batons intervened to disperse the protesters. While some protesters were detained, no instances of violence were reported.

In the week of 16 September 2015, in Andoung Meas district, Ratanak Kiri province, hundreds of villagers from about 135 families of the Jarai ethnic minority last week continued to block an Australian gold mining company from accessing a plot of land that is licensed for exploration.

On 16 September 2015, a group of villagers gathered to protest a land dispute in Andong Trabek commune, Romeas Hek district, Svay Rieng province. Police officers then attempted to block them from traveling to the provincial court for a hearing.

assoc_actor_2: ADHOC: Cambodian Human Rights and Development Association
notes: An NGO worker was allegedly attacked in his house by a military police official and six timber dealers in retailiation for filing a forestry crime report against them.
On 13 September 2015, about 400 students and villagers protested in Phnom Penh to demand the release of two men arrested while protesting a land dispute.
On 7 September 2015, dozens of employees of a state-owned telecom agency protested in Phnom Penh over allegations that a manager had pocketed payments from a private firm.

On 2 September 2015, protesters camped out near the provincial courthouse in Khemara Phoumint City to protest the arrest of three activists from an environmental NGO. Police broke up the camp, arresting 17 of the protesters.

assoc_actor_1: LICADHO: Cambodian League for the Promotion and Defense of Human Rights
notes: On 27 August 2015, police attempted to arrest a group of people protesting to demand the release of three jailed activists in Koh Kong province's Khemara Phoumint city.
On 26 August 2015, a police officer was killed and another injured when an old rocket exploded along Oddar Meachey province's border with Thailand.
On 20 August 2015, about 85 protesters gathered outside the Koh Kong provincial court in Khemara Phoumint city to demand the release of three detained activists.
On 19 August 2015, more than 400 factory employees lobbed rocks at their factory, demonstrating against alleged labor abuses. The factory is in Svay Rieng province's Bavet city.
On 17 August 2015, about 300 market vendors gathered near the Prime Minister's villa in Phnom Penh to protest against plans to demolish a market.

Arrests: Local security forces arrested Senator Hong Sok Hour from the opposition party, accusing him of treason for posting a fake Vietnam-Cambodia border treaty on his Facebook page. The arrest was carried out under the order of the Prime Minister.

On 9 August 2015, in Phnom Penh's Russey Keo district, about 200 people protested to demand the release of two women who were arrested last week. The pair was charged with chaining up their 13-year-old niece and selling her for sex.

On 6 August 2015, Daun Penh security guards prevented journalists from interviewing land rights activists near Phnom Penh City Hall, kicking some of the reporters and activists, attempting to confiscate cameras, and deleting photos. The activists were protesting against Phnom Penh's governor regarding land rights. No injuries reported.

On 5 August 2015, a group of families living in Phnom Penh protested outside a district governor's office in Phnom Penh to ask for a donation to build a drainage system in their flood-prone community.
On 2 August 2015, about 100 villagers burned effigies of officials involved in a land dispute in Ta Ches commune, Kompong Tralach district, Kompong Chhnang province.
From July 27 to July 30, 2015, protesters attempted to stop a company from dredging sand in Botum Sakor district's Andong Teuk estuary, accusing the company of polluting the local water system.
From July 27 to July 30, 2015, protesters attempted to stop a company from dredging sand in Botum Sakor district's Andong Teuk estuary, accusing the company of polluting the local water system.
From July 27 to July 30, 2015, protesters attempted to stop a company from dredging sand in Botum Sakor district's Andong Teuk estuary, accusing the company of polluting the local water system.
From July 27 to July 30, 2015, protesters attempted to stop a company from dredging sand in Botum Sakor district's Andong Teuk estuary, accusing the company of polluting the local water system.

On 26 July 2015, in Phnom Penh, Cambodian authorities arrested six protesters as they stood outside of the parliament building to rally against the passing of a controversial NGO law. The six demonstrators were arrested out of a crowd of dozens because they were wearing prison uniforms and had chained their feet together, so were not able to run away from the parliament building when the riot police were chasing away the other protesters.
On 24 July 2015, in Phnom Penh, about 400 protesters gathered peacefully outside Parliament during the vote on a bill that will place tight restrictions on NGOs. The bill was approved.

On 22 July 2015, protesters surrounded a police station in Char commune, Prey Kabbas district, Takeo province, demanding that an alleged criminal accused of kidnapping a child be handed over for summary execution.

On 22 July 2015, in Phnom Penh, about 100 vendors who sell at Doeum Kor Market protested in front of City Hall, voicing concerns about a new mall that is planned to be built on the market site. They are calling for the construction of the mall to be delayed until after their leases on market space expire in 2020.

On 22 July 2015, in Phnom Penh, about 50 bus drivers began a protest against the bus company they work for, demanding the rehiring of five co-workers who they say were fired for forming a labor union. The protest went on for at least a week, although it was unclear whether the drivers protested every single day.

On 22 July 2015, in Phnom Penh, hundreds of people gathered in 13 provinces across Cambodia to protest a controversial NGO law. Members of community groups and NGOs distributed leaflets, released balloons, held community forums, and organized marches in last-ditch efforts to stop the bill from passing.

On 20 July 2015, in Phnom Penh, about 300 protesters from Svay Rieng and Preah Sihanouk provinces marched to parliament to file petitions urging local authorities to intervene to resolve ongoing land disputes in their home provinces. Two hundred other protesters were blocked from marching to the capital by district authorities.

On 20 July 2015, in Phnom Penh, about 200 supporters of a garment workers' strike demonstrated outside the Phnom Penh Municipal Court, which had issued an injunction ordering the workers to return to work. The protesters said they would not adhere to the injunction.

On 19 July 2015, in Svay Rieng province, Vietnamese and Cambodian border authorities prevented about 1,800 Cambodians belonging to the CNRP from crossing the border into the southern Vietnamese province of Long An. Despite not being permitted to cross the border, about 800 of the Cambodians walked to an area about 600 meters from the border, and about 100 approached a border marker to conduct a 'survey.'

On 18 July 2015, in Phnom Penh, six activists were arrested for handing out leaflets denouncing a controversial NGO law. The District Governor said the protesters were arrested because they 'launched a protest along the street and public places without permission from the local authorities.' They were later released.

On 14 July 2015, in Phnom Penh, at least 500 workers from three garment factories protested outside the Labor Ministry to demand that government officials intervene after the factories they work for refused to meet their demands for food and transportation subsidies. The protesters also voiced concerns about poor working conditions.
On 13 July 2015, in Phnom Penh, hundreds of people rallied to protest the passage of a controversial NGO law.

On 7 July 2015, in Phnom Penh, hundreds of protesters gathered to voice opposition to a controversial draft NGO law that they say will place undue restrictions on NGOs and undermine the role of civil society. The protesters gathered outside of parliament, holding banners and shouting slogans against the draft law. The group was confronted by around 100 security guards, but no clashes were reported.
On 7 July 2015, about 100 people protested outside the provincial headquarters in Siem Reap City to demand the release of two opposition CNRP activists.

On 28 June 2015, in Svay Rieng province, around 300 Cambodian demonstrators scuffled with around 300 Vietnamese security personnel while they attempted to reach a disputed border area along the Cambodia-Vietnam border. Some Vietnamese demonstrators reportedly attacked the Cambodian demonstrators with wooden clubs, leaving at least 18 people injured.

On 28 June 2015, in Phnom Penh, more than 200 protesters, comprised of civil society organizations and monks, marched to the National Assembly to demand the withdrawal of a controversial draft law on NGOs and associations. The protesters say the law is designed only to serve political interests.

On 26 June 2015, over 1,000 teachers and students demonstrated outside a school in Banteay Meanchey province's Serei Saophoan city against a private construction firm that was working on disputed land.

On 25 June 2015, about 100 garment workers blocked the exit of a factory in Phnom Penh to protest working conditions. Four protesters were injured when a truck driver unintentionally drove into the crowd.
On 25 June 2015, in Phnom Penh, four activists protesting the government to stop a Vietnamese sand dredging company were arrested by about 100 police officers. They were released later that day.
On 24 June 2015, hundreds of factory workers blocked National Road 3 in Takeo province to demand an increase in their wages.
A man was badly injured when a decades-old land mine exploded after he ran it over with a tiller. The detonation left him with injuries all over his body and destroyed the tiller.
On 11 June 2015, more than 100 protesters gathered outside Poipet City Hall in support of families who were not offered compensation for land that was taken from them to complete a railway project.

On 10 June 2015, about 50 residents of Paoy Paet town (Banteay Meanchey) protested against the Anco utilities company over its digging up of a portion of road leading to the Kai Don Reservoir. Residents claim the road is a historical landmark, but the company says it needs to expand the reservoir in order to provide more water to Poipet and surrounding areas. Anco is struggling to supply the town with adequate fresh water supplies during drought-like conditions.

On 8 June 2015, in Ratanakiri province, around 200 Cambodian activists confronted dozens of Vietnamese soldiers and villagers, resulting in a standoff over the digging of irrigation ponds in a non-demarcated area along the Vietnam-Cambodia border. The activists faced off against 50 Vietnamese soldiers armed with guns and patrol dogs, and pushed forward into the 'white zone' after about three hours.

On 11 June 2015, 500 factory workers attempted to march to the Prime Minister's house in Phnom Penh to call for improvements to working conditions. The protesters were blocked from completing their march by district security guards.

On 7 June 2015, about 200 midwives and nursing students protested at the International University in Phnom Penh yesterday after reportedly being denied the necessary documents required to sit the Ministry of Health's state civil servant exam this summer. The protesters held banners and prepared to burn tires, but were halted by university administrators, who promised to find a solution to the problem. The students said the university did not release their graduate certificates in time, and so they were unable to qualify to take exams that are a prerequisite for the intended professions.
On 5 June 2015, about 20 protesters marched to Phnom Penh Municipal Court to ask it to revoke an injunction ordering striking workers to return to their jobs.
On 4 June 2015, 30 protesters gathered outside the National Assembly in Phnom Penh to call for a CPP lawmaker to be removed from his post for the suffering he caused as municipal governor.

On 1 June 2015, in Rovieng (Samroang, Takeo), one hundred and fifty people gathered to protest the Thy Ngar Company over a land dispute. Two thousand protesters were expected to attend, but many were blocked from the area by authorities.

Non-violent activity: A land dispute between Vietnamese soldiers and Cambodian civilians resulted in Vietnamese soldiers blocking about 500 Cambodians along with four members of the CNRP from accessing an area the Cambodians claimed was Cambodian territory.
On 25 May 2015, some 20 Cambodian workers who say they were ripped off by a company they worked for in Sweden gathered at the country's embassy in Phnom Penh to ask for assistance.

On 18 May 2015, dozens of villagers in Battambang's Banan district blocked a dirt road to prevent a sand-dredging company's trucks from accessing the area and asked the local government to stop the company's activities to prevent further collapse of a riverbank. About 70 of the 100 villagers who protested the company's sand-dredging activities in Banan district in Battambang province erected blockades in the road and formed a line to prevent the trucks from entering the area.

On 18 May 2015, in Phnom Penh, about 100 villagers involved in two different land disputes in Kratie and Preah vihear provinces converged on the National Assembly to ask the country's lawmakers for help in settling their cases.

On 16 May 2015, in Phnom Penh, ninety-five Chinese nationals working at a construction site on Koh Pich island protested outside the Chinese Embassy and then a commune office to lodge a complaint against their employer for allegedly confiscating their passports.

On 7 April 2015, in Phnom Penh, about 100 women's rights activists gathered near the National Assembly, planning to demonstrate to demand female representation on the reformed National Election Committee, but were blocked by police.

On 6 April 2015, in Chuk district (Kampot), about 200 villagers resisted an attempt by provincial officials and military police to demarcate land spanning three villages that is earmarked for families of retired military officials. Villagers pushed and shoved the officials and police away from the disputed area.

On 5 April 2015, in Phnom Penh, a group of about 25 dog owners with at least 30 dogs gathered at Neak Banh Teauk Park to raise awareness of the 'pet meat' trade in Cambodia. The protesters were quickly moved by police to a plaza outside of the Phnom Penh Center and then later told to disperse.

On 16 March 2015, in Dangkor district, Phnom Penh, more than 200 striking workers demonstrated in front of Siko Phnom Penh Garment Factory yesterday after management fired an employee who founded a new labor union there, according to a union representative.

On 13 March 2015, in Phnom Penh, Seven Beehive Radio employees demonstrated outside the station against the station's withholding of a month's pay from four workers accused of consistently turning up late for work. Two employees were fired without notice or severance pay.

On 10 March 2015, in Phnom Penh, more than 30 workers from a bankrupt Chinese-owned garment factory protested outside the municipal court calling for the issuance of an injunction to ensure the factory's 300 former employees receive their severance pay.

On 8 March 2015, in Phnom Penh, about 25 former employees of the Chang Sheng Garment factory --which was destroyed in a fire last year--protested outside the offices of the Coalition of Cambodian Apparel Workers' Democratic Union (CCAWDU), which they accuse of withholding severance packages owed to some 180 workers.

On 2 March 2015, in Meanchey district, (Siem Reap), more than 50 CNRP officials seeking the removal of lawmaker Ke Sovannaroth as the party's head in Siem Reap province carried through with a threat to bring their case to Phnom Penh, demonstrating for two hours outside the opposition's headquarters in Meanchey district. The protesters accuse Ms. Sovannaroth of nepotism and spending irregularities.

On 27 February 2015, in Phnom Penh, about 200 garment workers protested outside the Phnom Penh Municipal Court after 20 colleagues were turned away when trying to enter the Smart Shirts factory earlier the same morning, union leaders said.

On 26 February 2015, in Pur Senchey district in Phnom Penh, thousands of striking garment workers from Quantum Clothing factory gathered in front of the factory demanding a wage increase. The protester began fighting and pushing other employees attempting to enter the plant. No one was injured.

On 25 February 2015, in Phnom Penh, about 1,000 garment workers from Quantum Clothing factory demonstrated outside the factory against a government provision that excludes workers who were already making more than $128 a month from getting a guaranteed raise. The protester were blocking the gate and the entrance. Subsequently, factory official allegedly attacked two workers grabbing them by their hair and slapping one of them in the face.

On 25 February 2015, in Pur Senchey district in Phnom Penh, thousands of striking garment workers from Quantum Clothing factory gathered in front of the factory demanding a wage increase. The protesters accused their bosses of attacking two employees during the protest.
On 24 February 2015, in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk), about 100 villagers from 19 communities marched to the provincial hall demanding intervention in their land disputes.

On 21 February 2015, in Banteay Meanchey province, some 100 farmers gathered at Banteay Meanchey Provincial Hall to protest the actions of a company they accuse of excavating 50 hectares of their rice fields for soil, which it sells by the truckload, according to protesters.

From February 15-17, 2015, about 200 workers from Hor Ling garment factory in Kampong Speu province continued striking over poor working conditions and their Chinese boss's alleged attack against 29-year-old former staff member Chouk Phally with an electroshock weapon.

From February 15-17, 2015, about 200 workers from Hor Ling garment factory in Kampong Speu province continued striking over poor working conditions and their Chinese boss's alleged attack against 29-year-old former staff member Chouk Phally with an electroshock weapon.

From February 15-17, 2015, about 200 workers from Hor Ling garment factory in Kampong Speu province continued striking over poor working conditions and their Chinese boss's alleged attack against 29-year-old former staff member Chouk Phally with an electroshock weapon.

On 14 February 2015, in Snam Krapoeu commune (Kong Pisei, Kampong Speu), about 200 workers from Hor Ling garment factory began striking and protesting in front of the factory over poor working conditions and their Chinese boss's alleged attack against 29-year-old former staff member Chouk Phally with an electroshock weapon.

On 12 February 2015, in Phnom Penh, dozens of vendors gathered outside Sorya Mall holding signs stating their demands for a 30 percent reduction in rental fees and a change of management, after negotiations between vendors and management at Phnom Penh's Sorya Mall ended without a solution.

On 11 February 2015, in Phnom Penh, some 200 representatives of 16 communities from across the country marched through the city dropping off copies of a petition calling for the release of 11 jailed anti-eviction activists and an end to state-sanctioned violence against villagers in land disputes.

On 5 February 2015, in Phnom Penh, government security guards and riot police blocked about 50 demonstrators from marching to Freedom Park to protest for the release of 19 imprisoned anti-eviction activists, monks and opposition CNRP figures. The protesters gathered outside the U.S. Embassy and planned to rally at Freedom Park before delivering a petition to the National Assembly. They were stopped from marching, but were allowed to ride tuk-tuks to the National Assembly to deliver their petition.

On 1 February 2015, in O'Chum district (Rattanak Kiri), villagers protested against a Chinese company for bulldozing their land and nearby family graves to create a rubber plantation. The company representative said they had received permission from the government to develop the new rubber plantations on the old plantations in the area. The villagers are demanding compensation.

On 25 and 26 Jan 2015, in Koh Anlong Chin commune (Sa'ang, Kandal), hundreds of protesters burned tyres along riverbanks, demanding local authorities intervene with a sand dredging plan by Sok Teang Import Export in the area.

On 25 and 26 Jan 2015, in Koh Anlong Chin commune (Sa'ang, Kandal), hundreds of protesters burned tyres along riverbanks, demanding local authorities intervene with a sand dredging plan by Sok Teang Import Export in the area.

On 21 January 2015, in Phnom Penh, dozens of security personnel dispersed about 50 villagers from Freedom Park after they attempted to hold a second day of protests over land disputes and demand the release of 10 detained activists and a monk a day ahead of their appeal trial.

On 20 January 2015, in Phnom Penh, 60 protesters were turned away by authorities from Freedom Park. Protesters were attempting to demonstrate over land disputes and demand the release of 10 detained activists and a monk ahead of their appeal trial.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (Cambodia); CCU: Cambodian Confederation of Unions
notes: Around 19 January 2015, in Kampong Siem district (Kampong Cham), about 200 people protested in front of the provincial labour department demanding that the factory reinstates three Cambodian Alliance of Trade Unions (CATU) representatives that were fired last year. The protest was led by the president of the Cambodian Confederation of Unions.

In the week of the 15 Jan 2015, in Kampong Siem district (Kampong Cham), thousands protested in front of the Manhattan garment factory demanding that the factory reinstates three Cambodian Alliance of Trade Unions (CATU) representatives that were fired last year.

On 6 January 2015, fighting broke out in Phnom Penh as evictees were blocked from reclaiming their land by a woman who once represented them. Evictees fought intermittently with the woman and a group of people she claimed were the real evictees. The fighting included shouting and throwing building equipment out of reach. No injuries were reported.

On 5 January 2015, about 500 farmers, armed with axes and knives, from Banteay Srei district blocked the main road leading to Kulen Mountain to draw attention to their dispute with the Forestry Administration over 350 hectares of land in the area. The military police arrested two villagers after they were taunted by the protesters.

On 5 January 2015, around 300 villagers from Memot district representing 634 families attempted to travel to Prime Minister Hun Sen's speech to bring their land dispute case with Memot Rubber Plantation Co to the premier's attention. The villagers were blocked by authorities from attending the speech.
Property destruction: Officials allegedly burned down cottages villagers had built on disputed land in Banteay Srei district.
On 4 January 2015, farmers from Banteay Srei district protested after officials burned down cottages the villagers had build on disputed land between the villagers and the Forestry Administration.

On 3 January 2015, in Phnom Penh, about 100 military police, riot police and government security guards blocked a roughly equal number of protesters from Phnom Penh's Borei Keila community from marching to the National Assembly to deliver a petition protesting their evictions three years ago.
On 1 January 2015, in Phnom Penh, an angry mob of protesters confronted Lak Sopheap at a protest against her dismissal from the CNRP. No injuries were reported.

On 31 December 2014, more than 40 villagers from 80 families in Chheb district's M'lou Prey I commune demonstrated against a group from Chinese concessionaire Rui Feng International measuring more than 16 hectares of land claimed by residents.

On the last week of December, Thai soldiers attempted to enter the disputed territory of An Ses/Chong Arn Mar (Choam Khsant district, Preah Vihear Province) and opened fire, leading Cambodian troops to shootback in self-defence. Cambodian officials denied that any shooting had occurred.

On 29 and 30 December 2014, villagers in Brame commune (Preah Vihear) confiscated bulldozers and briefly held hostage two drivers from Chinese firms Rui Feng International and Lan Feng. Villagers are in a land dispute against the company Rui Feng.

On 29 and 30 December 2014, villagers in Brame commune (Preah Vihear) confiscated bulldozers and briefly held hostage two drivers from Chinese firms Rui Feng International and Lan Feng. Villagers are in a land dispute against the company Rui Feng.

On 29 December 2014, dozens of ethnic minority Tompuon villagers protested outside of Seda commune hall, in Ratanak Kiri. The villagers, representing 215 affected families, are against the destruction by a company of an area in Lumphat Wildlife Sanctuary that is used as a community forest.

Movement of forces: on 29 December, Cambodia started to move soldiers and weapons to the Chong Arn Ma pass (An Ses border crossing, near Choam Khsant in Preah Vihear), while evacuating civilians from a local market. The movement started after Cambodian authorities moved in equipment to begin work on a development project in an area claimed by both countries. Thailand also boosted its military presence in the area.

On 29 December 2014, hundreds of workers from the Cambo Kotop garment factory in Phnom Penh's Por Sen Chey district demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Labour and National Assembly, in Phnom Penh. The workers have several demands, including the reinstatement of five representatives of the Collective Union of Movement of Workers (CUMW).

On 24 December 2014, striking workers at Cambo Kotop garment factory in Phnom Penh's Por Sen Chey district burned tyres. The workers have several demands, including the reinstatement of five representatives of the Collective Union of Movement of Workers (CUMW).

On 23 December 2014, about 100 villagers blocked the National Road 6A with wooden beds and their bodies for three hours. The villagers are embroiled in a land dispute with Eng Kang Development Cooperation and Construction, in Phnom Penh's Chroy Changvar district.
On 22 December 2014, about 100 garment workers at Kampong Cham province's Manhattan factory held a protest following the termination of 10 Cambodian Trade Union Alliance members.

On 22 December 2014, 300 striking garment workers at Ginwin Industry (Cambodia) blocked the road in front of the Kandal province factory. They were pushed by police and military police. Capital of the province coded as location.

On 22 December 2014, about 2,000 striking garment workers blocked National Road 4 in Phnom Penh's Por Sen Chey district. The workers started protesting after the management fired five Collective Union of Movement of Workers (CUMW) officials.

On 22 December 2014, six journalists representing four media outlets were beaten, shot at and had their equipment destroyed while trying to cover the scene of a traffic accident, in Daun Penh district's Srah Chak commune, in Phnom Penh.

On 21 December 2014, Paoy Paet town cartpullers demonstrated against new inspections and unofficial fees levied since carts were rerouted through Rachas Market, 500 metres from the checkpoint. The workers transport goods across the Thai Cambodia border.

On 16 December 2014, more than 200 villagers from Kampong Speu protested in front of ANZ Royal Bank's headquarters in Phnom Penh. The group, representing 800 families from Thpong and Oral districts, demanded the bank pay them compensation from a land dispute with Phnom Penh Sugar Company.

Movement of forces: In December 2014 (no specific date mentioned), China reported that around 200 Thai soldiers had been deployed to the disputed area of An Ses/Chong Arn Mar (Choam Khsant district, Preah Vihear Province).

On 10 December 2014, around 3000 people, including Buddhist monks and garment workers, massed outside the parliament building in Phnom Penh calling for respect for human rights and the release of a group of jailed land activists. Many protesters were holding balloons, flags and portraits of jailed activists, as they marked the UN-designated global Human Rights Day.

On 09 December 2014, around 300 villagers marched along the Sesan River in Stung Treng province to mark Human Rights Day. The group wanted to raise awareness of the 'negative impacts of hydropower dams,' and three proposed Chinese-backed projects on the Mekong River tributary in particular.

On 09 December 2014, around 20 people marched in Phnom Penh to the embassies of the U.S., Japan, South Korea and several EU nations to petition for intervention in the cases of the 18 activists arrested in November. The group of demonstrators claim the arrests are part of efforts by the authorities to curb dissent and intimidate those speaking up on protection of human rights.

On 09 December 2014, groups of between 100 and 200 protesters each marched along National Routes 1 through 7 towards Phnom Penh. The protesters planned to deliver petitions to the National Assembly, or parliament, on 10 December, to mark Human Rights Day.

On 01 December 2014, about 1,600 striking workers demonstrated in front of Now Corp., a garment factory in Kandal's Ang Snuol district. The workers demanded $15 for accommodation or transportation, $26 per month for lunch and allowing pregnant workers to leave 15 minutes before the workday ends.
On 01 December 2014, about 100 workers demonstrated outside UDS Garment Co., in Phnom Penh, to protest against the firing of three Free Trade Union (FTU) representatives.
On 26 November 2014, a group of men allegedly showed up at a protest in Kandal Province, attempted to steal equipment and beat several strikers, leaving at least five workers injured.
On 26 November 2014, twenty Boeung Chhouk community members marched to government offices to protest against the impending loss of land.

On 24 November 2014, striking workers from Chim Li garment factory blocked National Road 4 in Phnom Penh for about two hours, as workers demanded government intervention to solve their grievances. They demanded for the management to reinstate a fired employee and pay a daily lunch allowance of 4,000 riel ($1), among other points.
On 19 November 2014, a man was seriously injured and lost his left leg when he stepped on an antipersonnel mine, in Chork Rokar village (Samlot district, Battambang).

On 17 November 2014, about a hundred villagers from Preah Vihear province who had been staying in Phnom Penh for almost three months gathered in front of the National Assembly. They asked the government for a speedy resolution to their land dispute with a ruling party lawmaker.

On 17 November 2014, about 600 striking workers marched to the National Assembly and Ministry of Labour in Phnom Penh, hitting empty pots with spoons. They delivered petitions pleading for government intervention, as the Chuen Leu garment factory refused to pay them seniority bonuses.
On 16 November 2014, hundreds of people gathered in front of Phnom Penh's Prey Sar prison to demand the release of 17 incarcerated activists, monks and opposition members.

On 14 November 2014, around 300 land campaigners, students and union members protested at the National Assembly in Phnom Penh, They claimed the recent arrests of 16 people were politically motivated, and demanded that the prisoners be freed unconditionally.

In the week of 9-15 November, security guards for Chinese firm Union Development Group razed two villages in Koh Kong province, destroyed 14 homes and attacked villagers with stones, axes and knives. The villagers, from Kiri Sakor district, are involved in a land dispute with the company.

On 12 November 2014, a group composed of three female land rights activists and a defrocked monk protested outside the Phnom Penh Municipal Court to demand the release of seven activists who were jailed for blocking traffic during a protest. The four were arrested and sentenced to one year in prison each.

On 10 November 2014, several dozen protesters blocked the road outside Phnom Penh City Hall to protest against flooding in their homes located in Boeung Kak neighbourhood. Seven female land rights activists were arrested and sentenced to one year in prison each for blocking traffic.

On 04 November 2014, more than 200 people demonstrated in front of Juhui Footwear, in Cheung Prey district, Kampong Cham province. The protesters showed support to the workers arrested after a violent protest in October.

On 04 November 2014, more than 100 demonstrators staged an anti-eviction protest in front of Koh Kong province's City Hall. The group demonstrated in support of a jailed community representative who was denied bail.

On 03 November 2014, police and military police cracked down on more than 100 anti-eviction protesters who were blocking the Koh Kong bridge. The villagers, locked in a dispute with the company that manages the Koh Kong Special Economic Zone, demonstrated in support of a jailed community representative. At least one woman was injured.

On 03 November 2014, more than 200 garment workers from Huey Chue factory blocked the road in front of the Ministry of Labour in Phnom Penh until officials accepted their petition for assistance. The workers demanded the payment of seniority benefits, the reinstatement of a fired coworker and the rehirement of roughly 200 people the company fired.

On 01 November 2014, owners of handicraft and furniture shops protested with workers and villagers against the local forestry administration officials in Preah Vihear town (Tbaeng Mean Chey city). The officials raided their shops, seizing raw timber and finished products.

On 30 October 2014, more than 300 people from communities in a land dispute with Memot Rubber Plantation Co blocked a portion of National Road 7 in Tbong Khmum province's Tbong Khmum district. The protesters, representing 638 families from different parts of Khnong Kropeu village, wanted to put pressure on authorities to grant them legal land titles.

On 26 October 2014, almost 100 workers protested outside the Ministry of Labour, in Phnom Penh, calling on the government to scrap a law forbidding people with criminal convictions from registering a union.

On 25 October 2014, more than 200 demonstrators burned a factory gate and hurled stones at the police, at Juhui footwear factory in Choeung Prey district of the eastern Kampong Cham province. They were dispersed by the police. Eight officers were injured and 10 demonstrators were arrested. The workers demanded higher wages and better working conditions.

On 20 October 2014, more than 200 people from eight communities in danger of losing land due to a railroad project funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) protested outside of its offices, in Phnom Penh

On 20 October 2014, about 100 people representing 333 families in Choam Ksan district's Kantuot commune and Tbeng Meanchey district's Palhal commune marched in Phnom Penh to the Chinese, Russian and Australian embassies. As they attempted to deliver petitions to Prime Minister Hun Sen, they were violently attacked by the police. At least 18 people were injured.

On 17 October 2014, around 300 survivors of the Khmer Rouge regime protested outside the Court in Phnom Penh, as the trials of two former leaders resumed. The protesters demanded monetary compensation for their suffering.

On 17 October 2014, more than 100 human rights activists, youths and Buddhist monks marched on the streets in Phnom Penh to protest against a refugee deal that Cambodia signed with Australia last month. Under the deal, Australia will send refugees, who intend to seek asylum in Australia, to resettle in Cambodia.

On 13 October 2014, about 80 villagers marched in Tbaeng Meanchey to seek the intervention of the central government in their dispute. Accompanying the protesters were 40 ethnic Kuoy villagers. They attempted to marched to the National Assembly but were blocked by security forces. No violence occurred.

On 13 October 2014, some 2,000 unionists marched to several embassies in Phnom Penh and set up a meeting between labour leaders and parliamentarians at the National Assembly. The group support an increase in the monthly minimum wage to $177 in Cambodia's garment sector.

On 13 October 2014, about 100 residents of Boeung Chhouk community protested outside the City Hall, in Phnom Penh. They demanded that authorities issue them land titles and end court action against six of their representatives.

assoc_actor_2: Former KPNLF: Khmer People's National Liberation Front (Cambodia)
notes: On 13 October 2014, three representatives of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front were physically assaulted in Phnom Penh (Phnom Penh) by Daun Penh district security guards while attempting to file a letter to city hall requesting permission to hold an anti-Vietnam protest.

On 12 October 2014, a journalist from Khmer Journalists Democracy (KJD) was fatally shot in Kratie province while investigating illegal logging near the border with Mondulkiri province. The suspect of the shooting is a police officer in Sre Chhouk commune in Keo Seima district, and also a timber trader. Some officers said that the journalist had been extorting luxury wood from the suspect.

On 12 October 2014, two journalists were allegedly assaulted by a group of suspects smuggling luxury wood, in northern Preah Vihear province. They claim when they encountered a vehicle they believed to be hauling illegal timber and took pictures of the cargo, the smugglers surrounded them and began to beat them with their helmets and sticks.

On 11 October 2014, around 40 drivers of the city's new public buses protested in front of the night market in Phnom Penh. They demanded a higher wage, but an official said they were 'confused' about the salary agreement.

On 09 October 2014, about 20 former residents from Boeung Kak lake community protested in front of a land measurement process in Phnom Penh for two former residents who were given plots by the City Hall. They protesters, who accepted $8,500 to relocate years ago, now say that the compensation was inadequate.

assoc_actor_1: Buddhist Group (Cambodia); Khmer Krom Ethnic Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 08 October 2014, more than 100 ethnic minority Khmer Krom monks and activists concluded their 5-day protest against a former Vietnamese diplomat. The group marched in Phnom Penh from the Freedom Park to the Vietnamese embassy, which was fortified by riot- police and metal barricades.

On 07 October 2014, more than 200 villagers in Kulen district (Preah Vihear province) set fire to an economic land concessionaire's property after the company, Seladamex, said the residents would have to wear official identification to enter and farm on what they say is their own land.

On 06 October 2014, a clash occurred between striking workers and managers and workers in Juhui Footwear factory, in Kampong Cham City. A factory manager said the mob broke through their gate and threw shoes, rocks and other projectiles, injuring three, while one worker said the managers provoked assaults to the strikers, ordering other workers to gather rocks, and that they first threw water bottles at strikers, then also grabbed and slapped women.

On 06 October 2014, about 3,000 Cambodians, including villagers victims of land grabs, activists and monks, marched to parliament and Prime Minister Hun Sen's residence in Phnom Penh in a bid to highlight the plight of the landless on World Habitat Day.

assoc_actor_1: Buddhist Group (Cambodia); Khmer Krom Ethnic Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 06 October 2014, hundreds of Khmer Krom protesters marched to the French Embassy and the Council of Ministers in Phnom Penh. The group called for support in their demands for an apology from Vietnam over comments made four months ago by a former embassy spokesman.Protesters handed out leaflets promoting the boycott of Vietnamese products.

On 05 October 2014, teachers marched in Phnom Penh to mark World Teachers Day demanding salaries commensurate with living expenses. Hundreds of armed policemen blocked the access to the prime minister's house and the Ministry of Education.

assoc_actor_1: Buddhist Group (Cambodia); Khmer Krom Ethnic Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 05 October 2014, for the second running day, about 100 ethnic minority Khmer Krom monks and activists set Vietnamese flags on fire, in front of the Vietnamese Embassy, in Phnom Penh. The group demanded an apology from a Vietnamese diplomat, and for him to recognize that Kampuchea Krom, which is now a part of Vietnam, is Cambodia's former territory.

assoc_actor_1: Buddhist Group (Cambodia); Khmer Krom Ethnic Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 04 October 2014, about 100 ethnic minority Khmer Krom monks and activists set Vietnamese flags on fire for the second time, in front of the Vietnamese Embassy, in Phnom Penh. The group demanded a Vietnamese diplomat to recognize that Kampuchea Krom, which is now a part of Vietnam, is Cambodia's former territory.

On 03 October 2014, approximately 100 Buddhist monks on marched in Phnom Penh amid rumors that the Ministry of Cults and Religion has leased a parcel of the iconic Buddhist Institute's land to a nearby NagaWorld hotel and casino. Anti-riot police was present, but no clashes occurred.

On 30 September 2014, more than 20 monks from Siem Reap protested in Phnom Penh in support of two fellow monks who had been defrocked and jailed after accusations that they were using drugs, drinking alcohol and having sex with women. The protesters claim the persecuted duo are victims of plot to remove them from the Po Lanka Pagoda in the province.

On 30 September 2014, about 200 villagers from Kampong Speu province protested outside ANZ Royal Bank in Phnom Penh. The group called for the public to stop using its services following unanswered calls for compensation over alleged land grabbing by ruling party Senator Ly Yong Phat, who financed his agro-concessions with loans from the bank.

On 29 September 2014, one Cambodian soldier was shot three times and a Thai soldier was reportedly injured in a brief exchange of gunfire on the Cambodian Thai border in the vicinity of Preah Vihear temple, near the An Ses border crossing (Choam Khsant district, Preah Vihear Province). Top military commanders in the area had gone to visit the area to determine the cause of the incident, but the situation at the border was normal.

assoc_actor_1: Former CPK: Communist Party of Kampuchea
notes: On 29 September 2014, a group of former Khmer Rouge soldiers from Banteay Meanchey's Malai district left their temporary base at a local pagoda and marched to the Council of Ministers in Phnom Penh over a land dispute.

On 29 September 2014, nearly one hundred people from three provinces (Battambang, Pailin and Preah Sihanouk) gathered at Freedom Park in Phnom Penh to demand that the government help them solve their land disputes.

On 26 September 2014, about 200 human rights activists, youths and Buddhist monks gathered in front of the Australian Embassy in Phnom Penh to protest against an Aussie plan to send asylum seekers to Cambodia. Hundreds of security forces have been deployed to safeguard the Embassy but no violence has occurred.

On 18 September 2014, villagers displaced by a development project at Phnom Penh's Boeung Kak Lake marched to the World Bank offices to demand the organization to reconsider a potential loan of $25 million for the development of land concessions. Forty families say that they had not received compensation or a 'just resolution' in their dispute.

On 17 September 2014, about 500 workers joined a brief rally at a garment factory in an industrial park in Phnom Penh to urge international buyers, including GAP, Levi's, H&M, Puma and ZARA to lift their basic wage to $177 a month.

On 15 September 2014, an environmental group blocked a road in the Areng Valley to prevent security forces from entering the area. Nine activists were briefly detained. The group is opposed to the construction of the planned Stung Cheay Areng hydropower dam in the valley.

On 15 September 2014, about 200 ethnic Phnong villagers gathered in Mondulkiri province's Busra commune to protest against several companies that hold economic land concessions in the area. The villagers accused the Kau Su Dak Lak Company and French-owned rubber giant Socfin of digging channels that blocked roads used by them.

On 11 September 2014, 78 Kroeung minority villagers climbed up a mountain to a community forest to challenge CRD Company. They claim the company is illegally felling their trees, in Ratanakkiri's O'Chum district.

On 11 September 2014, about 100 community leaders, representatives of nongovernmental organization (NGO), youths and monks staged a protest on boats calling on neighboring Laos to halt the construction of the controversial Don Sahong dam on the Mekong River. They claim the dam project would destroy fisheries central to the food security of millions of people and harm endangered dolphins.

On 6 September 2014, security guards allegedly working for a private company opened fire on ethnic Phnong villagers in Mondulkiri province's Pech Chreada district, injuring three people. The villagers were taking a break from hunting animals in a community forest when three men, dressed in army fatigues and armed with AK-47 rifles, appeared and shoot at them. The villagers were about 1,000 metres away from a rubber company's land.

From 01 to 04 September 2014, more than 100 tuk-tuk drivers protested outside Aeon Mall in Phnom Penh. The drivers protests for having no access to customers, as the union Confederation Development Association (CCDA) has exclusive rights to operate in the mall. The protest ended when they agreed to join the union.

From 01 to 04 September 2014, more than 100 tuk-tuk drivers protested outside Aeon Mall in Phnom Penh. The drivers protests for having no access to customers, as the union Confederation Development Association (CCDA) has exclusive rights to operate in the mall. The protest ended when they agreed to join the union.

From 01 to 04 September 2014, more than 100 tuk-tuk drivers protested outside Aeon Mall in Phnom Penh. The drivers protests for having no access to customers, as the union Confederation Development Association (CCDA) has exclusive rights to operate in the mall. The protest ended when they agreed to join the union.

On 01 September 2014, about 50 villagers gathered outside the Asian Development Bank, in Phnom Penh. The villagers, who live near railway lines, demanded more detailed information about what will happen to them during forthcoming phases of a bank-funded railway rehabilitation project.

On 01 September 2014, nearly 400 workers marched from their garment factory in Por Sen Chey district to Phnom Penh's Ministry of Labour, where they demanded the government intervene in their dispute. The workers, from Xi Fang garment factory, had several demands, including the readmission of three fired union workers.

From 01 to 04 September 2014, more than 100 tuk-tuk drivers protested outside Aeon Mall in Phnom Penh. The drivers protests for having no access to customers, as the union Confederation Development Association (CCDA) has exclusive rights to operate in the mall. The protest ended when they agreed to join the union.

On 01 September 2014, about 30 people protested outside the Chbar Ampov district police station, in Phnom Penh, to call for the release of a young man. The man was attacked with blades by a Vietnamese gang, and arrested together with seven offenders. The attack stoked anti-Vietnamese sentiment among the protesters.

On 01 September 2014, about 100 villagers burned tyres in protest to an operation that seized 10 unlicensed sand-dredging barges, in Phnom Penh's Chbar Ampov district. The seizure of vessels set off fears that the dredging could cause riverbank collapses.

On 28 August 2014, more than 100 monks protests at Sansam Kosal pagoda in Meanchey district in Phnom Penh, after a Khmer Krom monk was called to a meeting with district religious authorities. They feared the monk, who took part in recent nationalist protests outside the Vietnamese Embassy, was going to be defrocked for his political activities.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 27 August 2014, about 100 activists from the Boeung Kak, Borei Keila and Lorpeang communities were forcefully dispersed during a march to the National Assembly, in Phnom Penh. The protesters threw eggs at the Singapore Embassy, as they had been calling on the embassy to intervene in a deal involving Singaporean firm HLH Group buying land at the controversial site from the Boeung Kak lake developer.

On 27 August 2014, workers from Xi Fang garment factory, in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh, burned tyres in front of the factory while picketing. The workers had several demands, including the readmission of three fired union workers.
On 26 August 2014, more than 80 supporters of four representatives of villagers displaced by a special economic zone in Koh Kong province protested outside the provincial court.

On 26 August 2014, about 300 villagers from Banteay Meanchey, Battambang and Pailin gathered in Phnom Penh with the intention of submitting petitions directly to the premier, demanding the resolution of their land disputes. The police directed the protesters away from Hun Sen's house, guiding them to a pagoda in Russey Keo district.
On 26 August 2014, about 30 people gathered outside the Asian Development Bank's office in Phnom Penh, demanding answers about a railway project which will cause evictions.

On 25 August 2014, about 60 protesters from three provinces (Battambang, Pailin, Banteay Meanchey) were prevented from marching to the National Assembly in Phnom Penh by authorities. The villagers, who are staying at the Samaki Rainsey pagoda, intended to submit petitions calling for action on their land disputes.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 25 August 2014, in Phnom Penh, more than 70 villagers marched to the Ministry of Justice and the National Assembly with about 100 activists from Boeung Kak, Thmor Kol and Borei Keila, to hand a petition. The villagers are involved in a long-running dispute with the KDC company in Kampong Chhnang province.

On 25 August 2014, 17 former bus drivers for the Phnom Penh Sorya Transportation Company and 50 people from three workers union demonstrated at the factory's headquarters. When the drivers tried to block buses from leaving, company security staff roughly dispersed them and a clash occurred. At least one security guard was seriously injured.

On 19 August 2014, hundreds of workers at Jiun Ye Garment factory in Samaki Meanchey district, Kampong Chhnang province blocked National Road 5 for about four hours. There was a minor fight with security forces, but no one was injured. The workers demanded better working conditions.
On 18 August 2014, workers at Jiun Ye Garment factory in Samaki Meanchey district, Kampong Chhnang province blocked National Road 5 to protest. The workers demanded better working conditions.

On 18 August 2014, hundreds of You Li International garment employees blocked National Road 1 in front of the factory, in Bavet, Svay Rieng province, while negotiations were taking place inside. The director of the Svay Rieng branch of the Collective Union of Movement of Workers (CUMW) was arrested.

On 18 August 2014, a group of about 300 villagers from Kratie province were beaten by a mix of security forces and police with batons, shields and electric batons, when they were heading toward PM Hun Sen's house to protest. At least 10 people were injured, including a 4-year-old child. The villagers, from Kratie's Snuol district, are embroiled in a land dispute with a South Korean agribusiness.

On 17 August 2014, about 30 environmentalists, some of whom were dressed as animals, did a bicycle ride in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh. About 100 security officers were deployed to stop them, but there was no report of violence. The young activists, from NGO Mother Nature, protested against the planned Stung Cheay Areng hydropower dam.

On 16 August 2014, about 300 Cambodian workers and garment merchants blocked the Aranyaprathet Paoy Paet border checkpoint, by parking their two wheel carts in front of the Paoy Paet side of the Thai-Cambodian friendship bridge. They demanded the release of a group of Cambodian workers and vendors who were earlier arrested by Thai customs officials.

On 14 August 2014, more than 200 Kampong Speu villagers protested outside ANZ Royal bank offices in Phnom Penh, demanding compensation for alleged land grabbing perpetuated by sugar tycoon Ly Yong Phat, who financed his agro-concessions with loans from the bank.

On 14 August 2014, a few hundred workers from Xin Chang Xin garment factory in Russey Keo district, Phnom Penh, marched to the Ministry of Labour to claim money they say is owed to them by the company.
On 14 August 2014, a group of Boueng Kak lake evictees protested outside the National Assembly in Phnom Penh to ask for further restitution from City Hall and private developer Shukaku Inc.

assoc_actor_1: Buddhist Group (Cambodia); Khmer Krom Ethnic Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 13 August 2014, hundreds of monks and other representatives from Khmer Krom ethnic minority held a protest in fron of the Vietnamese Embassy, in Phnom Penh. They were calling on Phnom Penh to demand an apology from Hanoi for statements claiming historic ownership over disputed territory. They started marching from the Freedom Park to the Embassy.

On 13 August 2014, villagers from Ta Ches commune's Lorpeang village (Kampong Chhnang) marching in protest in Phnom Penh were confronted by security guards and district police and prevented from reaching the National Assembly. The villagers are involved in a land dispute with KDC International company. No clash occurred and there was no violence.

On 12 August 2014, nearly 100 villagers from Ta Ches commune's Lorpeang village (Kampong Chhnang) marching in protest to Phnom Penh were attacked by more than 100 police and military police, in the beginning of their journey. At least one man was seriously injured, and many were arrested. The villagers are involved in a land dispute with KDC International company.

On 12 August 2014, a few hundred people and union representatives gathered at Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh, for International Youth Day. The demonstrators later marched to the National Assembly bearing petitions voicing youth concerns on a number of issues. District security guards were in the area but no violence occurred.

assoc_actor_1: Buddhist Group (Cambodia); Khmer Krom Ethnic Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 12 August 2014, hundreds of monks and other representatives from Khmer Krom ethnic minority held a protest in fron of the Vietnamese Embassy, in Phnom Penh, where they burned a Vietnamese flag in front of the Embassy. They demanded an apology from Hanoi for statements claiming historic ownership over disputed territory.

On 11 August 2014, about 400 villagers in Preah Vihear province protested outside the office of FP Malaysia Plantation Company, which they say is attempting to take their land. Not clear the location of the protest.
On 11 August 2014, former bus drivers protested for eight hours outside Phnom Penh Sorya Transportation Company in the capital's Daun Penh district before agreeing to sit for negotiations.

assoc_actor_1: Buddhist Group (Cambodia); Khmer Krom Ethnic Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 11 August 2014, about 500 ethnic minority Khmer Krom monks and activists staged a protest to demand a Vietnamese diplomat to recognize the history of former Kampuchea Krom provinces. Protesters gathered at the Freedom Park in Phnom Penh before marching through streets to deliver a petition to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and embassies of ASEAN countries. In June, the diplomat said that the former provinces belonged to Vietnam long before France's official transfer of the land in 1949.

On 06 August 2014, about 80 villagers from Lor-peang village (Kampong Chhnang province) continued to camp outside the Provincial Court to demand the release of two people jailed over their role in a long-running land dispute with the politically connected KDC Company.

On 05 August 2014, about 70 residents of Lor-peang village (Kampong Chhnang province) descended on the provincial court to demand the release of two people jailed over their role in a long-running land dispute with the politically connected KDC Company.

On 05 August 2014, workers from Vantage River Textile factory in Mittapheap district, Preah Sihanouk, marched on the local labour department after three days of protests against the sacking of seven employees.
From 02 to 04 August 2014, workers from Vantage River Textile factory in Mittapheap district , Preah Sihanouk/Sihanoukville, protested against the sacking of seven employees.
From 02 to 04 August 2014, workers from Vantage River Textile factory in Mittapheap district , Preah Sihanouk/Sihanoukville, protested against the sacking of seven employees.
From 02 to 04 August 2014, workers from Vantage River Textile factory in Mittapheap district , Preah Sihanouk/Sihanoukville, protested against the sacking of seven employees.

On 01 August 2014, more than 200 Kampong Speu villagers protested outside ANZ Royal bank offices in Phnom Penh, demanding compensation for alleged land grabbing perpetuated by sugar tycoon Ly Yong Phat, who financed his agro-concessions with loans from the bank.
On 31 July 2014, three people were severely hurt when a tractor in Svay Chek district in Banteay Meanchey ran over a buried anti-tank mine in a former battlefield.

On 30 July 2014, about 150 ethnic Kuoy villagers protested outside Preah Vihear Provincial Court (Tbaeng Mean Chey city, capital of the province). They protested the questioning of eight villagers and an NGO staff member for allegedly inciting villagers in Tbeng Meanchey district to destroy 36 tonnes of sugarcane.

On 29 July 2014, about 100 protesters demonstrated outside the Cambodian Asian Labor Alliance Organization (CALAO) in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh. The Cambodians hoped to migrate to Japan to work in the electronics industry, but claimed they were duped by slick radio advertising and false promises by the organization's staff.

On 28 July 2014, guards used stun guns and batons in a confrontation with land-rights protesters outside the Monivong Boulevard offices in Phnom Penh. Two women, both from the Borei Keila community, were left unconscious from the beating.

On 27 July 2014, a Royal Cambodian Armed Forces soldier shot a 19-year-old farmer dead in Srayorn commune, Kulen district (Preah Vihear province) during a disagreement over a neighbour's apparent land dispute.

On 26 July 2014, a soldier shot and killed a civilian during a scuffle that began after the soldier accused a group of villagers of planting crops on his commanders land in Kuleaen district (Kuleaen, PV).

Between the days 17-24 July 2014, clashes broke out between striking garment workers and employees who are against the industrial action at Tae Young factory in Kandal province. Five people were mildly injured.

On 23 July 2014, employees from Phnom Penh's Sun Well Shoes marched to Por Sen Chey district hall, with a list of seven demands, including the firing of a manager and $15 per month for accommodation and transportation. They had been protesting in front of the factory for nearly 10 days.

A military police officer beat up a man and threatened to kill him after a minor collision with his motorbike, in Phnom Penh. The officer was arrested on the 23 July, but the victim withdrew his complaint after the officer offered him $1,000 in compensation.

On 22 July 2014, Kampuchea Krom activists continued to protest in from of the Vietnamese Embassy in Phnom Penh, to demand apologies from the embassy's spokesman, who defended that former Kampuchea Krom provinces belonged to Vietnam. The protest ended after authorities accepted a petition from the demonstrators.

From 14 to 22 July 2014, employees from Phnom Penh's Sun Well Shoes protested in front of the factory. They demanded for several benefits and better working conditions, including the firing of a manager and $15 per month for accommodation and transportation.

On 21 July 2014, about 500 garment workers from Teng Xun factory in Kampong Speu protested outside, demanding better working conditions. The protest started after their bosses had complained that they spend too much of their working day talking on the phone and listening to music.

From 14 to 22 July 2014, employees from Phnom Penh's Sun Well Shoes protested in front of the factory. They demanded for several benefits and better working conditions, including the firing of a manager and $15 per month for accommodation and transportation.

On 21 July 2014, hundreds of protesters from Ethnic Khmer Krom minority marched through streets in Phnom Penh to deliver a petition to foreign embassies. They protested against a declaration made by a spokesman for the Vietnamese Embassy, which defended that former Kampuchea Krom provinces belonged to Vietnam long before France's official transfer of the land in 1949.

From 14 to 22 July 2014, employees from Phnom Penh's Sun Well Shoes protested in front of the factory. They demanded for several benefits and better working conditions, including the firing of a manager and $15 per month for accommodation and transportation.

On 19 July 2014, an estimated crowd of more than 10,000 supporters marched with Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP) head Sam Rainsy through Phnom Penh to the opposition headquarters. They protested against the arrest of eight CNRP politicians after a violent riot on 16 July.

From 14 to 22 July 2014, employees from Phnom Penh's Sun Well Shoes protested in front of the factory. They demanded for several benefits and better working conditions, including the firing of a manager and $15 per month for accommodation and transportation.

On 16 July 2014, workers from Ocean Garment factory blocked Russian Boulevard in Phnom Penh. Workers protested the factory's refusal to abide by an Arbitration Council decision in their favour. The blockade ended after Ministry of Labour officials told the workers they would mediate a discussion between the groups.

From 14 to 22 July 2014, employees from Phnom Penh's Sun Well Shoes protested in front of the factory. They demanded for several benefits and better working conditions, including the firing of a manager and $15 per month for accommodation and transportation.

On 15 July 2014, an old unexploded ordnance (UXO) blew up leaving at least eight people seriously injured, in Pursat's Veal Veng district. The device, found by a child, exploded when children where playing with at home.

On 15 July 2014, around 300 opposition activists protested outside Phnom Penh's Freedom Park, to demand the reopening of the country's main protest venue. The activists clashed with security guards, by fighting with sticks and stones, leaving at least 30 people injured. The police fired tear gas to disperse the rioters. Three CNRP politicians, including prominent MP-elect Mu Sochua, were arrested.

From 14 to 22 July 2014, employees from Phnom Penh's Sun Well Shoes protested in front of the factory. They demanded for several benefits and better working conditions, including the firing of a manager and $15 per month for accommodation and transportation.
