On 12 and 13 July 2014, more than 200 residents of Lorpeang village (Kampong Chhnang) demonstrated against KDC International by casting a curse on the politically connected to the development company and burning several effigies.

On 12 and 13 July 2014, more than 200 residents of Lorpeang village (Kampong Chhnang) demonstrated against KDC International by casting a curse on the politically connected to the development company and burning several effigies.
On 12 July 2014, an anti-tank mine from the civil war exploded, injuring an agricultural worker in Kdol Tahen commune (Bavel, Battambang).

On 10 July 2014, more than 1,000 workers held a protest in front of Ocean Garment factory in the capital, burning tyres and blocking the road. They demonstrated against the management's refusal to abide by a ruling that workers should be paid in full for a one-month closure.

assoc_actor_1: Buddhist Group (Cambodia); Khmer Krom Ethnic Group (Cambodia); Students (Cambodia)
notes: On 08 July 2014, about 100 Cambodian students and monks from Khmer Krom ethnic minority clashed briefly with police Tuesday while protesting remarks made by a Vietnamese embassy official on the issue of Cambodian land lost to Hanoi. Police used batons to disperse the protesters, who responded by hurling stones.

source: Phnom Penh Post; States News Service (United States)
notes: On 07 July 2014, there were violent clashes between villagers and armed representatives of a company owned by the wife of Minister of Mines and Energy Suy Sem, in Lor Peang village in Kampong Chhnang province. A group of villagers used machetes and sticks to protect their leaders from being arrested by about 200 policemen. At least one person was beaten unconscious and more than a dozen were injured.

On 07 July 2014, 30 grade 12 students from Kampong Thom travelled to Phnom Penh to protest outside the Ministry of Education. They blame their teacher of favouritism and an inherently unequal system for preventing them from sitting the national exam and graduating.

On 06 July 2014, about 100 villagers protested in the capital's Por Sen Chey district, after workers fenced off more than 3 hectares of the land they claim in Kouk Rokar commune. They allege two powerful families are trying to push them off their land

On 30 June 2014, security guards working for a firm building a resort in Botum Sakor district (Koh Kong province) beat a woman who was trying to farm the land. The woman had been evicted from her land the past year to make way for a Union Development Group (UDG) project.

On 29 June 2014, clashes broke out between a group of CNRP activists and about 100 CPP supporters near Romduol district in Svay Rieng province. The CNRP group was trying to reach a disputed section of the Cambodia-Vietnam border, when the other group, with some men wielding sticks, blocked their way and a fight started. No serious injuries occurred.

On 28 June 2014, about 400 garment workers blocked access to Canadia Industrial Park in Phnom Penh to demand full severance pay. The workers lost their jobs when their factory, Hongkong Yufeng suddenly closed on June 9. Their protest was headed by worker unions like Workers Friendship Union Federation (WFUF).

On 28 June 2014, supporters of high-profile activist Tep Vanny clashed with supporters of rival activist Heng Mom in Phnom Penh. The groups disagree over the construction of a new military police station planned for the Boeung Kak neighbourhood. Activists threw rocks at each other, leaving some people injured.

From 17 to 26 June 2014, workers at Harta Packaging Industries blocked gates at the factory, in Por Sen Chey district in Phnom Penh. On 21 June, the blockade led to the factory's shutdown, preventing shipments. Former workers had been protesting since February 2014 over unpaid seniority bonuses.

On 26 June 2014, hundreds of villagers from Battambang, Banteay Meanchey and Preah Sihanouk provinces joined evictees from the capital to protest in front of the Asian Development Bank's office in Phnom Penh. The demonstrators were evicted from their homes as a result of the ADB-funded $143 million restoration of the country's railway system, and complained about their treatment and relocation.

From 17 to 26 June 2014, workers at Harta Packaging Industries blocked gates at the factory, in Por Sen Chey district in Phnom Penh. On 21 June, the blockade led to the factory's shutdown, preventing shipments. Former workers had been protesting since February 2014 over unpaid seniority bonuses.

On 19 June 2014, more than 300 workers from a garment factory in Phnom Penh's Russey Keo district marched to the Ministry of Labour. The workers, representing about 800 workers from Wincam Corporation who began striking 10 days earlier, demanded government intervention as they seek for better working conditions.
On 19 June 2014, about 200 workers who have been on strike since January burned tyres outside Harta Packaging factory in the capital's Por Sen Chey district.

Displacement: Between June 1 and June 18, thousands of Cambodian laborer's returned from Thailand across the different checkpoints, mainly the border town of Paoy Paet in Banteay Meanchey. The mass return of workers has been driven largely by Thailand's military, which had instructed private companies not to accept illegal immigrants after leading a coup in 22 May.

From 17 to 26 June 2014, workers at Harta Packaging Industries blocked gates at the factory, in Por Sen Chey district in Phnom Penh. On 21 June, the blockade led to the factory's shutdown, preventing shipments. Former workers had been protesting since February 2014 over unpaid seniority bonuses.

From 17 to 26 June 2014, workers at Harta Packaging Industries blocked gates at the factory, in Por Sen Chey district in Phnom Penh. On 21 June, the blockade led to the factory's shutdown, preventing shipments. Former workers had been protesting since February 2014 over unpaid seniority bonuses.

On 17 June 2014, more than 20 villagers went to Phnom Penh to seek Prime Minister Hun Sen's intervention against Vietnamese agribusiness concessionaire Dotisaigon-Benhwoeuk (SBK), which they accuse of encroaching on their land. The villagers represented nearly 200 ethnic Phnong families in Kratie province's Chet Borey district.

On 12 June 2014, hundreds of employees from Ocean Garment factory gathered in front of Phnom Penh International Airport. They planned to march to PM Hun Sen's home to demand intervention in their dispute, but were blocked by police. On May 24, the factory announced it would suspended operations for one month.

On 10 June 2014, workers at Ocean Garment factory, in Phnom Penh, broke a thumb-scanner machine as they became increasingly frustrated with the uncertainty of their jobs and feared the company will close. On May 24, the factory announced it would suspended operations for one month. Workers began a strike to demand the payment of their full salaries during the period.

On 09 June 2014, about 800 workers in the industrial park on Veng Sreng Boulevard in Phnom Penh stood outside T&K Garment factory in protest. Union representatives left negotiations and continued a strike that began two weeks before, as workers claimed that they were promised a 2,000 riel daily.

On 03 June 2014, more than 1,000 garment workers tried to march from their Por Sen Chey district factory to the Ministry of Labour, in Phnom Penh. The Ocean Garment factory suspended the workers without informing them in advance. The demonstrators were blocked by the police, but no violence was reported.

On 02 June 2014, fifty-seven families blocked a company's bulldozers from clearing the land and prevented employees from building a fence around the plot, in Kampong Chhnang's Kampong Tralach district. The villagers had been involved in a decadelong land row with KDC International, owned by the wife of Minister of Mines and Energy.

On 29 May 2014, nearly 100 villagers and monks marched in Phnom Penh to protest the demolition of a Buddhist institute's main gate and portions of a surrounding wall to facilitate power supply to a nearby casino. The demonstrators were blocked on the road by riot police armed with batons and shields, but no violence was reported.

On 26 May 2014, about 200 demonstrators, representatives of more than 400 evicted families, marched in Phnom Penh to demand for the return of their lands. More than 200 homes and over 2,000 hectares of crops were destroyed earlier in May by Vietnamese rubber firm Bin Pheurk, in an eviction process.

On 23 May 2014, a war-left mortar round exploded, killing an old woman and seriously injuring five others in Kampong Svay (Kampong Thom province). A man was hitting a mortar shell with a hammer to remove saleable scrap-metal, when the device exploded.

On 20 May 2014, about 200 protesters gathered outside the Phnom Penh Municipal Court to demand the release of 23 labor activists and garment workers, who were detained during violent protests in January. Rioters hurled stones at security forces in a provocative act, however, security forces did not fight back. Two security forces were injured on head and hand.

On 19 May 2014, more than 100 vendors from Prey Veng Market gathered in front of Provincial Hall in Prey Veng town to protest what they consider unreasonable demands placed on them by the market's private administrators earlier May.

Property destruction: In the month of May 2014, villagers homes were burned down during an eviction drive by the Vietnamese rubber firm Bin Pheurk, in Kratie's Snuol district, to make land for the Vietnamese rubber firm Bin Pheurk. Villagers claim more than 200 homes and over 2,000 hectares of crops were destroyed.

Displacement: Approximately 2,000 Chinese business people and tourists have crossed the Vietnamese border into Cambodia to escape anti-China riots in Vietnam. Location not mentioned, location coded as main border crossing point, Paoy Paet city.

On 14 May 2014, more than 100 Caltex staff from 18 petrol stations in Phnom Penh gathered at the Bok Kou station in Chamkarmon district to demonstrate. The workers demand a raise and an annual bonus, and they plan to submit a petition to the US Embassy.

On 13 May 2014, a military officer attempted to stab a forest activist in Sandan district's Mean Rith commune (Sandan, Kampong Thom province). The activist had previously filled complaints against 15 officials, including the aggressor, for involvement in illegal logging. Not possible to find geolocation of commune, district is coded as location.

On 12 May 2014, hundreds of Cambodian staff of U.S.-owned petroleum Caltex protested in Phnom Penh petrol stations as attendants and assistants held banners. The workers were demanding a raise and an annual bonus.

On 10 May 2014, two Cambodian deminers were killed when an old anti-tank mine from the civil war they were trying to remove from the ground exploded, in Samlot commune (Battambang). The two deminers were employees of the British demining charity Halo Trust.

On 09 May 2014, dozens of supporters protested outside Cambodia's Supreme Court in Phnom Penh, as the court upheld a decision to deny bail to 21 people arrested during a deadly garment worker strike crackdown in January.

On 9 May 2014, a group of gangsters allegedly threatened the life of a human rights worker in Tuol Kork district in Phnom Penh, as the activist was taking video footage for a documentary on the land dispute in the area. The men were carrying axes, hammers and knives, and said they worked for the landowner. One of them pushed the activist off the area and another another swung an axe near the worker's head.

On 05 May 2014, thousands of workers took to the streets to block National Highway No. 3, in Wingstar Shoes Co. Ltd in Moha Ruessei Commune (Kampong Speu province). They had been on strike since April, for transportation and food allowances.

On 05 May 2014, hundreds of CNRP supporters rallied through the streets of Phnom Penh, with a motorcade seting off from the CNRP headquarters in Meanchey district and leading supporters around the city.

On 04 May 2014, thousands of CNRP supporters marched in Kampong Cham province, in support of the party in the upcoming council elections. A large number of military police blocked them from entering market areas.

On 04 May 2014, about 500 people with tuk-tuks and motorbikes gathered at the Cambodia National Rescue Party headquarters in Phnom Penh before taking to their vehicles, from which they blasted the party's anthem and shouted slogans over megaphones across the city. Only a handful of police were seen on the streets.

assoc_actor_1: Buddhist Group (Cambodia); CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Journalists (Cambodia)
notes: On 02 May 2014, police security forces chased and beat protesters near Phnom Penh's Freedom Park, after demonstrators taunted the officials. About 200 Cambodia National Rescue Party supporters had showed up for a planned local government campaign rally. At least five people were injured, including an opposition supporter, a Buddhist monk and a local journalist.
On 02 May 2014, soldiers used force to end a strike at a garment factory on Veng Sreng Boulevard, in Phnom Penh. Workers demanded a lunch bonus and an end to forced overtime.
On 2 May 2014, Daun Penh district security guards chased and beat a VOD journalist for reporting on a council election event at Freedom Park in Phnom Penh city (PM, PP).

assoc_actor_1: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 01 May 2014, security forces beat demonstrators after an International Labour Day rally was held outside Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh. Nearly 1000 factory workers and supporters of the opposition Cambodia National Rescue Party had gathered on the streets. At least five people were hurt by security forces.
On 01 May 2014, about 500 workers gathered the National Assembly Palace in Phnom Penh to demonstrate on International Labour Day. There was no report of violence

On 28 April 2014, striking workers, including garment workers, allegedly broke factory and car windows in Tai Seng Special Economic Zone, in Bavet city. Some factories closed, with security guards posted in front of factory gates to block workers from entering. Union movements estimate that about 30.000 workers are on strike in Bavet city.

assoc_actor_2: Aid Workers (International); UN: United Nations; Women (International)
notes: 'A UN contractor was killed outside her home when she confronted her attacker, a man who was trying to steal her bicycle.'

On 27 April 2014, some 500 residents of Prey Lounh village in Bati district (Takeo) beat and stoned a man to death based on the belief that he was a sorcerer responsible for the unexplained demise of nine community members since 2012.

On 26 April 2014, a group of 600 angry villagers with wooden sticks and stones gathered at the residence of a man accused of witchcraft in Kampong Speu, Cambodia. The man was stoned and beaten to death.

On 23 April 2014, about 80 villagers protested outside Banteay Meanchey Provincial Hall (Sisophon city, also called Serei Saophoan), to demand the release of two former Khmer Rouge soldiers allegedly arrested for illegally occupying land in Malai district.

On 22 April 2014, 700 garment workers at Unity Fashion factory (Tumnob Thum commune) walked off the job and demonstrated outside the factory after managers said they would dock wages of workers who did not show up on April 17 (after Khmer New Year), in Kandal Province.

On 22 April 2014, about 700 monks and residents gathered in protest outside the unfinished Wat Kohbodhivong in Phnom Penh's Sen Sok district. They claim a deputy district governor and a land tycoon are attempting to seize land deemed sacred.

On 19, 20 and 21 April 2014, workers, including garment workers, from three factories held public protests outside their factories in Tai Seng Special Economic Zone, in Svay Rieng Province. The workers are demanding a $50 financial compensation and calling on factories to rehire 43 workers they say have been fired since a nationwide strike in January.

assoc_actor_2: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Journalists (Cambodia); Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 21 April 2014, at Least 10 people were injured when about 30 district security guards attacked a peaceful crowd of journalists, NGO workers and supporters of opposition lawmaker-elect Mu Sochua after she ran into the middle of Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh.

On 19, 20 and 21 April 2014, workers, including garment workers, from three factories held public protests outside their factories in Tai Seng Special Economic Zone, in Svay Rieng Province. The workers are demanding a $50 financial compensation and calling on factories to rehire 43 workers they say have been fired since a nationwide strike in January.

On 19, 20 and 21 April 2014, workers, including garment workers, from three factories held public protests outside their factories in Tai Seng Special Economic Zone, in Svay Rieng Province. The workers are demanding a $50 financial compensation and calling on factories to rehire 43 workers they say have been fired since a nationwide strike in January.

On 18 April 2014, more than 400 vendors protested against orders to move to new market sites, in Sisophon (Banteay Meanchey - the city is also called Serei Saophoan). The police arrested three people.

On 18 April 2014, about 100 students protested in front of the University of Health Sciences on Phnom Penh's Monivong Boulevard, waving banners with slogans denouncing the lack of transparency and fairness in administrating national exams and calling for them to be cancelled.

On 17 April 2014, police clashed with CNRP supporters who attended a remembrance ceremony in Phnom Penh to mark the day the Khmer Rouge seized the capital in 1975. The deputy governor of Phnom Penh's Dangkor district, who was leading the police forces, was slightly injured.

During a Khmer New Year (14-16 April 2014) party, a commune police chief shot his gun towards the sky to break up a fight and make the villagers afraid, in Samlei commune, Svay Rieng. No one was injured. The villagers lodged an official complaint against the police chief.
On 11 April 2014, a reporter was allegedly beaten in custody while covering illegal logging in Pursat province. Capital of the province coded as location.

On 10 April 2014, Sorn Mongkul, a journalist with the Kampuchea Thmey newspaper, was severely beaten by deputy national military police commander Lay Sopheap and Kong Thearith, an assistant to Preah Vihear provincial military police. The journalist was covering illegal logging in Preah Vihear.

On 08 April 2014, more than 200 workers at a company connected to Thai firm K Cement downed tools and protested in front of the factory in Kampot town. They demanded major pay increases and for fired unionists to be reinstated.

On 04 April 2014, 100 activists stood outside the Phnom Penh Municipal Court to support the release of two activists detained in connection with a deadly crackdown by security forces during a garment worker strike in January. The activists were denied bail by the court. Security personnel guarded the protest but no violence occurred.

On 01 April 2014, about 50 locals gathered outside Pailin's provincial police station to call for the release of three detained villagers who had protested against a forced eviction. A village representative was arrested after making a speech to the demonstrators.

On 31 March 2014, villagers from the Areng Valley took part in a motorbike rally alongside monks and activists to protest the planned construction of the controversial Stung Cheay Areng dam, in Koh Kong.

On 31 March 2014, police beat a group of several hundred anti-government demonstrators who were demanding a license for an opposition television channel, in Phnom Penh. At least two people were injured.

On 29 and 30 March 2014, four hundred activists made their way along the Mekong River by longboat through Kratie province's Sambor district and Stung Treng province's Thala Barivat district near the Cambodian-Lao border in protest of the planned Laos's Don Sahong dam.

On 29 and 30 March 2014, four hundred activists made their way along the Mekong River by longboat through Kratie province's Sambor district and Stung Treng province's Thala Barivat district near the Cambodian-Lao border in protest of the planned Laos's Don Sahong dam.

On 30 March 2014, opposition leader Sam Rainsy led hundreds of supporters in a march through the capital and a meeting at his party's headquarters (CNRP) in Phnom Penh. He decided to abandon a plan to stage a protest at Freedom Park, as the are was surrounded by riot-police armed with batons and shields.

On 29 and 30 March 2014, four hundred activists made their way along the Mekong River by longboat through Kratie province's Sambor district and Stung Treng province's Thala Barivat district near the Cambodian-Lao border in protest of the planned Laos's Don Sahong dam.

On 29 and 30 March 2014, four hundred activists made their way along the Mekong River by longboat through Kratie province's Sambor district and Stung Treng province's Thala Barivat district near the Cambodian-Lao border in protest of the planned Laos's Don Sahong dam.
On 29 March 2014, a 12-year-old boy was killed and another seriously injured when a rusty 60mm artillery shell he was playing with exploded, in Salakrov district (Pailin).

On 28 March 2014, a man died and another was injured when a 1970s anti-tank mine exploded when two men drove a mini-tractor over the explosive, which lay just 20cm to 30cm beneath a new road in Battambang's Rattanak Mondul district.

On 26 March 2014, two children and a woman were seriously injured when they stepped on a landmine in Svay Chek district, near a border patrol station in Banteay Meanchey. The woman lost her leg and the children were seriously injured.

On 22 March 2014, a bus with activists from Boeung Kak, Borei Keila and Thmor Kol communities was shot by an unknown man in a motorycle, near the Daun Penh Referral Hospital, close to the Chhroy Changva Bridge, in Phnom Penh.

On 17 March 2014, an unidentified group set fire to a house in Phnom Penh's Tuol Kork district, by pouring petrol around the house. The family is involved in a land dispute with a private company, Khun Sear Import Export, and claims that the company is behind the attack.

On 15 and 16 March 2014, about 150 ethnic minority Chorng villagers worked in rotating shifts to block a road that was to be used to transport heavy machinery onto their lands to start construction of the highly controversial Stung Cheay Areng dam, in Areng Valley in Thma Baing district (Koh Kong).

On 15 and 16 March 2014, about 150 ethnic minority Chorng villagers worked in rotating shifts to block a road that was to be used to transport heavy machinery onto their lands to start construction of the highly controversial Stung Cheay Areng dam, in Areng Valley in Thma Baing district (Koh Kong).

On 11 March 2014, villagers in Thmorda commune, Veal Veng district (Pursat) claimed that security forces and environmental officers opened fire and tried to burn down their houses and plantations, after accusing them of living on state land. The villagers are involved in an ongoing land dispute with local tycoon Try Pheap's MDS Import Export Co Ltd.

On 11 March 2014, 50 supporters from the Borei Keila community rallied outside Phnom Penh's Municipal Court. They were gathered to support seven people from community allegedly injured by baton-wielding security forces in February, who filed a lawsuit against Prampi Makara district authorities.
On 10 March 2014, some 200 ethnic Kuoy minority villagers in Preah Vihear's Chheb district blocked tractors belonging to a Chinese company from bulldozing their rice crops.

On 08 March 2014, about 500 people gathered around Freedom Park in Phnom Penh to discuss the minimum wage and the continued detention of 21 activists and garment workers arrested at January demonstrations. Security guards kept barricades around the park, but there were no reports of violence.

On 04 March 2014, about 100 taxi drivers protested in front of the Kampot Provincial Hall in Kampong Bay, claiming the private company running the province-owned parking lot for 'tourist' vehicles was charging as much as twice the advertised price.

On 03 March 2014, around 100 villagers clashed with several hundred security and anti-riot police who prevented them from marching to the Supreme Court, in Phnom Penh. They demanded that the Supreme Court reconsider allowing bail for 21 garment workers and human rights activists arrested. At least two villagers were injured.

On 25 February 2014, about 300 doctors, nurses and other staff from Phnom Penh Municipal Referral Hospital and the neighbouring Prampi Makara district health centre protested after authorities said they were relocating them to a smaller building at the back of the premises.

On 21 February 2014, a girl and a boy were killed by a mortar round, left from the war time, in Bavel district, Battambang province. The victims scratched the ground near their village and found the shell, then they used rock to smash it, triggering the explosion.

On 18 February 2014, a mob beat to death a Vietnamese-Cambodian man in Phnom Penh. Nguyen Yaing Ngoc, was chased and attacked by a group of Cambodians after he responded to a call for help from a neighbor whose motorbike had been struck by a car. Witnesses said the crowd was incited to beat him by shouts of derogatory terms for Vietnamese people.

On 15 February 2014, authorities (Prampi Makara district security forces) violently evicted Borei Keila community activists from an unfinished building they had occupied in Phnom Penh. At least seven people were severely injured.
On 15 February 2014, in Phnom Penh, a group of men beat and killed a Vietnamese national after he was involved in a minor traffic accident and an onlooker shouted anti-Vietnamese slurs.

On 11 February 2014, about 200 supporters stood outside the Appeal Court in Phnom Penh, in support of those arrested at demonstrations supporting a nationwide garment worker strike in January. The judge denied bail to 21 detainees arrested.

On 11 February 2014, 64 Preah Sihanouk veterans gathered in front of the Department of Social Affairs, Veterans and Youth Rehabilitation to demand the payment of 10 to 12 months' worth of pension. They received their pensions a day after the protest.

On 10 February 2014, dozens of protesters outside the Ministry of Justice and the Appeals Court in Phnom Penh called for the release of the 23 activists and workers arrested in January, as a prison official said several of the detainees were on hunger strike.

On 05 and 06 February 2014, more than 100 villagers from Botum Sakor and Kiri Sakor districts (Koh Kong province) have been protesting outside the offices of Tianjin Union Development after firm representatives, backed by soldiers, began burning and tearing down their houses.

On 05 and 06 February 2014, more than 100 villagers from Botum Sakor and Kiri Sakor districts (Koh Kong province) have been protesting outside the offices of Tianjin Union Development after firm representatives, backed by soldiers, began burning and tearing down their houses in the previous week.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 03 February 2014, more than 100 land rights activists of communities in Boeung Kak, Borei Keila, Thmor Kol and other areas gathered in Phnom Penh to protest against comments made by Cambodia's representative to the UN Human Rights Council Mak Sambath. The UN representative said that many people displaced by land disputes were falsely trying to claim recompense.

On 31 January 2014, a Cambodian journalist was beaten to death by a group of 10 fishers after he had reported on illegal fishing methods, in Cholkiri district (Kamponh Chhnang). Two of his relatives who tried to help him were also beaten and taken to hospital.

On 30 January 2014, three children died in Kampong Leng district (Kampong Chhnang province) when an unexploded rocket they found and handled blew up. The area is the site of a former Vietnamese barracks.

Property destruction: End of January/beginning of February, local authorities, soldiers and Tianjin Union Development company representatives demolished 42 homes in Ta Noun commune and two houses in Koh Sdech commune, to make way for large-scale ecotourism development.

On 28 January 2014, more than 2,000 garment workers at a Vattanac II Industrial Park (Phnom Penh) protested in front of the complex, threatening to block National Road 3 and demanding the reinstatement of 11 union officials and the firing of the manager who allegedly dismissed them. Workers started a strike on 25 January.

On 27 January 2014, security forces fired smoke bombs and used batons to disperse protesters in Phnom Penh. Around 200 protesters were in front of the Ministry of Information against the ministry's rejection of the opposition-aligned Beehive radio station request for a relay and a TV station. At least seven protesters were injured.

On 26 January 2014, more than 1,000 ruling party (Cambodian People's Party) supporters gathered to protest against a planned public meeting at the CNRP's Kampong Cham headquarters, Kampong Cham. Only a few hundred CNRP supporters had managed to gather at the party office.

assoc_actor_1: Buddhist Group (Cambodia); CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Farmers (Cambodia); Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 26 January 2014, about two hundred textile workers, union members, land protesters and several monks did a rally at Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh. A brief clash broke out and security forces used batons against the protesters, who in turn responded by throwing rocks, water bottles and sticks. At least 10 people were injured.

On 23 January 2014, more than 200 activists and monks submitted petitions to foreign embassies in the capital Phnom Penh. They were calling for pressure on Prime Minister Hun Sen's government to release 23 protesters held following the violent government crackdown in the beginning of January.

On 22 January 2014, more than 100 unionists and workers marched, many holding lotus flowers, to a park where a statue of Chea Vichea stands, in Phnom Penh. The day marked the 10th anniversary of the death of Vichea, a prominent labour leader was gunned down in 2004 in broad daylight.

On 21 January 2014, a rally was being held by activists when police came and temporarily detained 11 activists, in Phnom Penh. The activists were marching to the US Embassy to deliver a petition calling for the release of 23 people jailed in the beginning of January.

On 19 January 2014, about 50 security officers, armed with batons, dispersed a small group of around 10 people as they tried to hold prayers in the capital Phnom Penh for the release of people arrested during riots.

On 14 January 2014, a few thousand people rallied outside the Phnom Penh Municipal Court to show their support for opposition leaders (CNRP). They were being questioned in connection of recents protests against the PM, but no charges were brought against them.

Defusal: on 13 January, 27 pieces of unexploded ordinance, believed to be from Lon Nol-era, were found near Sla village, in Voasar commune (Kampong Speu, Samrong Tong). Demining experts and district military police dug out and detonated the war remnants on the spot.

On 13 January 2014, about 200 Boeung Kak villagers gathered unhindered by security forces at the UN Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights in Phnom Penh to deliver a petition to Surya Subedi, UM Special rapporteur to Cambodia.
On 09 January 2014, a small gathering of nine youth activists calling for new elections and justice were dispersed by security officials at Freedom Park, Phnom Penh.

On 06 January 2014, 200 villagers in Takeo's Angkor Borei district protested outside the district hall to demand lower prices of electricity and water be lowered. The villagers are from Angkor Borei and Prek Phtorl communes,

On 06 January 2014, five Boeung Kak lake activists protested outside the French Embassy in Phnom Penh to petition the release of fellow activists taken into custody the previous week. They were arrested by police officers, following a new ban on public demonstrations in the capital.

On 04 and 05 January 2014, Cambodian police removed about 1,000 anti-government protesters, including garment workers, from an industrial park in Phnom Penh. The authorities pulled down temporary speaker platforms, overturned food stalls and pushed people away from the park. Workers had been protesting since December 2013 for higher wages.

On 04 and 05 January 2014, Cambodian police removed about 1,000 anti-government protesters, including garment workers, from an industrial park in Phnom Penh. The authorities pulled down temporary speaker platforms, overturned food stalls and pushed people away from the park. Workers had been protesting since December 2013 for higher wages.

On 03 January 2014, an ethnic Kuoy group protested outside the district police station of Tbeng Meanchey (Preah Vihear) for the release of four monks and three NGO workers, arrested on 02 January during a protest.

assoc_actor_1: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 03 January 2014, garment workers clashed with police officers in Phnom Penh, when several hundred workers blocking a road began burning tires and throwing objects at police officers. Officers fired AK-47 rifles into the air and that others shot at ground level, leaving at least four people killed and several wounded. Human rights groups are claiming five were killed.

On 02 January 2014, ethnic Kouy villagers held a protest against an alleged land grab by three plantation companies (Chinese firms Lan Feng and Roy Feng and a local company, Ly Heng) in Preah Vihear's Tbeng Meanchey district. Four monks and three NGO workers were arrested by about 40 armed police and military officers detained them as they left the protest site.

assoc_actor_1: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 02 January 2014, clashes broke out between garment workers and a special military unit near the Yak Jin factory in the Por Senchey district in Phnom Penh, when a small number of people started throwing stones at the factory and at the security forces. The officers were seen brandishing metal pipes, knives, AK47 rifles, slingshots and batons. Activists said about a dozen people were believed to have been arrested including five monks, while several people were injured.

assoc_actor_1: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 01 January 2014, protests continue to be held daily in Phnom Penh to demand higher wages. Thousands were gathering since December 2013 to protest against PM Hun Sen's government. Garment workers and the opposition CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party were involved in the daily rallies.

On 31 December 2013, thousands of workers, including garment workers, from some 300 different factories flocked to the Ministry of Labor Building in Phnom Penh, as the Ministry announced it would raise minimum wages to U.$ 100 per month, against the initial proposal of US$ 95. The demonstrators shouted for Ith Samheng, Minister of Labour, to come out and speak to them.

On 30 December 2013, protesters gathered outside the Labor building, in Phnom Penh, to demonstrate against the government wage increase for garment workers and footwear workers. Officials announced the wage would increase to US$ 95, though unions had called for the wages to be doubled to US$ 160.

assoc_actor_1: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 29 December 2013, protesters continued to gather at Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh. Striking garment workers and CNRP supporters demanded the government to double the minimum wage and called on PM Hun Sen to resign.

On 29 December 2013, more than 300 monks and civilians protested in Phnom Penh. The groups demands included the resignation of Ministry of Cults and Religion chief Min Khin, prompted by the theft of artefacts from a stupa at Oudong Mountain earlier in December.

On 29 December 2013, hundreds of tuk-tuk, motorbike and taxi drivers protested outside the Ministry of Economy and Finance, in Phnom Penh. They called on the government to limit fuel prices at 4.000 riel ($1) per litre, against the current 5.000 riel price.

assoc_actor_1: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 28 December 2013, protesters continued to gather at Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh. Striking garment workers and CNRP supporters demanded the government to double the minimum wage and called on PM Hun Sen to resign.

assoc_actor_1: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 27 December 2013, thousands of workers, including garment workers, joined daily anti-government demonstrations organized by the CNRP at Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh. They demanded the government to double the minimum wage and called on PM Hun Sen to resign.

On 27 December 2013, garment and footwear striking workers clashed with police and blocked a key highway in the Special Economic Zone, in Phnom Penh. The workers threw stones at the police officers, who in turn beat the rioters using electric batons, shields and guns. Seven workers and seven military police officers were injured.

assoc_actor_1: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 26 December 2013, striking garment workers joined opposition CNRP supporters at Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh, in the 12th consecutive day of mass demonstrations at the capital. The groups called for the resignation of Prime Minister Hun Sen and a re-election.

On 26 December 2013, Boeung Kak villagers continued their protest by blocking Monivong Boulevard in Phnom Penh. The group demanded additional compensation for 2008 agreements with the municipality for their land dispute. They ended their blockade in the morning with promises to protest again the following week.

assoc_actor_1: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 25 December 2013, thousands of striking workers protested at the Manhattan Special Economic Zone in Bavet, Svay Rieng province. They were joined by Sam Rainsy, president of the opposition Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP). The group protested against the low wage increase for 2014.

assoc_actor_1: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 25 December 2013, around 3.000 garment workers and CNRP supporters marched through streets in Kampong Cham province. The group protested against the low wage increase for 2014.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Buddhist Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 25 December 2013, Boeung Kak villagers entered their third day of protests, blocking Monivong Boulevard in Phnom Penh. The group, which demands additional compensation for 2008 agreements with the municipality for their land dispute, is backed by the Independent Monks Network.

assoc_actor_1: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 25 December 2013, an estimated 3.000 garment workers from various factories demonstrated at Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh, to protest against the low wage increase for 2014. They joined the CNRP protest, which demanded a new election following contested polls in July.

On 24 December 2013, about 5.000 garment workers in the Manhattan Special Economic Zone, in Bavet, Svay Rieng province, demonstrated to back their call for a much higher minimum wage. The Labor Advisory Council had decided to raise the minimum wage from the current US$ 80 to US$ 95 for full-time workers and US$ 90 for temporary workers, when the suggested amount by unions was US$ 160.

On 24 December 2013, about 3.000 workers from Medtecs Cambodia Co Ltd in Kampong Cham held protests, setting road blocks in the province. The workers protested against the Labor Advisory Council decision to raise the minimum wage from the current US$ 80 to US$ 95 for full-time workers and US$ 90 for temporary workers, when the suggested amount by unions was US$ 160.

On 24 December 2013, at least 500 workers from the Pak Sun Knitting Factory surrounded the Ministry of Labor building in Phnom Penh, to protest. The workers protested against the Labor Advisory Council decision to raise the minimum wage from the current US$ 80 to US$ 95 for full-time workers and US$ 90 for temporary workers, when the suggested amount by unions was US$ 160.
On 24 December 2013, the CNRP entered its 10th day of protests, with thousands protesting in Phnom Penh. The opposition party supporters called for new elections, after contested polls held in July.

On 24 December 2013, the police and security personnel (security guards hired by the Daun Penh district) beat up a monk and two civilians outside City in Hall in Phnom Penh, during a second day of protests involving families evicted from the capital's Boeung Kak lake area in 2008. Two other people were also injured.
On 23 December 2013, the CNRP entered its 9th day of protests, with thousands protesting in Phnom Penh. The opposition party supporters called for new elections, after contested polls held in July.

On 23 December 2013, about 100 former Boeung Kak residents and supporters shut Monivong Boulevard to traffic for hours as they burned tyres, in Phnom Penh. The group was demanding additional compensation for 2008 agreements with the municipality for their land dispute.

On 22 December 2013, about 20.000 protesters spent about four hours walking through streets in Phnom Penh. The group was led by CNRP opposition leader Sam Rainsy, to call for new elections after contested polls in July.

On 21 December 2013, Cambodian and Thai troops engaged in a 20-minute fire fight, with one Thai soldier sustaining an injury, in Koh Kong. The clash occurred after a group of patrolling Thai soldiers strayed into Cambodian territory, then opened fire after refusing to withdraw. Location coded: only commune in Koh Kong that borders Thailand.
On 21 December 2013, CNRP demonstrations entered the 7th day, with leader Sam Rainsy making a speech to about 5.000 supporters at Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh, after he led them to march on streets.
On 20 December 2013, CNRP demonstrations entered the 6th day, with thousands protesting in Phnom Penh. The opposition party supporters called for new elections, after contested polls held in July.

On 19 December 2013, protesters led by CNRP leader Sam Rainsy marched along National Highway No. 5 north of Phnom Penh, going back into the city to Freedom Park, where the party chief delivered a speech to the crowd. This was the fifth day of a series of demonstrations, calling for new elections, after contested polls held in July.

On 18 December 2013, CNRP leaders Sam Rainsy and Kem Sokha led a few thousand of their supporters in a parade around Phnom Penh in tuk-tuks and motorbikes. The opposition party had been protesting the past days for new elections, after contested polls held in July.
On 17 December 2013, hundreds of demonstrators and monks gathered near the Cambodian Royal Palace in Phnom Penh, demanding an investigation into the alleged theft of rare Buddha relics.

On 17 December 2013, about 3.000 supporters of the opposition CNRP protested at Freedom Park in Phnom Penh for the third day to call for new elections. Afterwards, CNRP leader Sam Rainsy and protesters traveled by cars and motorcycles through streets in the city.

On 16 December 2013, garment workers from three factories in Svay Rieng province protested to increase the minimum wage, and about 100 workers entered other factories to urge other workers to join their protests. Factories affected included those in the Manhattan Special Economic Zone, in Bavet.

On 16 December 2013, around 4000 supporters of the opposition CNRP protested at Freedom Park in Phnom Penh for the second day. Afterwards, CNRP leader Sam Rainsy and about 2000 protesters traveled by motorcycle through streets in the city. Security forces were deployed, but there was no report of incidents during the protest march.
On 15 December 2013, an estimated 10000 protesters, massed in Freedom Park in Phnom Penh. The protest, staged by opposition party CNRP, demanded a new election after contested polls held in July.

On 11 December 2013, a group of about 50 protesters were blocked by police from delivering to the Japanese embassy a petition in Phnom Penh. The group later delivered petitions to the US and French Embassies, encouraging signatories to the 1991 Paris Peace Agreement to uphold its principles.

On 10 December 2013, about 300 people, with CNRP flags gathered in front of the US embassy in Phnom Penh at night, demanding justice and freedom. After a few hours, most of the crowd dispersed, but police and district security guards forcefully removed the remaining 11 people that refused to leave.

On 10 December 2013, to mark International Human Rights Day, about 1000 monks and their supporters, who spent days marching to the capital, marched to the National Assembly in Phnom Penh, calling for an end to rights abuses.

On 10 December 2013, a group of individuals began verbally taunting riot police before throwing rocks and lit Molotov cocktails toward them in Wat Phnom roundabout in Phnom Penh. About 200 armed riot police officers dispersed the crowd, but were unable to find the individuals responsible for the riot.

On 10 December 2013, to mark International Human Rights Day, about 5.000 opposition CNRP supporters demonstrated at Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh. During the protest, a man was beaten by a small group of demonstrators, who accused him of being an undercover policeman. He suffered minor injuries.
On 10 December 2013, to mark International Human Rights Day, more than 15000 people gathered at Angkor Gyeongju area, in Siem Reap. The crowd heard a speech by CNRP leader Sam Rainsy.

On 06 December 2013, more than 500 students and teachers from two high schools protested outside O'Ambel High School in Serei Saophoan city. They demanded better safety around schools after a truck crashed into a rice mill near one of the schools, injuring a man.
On 06 December 2013, more than 200 people protested in front of You Can Win International School in Chamkarmon district, Phnom Penh. The local NGO was involved with a scam operation.

On 27 November 2013, about 300 villagers gathered in front of Romdoh commune hall (in Preah Vihear's Rovieng district) to protest against a mining company drilling on their land. They claimed that authorities and company representatives had failed to meet them the day before as promised, to negotiate their land dispute.

On 23 November 2013, a mob of monks and villagers blocked Route 6A for hours in Phnom Penh as they burned excavator and pipes. The group started to protest to stop construction workers from tearing down a crematorium, across the street from a pagoda. The municipality had planned to tear down the crematorium to make way for a private excavation project, but after the protest the project was cancelled.

On 22 November 2013, hundreds of people gathered near the Supreme Court, in Phnom Penh, to show support for the rights activist Yorm Bopha. The Court freed Bopha and ordered her retrial. Bopha is from the Boeung Kak lake community, which is involved in a long-running land dispute with a company.

On 19 November 2013, two people were seriously injured and five others slightly injured when unexploded ordnance (UXO) detonated in Trapaing Prey commune, Anlong Veng district, Oddar Meanchey province. The group of seven, workers in a rice field, had been enjoying lunch together when a man stepped on the landmine.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Thma Koul Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 19 November 2013, more than 200 villagers from Boueng Kak, Borei Keila and Thmor Korl communities gathered in front of the Supreme Court in Phnom Penh. The group demanded the release of jailed rights campaigner Yorm Bopha, ahead of her final appeal against a criminal conviction. The communities are all involved in land disputes.

On 15 November 2013, more than 200 people held a protest outside You Can Win International School in Chamkarmon district, in Phnom Penh. The protesters were scammed out of money through an overseas employment grift, and demanded their money back.

On 12 November 2013, police fired live ammunition into a crowd of about 600 rioting garment workers in Stung Meanchey district, Phnom Penh, killing one woman and leaving at least six other people injured. The strikers threw rocks and bricks at police, who fired water cannons into the crowd in response, and later started shooting. The striking workers, from SL Garment Processing (Cambodia) Ltd., attempted to march from the factory to Prime Minister Hun Sen's house, where they planned to hold a demonstration.

On 04 November 2013, demonstrations continued in front of SL Garment Processing Ltd., in Phnom Penh. Striking workers had been protesting several times to demand the company to cut ties with a shareholder who ordered a military police presence in the factory.

On 31 October and 01 November 2013, about 10 striking workers were injured during demonstrations when uniformed and plain-clothes factory employees pelted the crowd of about 1.500 workers with projectiles at SL Garment Processing Ltd. in Phnom Penh. SL management claimed the strikers pushed through the factory's gates and began hurling rocks at security guards and employees working.

On 31 October and 01 November 2013, about 10 striking workers were injured during demonstrations, when uniformed and plain-clothes factory employees pelted the crowd of about 1.500 workers with projectiles, at SL Garment Processing Ltd., in Phnom Penh. SL management claimed the strikers pushed through the factory's gates and began hurling rocks at security guards and employees working.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 30 October 2013, about 200 villagers, from five communities, including Borei Keila and Boeung Kak, protested outside the City Hall in Phnom Penh (Phnom Penh) to demand a resolution to their long-running land disputes. The police and Daun Penh district security guards used violence to disperse the protesters. At least three villagers were injured.

On 28 October 2013, between 400 and 500 villagers in Tbeng II commune's Kdak village (Preav Vihear's Kulen district) used a palm tree to block provincial officials attempting to confiscate tonnes of luxury timber from their village.

On 27 October 2013, two Cambodian soldiers sustained injuries after accidentally setting off a buried anti-personnel mine in Chheu Krom village near a military camp, in Pailin. The soldiers were clearing the grass in a cassava plantation.

On 25 October 2013, opposition CNRP ended their three-day protest over the July disputed elections, in Freedom Park, Phnom Penh. The protesters marched to embassies in order to submit petitions. Security forces were deployed, but no clash or violence occurred.

On 24 October 2013, a clash occurred between security guards and striking garment workers who blocked the road in front of the SL Garment Processing Ltd. Factory, in Phnom Penh. Security Guards fired projectiles from a slingshot, and some strikers workers retaliated by throwing rocks and bottles back. About 10 people were injured.

On 24 October 2013, opposition CNRP continued for the second day their three-day protest over the July disputed elections, in Freedom Park, Phnom Penh. The protesters marched to the embassies of the United States, the United Kingdom, and France in order to submit petitions. Security forces were deployed around the protest site and along streets in the city, but no clash or violence occurred.

On 23 October 2013, opposition CNRP started a three-day protest over the July disputed elections in Freedom Park, Phnom Penh. The demonstration gathered about 10000 people, who marched to the United Nations human rights office, where they deliver a petition calling on the UN and foreign powers to intervene. Thousands of riot police were deployed but no clash or violence occurred.

On 22 October 2013, nearly 400 workers at the USA Fully Field Garment factory blocked National Road 2 in Phnom Penh's Meanchey district, after fears spread that the factory was winding down operations and the workers would not be paid their salaries by the management.

On 21 October 2013, more than 150 families from Andong Teuk commune (Koh Kong's Botum Sakor district) protested demanding compensation from agro-industrial giant Sinimexim Investment Co Ltd for bulldozing their plantation land. They were confronted and dispersed by authorities. No violence occurred.

On 21 October 2013, anti-riot police cleared Freedom Park in Phnom Penh of hundreds of protesters who had gathered to air grievances against the government. Police moved in carrying weapons and electric batons, but soon about 500 protesters reassembled nearby. No violence occurred.

On 21 October 2013, about 10 SL Garment Processing Ltd. strikers were injured when police cracked down on a demonstration in front of Prime Minister Hun Sen's house, in Phnom Penh. The workers had been protesting several times to demand the company to cut ties with a shareholder who ordered a military police presence in the factory.

On 17 October 2013, a group of about 250 people, many from the Borei Kela community, were violently suppresed by police armed with batons. The group was marching to City Hall and blocked Monivong Boulevard to protest against land evictions. At least three women were left unconscious.

On 13 October 2013, an undercover police officer was beaten unconscious by demonstrators during a protest in Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh. The crowd was suspicious of the man wearing journalist credentials and civilians clothes but holding a gun; they then stripped off his clothes and beat him. The demonstration marked World Teacher's Day and was attended by about 200 teachers and union members, who demanded a salary increase.

actor2: Military Forces of Thailand (2011-2014) Thai Rangers
notes: On 10 October 2013, naval officials from the Royal Cambodian Navy allegedly opened fire on patrolling Thai rangers on the Tatai river in Koh Kong's Smach Meanchey district. The rangers tried to seize an allegedly illegal shipment of rosewood which the naval officials were shipping to Vietnam or Thailand. After a six-hour standoff between the rangers and naval officials, the rangers managed to confiscate 12 tonnes of rosewood. No one was arrested.

On 10 October 2013, approximately 200 police officer armed with riot shields and batons suppressed a demonstration of about 300 monks and community representatives in Phnom Penh. The protesters were marching to mark World Habitat Day and protest against land evictions. Some demonstrators suffered minor injuries.

On 06 October 2013, the CNRP staged another mass protest in Phnon Penh, with the presence of about 10.000 people. The demonstration was part of a push to demand an independent probe to investigate alleged cheating during the national elections in July.
On 3 October 2013, a Kampong Cham police official allegedly opened fire on, chased and beat a teen in Memot district following a traffic dispute. The officer was arrested.

On 1 October 2013, a mob of 500 villagers beat a man to death in Prey Chor district's Thmor Poun commune, Kampong Cham province. The man allegedly slaughtered his wife and stepdaughter with a pair of scythes, and reportedly taunted the villagers with his wife's cut hand.

On 27 September 2013, about 4000 workers gathered at SL Garment Factory, and marched towards the Prime Minister's house in Sihanouk Boulevard, Phnom Penh. The group was stopped by about 1000 military police and seven fire trucks. But a small group eventually was able to deliver a petition detailing the workers' 11 demands to members of the prime minister's cabinet.
On 24 September 2013, hundreds of workers from SL Garment Processing Ltd gathered at one of the factory's two Meanchey district locations, in Phnom Penh.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 24 September 2013, Boeung Kak and Borei Keila community members pulled back razor-wire road barrier in Daun Penh. The protesters managed to lodge complaints with district authorities in connection with a violent police crackdown on 22 September at Wat Phnom pagoda. 50 national police officials arrived on the scene, but no violence occurred.

On 24 September 2013, about 150 workers from Chhin Chin garment factory briefly blocked National Road 4 in front of the factory, in Phnom Penh's Por Sen Chey district. The workers ended the protest after the management agreed to meet their demands.

On 23 September 2013, protesters gathered at Wat Phnom pagoda in Phnom Penh to demonstrate against the violent police crackdown on garment factory protesters the day before. The crowd became angry and chased an undercover police officer. He managed to escape uninjured.

On 22 September 2013, dozens of police dressed in civilian clothes descended on a peaceful vigil at Wat Phnom pagoda in Phnom Penh. The police beat the 20 demonstrators with slingshots, batons and electric prods, leaving at least six people injured, including journalists and right workers.

On 21 September 2013, military police fired rounds inside a garment factory, and severely beat one man, at SL Garment Processing, in Phnom Penh. Some 2000 striking workers were blocking a road or demonstrating inside the factory when the police clashed with the workers. At least ten workers were injured.

On 20 September 2013, police armed with shields and riot gear dispersed some eight monks and 30 other demonstrators from the main pagoda in Phnom Penh, Wat Phnom. The demonstrators were supporting Prince Sisowatch Thomico, the King's cousin, in his hunger strike. Some of the monks were injured.

On 19 September 2013, police in Phnom Penh blocked about 200 monks from marching to the Royal Palace in protest. The monks intended to call on the King to convene parliament only after the political deadlock caused by the national election results is resolved.

On 17 September 2013, Nhem Panha, 19, was found floating in a fishing net in Ponhea Leu district's Kampong Os commune, Kandal. The young man was a strong supporter of CNRP and he was previously involved in a scuffle with ruling party activists during the election campaign. Rights groups believe the murder was politically motivated, however no suspect was arrested.

On 17 September 2013, about 10000 CNRP supporters protested gathered in Phnom Penh, as part of a three-day mass demonstration. They protested against the results of the 28 July election that gave victory to Prime Minister Hun Sen's ruling party.

On 16 September 2013, about 8000 CNRP supporters protested in Phnom Penh, in the second day of a planned three-day rally. They protested against the results of the 28 July election that gave victory to Prime Minister Hun Sen's ruling party.

On 15 September 2013, one demonstrator was shot dead and several were wounded after a clash with security forces in Phnom Penh. An estimated 20.000 CNRP supporters began a mass demonstration expected to last for three days, by marching to Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh. They protested against the results of the 28 July election that gave victory to Prime Minister Hun Sen's ruling party. Security forces fired smoke grenades, tear gas and water cannon at rock-throwing protesters.

Defusal: On 13 September, a makeshift bomb was discovered near the Parliament, in Phnom Penh, and three M79 grenades were also found close to Freedom Park. The discovery of the bombs add to tensions in the capital, ahead of planned protests over Prime Minister Hun Sen's disputed election win. The devices were exploded by bomb experts.

On 7 September 2013, at least 20000 opposition supporters protested at the Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh. The group protested against the results of the 28 July election in which the Prime Minister Hun Sen's ruling party won a majority of vote. Security officer were placed around the area, but there were no reports of violence.

On 05 September 2013, around 4000 garment workers marched from the SL Garment Processing factory, to Phnom Penh's City Hall to urge the government to intervene in their dispute. The workers protested after the factory fired hundreds of their colleagues for striking over their working conditions.

On 05 September 2013, more than one hundred employees of the Apsara Authority protested outside the department's Slakram commune offices in Siem Reap city. They demanded compensation for the additional travel costs they will incur because their offices are to be relocated to the outskirts of Siem Reap city.

On 04 September 2013, villagers from Bakeo and O'Chum districts in Ratanak Kiri province briefly blocked a national road, after detaining three rubber plantation workers, to call for intervention in their long-standing land dispute with Chinese company for Swift Rubber Limited.

On 04 September 2013, police and security guards blocked protesters as they tried to leave the capital's Boeung Kak area to march to the Supreme Court, in Phnom Penh. The protesters planned to march to mark the first anniversary of the arrest and imprisonment of Boeung Kak land-rights activist Yorm Bopha. No violence occurred.
Around 4 September 2013, nearly 40 people, predominantly women and girls, gathered outside the Council of Ministers in Phnom Penh to sing and dance for peace.

On 01 September 2013, the CNRP held a rehearsal protest in Freedom Park, Phnom Penh, with several thousands supporters. The political party staged the rehearsal ahead of a planned mass protest against election results.
On 27 August 2013, a group of wood traders beat a journalist in Santre commune, Pursat. The journalist and another colleague had confronted the men trafficking wood by cart.

On 27 August 2013, approximately 4000 striking garment workers protested in front of the Ministry of Social Affairs to demand a resolution to their dispute. The day before, SL Garment Processing posted a notice saying some 6000 striking workers were fired unless they returned to work.

On 26 August 2013, the CNRP held a 20000 people protest rally In Phnom Penh. The opposition party demanded the government to set up an independent probe on widespread irregularities in recently-held national elections.

On 26 August 2013, a group of 10 union members were attacked by unidentified armed men carrying stones, sticks and cleavers, after the workers delivered pro-union leaflets in Phnom Penh's Por Sen Chey district, in front of Dayup Global Co Ltd.

On 22 August 2013, police officers, some of them armed with batons and shields, clashed with villagers and a CNRP lawmaker at a public election forum at a private home in Battambang town. About 50 officers blocked villagers from accessing the forum. Two people suffered minor injuries.

On 20 August 2013, three journalists from Kratie province allegedly beat with a wooden stick and a brick a Snuol district police officer they believed was transporting luxury timber. The journalists were detained by provincial police.

A landmine blast tore both legs from a 19-year-old man as he searched for bamboo shoots in wooded area in Pailin province's Sala Krao district. No date mentioned for the event, coded date of the news article.

On 18 August 2013, a robber was badly beaten by a mob after unsuccessfully trying to rob a jewelry seller at a Preah Sihanouk market. Police intervened to prevent the man from being killed. The man and another suspect were arrested by authorities.

On 14 August 2013, a bomb exploded at the Cambodian People's Party headquarters in Kampong Speu province's Kang Pisey district, damaging a CPP signboard, a wall and some parts of the headquarters itself, but resulting in no injuries.

On 14 August 2013, a landmine killed six people and injured one man after the group ran over it riding in a homemade tractor in Preah Vihear's Choam Ksan district. The area is a former Khmer Rouge territory.

On 14 August 2013, about 400 people, including monks and local NGO activists, staged a peace march in Phnom Penh to call for a calm resolution to an election impasse as the opposition challenged the official preliminary results of the disputed national polls.

On 14 August 2013, about 500 striking workers from SL Garment Processing (Cambodia) blocked another 3500 from entering the factory, in Phnom Penh. The workers demand the company to cut ties with a shareholder who ordered a military police presence there.

On 12 August 2013, CNRP activist was shot in the back of the head at his Treng Trayoeng commune grocery shop in Kampong Speu province's Phnom Srouch district. Three men were arrested, including the mastermind of the crime, who confessed the killing due to a land dispute, not to political reasons.

On 12 August 2013, striking workers at SL Garment Processing (Cambodia) protested at the factory, in Phnom Penh. The workers demand the company to cut ties with a shareholder who ordered a military police presence there.

Movement of forces: on 09 August, Cambodia military forces deployed armoured personnel carriers and soldiers to Phnom Penh, to prevent any violence if mass demonstrations following disputed polls go ahead.

On 7 August 2013, a bomb exploded at the rear gate of the Phnom Penh Municipal Court, blackening the walls and leaving a small patch of broken pavement but resulting in no injuries. No suspects were identified.

On 05 August 2013, more than 60 villagers from Kampong Cham province's Stung Trang district staged a protest at Areaks Tnot commune hall. They demanded answers for a massive price hike that has accompanied the installation of electricity meters ahead of a planned switchover to state-provided power.
On 03 August 2013, more than 4000 workers protested outside Chinese-owned Juhui Footwear Co in Kampong Cham province, after rejecting an offer to end their strike.

On 03 August 2013, about 100 residents of Koh Prak village in Kien Svay district's Phoum Thom commune (Kandal) protested against the unidentified company's placement of three pipes in the river. They accuse the company of illegally pumping sand out of Koh Prak River, and fear erosion. After the protest, pumping stopped.
On 31 July 2013, two children and a man were killed when their buffalo cart hit an anti-tank mine left over from the country's civil war, in Oddar Meanchey. Capital of the province coded as location.

On 28 July 2013, rioters in Sa'ang Phnom commune (Kandal province's Sa'ang district) blocked unfamiliar voters from casting their ballot at a polling station. The villagers claimed they wanted to make sure the elections would be fair. Days later, the police investigated the rioters, claiming they were the newcomers, not the ones being blocked from voting.

On 28 July 2013, about 100 villagers protesting against voting irregularities were stopped by authorities, in Kanh Chriech district's Kdoeung Reay commune, Prey Veng. The villagers protested against people they considered outsiders, or Vietnamese voters, coming to vote in their commune. No violence occurred.

On 28 July 2013, during national election day, residents detained a polling station director inside a pagoda in Phnom Penh's Stung Meanchey district, over allegations that names were left off the voter list. Rioters threw rocks at civilians and two military police vehicles were set on fire. Some 100 riot police were sent to stop the demonstration.

On 24 July 2013, about 2500 garment workers protested outside Asia Dragon (Garment) Co Ltd in Bati district, Takeo, as the factory negotiated several workers conditions with the mediation of the Coalition of Cambodian Apparel Workers' Democratic Union (C.CAWDU).

On 23 July 2013, a group of ruling (CPP) and opposition party (CNRP) supporters clashed in Phnom Penh's Meanchey district, leaving a CNRP activist injured. Hundreds of youth were involved in the clash, and the groups allegedly threw rocks at each other. It took police and military police nearly an hour to break up the fight.

On 17 July 2013, three farmers suffered mild to serious injuries when a B40 rocket they dug up exploded, when they were picking rubber tree plants on a plantation, in Tbong Khmum district's Veal Vong village, Kampong Cham. Unable to find district or village. Location coded: capital of the province.
On 15 July 2013, a clash occurred between CNRP and CPP supporters in Ponhea Leu district's Kampong Os commune, Kandal, which left a CPP supporter with a head injury. A CNRP activist was arrested.

On 9 July 2013, villagers affected by land grabs demonstrated at Pursat Provincial Court Pursat (Pursat). They showed their support to Koch Veng, a land activist who frequently protests against the Pheapimex Company, and is currently facing charges of fraud. Due to the protest, the verdict hearing of Veng was delayed.

On 07 July 2013, about 400 villagers affected by land grabs demonstrated at Pursat Provincial Court in Pursat (Pursat). They showed their support to Koch Veng, a land activist who frequently protests against the Pheapimex Company, and is currently facing charges of fraud.

On 5 July 2013, election campaigners of the opposition Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP) clashed with residents of a luxary villa who are military officers and supporters of the ruling CPP. Thones were thrown and shots fired, no casualties reported.

On 02 July 2013, Boeung Kak lake protesters blocked Monivong Boulevard in Phnom Penh, and later marched to Prime Minister Hun Sen's house, to demand authorities to resolve their land disputes before the National Election on July 28. They were prevented from continuing the march by CPP supporters and the police. No violence occurred.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 01 July 2013, protesters from Boeung Kak and Borei Keila communities blocked parts of Monivong Boulevard in Phnom Penh, demanding authorities to resolve their land disputes before the National Election on July 28. The group clashed with police, and one pregnant woman allegedly miscarried after being kicked in the stomach.

On 01 July 2013, about 400 garment workers gathered outside the Ministry of Social Affairs in Phnom. The workers, from the Pine Great (Cambodia) factory in Phnom Penh's Meanchey district, called for government intervention against the factory owner who fled without paying them overdue wages.

On 01 July 2013, 44 condom packers workers protested outside the office of health NGO Population Services Khmer (PSK) in Phnom Penh. The workers, out of work since their contracts ended the day before, demanded unpaid seniority bonuses.
On 30 June 2013, a suspected burglar was beaten unconscious by villagers, for allegedly breaking into the house of a Chinese garment factory employee, in Choam Chao commune, in Phnom Penh.

assoc_actor_1: Buddhist Group (Cambodia); Khmer Krom Ethnic Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 25 June 2013, more than 100 monks and other demonstrators protested against in Freedom Park, Phnom Penh. They protested against the Vietnam government's continued incarceration of two monks for their alleged affiliation with Kampuchea Krom organisations.

On 25 June 2013, NagaWorld security guards violently beat striking workers protesting in front of the casino, in Phnom Penh. One worker was hospitalised, and two others were knocked unconscious during the brief clash. The workers were protesting after more than 400 employees allegedly involved in a strike were fired.

On 24 June 2013, a reporter from Cheat Sachak newspaper from Ratanakkiri province was allegedly beaten by a group of illegal loggers to stop him from reporting on their activities, near Stung Treng's Sesan district. The reporter later filed a complaint to provincial military police and rights group Adhoc.

On 20 June 2013, about 200 protesters clamoured in front of Ang Snuol district's Poeuk commune chief's office, in Kandal province, demanding the state take control of providing their electricity. The villagers claimed the private company contracted to provide electricity to the region about 10 years ago charges far more than state prices.

On 20 June 2013, two men were beaten - one nearly to death - by a mob in Phnom Penh's Por Sen Chey district. The men allegedly attempted to steal a motorcycle from another man, and a mob soon gathered when the man started to call for help.

On 19 June 2013, villagers continued demonstrating outside Koh Kong Provincial Hall to demand a solution for their land disputes. The families are affected either by Chinese firm Tianjin Union Development Group's tourism development in Botum Sakor and Kiri Sakor districts or Heng Huy Agriculture Company's concession in Sre Ambel district.

On 19 June 2013, about 3000 garment factory workers blocked National Highway 2 in Phnom Penh. The workers, from MandV International Manufacturing factory, supported demands for better salaries and working conditions, as Prime Minister Hun Sen cautioned about job losses if manufacturers quit the country over wage demands.

On 18 June 2013, villagers continued demonstrating outside Koh Kong Provincial Hall to demand a solution for their land disputes. The families are affected either by Chinese firm Tianjin Union Development Group's tourism development in Botum Sakor and Kiri Sakor districts or Heng Huy Agriculture Company's concession in Sre Ambel district.

On 18 June 2013, hundreds of NagaWorld casino workers protested over wage demands in Phnom Penh. Armed police and security guards broke up the peaceful protest of mostly young women, briefly detaining 19 workers and their union leaders.

On 18 June 2013, about 30 villagers from Boeung Kak community, including approximately a dozen children, descended on the palace in Phnom Penh. They intended to submit a petition to Queen Mother Norodom Monineath, pleading for a birthday intervention on behalf of imprisoned activist Yorm Bopha. The group was met by 60 officers and riot police who quickly cracked down on the protesters who in turn beat the officers.

On 17 June 2013, about 80 villagers representing 300 families protested outside Koh Kong Provincial Hall in Khemarak Phoumin (Smach Mean Chey, Koh Kong) to demand a solution for their land disputes. The families are affected either by Chinese firm Tianjin Union Development Group's tourism development in Botum Sakor and Kiri Sakor districts or Heng Huy Agriculture Company's concession in Sre Ambel district.

On 17 June 2013, about 50 members of the Boeung Kak community tried to march from Village 22 in Daun Penh district, Phnom Penh, to the Council of Ministers. The villagers protested to demand authorities overturn fellow Boeung Kak activist Yorm Bopha's guilty verdict and resolve their years-long land dispute. They were blocked from marching by more than 100 police and security guards, including riot squad members, but no violence occurred.

On 12 June 2013, a deminer was killed near the Cambodian-Thai border, in Cham Yeam villag, Koh Kong, when a piece of unexploded ordnance (UXO), believed to be an anti-tank mine, went off during a demining operation. Two other people were injured.

On 12 June 2013, about 500 protesters from 24 communities across the country protested in Phnom Penh to draw attention to land disputes they say are frequently ending with imprisonment as well as eviction. The villagers protested at the Ministry of Justice and dragged effigies of 'corrupt officials' to the National Assembly, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Supreme Council of Magistracy.

On 11 June 2013, a rally being held by CNRP leader Kem Sokha in Kandal's Kien Svay district was interrupted when 1000 people descended on the meetings. The group called for Sokha to publicly apologise for his alleged comments that a Khmer Rouge prison was a Vietnamese invention.

On 09 June 2013, about 3000 demonstrated at the streets in Kampong Cham province to call for Cambodia National Rescue Party vice-president Kem Sokha to apologise for his alleged comments regarding the Tuol Sleng interrogation centre during the Khmer Rouge regime. Sokha allegedly described the prison as a Vietnamese invention.

On 09 June 2013, an estimated 10000 people protested in Phnom Penh's Freedom Park to call for Cambodia National Rescue Party vice-president Kem Sokha to apologise for his alleged comments regarding the Tuol Sleng interrogation centre during the Khmer Rouge regime. Sokha allegedly described the prison as a Vietnamese invention. The CNRP accused the act as being orchestrated by the authorities.

On 08 June 2013, hundreds of workers from Sabrina Garment factory continued to protest outside the provincial court in Kampong Speu, demanding the release on bail of three Free Trade Union leaders and five of their rank and file, who were arrested after a violent riot on 03 June.

On 07 June 2013, hundreds of workers from Sabrina Garment factory continued to protest outside the provincial court in Kampong Speu, demanding the release on bail of three Free Trade Union leaders and five of their rank and file, who were arrested after a violent riot on 03 June.

On 06 June 2013, about 500 garment workers stood in front of the Kampong Speu Provincial Court, in Chbar Mon, to show support for the Free Trade Union leaders and members who have been in custody since a demonstration for higher wages in front of the factory turned violent.

On 05 June 2013, more than 1000 workers from Sabrina Garment Manufacturing factory gathered in the rain at Kampong Speu Provincial Court in Chbar Mon to demand the release of eight union members arrested on 03 June during a riot. About 100 police and military police officers were present, but no violence occurred.

On 03 June 2013, rioters entered a garment factory and threw objects at employees still at work, Sabrina Garment Manufacturing factory in Kampong Speu province. The police and the military police intervened, leaving several people injured and arresting eight workers.

On 01 June 2013, about a dozen Cambodians protested at a border checkpoint near Paoy Paet. The group, protesting against a Thai crackdown on new travel regulations, caused a roadblock which prompted Cambodian authorities to intervene.

Property destruction: On 30 May 2013, about 50 police, soldiers and environmental officials demolished two houses and cut down thousands of trees belonging to families, in Thma Da commune, Veal Veng district, Pursat. The villagers are locked in a land dispute with MDS Import Export Co, owned by tycoon Try Pheap.

On 29 May 2013, nearly 100 former employees of Mfone gathered for the third day to protest outside the former company's headquarters in Phnom Penh to claim compensation for what they are still owed by the company.

On 29 May 2013, Cambodian police fired water jets at protesters in Phnom Penh. The group of around 100 people were calling for more compensation or a return of land given by the government to a Chinese company for a commercial development. Three people were knocked unconscious.
