On 27 May 2013, more than 300 villagers protested outside the Kratie office of Korean-owned timber company Think Biotech Co. Protesters seized two company trucks from the company, which they who allege of grabbing their land.

On 27 May 2013, about 100 staff from NagaWorld casino protested In Phnom Penh. The workers demanded bosses introduce a casino-wide minimum wage of $150 per month and approve a 20 per cent increase to all other wages.

On 27 May 2013, nearly 100 former employees of bankrupt telecommunication provider Mfone gathered to protest outside the former company's headquarters in Phnom Penh to claim compensation still owed by the company.

On 27 May 2013, riot police moved 3000 factory workers - most of them women - off a roadblock in Phnom Penh, using electrict batons. At leat 23 people were hurt, including a pregnant woman who miscarried due to her injuries.

On 26 May 2013, more than 100 people from two communes in Kratie province's Sambor district gathered in front of the provincial office of Think Biotech, a Korean-owned timber company villagers say is encroaching on their land. 10 armed policemen and six soldiers took guard at the office's entrance.

assoc_actor_2: CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Buddhist Group (Cambodia)
notes: A senior Buddhist monk was found beaten to death on 23 May in his house in Svay Rieng province's Bavet city. The monk had with ties to political party CNRP, leading the opposition to call his death a politically motivated killing.

On 23 May 2013, nearly 90 representatives of 137 families from Battambang province protested in Butom Vatey pagoda, in Phnom Penh. The protesters, some of whom include former Khmer Rouge cadres, claimed authorities had seized land they had held since the late 1990s.

On 22 May 2013, more than 100 protesters facing eviction from Por Sen Chey district's Thmar Kaul community blocked traffic outside Phnom Penh airport. The protesters demanded information about the exact expansion plans and whether they would be properly compensated if forced to move.

On 22 May 2013, nearly 90 representatives of 137 families from Battambang province protested in Butom Vatey pagoda, in Phnom Penh. The protesters, some of whom include former Khmer Rouge cadres, claimed authorities had seized land they had held since the late 1990s.
On 21 May 2013, about 200 workers at V-Masou garment factory in Takeo province threw stones at the factory, breaking windows and doors, and blocked National Road 3.
On 21 May 2013, more than 4000 garment workers protested for better benefits in front of the Sabrina Garment factory, in Kampong Speu, when the factory used a fire truck to spray them with water.

On 21 May 2013, hundreds of students in Phnom Penh unfurled banners urging an end to UN rights scrutiny of Cambodia, after a lecture giving by UN Rapporteur for Human Rights Surya Subedi. The students accused Subedi of supporting political opposition groups.

On 20 May 2013, thousands of supporters of the CNRP marched through the streets of Phnom Penh calling for international pressure on the country's government to postpone July national elections and reform its electoral procedures. Military police, police officers and anti-riot police were deployed near the demonstrators, but no violence occurred.
On 20 May 2013, a group of moto-taxi drivers protested in front of the UN offices in Phnom Penh, demanding UN Rapporteur for Human Rights Surya Subedi to leave the country.

A Vietnamese rubber concessionaire is believed to have burned down more than $5,000 worth of property (one house, four huts, and some 200 bunches of cassava plants) related to a land dispute in O'Chum district, in Ratank Kiri. Some people were slightly injured when they were trying to escape from the fire. The chief of staff of the company and his Cambodian translator were arrested. Date is not provided (article is from May 15).

On 08 May 2013, about 800 workers at Master & Frank garment factory blocked the road, demanding the factory re-hire eight workers they say were sacked unjustly, in Kandal province's Ang Snuol district.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 08 May 2013, activists from Borei Keila and Boeung Kak community staged a demonstration in front of the South Korean embassy in Phnom Penh. They presented petitions to embassy officials, to ask for help with their land issues.
On 08 May 2013, about 700 workers from the Pine Great garment factory in Phnom Penh's Meanchey district blocked the road for half an hour, demanding due wages.

actor1: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Forestry Officials
notes: On 3 May 2013, a man was killed by forestry officials, in Anlong Veng commune, Oddar Meanchey. His mother claimed that her son was transporting illegally cut rosewood when forestry officials noticed his car and chase him, shooting at his car and forcing him into a fatal accident.
On 1 May 2013, a man lost an eye when a fire in front of his house set off a landmine in Bour commune, Battambang province.

On 1 May 2013, one man was killed and two others seriously injured in a mine explosion in Takeo province's Tram Kak district. The three men were clearing forest to build a home when one stepped on the mine.

On 01 May 2013, more than 5,000 people marched on the streets of Phnom Penh to mark International Labour Day. The protesters, many garment workers, converged to the National Assembly, where they presented a petition to legislators demanding improved working conditions.

On 30 April 2013, 30 villagers from the Jarai ethnic group directly confronted five Company 72 workers and their bulldozers in Yatung commune's Ten village, in Ratanakkiri's O'Yadav district. Company 72 is a Vietnamese firm operating in an economic land concession area granted to Cambodian company Men Sarun Co, Ltd. Villagers accuse the company of razing their farmland despite repeated requests to halt the land clearing.

On 30 April 2013, 22 villagers from the Jarai ethnic group in Lom village in Paknhai commune (in Ratanakkiri's O'Yadav district) gathered to protest against the Company 72. Company 72 is a Vietnamese firm operating in an economic land concession area granted to Cambodian company Men Sarun Co, Ltd. Villagers accuse the company of razing their farmland despite repeated requests to halt the land clearing.

On 29 April 2013, more than 300 garment workers protested outside the D&L Ultimate factory, in Dangkor district, Phnom Penh. They demanded the reinstatement of a worker they say was sacked after the company learned he had been elected as the leader of a newly formed union in the factory. The workers burned tyres and blared loud music.
On 24 April 2013, a 18-year-old was killed when he drove his tractor over an anti-tank landmine while plowing farmland in Pailin's Sala Krao district.

On 24 April 2013, about 2,000 Cambodian opposition supporters rallied in Phnom Penh. The protesters, mostly from the CNRP, demanded election reforms and guarantees that their leader Sam Rainsy can return to Cambodia to contest polls in July.

On 24 April 2013, nearly 100 former employees of the Horus Industrial garment factory protested in front of Phnom Penh Municipal Court, Phnom Penh. The group demanded the payment of their remaining wages and benefits, owed them since the factory's closure in November 2012.

On 25 April 2013, more than 2,000 workers at the Hung Wah I garment factory demonstrated outside the Por Sen Chey plant, in Phnom Penh. They protested over allegations that the company had refused to pay seniority bonuses to outgoing workers.

On 23 April 2013, about 100 villagers gathered in protest at Ou Chum commune hall in Ratanakkiri. They protested after Swift Rubber Limited, a Chinese company, bulldozed their crops in an effort to force them off company-leased rubber plantations without compensation.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Thma Koul Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 22 April 2013, about 70 female activists from three communities (Boeung Kak, Borei Keila and Thmarkol) were confronted by about 200 police officers carrying shields and sticks outside Prime Minister Hun Sen's home in Phnom Penh. The women were demanding the release of imprisoned activist Yorm Bopha, the demarcation of 12.44 hectares of land at Boeung Kak and the issuance of remaining land titles to families in that community. A few women suffered minor injuries.

On 22 April 2013, a group of 87 families gathered in the front of the Red Cross's office, in Tuol Kork district, Phnom Penh, to ask for food and plastic tents to use during the rainy season. The families had been evicted from Borei Kela community and many were not yet relocated.

On 12 April 2013, a legal aid NGO investigator was shot to death by a military police officer in Ta Khmau, Kandal province. The investigator had previously accused the officer of running illegal gambling activities during a Khmer New Year drinking session.

On 09 April 2013, about 200 former Mfone employees gathered in front of the Thai embassy in Phnom Penh. The workers protested over claims that Thaicom, a failed telco's parent company, had paid Thai staff even though Cambodian staff were still owed compensation.

On 09 April 2013, a group of activists protested outside the Delegation of the European Union to Cambodia in Phnom Penh. The group called for the cancellation of an EU-India Free Trade Agreement that could restrict access to life-saving medicines for more than 48,000 people with HIV/AIDS in Cambodia.

On 02 April 2013, more than 500 striking workers protested outside the Su Tong Fang garment factory in Phnom Penh to demand that the company begin the wage increase one month early. They also demanded holiday bonuses, seniority benefits and several other benefits.

On 01 April 2013, about 200 former employees of Cambodian telecommunications firm Mfone, led by the Cambodian Labour Confederation (CLC), protested outside the Ministry of Social Affairs, Veteran and Youth Rehabilitation, in Phnom Penh. The protesters demanded their overdue payments, as the company went bankrupt.

On 27 March 2013, about 200 villagers protested outside of the Cambodian Supreme Court in Phnom Penh, to protest against the rejection of the bail appeal of Yorm Bopha, a land rights activist from Boueng Kak lake community. They burned a scale of justice replica, and yelled 'Corrupt court, hear the cry of villagers.'
On 21 March 2013, workers from Maru Chuen garment factory in Phnom Penh blocked a company truck from entering the factory and broke its mirror with stones. No one was injured.

On 20 March 2013, workers from the Win Star garment factory in Kompong Speu province blocked National Road 3, after the government announced a higher minimum wage of U.S. $80 per month for garment and footwear workers. The workers, who had been on strike for days, demanded a minimum wage of U.S. $100 per month.

On 20 March 2013 morning, seven workers and one police officer were injured after police intervened to stop workers from blocking several company cars from entering the Maru Chuen garment factory in Phnom Penh's Dangkor district. The police used electric batons and stones to hit the protesters, injuring five women and two men, while workers threw stones back at police. Striking workers demand a minimum wage increase and other benefits.

On 20 March 2013 afternoon, striking workers and employees who had not joined the strike threw rocks at each other at Maru Chuen garment factory in Phnom Penh's Dangkor district. Six workers inside the factory were injured. Striking workers demand a minimum wage increase and other benefits.

On 19 March 2013, a group of 10 journalists were beaten by a group of seven men while trying to film a scene of a high-speed car crash, in Monivong Boulevard in Phnom Penh. One of the journalists was seriously injured. Two men were arrested.

On 18 March 2013, fifty Tampuon ethnic minority families protested in front of the Soeung Commune Hall in Bakeo district, Ratanak Kiri. They protested against their commune chief, who they alleged sold land that belonged to the Ratanakkiri community.

On 17 March 2013, about 300 former employees of bankrupt telco Mfone protested at the company's former headquarters, in Phnom Penh. The protesters demanded compensation for loss of seniority pay, of which some workers say they are owed $50,000.

actor1: Military Forces of Thailand (2011-2014) Thai Rangers
notes: On 16 March 2013, two Cambodian illegal loggers were wounded by gunfire from Thai troops and another six went missing after a raid on an illegal rosewood transport heading back to Preah Vihear province, near Choam Ksan district. The event occurred near a disputed area in the Thai-Cambodia border.

On 15 March 2013, villagers in the Thai-Cambodia disputed border region around Preah Vihear temple claimed that both Thailand and Cambodia have been moving more troops and weapons to the border zone, starting mid-March. The countries have a case in the International Court of Justice (ICJ) on the ruling of the Preah Vihear Temple, in Kantuot, and its surrounding area.

On 14 March 2013, hundreds of people gathered outside the Appeal Court in Phnon Penh to show their support to radio station owner Mam Sonando. The supporters cheered at the news of the verdict that substantially reduced from 20-year to 5-years his sentence on insurrection charges.

Property destruction: On 14 March 2013, security guards tore down the shelters of 12 families at the Borei Keila eviction site in Phnom Penh, while they were at the Court of Appeal supporting imprisoned Beehive radio director Mam Sonando. The guards were acting on behalf of the development firm Phan Imex, who owns the land.

On 13 March 2013, about 100 villagers from Boeung Kak lake community protested in front of the home of Prime Minister Hun Sem, in Phnom Penh, demanding land compensation for their evictions. The protesters were brutally beaten by about 300 security personnel, composed of municipal police and Daun Penh district security guards. At least six people were seriously injured.

On 12 March 2013, some 600 garment workers protested in front of the Sixplus Industry factory, an Adidas supplier, in Kandal province. The workers demanded a monthly minimum wage increase from $61 to $120 and day-off benefits, among other demands.
On 12 March 2013, about 1000 garment workers at the E Cheng Cambodia Cooperation factory protested in in Takeo province. The workers demanded a minimum wage increase to $80 and other benefits.

On 06 March 2013, police, military police and forestry officials shot into the air and threatened villagers while evicting about 100 families, in Smach Meanchey in Khemarak Phumin town. The villagers claimed that when they protested the forced evictions shots were fired, but no one was injured.

On 05 March 2013, striking workers protested outside the E Garment factory in Saang district, Kandal province. Five foreigners were briefly detained as they joined the group to meet with members of the Coalition of Cambodian Apparel Workers' Democratic Union outside the factory.

actor2: Military Forces of Thailand (2011-2014) Thai Rangers
notes: On 5 March 2013, a 16-member ranger patrol Thai unit was inspecting areas around Ta Kwai temple (Prasat Ta Krabey in Khmer) in Surin's Phanom Dong Rak district in Thailand (contested area in Kouk Khpos, Banteay Ampil, Oddar Meanchey, Cambodia). Three rangers stepped on landmines, and one ranger's right leg was blown off. The landmines were found to be Vietnamese-made TMN1 mines, which are commonly used by the Cambodian military.

On 05 March 2013, about 500 supporters of a Cambodian activist stood outside the Appeal Court in Phnom Penh to protest against his 20-years jail term. The activist, Radio station owner Mam Sonando, was convicted in October 2012 on charges including insurrection and inciting people to take up arms against the state.
On 4 March 2013, four people were injured after their tractor ran over a landmine, in Anlong Veng district, Oddar Meanchey province.

On 2 March 2013, a seven-year-old girl lost her eye and was severely injured from the shards of a B40 rocket that exploded when she picked it up while scavenging, in Choam Ksan district, Preah Vihear province. The area was a battle zone during the civil war.

On 27 February 2013, a mob beat to death a 40-year-old man on in Kong Pisei district, Kampong Speu province, because they believed his alleged practice of black magic caused illnesses. No suspects were arrested.

On 27 February 2013, workers protested outside the Kingsland Garment factory, in Phnom Penh. Workers threatened to go on hunger strike if the government did not help them resolve their dispute. The factory closed in December 2012 while still owing wages and benefits to its workers.

On 26 February 2013, more than 1000 protesters rallied outside the front entrance of NagaWorld Casino, in Phnom Penh. The protesters, mostly composed by casino's workers, demanded the reinstatement of four sacked food and beverage workers and compliance with Arbitration Council decisions that date back years. Police and military police joined private security guards near the casino's entrance.
On 25 February 2013, about 800 workers from NagaWorld Casino, in Phnom Penh, protested outside, demanding the reinstatement of sacked workers and better conditions.

On 23 and 24 February 2013, more than 100 workers from Kingsland Garment factory blocked National Road 2, in Phnom Penh, to demand for intervention in their case. The factory closed in December 2012 while still owing wages and benefits to its workers.
On 23 February 2013, a woman was killed by a 60-mm explosive UXO while clearing grass at a rubber plantation in Kravanh village, Snoul district (Kratie province).

On 23 and 24 February 2013, more than 100 workers from Kingsland Garment factory blocked National Road 2, in Phnom Penh, to demand for intervention in their case. The factory closed in December 2012 while still owing wages and benefits to its workers.

On 21 February 2013, private security forces allegedly beat with sticks, pipes and stones seven workers after a protest outside E Garment factory in Saang district, Kandal province. The workers, members of the Coalition of Cambodian Apparel Workers' Democratic Union (C.CAWDU), filled a complaint to commune police authorities.
On 20 February 2013, a police officer lost his right leg after stepping on a landmine while on border patrol in the jungle around Samlot district, in Battambang.
In the month of February, a man who was selling food on the street was attacked with wooden chairs and sticks, by three local military police officers.

On 13 February 2013, about 7000 garment workers from the Yung Wah Industrial Complex blocked traffic on National Road 21B in Takhmao town, Kandal, in solidarity with around 1,000 employees who said they are owed more than two months of salary by the company's Singaporean owner, who fled the country in December.

On 13 February 2013, a man was injured and taken to hospital after two anti-tank mines exploded while he was farming in Sampov Loun district, Battambang. The mines were believed to be remnants of the civil war period.

On 13 February 2013, hundreds of employees from state-owned Telecom Cambodia protested calling for the removal of director general Lao Saroeun, in Phnom Penh. The director was accused of corruption and mismanagement.

On 12 February 2013, about 7,000 workers blocked the road outside the shuttered Yung Wah Industrial garment factory complex, in Takhmao town, in Kandal province. The protesters demanded their salaries, which are two months overdue since the factory closed.

On 9 February 2013, a man attacked people at a Chinese New Year's party in Kamrieng district, in Battambang province with a grenade, injuring 14 people. The attack, believed to be carried out by three men who were arrested, was motivated by revenge related to a land dispute with the host of the party.

Defusal: On 08 February, a team composed of provincial police and the Cambodian Mine Action Centre (CMAC) uncovered and destroyed a cache of mortars, rockets and anti-personnel landmines Sisophon town (called Serei Saophoan), in Banteay Meanchey province. The materials were found when a local farmer in O'Ambel commune in Sisophon was inspecting an irrigation canal. Officials believe they were buried by Khmer Rouge guerrillas during fighting in the 1990s.

On 07 February 2013, striking workers from E Garment Factory in Sa'ang district, Kandal province, continued protesting. They demanded the factory reinstate 41 Coalition of Cambodian Apparel Workers' Democratic Union members sacked in 2007.

On 06 February 2013, about 200 workers at E Garment Factory in Sa'ang district, Kandal province, protested to demand the factory reinstate 41 Coalition of Cambodian Apparel Workers' Democratic Union members sacked in 2007. Seven workers, including a pregnant woman, claimed that they were injured in a clash with police outside the factory in, an allegation authorities denied.

On 30 January 2013, more than 100 truck drivers and owners parked outside Kampong Cham Provincial Governor Hun Neng's house. The group demanded the cancellation of several fines. The governor eventually agreed to return fines of almost $10,000 to the truck owners and drivers.
On 30 January 2013, a man had his leg amputated after stepping on a landmine while walking through a forest to chop wood, in Trapaing Chor commune, Oral district, in Kampong Speu.
On 27 January 2013, a police officer shot a driver who refused to pay a bribe of 2,000 riel ($0.50) at an unofficial checkpoint the officer had set up, in Phnom Penh.

On 24 January 2013, more than 700 garment workers blocked the Veng Sreng road in Phnom Penh for about four hours. The workers, from the International Royal Fashion garment factory, in Phnom Penh's Dangkor district, were dissatisfied with their employer's failure to respond to their demands, which included a monthly minimum wage increase from $61 to $93 and overtime bonuses.

On 21 January 2013, garment workers from the Yakjin (Cambodia) Inc factory protested the detention of two Buddhist monks outside the Chom Chao commune office in Por Sen Chey district, in Phnom Penh. The monks were detained and questioned by authorities after blessing striking garment workers at a factory.

On 21 January 2013, more than 300 striking workers from the International Fashion Royal garment factory in Phnom Penh marched to the South Korean Embassy after police blocked their march to Por Sen Chey District Hall. The workers demanded a monthly minimum wage increase from $61 to $93 and overtime bonuses.

On 17 January 2013, two demonstrators and three factory officials were injured in a clash at Winson International garment factory in Samrong Tong, Kampong Speu province. When demonstrators tried to get into an area of the factory, one security official used a pipe to beat the workers, leading to a clash between the groups.

On 17 January 2013, about 200 garment workers from the International Fashion Royal factory in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh rode tuk-tuks to the Ministry of Labour to ask for help to have their wages increased to $93 per month.

On 16 January 2013, about 80 families travelling to Phnom Penh from Kampong Chhnang province for a land dispute-related protest were blocked on their way to the capital and told to resolve the matter locally. The group was blocked to continue their march by provincial authorities, backed by armed police and military police forces, who put barricades on the road at Samaki Meanchey district.
On 16 January 2013, five former massage workers from Aziadee spa protested outside the spa against the sudden termination of their contracts, in Beoung Keng Kang 1 neighborhood, Phnom Penh.
On 15 January 2013, more than 700 workers from the Winson International Garment factory (located in Samraong Tong) in Kampong Speu province demonstrated for a minimum wage increase to $70 per month.

On 15 January 2013, four American demining experts got injured when an unexploded ordnance (UXO) exploded at a mine clearance training field in the Cambodian Mine Action Center (CMAC), in Kampong Chhnang province. Two of the experts were in critical condition.

On 15 January 2013, more than 2,000 striking workers continue to protest in front of Phnom Penh's Gladpeer Garment Factory and threatened to block National Road 4 if their demands remain unmet. The protesters' demands include that the factory - an H&M supplier - increase the monthly minimum wage from $61 to $93 per month, reinstate two fired union members and begin using long-term contracts.
On 14 January 2013, a man had to have his leg amputated after stepping on a landmine, while setting traps in a forest in Thma Da commune, Veal Veng district, in Pursat.

On 14 January 2013, more than 2,000 workers demonstrated in front of Gladpeer Garment Factory in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh, demanding a higher minimum wage and several other concessions. More than 20 police officers showed up at the protest, but no violence occurred.

From 04 to 13 January 2013, striking workers at the Kingsland garment factory in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh, had been protesting and sleeping in tents outside the factory after the company ceased operations while still owing hundreds of thousands of dollars in unpaid wages and benefits.

From 04 to 13 January 2013, striking workers at the Kingsland garment factory in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh, had been protesting and sleeping in tents outside the factory after the company ceased operations while still owing hundreds of thousands of dollars in unpaid wages and benefits.

From 04 to 13 January 2013, striking workers at the Kingsland garment factory in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh, had been protesting and sleeping in tents outside the factory after the company ceased operations while still owing hundreds of thousands of dollars in unpaid wages and benefits.

On 10 January 2013, about 100 motodops (motorbike taxi drivers) protested in front of the office of the Cambodian Center for Human Rights in Phnom Penh. They demanded the president Ou Virak to retract comments accusing victims and witnesses of giving false testimony during December's trial of Boeung Kak lake woman Yorm Bopha.

From 04 to 13 January 2013, striking workers at the Kingsland garment factory in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh, had been protesting and sleeping in tents outside the factory after the company ceased operations while still owing hundreds of thousands of dollars in unpaid wages and benefits.

From 04 to 13 January 2013, striking workers at the Kingsland garment factory in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh, had been protesting and sleeping in tents outside the factory after the company ceased operations while still owing hundreds of thousands of dollars in unpaid wages and benefits.

From 04 to 13 January 2013, striking workers at the Kingsland garment factory in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh, had been protesting and sleeping in tents outside the factory after the company ceased operations while still owing hundreds of thousands of dollars in unpaid wages and benefits.

On 6 January 2013, residents of Phnom Penh's Daun Penh district punched and slapped a man who police say stole a local woman's motorbike. The crowd pummelled the man before turning him over to police. He confessed to the crime and was sent to court.

From 04 to 13 January 2013, striking workers at the Kingsland garment factory in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh, had been protesting and sleeping in tents outside the factory after the company ceased operations while still owing hundreds of thousands of dollars in unpaid wages and benefits.

From 04 to 13 January 2013, striking workers at the Kingsland garment factory in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh, had been protesting and sleeping in tents outside the factory after the company ceased operations while still owing hundreds of thousands of dollars in unpaid wages and benefits.

On 31 December 2012, the Cambodian Confederation of Unions president Rong Chhun led a 300 people protest in Phnom Penh, to demand an increase in the minimum wage from the current US$ 61 to US$ 150 per month.

On 27 December 2012, about 300 workers continued their protest outside Master and Frank garment factory, in Ang Snuol district, Kandal province. The demonstrators were demanding the reinstatement of workers who had been fired.

On 27 December 2012, supporters of Boeung Kak lake community activist Yorm Bopha protested outside the Phnom Penh Municipal Court, after hearing the verdict that ordered her to serve three years in prison. At least five women protestors were injured by police wielding electric shields and batons.

On 26 December 2012, 50 police officers clashed with about 300 striking workers, as they protested in front of Master and Frank garment factory in Ang Snuol district, Kandal province. The demonstrators were demanding the reinstatement of workers who had been fired. Two workers were beaten unconscious.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 26 December 2012, residents of Boeung Kak lake and Borei Keila communities gathered outside Phnom Penh Municipal Court to celebrate the release of activist Tim Sakmony. They also demanded the release of activist Yorm Bopha, arrested in connection with the alleged beating by local residents of a suspected thief. Outside the Court, several motor taxi drivers staged protests supporting the charges against Yorm Bopha.

On 26 December 2012, factory security officers injured two striking workers at the Conpress Holdings factory in Meanchey district, Boeng Proluet, Phnom Penh. More than 200 rioters were burning tyres in front of the factory, when the officers threw rocks and used fire extinguishers against them.

On 24 December 2012, about 1.000 workers protested outside the Xing Chang Xing garment factory, in Russey Keo district, Phnom Penh. A union representative from the Coalition of Apparel Workers' Democratic Union claimed the company had hired a gangster to beat him up on 23 December, but the management of the factory denied the fact.

assoc_actor_1: ADHOC: Cambodian Human Rights and Development Association
notes: On 24 December 2012, about 100 demonstrators, including rights workers, stood outside the Phnom Penh Municipal Court as Adhoc senior investigator Chan Soveth was being questioned on the charge of aiding a criminal.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Thma Koul Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 20 December 2012, about 100 residents from Boeung Kak, Borei Keila and Thma Kul communities protested outside the World Bank office in Phnom Penh. They asked the institution to freeze loans to the government if there is no solution to their land dispute.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 17 December 2012, around 500 people protested in front of the National Assembly, in Phnom Penh. The demonstrators called for the Cambodian People's Party (CPP) to help in resolving land disputes. During the protest, the villagers danced and sang songs about their grievances. They also called for the release of land activists Yorm Bopha of Boeung Kak Lake community, Tim Sakmony of the Borei Keila community, and independent radio station director Mam Sonando.

On 11 December 2012, villagers from Svay Pak commune, in Phnom Penh, continued to protest against a sand dredging opeation they claimed was damaging their houses. They refused to move from the sand-dredging site, holding photos of Prime Minister Hun Sen and his wife.

On 10 December 2012, about 2,000 people marched from Olympic Stadium to Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh, to protest against land evictions. The police barred demonstrators from marching to the Council of Ministers, and a woman was knocked down by police and kicked in the stomach.

On 7 December 2012, a 22-year-old man was shot and then beaten to death in Sna Ansa commune, Krakor district, Pursat province. Family member claimed he was killed by police officers after an argument during a religious ceremony.
On 01 December 2012, about 200 striking garment workers broke several items at the Nex-T Apparel factory, in Phnom Penh. The workers had been striking to demand better working conditions.

On 24 November 2012, a 23-year-old man was beaten unconscious by a group of villagers in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh, after he and another man allegedly stole a motorbike. The police intervened and took the suspect to hospital.

On 19 November 2012, during the visit of US President Barack Obama, Sam Rainsy Party (SRP) supporters attempted to gather in front of the Peace Palace to request Obama's intervention in releasing independent Beehive Radio Director Mam Sonando, resolving land issues, and allowing the return of Sam Rainsy-leader of the National Rescue Party (NRP).

On 18 November 2012, during the visit of US President Barack Obama, about 100 protesters gathered at Boeung Kak lake area carrying large black banners emblazoned with the word 'SOS' next to photos of Obama and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 12 November 2012, more than 100 protesters from Boeung Kak and Borei Keila communities continued to protest outside the US embassy, in Phnom Penh, appealing for the release of two land activists.

On 08 November 2012, about 100 members of the Sam Rainsy Party's youth movement protested at Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh, to demand the release of political prisoners. The group was blocked from marching to the Royal Palace by a force of 200 police officials, and encountered a group of members of the Association of Democrats, who were protesting in support of their president, Mam Sonando.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 08 November 2012, about 100 Boeung Kak and Borei Keila residents, mostly women, continued to protest outside the US embassy, in Phnom Penh. They asked for the release of two women activists, arrested for their role in protests against land disputes.

On 3 November 2012, a 42-year-old man was stabbed to death by at least two unidentified villagers, in Krapeu Krom village, Veal Veng district, in Pursat province. The victim had been accused of using sorcery to make villagers sick.

On 01 November 2012, about 200 residents of Krasang village blocked National Road 7 in Snuol commune, Kratie province. The villagers, involved in a land dispute with Herasy Co Ltd, accused the provincial governor of deliberately cutting them out of a national land-titling scheme.
On 25 October 2012, forty-six families facing eviction in Meanchey district protested in front of the city hall in Phnom Penh. The demolition of their homes was later postponed.

On 22 October 2012, about 200 villagers gathered in front of Prek Taten/Preaek Ta Teaen pagoda, in Kandal province, to protest the expulsion of a monk, after he was allegedly discovered having a love affair with a woman.
On 22 October 2012, more than 1.000 workers from Top World Garment factory protested in Phnom Penh, after a Chinese manager ripped in half two portraits of former King Norodom Sihanouk.
On 10 October 2012, a 40-year-old man was beaten to death after he stole a necklace of an elderly woman, in Trapaing Thmat village, in Cheung Prey district, Kampong Cham.
On 09 October 2012, villagers from Preah Vihear protested in front of the Prime Minister's house, in Phnom Penh, to seek intervention in a land dispute with the extinct NGO DARPO.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 08 October 2012, about 400 representatives of 40 communities, including Boeung Kak and Borei Keila, protested at the former Dey Krahorm eviction site, in Phnom Penh, to mark World Habitat Day event.

On 7 October 2012, three Cambodian farmers from the same family died after their truck hit an old anti-tank mine in Ta Sanh commune, Samlout district, Battambang. Other two relatives were seriously injured in the blast.

On 7 October 2012, three Cambodian farmers from the same family died after their truck hit an old anti-tank mine in Battambang. Other two relatives were seriously injured in the blast. The landmine is believed to be from the civil war in the country.

From 02 to 04 October 2012, more than 600 garment workers protested outside Tae Young Co factory, in Ang Snuol district, Kandal. They demanded the reinstatement of 16 fired workers, and the removal of a legal action against eight of them for inciting a strike.
On 04 October 2012, about 1.000 garment workers burned tyres in front of the Cambo Kotop Ltd factory in Por Sem Chey district, in Phnom Penh. The workers demanded better working conditions.

From 02 to 04 October 2012, more than 600 garment workers protested outside Tae Young Co factory, in Ang Snuol district, Kandal. They demanded the reinstatement of 16 fired workers, and the removal of a legal action against eight of them for inciting a strike.

From 02 to 04 October 2012, more than 600 garment workers protested outside Tae Young Co factory, in Ang Snuol district, Kandal. They demanded the reinstatement of 16 fired workers, and the removal of a legal action against eight of them for inciting a strike.

On 01 October 2012, more than 500 garment workers picketed at the Tae Young Co factory, in Ang Snuol district, Kandal. They demanded the reinstatement of 16 fired workers, and the removal of a legal action against eight of them for inciting a strike.

On 1 October 2012, six farmers were killed and other two were seriously injured when their tractor ran over an anti-tank mine in Rotonak Mondul district, Battambang province. The landmine is believed to be from Cambodia's 1980s civil war.

On 01 October 2012, thousands of demonstrators gathered outside the Phnom Penh Municipal Court to show their support for the activist Mam Sonando. The activist was convicted and sentenced to 20 years on four counts related to an alleged secessionist movement.

On 25 September 2012, a 42-year-old journalist for the Ta Prum weekly newspaper was severely beaten by three men, at his home in Malik commune, Andong Meas district, in Ratanak Kiri province. The suspects of the crime are a former police officer and two villagers, all accused of being illegal loggers.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 24 September 2012, more than 60 people protested at the National Assembly, the UN Human Rights Office, the Danish Embassy and the German Embassy, in Phnom Penh. The group delivered petitions to ask for the release of two jailed women from the Boeung Kak and Borei Keila communities, arrested for their role in protests against land disputes.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 19 September 2012, about 100 residents from the Boeung Kak and Borei Keila communities continued to protest outside Appeal Court in Phnom Penh. They claimed for the release of two women activists, arrested for their role in protests against land disputes.

On 16 September 2012, Boeung Kak residents held a demonstration in Phnom Penh, burning effigies of corrupt officials to mark a year since authorities destroyed their houses in a land eviction process.

On 12 September 2012, a group of motodops (motorbike taxi drivers), members of the Cambodia for Confederation Development Association, marched to the office of human-rights group Licadho in Phnom Penh. They protested against allegations made by a Licadho senior adviser supporting land activist Yom Bopha, who was accused of beating two motodops.

On 12 September 2012, about 200 protestors camped outside Phnom Penh Municipal Court, while Mam Sonando was on trial on charges of secessionism and insurrection. Sonando is the director of independent Beehive Radio station, and president of the Association of Democrats.

On 11 September 2012, Cambodian journalist Hang Serey Udom was found dead in the trunk of his car, in Ratanak Kiri province. The journalist was covering illegal logging and deforestation. He had left his house on 09 September, without returning. A military police officer was arrested.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 11 September 2012, about 65 Borei Keila and Boeung Kak community supporters marched to the Ministry of Justice, in Phnom Penh. The group demanded the release of land activists Tim Sakmony and Yorm Bopha.

On 11 September 2012, around 500 people demonstrated outside the Phnom Penh court, where Mam Sonando, a leading government critic from The Association of Democrats, went on trial for an alleged secessionist plot. Authorities and anti-riot police briefly clashed with the rioters, injuring several people.

On 10 September 2012, a mob beat two thieves to death who were stealing jewellery from a gold seller in Por Sen Chey district in Phnom Penh (Phnom Penh). The robbers had shot at a couple and entered their house, but as they fled with the jewellery the mob attacked them.

On 10 September 2012, about 200 motodops (motorbike taxi drivers), members of the Cambodia for Confederation Development Association, rode from Freedom Park to the Court of Appeal in Phnom Penh. They protested the detention of Boeung Kak community activist Yorm Bopha.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 10 September 2012, about 200 residents from the Boeung Kak and Borei Keila communities were blocked by about 100 police from reaching the Ministry of Justice in Phnom Penh. The group wanted to file a petition objecting the arrest of their women activists.
On 9 September 2012, three boys died when an old B-40 rocket exploded as they tried to break it open, in Trapeang Prasat district, Oddar Meanchey province.

On 06 September 2012, about 300 workers protested outside Top Form garment factory in Phnom Penh. The striking workers claimed their employer was withholding up to US$ 9 per month 'tax' from their wages.
On 05 September 2012, about 100 people, including Borei Keila residents, protested outside Phnom Penh Municipal Court, as a fellow land-rights activist was sent to Prey Sar prison.

On 04 September 2012, about 100 villagers marched through Paoy Paet town (Banteay Meanchey) after contractors bulldozed through four hectares of their crops in Stung Bot village the day before. The villagers demanded compensation and the right to remain on their land.
On 31 August 2012, a 28-year-old alleged moto thief was beaten by a mob in Kampot town. The police intervened and arrested the man.

On 30 August 2012, a small homemade bomb exploded at a bridge on National Road 4 near Pich Nil, a traditional place of Buddhist prayer in Traeng Trayueng commune, Phnom Sruoch district, Kampong Speu. No one was injured in the explosion.
On 30 August 2012, more than 40 representatives of 223 vendors protested at the Ngin An market in Phnom Penh. The vendors protested against an eviction letter from the District Hall.
On 27 August 2012, about 50 women and children from Boeung Kak community gathered outside Phnom Penh City Hall to urge authorities to demarcate their land.

On 26 August 2012, about 50 villagers from Kien Svay district, in Kandal, protested at the local port against a Vietnamese sand-dredging company. The villagers, from Koh Prak village in Phoum Thom commune, claimed the works of the company led to the collapse of a shoreline of their lands into the Mekong river.

On 22 August 2012, more than 2.500 workers from Ocean Garment factory briefly clashed with about 100 police officers as they tried to march to Prime Minister Hun Sen's house with a petition, in Phnom Penh. The workers demanded the dismissal of a factory manager who allegedly sexually harassed four female workers. This was the second march that turned violent.

On 20 August 2012, more than 2.500 workers from Ocean Garment factory briefly clashed with about 100 police officers as they tried to march towards the Ministry of Social Affairs, in Phnom Penh. The workers demanded the dismissal of a factory manager who allegedly sexually harassed four female workers.
On 12 August 2012, four farmers were injured when an unexploded ordinance detonated at a cassava plantation in Pir Thnu commune, in Kratie province.

On 06 August 2012, about 200 villagers from Kulen district, in Preah Vihear, protested against authorities who had been burning their houses and clearing farmland. Authorities claim the Srayang area is supposed to house the families of 160 disabled soldiers.

Mass grave: On 6 August 2012, mass graves suspected to be hundreds of Khmer Rouge victims were recovered in Du Dantry village, Kampong Thkov commune, Kralanh district (Siem Reap). The skeletal remains of at least 20 people were found.
On 5 August 2012, a 24-year-old man was severely beaten by a mob after he hit two motorbikes and a home with his car in Rolea Bier district, Kampong Chhang.

On 3 August 2012, one teenager died and three other children were injured when a Khmer-Rouge era rocket exploded in Phnom Sroch district, Kampong Speu province. The children had taken their cows to graze near Kraing Lahong village when they discovered the discarded B-40 rocket and started to throw stones at it.

On 31 July 2012, more than 200 villagers protested outside Muk Kampoul district hall in Kandal province to demand land titles. The villagers claimed the company CT Mart cleared 86 hectares of their land in 2006 to build a dam, in Peang village, Sambuor Meas commune.

Mass grave: Around 31 July 2012, mass graves suspected to be hundreds of Khmer Rouge victims were recovered in Kampong Thkov commune, Kralanh district (Siem Reap). The skeletal remains of at least 17 people were found.

On 26 July 2012, villagers from Choam Chao commune near the Phnom Penh International Airport protested in front of the Por Sen Chey district in Phnom Penh. They protested against an eviction notice given to them, to evacuate their homes in seven days, with no offer of compensation.

On 24 July 2012, about 60 police officers allegedly beat garment workers from Tai Yang and Camwell factories who were striking near National Road 4, in Ang Snuol, Kandal province. At least 11 workers were slightly injured.
On 24 July 2012, more than 1.000 workers from Golden Gain Shoe Company blocked a road and marched towards the Ministry of Labour in Phnom Penh, to ask for better working conditions.

On 23 July 2012, two women were knocked unconscious by security guards in front of Master & Frank (Cambodia) garment factory, in Ang Snuol district, Kandal province. The workers were protesting to demand the reinstatement of a sacked union leader.

On 23 July 2012, the president of the Cambodian Confederation of Unions and 100 workers protested in front of the US Embassy in Phnom Penh. The group delivered a letter asking North-Americans to boycott clothing made by Tai Yang Enterprises.

On 23 July 2012, more than 1.000 striking workers from the Golden Gain Shoe Company protested in the streets of Phnom Penh, playing drums and carrying banners listing their demands for better working conditions.

On 23 July 2012, about 100 members of the Association of Democrats held a demonstration at the Preah Ang Dang Keu shrine, in Phnom Penh. The group burned incense and kneeled in prayer, calling for the release of their president, Mam Sonando, arrested on charges including plotting against public civil servants and insurrection.

On 19 July 2012, more than 100 villagers protested in front of Banan district hall in Battambang, to demand the release of six villagers who were arrested for allegedly accepting money to divide state land.
On 19 July 2012, more than 100 workers protested outside Master & Frank (Cambodia) garment factory in Ang Snuol district, Kandal to demand the reinstatement of a C.CAWDU union leader.

On 19 July 2012, more than 100 workers from Hai Yon shoe factory protested in the city centre of Phnom Penh, to demand the reinstatement of sacked workers and transportation and accommodation allowances.

actor1: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Prison Guards
notes: On 19 July 2012, a man grabbed a rifle from an officer near a shopping mall and killed one woman and injured five others, near the Sovanna shopping mall in Phnom Penh. The man, who worked as a prison guard, then shot and killed himself. The reasons for the shooting remained unclear.

On 18 July 2012 , Cambodia and Thailand pulled hundreds of soldiers out of the disputed border area of Preah Vihear temple, in Kantuot commune, replacing them with police and security guards. The movement of troops happened one year after a ruling by the UN's highest court.

On 12 July 2012, Cambodian troops fired shots at a passenger aircraft flying near the country's disputed border with Thailand, near Sa Kaeo (border with Banteay Meanchey). The Cambodian soldiers misunderstood the Bangkok Airways jet for a spy plane. Capital of the province coded as location.

assoc_actor_1: CATU: Cambodian Alliance of Trade Unions; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 11 July 2012, about 100 garment workers from Tai Yang Enterprises protested in Freedom Park, Phnom Penh, to demand better working conditions. About 20 protesters of the group marched on the streets to deliver a petition to the Prime Minister when they were violently beaten by police forces.

On 10 July 2012, about 300 garment workers from Horus Industrial Corp protested in front of the factory, in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh. They demanded the reinstatement of workers and union officials who were dismissed in June.

On 10 July 2012, Boeung Kak residents held a demonstration outside the US embassy in Phnom Penh. The villagers demonstrated against the guilty convictions of 14 activists who had been jailed for protesting against a land eviction.

On 09 July 2012, garment workers from factories owned by Tai Yang Enterprise protested in Ang Snuol district, Kandal. The workers called for a monthly transportation and accommodation stipend, and a bonus for good performance, among others demands.

On 7 July 2012, a 37-year-old farmer from Oddar Meanchey and his two oxen were killed in an anti-tank mine explosion, when his cart rolled over a civil war-era landmine, in Tumnup Thmey village, Anlong Veng district, Oddar Meanchey.

On 05 July 2012, garment workers briefly clashed with riot police as they marched from Ang Snuol district, in Kandal province, towards Phnom Penh. More than 4.000 workers from factories owned by Tai Yang Enterprise Co went on strike to demand better working conditions.

On 05 July 2012, about 4.000 striking garment workers from Tai Yang Enterprise blocked National Road 4, in Angk Snuol, Kandal, for more than seven hours. The workers demanded economic support for transportation, bonus pay for good performance and a contribution to child-care costs.

On 04 July 2012, thousands of garment workers from factories owned by Tai Yang Enterprise blocked National Road 4 for more than seven hours, in Ang Snuol district, Kandal. The workers called for a monthly transportation and accommodation stipend, among others demands.
On 02 July 2012, about 500 workers protested outside Wai Full Garments (Cambodia) Ltd factory in Kandal province, to protest against the dismissal of a worker who wanted to form a union.

On 29 June 2012, more than 500 villagers, students, monks and activists held a march in the capital city of Kompong Cham province, to protest against the Xayaburi dam project on the Mekong River in Laos. The villagers claim the dam is undergoing construction, despite a pledge to halt progress while officials conduct a potential impact study.

On 27 June 2012, about 200 human rights activists and relatives of the 13 Boeung Kak lake activists gathered near the Appeal Court In Phnom Penh to demonstrate their support, as the Court ordered the release of the women. The demonstrators clashed with about 300 police and military police who were deployed to block them. At least a dozen people were injured.

On 25 June 2012, about 100 Boeung Kak residents protested outside the Court of Appeal in Phnom Penh, to call for the release of 15 Boeung Kak lake community activists, jailed for demonstrating against a land eviction.
On 18 June 2012, about 150 Boeung Kak villagers gathered outside the Royal Palace in Phnom Penh, to call for the release of 15 community activists, arrested for protesting against a land eviction.

On 17 June 2012, about 300 people villagers blocked National Road 6A in Batheay district, Kampong Cham, to protest against the raising of electricity prices by the owner of the area's private generator.

On 14 June 2012, over 100 protesters gathered near Prime Minister Hun Sen's home in Phnom Penh to deliver petitions calling for the release of the 13 Boeung Kak lake activists. Cambodian authorities asked a court to review the jailing of the women. 50 police officers set road blocks preventing the protesters from marching to the PM house.

On 13 June 2012, about 50 Boeung Kak residents protested in Phnom Penh to demand the release of 15 community activists arrested for protesting against a land eviction. The villagers delivered petitions to the US and European Union embassies, asking for their intervention to free the prisoners.

On 11 June 2012, about 100 people demonstrated in front of the Royal Palace in Phnom Penh to urge King Norodom Sihamoni to help obtain the release of the 13 women arrested on 22 May. The women were trying to rebuild their homes in Boeung Kak lake area when they were arrested.
On 10 June 2012, about 200 people protested outside Prey Sar prison in Phnom Penh to call for the release of 15 Boeung Kak villagers who were jailed for protesting against a land eviction.

On 06 and 07 June 2012, more than 300 garment workers protested outside Horus Industrial Corp sports-wear factory, in Meanchey district in Phnom Penh. The workers demands included transportation and accommodation allowance.

On 06 and 07 June 2012, more than 300 garment workers protested outside Horus Industrial Corp sports-wear factory, in Meanchey district in Phnom Penh. The workers demands included transportation and accommodation allowance.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Buddhist Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 31 May 2012, more than 200 Boeung Kak residents and activist monk Loun Savath protested outside the Ministry of Justice in Phnom Penh. The demonstrators called for the release of 15 residents jailed in May.

On 29 May 2012, striking garment workers threw rocks at SL Garment factory, and one woman was hit in the head, in Phnom Penh. The violence occurred after workers were informed that the company backed away from the agreement after they returned to their jobs.
On 28 May 2012, workers threw stones at one of two SL garment factories in Phnom Penh, after the management refused to recognise a document they signed as a formal agreement to end the strike.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Buddhist Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 28 May 2012, about 200 people, including activist monk Loun Savath, and Boeung Kak residents, protested outside the National Assembly in Phnom Penh, in support of the 13 Boeung Kak women sentenced to prison.

On 25 May 2012, an activist from the Human Rights Party was shot dead, supposedly by a police officer, in Kouk Rovieng commune, Cheung Prey district, Kampong Cham. The investigators claimed the shooter was not a police officer, and that the crime happened because of a dispute between neighbours.

On 24 May 2012, several hundred people from the Boeung Kak Lake community protested in Phnom Penh against the arrest of 13 women who tried to rebuild their destructed homes on 22 May. The group was evicted to make way for a residential development project. Prominent monk Loun Savath, who was supporting the protest, was briefly detained.
On 24 May 2012, about 500 workers protested outside the Honda NCX company in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh. The workers claimed employees were being fired for trying to unionise.

On 24 May 2012, striking workers from SL Garment Processing continued to protest outside SL1 and SL2 factories, in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh. The workers demands included transport and living allowances.

On 23 May 2012, two farmers were seriously injured when a landmine exploded, in Paoy Paet town, Banteay Meanchey. The men had found the landmine in a rice field and allegedly played with it before it exploded.
On 23 May 2012, more than 100 workers protested outside the Honda NCX company in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh. The workers claimed employees were being fired for trying to unionise.
On 23 May 2012, about 70 Boeung Kak villagers protested outside Phnom Penh municipal court in support of 13 women who were arrested on 22 May for protesting against land evictions.

On 23 May 2012, private security guards from SL Garment factories pushed and beat workers who were striking outside the factory, located in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh. About 300 police and military police officers were present but did not engage in the fight. The workers demands included transport and living allowances.
On 22 May 2012, women residents of Boeung Kak lake area protested land evictions by symbolically rebuilding the homes of several families who were evicted in Phnom Penh. Thirteen women were arrested.

On 22 May 2012, garment workers from SL Garment Processing (Cambodia)'s SL1 and SL2 factories continued to protest in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh. The workers demanded transport and living allowances.
On 21 May 2012, about 200 gold sellers demonstrated outside Mongkol Borei district police headquarters, in Banteay Meanchey, after the arrest of three gold vendors accused of buying stolen goods.

On 21 May 2012, nearly 100 Boeung Kak lake villagers carried mattresses, umbrellas and food to the Phnom Penh City Hall to protest against the government inaction on the long-standing land dispute over their eviction. Police officers followed the protest, but there were no reported clashes.
On 21 May 2012, some 3000 garment workers from SL factory gathered in front of the Social and Labour Ministry in Phnom Penh to demand better working conditions.
On 21 May 2012, a group of 10 men hired by Haiyun garment factory were accused of beating workers as they protested, in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh.

On 19 and 20 May 2012, 135 ethnic Kouy families protested in Tbeng Meanchey district, in Preah Vihear. The demonstrators, from Brame, Srae Preang and Bos Tom villages, claimed Lan Feng Company was bulldozing their farmland.
On 20 May 2012, garment workers from SL factory protested in Phnom Penh to demand better working conditions.

On 19 and 20 May 2012, 135 ethnic Kouy families protested in Tbeng Meanchey district, in Preah Vihear. The demonstrators, from Brame, Srae Preang and Bos Tom villages, claimed Lan Feng Company was bulldozing their farmland.
On 19 May 2012, garment workers from SL factory protested in Phnom Penh to demand better working conditions.

On 17 May 2012, workers from SL Garment Processing protested outside SL1 and SL2 factories, in Phnom Penh. Their demands included the introduction of accommodation, transportation and attendance bonuses.

On 16 May 2012, security forces fatally shot a teenage girl during a clash with about 200 villagers armed with axes and crossbows, in Kratie province. The villagers were demonstrating as about 400 police and soldiers raided a settlement after community leaders rejected demands to vacate their farmland for several months. The residents of Pro Ma in the Chhlong district's Kampong Damrei commune later accused the military and local police of forcing men and women to strip naked and handcuffing them.
On 02 May 2012, about 2.000 garment workers protested outside New Archid factory in Kandal province. Workers claimed three supervisors punched a union leader and used an electric baton on him.

On 2 May 2012, a Thai soldier was allegedly badly injured by a landmine device placed in the Thai-Cambodian border, near the area surrounding Preah Vihear temple. Thai military accused Cambodia of placing the devices along the border, but the Cambodian government stated the area still have landmines from the Khmer Rouge regime.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 02 May 2012, about 2.000 demonstrators, including members of Boeung Kak and Borei Keila communities, marched through the streets of Phnom Penh, to demand compensation for their eviction. The group was beaten by riot police, and six women were injured.

On 02 May 2012, more than 700 striking garment workers protested outside SH clothing factory in Phnom Penh. The workers burned tyres to try to force the management to negotiate their demands, which included an increase in their basic salary.

On 02 May 2012, about 700 garment workers protested outside the Lim Line factory in Russey Keo district, Phnom Penh. Their demands included $10 accommodation allowance and the dismissal of a supervisor.

On 02 May 2012, riot police blocked a group of around 100 protesters from marching to the local offices of the World Bank and the European Union, in Phnom Penh. The police hit and kicked the protesters, injuring at least five people. The group, residents from Boueng Kak lake area, demanded compensation for being evicted from their homes to make way for a luxury development.

On 01 May 2012, about 100 residents from Boeung Kak lake area protested outside Cambodia's National Assembly in Phnom Penh. They demanded land titles they said they were promised after being evicted from their homes. About a dozen women stripped down to their underwear during the protest. About 100 police officers stood by, but the crowd dispersed peacefully.
On 01 May 2012, about 6000 workers marched in Phnom Penh to mark International Labour Day. The demonstrators claimed for pay increases, better working standards and the creation of a labour court.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 30 April 2012, more than 150 protesters from Boeung Kak lake and Borei Keila communities marched through the streets of Phnom Penh. The demonstrators were bound in chains to symbolize their struggle, related to land disputes in the capital.

On 28 April 2012, about 50 families in Banlung town, Ratanak Kiri, protested against a rubber company's attempt to demolish their houses. Villagers wielded axes and blocks of wood, and chased away about 100 employees from Fwif Rubber Plantation Company.

On 26 April 2012, activist Chhut Vuthy was fatally shot while documenting illegal logging in Veal Bei commune, Mondol Seima, Koh Kong province. A military police officer, believed to be the shooter, was also killed, shot with his own gun during a fight with a security guard who tried to disarm him. Commune not found.

On 26 April 2012, a fight occurred between striking workers and workers who wanted to end their protest, in SH garment factory in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh. Three workers suffered minor injuries.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 26 April 2012, more than 100 villagers from Boeung Kak lake, Borei Keila and Street 347 gathered at Freedom Park in Phnom Penh. The demonstrators intended to walk to Prime Minister Hun Sen's house with a petition, but were blocked by about 100 police and security district guards.

On 25 April 2012, more than 1.000 workers protested outside Anful garment factory in Samrong Tong district, Kampong Speu. The striking workers demanded travelling allowances and payment for overtime work.

On 25 April 2012, more than 700 workers protested outside Fabric Art factory in Samrong Tong district, Kampong Speu. The striking workers had a 15-point list of demands that included the reinstatement of workers and improvements to the health and safety of the factory conditions.
On 25 April 2012, a man was killed after his tractor drove over a buried anti-tank mine in a rice field in Tuol Pongro commune, Malai district, Banteay Meanchey province.

On 25 April 2012, more than 700 workers continued to protest outside SH garment factory in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh. The workers had nine demands, including the sacking of administration officials, and an increase in their salaries.

From 20 to 24 April 2012, more than 700 striking workers protested outside SH garment factory in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh. The workers had nine demands, including the sacking of administration officials, and an increase in their salaries.
On 23 April 2012, a drunk soldier threw a Chinese made mine into a house in Banteay Ampil district, Oddar Meanchey, seriously injuring five people.

From 20 to 24 April 2012, more than 700 striking workers protested outside SH garment factory in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh. The workers had nine demands, including the sacking of administration officials, and an increase in their salaries.

From 20 to 24 April 2012, more than 700 striking workers protested outside SH garment factory in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh. The workers had nine demands, including the sacking of administration officials, and an increase in their salaries.

On 21 April 2012, a clash occurred between military police officers and about 300 villagers from Pi Thnou commune blocking National Road 76, in Kratie Province. Police officers claimed they were attacked with knives, while the villagers claimed they were beaten by the authorities.

From 20 to 24 April 2012, more than 700 striking workers protested outside SH garment factory in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh. The workers had nine demands, including the sacking of administration officials, and an increase in their salaries.

From 20 to 24 April 2012, more than 700 striking workers protested outside SH garment factory in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh. The workers had nine demands, including the sacking of administration officials, and an increase in their salaries.

assoc_actor_1: Former Government of Thailand (2011-2014); UDD: United Front for Democracy against Dictatorship
notes: On 14 April 2012, about 30000 'Red Shirt' (United Front for Democracy Against Dictatorship) supporters and former Thai premier Thaksin Shinawatra held a rally in Siem Reap (Siem Reap). The event was the first major rally Thaksin attended since being toppled from power by a military coup in 2006.
On 07 April 2012, more than 1.000 veterans and disabled soldiers demonstrated in Siem Reap town (Siem Reap) over the late and incomplete issuing of their pensions.

On 06 April 2012, about 200 villagers from Kampong Damrei commune blocked the road from Kratie town to Chhlong district, in Kratie province. The villagers, involved in a land dispute with Kasotim company, demonstrated after one of their representatives was arrested by authorities.

On 05 April 2012, 20 villagers from Boeung Kake lake community protested outside the municipal police headquarters in Phnom Penh. They accused police officials of not taking action against a case of violence and theft in their community.

On 05 April 2012, a fight occurred between residents from Trapaing Anchang village, and evicted families who had recently moved to the village, located in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh. The fight occurred when the families invited doctors to visit them, but were denied entrance by the village chief. Nine people were injured, two of them seriously.

On 03 April 2012, about 300 villagers from Kbal Trach commune protested outside the office of Pheapimex Group, in Krakor district, Pursat. The protesters, from six different villages, demanded the company to stop clearing their lands.

On 2 April 2012, the father of a candidate from the Sam Rainsy Party (SRP) was shot dead by three unidentified armed men who entered his home in Siem Reap province. SRP politicians claimed the murder was an intimidation tactic by the ruling party, months before communal elections. Location coded: commune where the candidate will run for the elections.

On 31 March 2012, about 500 villagers from Pithnou/Pir Thnu commune blocked National Road 76 for nearly ten hours, in Snuol district, Kratie province. The villagers were protesting to demand local authorities to help settle a land dispute with four private companies.

On 31 March 2012, two young boys were killed and a woman was seriously injured after an unexploded ordinance (UXO) exploded in Anlong Veng district, Oddar Meanchey province. The boys had found the B40 rocket in the forest near their house and played with it.

On 27 March 2012, about 100 police officers violently suppressed a protest near Win Shing-tex Cambodia garment factory, in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh. About 900 striking workers were demanding the reinstatement of five union representatives, and an increase in transportation allowance. The police injured three women.

On 24 March 2012, a group of 100 villagers tried to defrock the chief monk of a local pagoda, in Tuol Pongro commune, Malai, Banteay Meanchey. The villagers claimed he was being disrespectful by praying in Thai, and not in Khmer.

On 22 March 2012, more than 200 villagers protested in front of the Battambang provincial court. They demanded the court to reconsider its decision to give a plot of land to suspected land speculators.

On 22 March 2012, about 100 Boeung Kak lake residents protested in the streets of Phnom Penh, carrying banners and dragging scarecrows representing corrupt officials. They demanded explanations about the land designated for evicted residents. They later burned the effigies.

On 21 March 2012, more than 300 villagers blocked National road 76 for more than four hours. The villagers, from Pir Thnu commune, Snuol district, in Kratie province, are involved in a land dispute with the Dai Nam company, and demanded from the authorities a resolution for their case. Military police arrested one villager.

On 21 March 2012, a representative for the Coalition of Apparel Workers' Democratic Union (C.CAWDU) was injured when he was struck over the head numerous times, during a protest outside Evergreen Garment Company factory, in Por Sen Chey district, Phnom Penh. The victim claimed he was beaten by a rival from the National Union Alliance Chambers of Cambodia (NACC).

From 15 to 19 March 2012, more than 400 workers protested outside the Hwa Sin Print factory, in Chaom Chao commune, Por Senchey district, Phnom Penh. The workers demanded the reinstatement of a union representative, and the improvement of their working conditions.

From 15 to 19 March 2012, more than 400 workers protested outside the Hwa Sin Print factory, in Chaom Chao commune, Por Senchey district, Phnom Penh. The workers demanded the reinstatement of a union representative, and the improvement of their working conditions.

On 17 March 2012, five farmers were injured, three of them seriously, when a landmine exploded as they cooked rice in a field in Trapaing Ser village, Snuol district, Kratie province. Coordinates for the village not found.

From 15 to 19 March 2012, more than 400 workers protested outside the Hwa Sin Print factory, in Chaom Chao commune, Por Senchey district, Phnom Penh. The workers demanded the reinstatement of a union representative, and the improvement of their working conditions.

From 15 to 19 March 2012, more than 400 workers protested outside the Hwa Sin Print factory, in Chaom Chao commune, Por Senchey district, Phnom Penh. The workers demanded the reinstatement of a union representative, and the improvement of their working conditions.

From 15 to 19 March 2012, more than 400 workers protested outside the Hwa Sin Print factory, in Chaom Chao commune, Por Senchey district, Phnom Penh. The workers demanded the reinstatement of a union representative, and the improvement of their working conditions.

On 14 March 2012, about 70 residents of Boeung Kak lake gathered outside the Phnom Penh municipal hall. The protesters asked the city officials to include their 58 families in an inclusion zone that would secure their eligibility for land titles.

On 14 March 2012, almost 400 workers protested in front of the Hwa Sin Print factory, in Chaom Chao commune, Por Senchey district, Phnom Penh. The workers demanded the reinstatement of a union representative, and the improvement of their working conditions.

On 10 March 2012, two boys were killed when a B-40 grenade exploded, in Kandorl commune, Botum Sakor district, Koh The boys had found the device, believed to be from the civil era period, and were playing with it, when it exploded.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 09 March 2012, 400 residents from Boeung Kak lake and Borei Keila communities marched through Daun Penh district, in Phnom Penh, to mark International Women's Day. The women carried placards with images of events where authorities used violence to evict villagers.

On 09 March 2012, a group of 30 university students carried signs and chanted anti-domestic abuse slogans in Tuol Kork district, in Phnom Penh, to mark International Women's Day. The students were dressed in skirts and sashes, a traditional Khmer clothing, made from newspaper articles reporting domestic abuse.

From 05 to 08 March 2012, more than 1.000 villagers in Prey Veng (Prey Veng) town blocked traffic on National Road 11, outside the office of the Cambodian People's Party. The villagers demanded a decrease in the price of water, from 1,800 riels per cubic metre to 1,200 riels.

From 05 to 08 March 2012, more than 1.000 villagers in Prey Veng (Prey Veng) town blocked traffic on National Road 11, outside the office of the Cambodian People's Party. The villagers demanded a decrease in the price of water, from 1,800 riels per cubic metre to 1,200 riels.

From 05 to 08 March 2012, more than 1.000 villagers in Prey Veng (Prey Veng) town blocked traffic on National Road 11, outside the office of the Cambodian People's Party. The villagers demanded a decrease in the price of water, from 1,800 riels per cubic metre to 1,200 riels.

From 05 to 08 March 2012, more than 1.000 villagers in Prey Veng (Prey Veng) town blocked traffic on National Road 11, outside the office of the Cambodian People's Party. The villagers demanded a decrease in the price of water, from 1,800 riels per cubic metre to 1,200 riels.

On 1 March 2012, a warhead of a 60-mm shell exploded, injuring 20 children, at a school in Preah Vihear's Kulen district. One of the children had picked up an unexploded 60-mm shell from a field nearby and brought it to play in the classroom.

On 29 February 2012, more than 200 villagers gathered in protest in Samrong Thom commune, Kien Svay district, Kandal. The villagers urged the National Authority for Land Dispute Resolution to resolve their long-standing dispute with a CPP official.

On 28 February 2012, more than 500 ethnic minority villagers who live along the Se San River marched on foot and led a boat procession to the Lower Se San 2 Hydroelectric Dam construction site, near Stung Treng city. The group protested against the construction of the Vietnamese-led hydroelectric dam that will relocate them from their ancestral land.

On 28 February 2012, a man was severely beaten by a mob after stealing a motorbike in Por Senchey district, in Phnom Penh. The owner of the bike noticed it was stolen and yelled for help, leading the locals to detained the thief. The police intervened as the man was being severely beaten, and arrested him.
On 27 February 2012, three men were injured after one of them stepped on a landmine in Samlot district, Battambang. The men had been clearing a forest to cultivate corn.

On 27 February 2012, about 100 former residents of Borei Keila community protested in the ploth of land reserved for the evicted families in Phnom Penh. The group lined in the pavement next to two buildings under construction before occupying an adjacent road for an hour.

On 23 February 2012, nearly 2,000 workers blocked National Road 7 for 10 minutes, before moving their protest to the gates of Medtecs (Cambodia) factory in Kampong Siem district's Manhattan Industrial Garden, in Kampong Cham province. The workers shattered the windows of their factory with stones. About 400 police and military police were deployed, but they did not engage with the protesters.

On 23 February 2012, around 2.000 Cambodian garment workers blocked a national highway and vandalized the factory Manhattan Textile and Garment Corp in Kampong Cham Special Industrial Economic Zone. They claimed the company had refused to implement benefits ordered by a labor arbitration body. 200 military and regular police were sent to restore order.

On 23 February 2012, more than 100 Boeung Kak lake residents, wearing traditional outfits and carrying Buddha statues, protested outside Phnom Penh Municipal Court. The demonstrators stood in support of four villagers who appeared in the court in connection to allegations that they insulted and obstructed authorities during a protest in November 2011.

On 22 February 2012, nearly 3,000 striking workers from the Manhattan Cambodia garment factory protested outside the provincial hall in Kampong Cham. The workers demanded the implementation of better working conditions mandated by an arbitration body.

On 21 February 2012, more than 300 Tumpoun ethnic minority villagers captured four security guards of a rubber plantation company and another staffer, tied them up and held them hostage, in Lumphat district, in Ratanakkiri province. The event occurred after a dispute between workers from the Jing Zhong Ri Cambodia Co Ltd and villagers.

On 21 February 2012, workers protested outside the Magnate Footwear Co. Ltd's factory in Choam Chao commune, Phnom Penh. The striking workers were demanding the reinstatement of three union representatives, and the improvement of working conditions.

On 20 February 2012, about 2,000 workers from the Manhattan Textile and Garment Corp. in the province's Special Industrial Economic Zone in Kampong Cham marched to provincial government offices. They demanded the implementation of better working conditions mandated by an arbitration body.

On 20 February 2012, a man opened fire on a crowd of striking garment workers, injuring three women, at Manhattan Special Economic Zone ( SEZ) situated in Bavet city. About 3,000 workers had gathered to demand better working conditions, but they started burning tyres and the factories' properties. The man ran away.

On 20 February 2012, about 300 workers protested outside the Magnate Footwear Co. Ltd's factory in Choam Chao commune, Phnom Penh. The striking workers were demanding the reinstatement of three union representatives, and the improvement of working conditions.
On 19 February 2012, a 49-year-old broke his right ankle after stepping on a landmine while he was searching for vegetables, in Thma Puok district, Banteay Meanchey province.
