On 19 February 2012, a 58-year-old man suffered minor injuries after stepping on a mine while he was hunting rabbits, in Thma Puok district, Banteay Meanchey province.

On 16 February 2012, more than 1,000 striking workers from Sun Well Shoes Co Ltd factory blocked National Road 4 for half an hour, before being dispersed by police. The striking workers had a list with 21 demands, including the firing of an administrative manager.

On 15 February 2012, more than 500 workers from the Sun Well Shoes Co Ltd factory protested in Phnom Penh. The striking workers had a list with 21 demands, including the firing of an administrative manager.
On 14 February 2012, a man was nearly beaten to death by villagers and arrested for allegedly stealing cows in Phnum Sruoch district, Kampong Speu.

On 09 February 2012, about 300 villagers gathered outside the provincial court in Chbar Mon, Kampong Speu, to demand the release of two detained villagers and to urge the court not to delay questioning another villager who had been summonsed. The group of villagers, involved in two separate land disputes, claimed the police, military police and soldiers threatened them with assault rifles.

On 3 February 2012, eight Cambodian farmers were killed and one was seriously injured after their truck hit two old anti-tank mines, on an unmarked road in Ou Sampoar commune, Malai district, in Banteay Meanchey province.

On 02 February 2012, a group of 170 villagers blocked machines of the Cheat Aphiwat Co Ltd from razing land in Banteay Chhmar commune, Banteay Meanchey province. The villagers, from Thma Puok district in Banteay Meanchey and from Banteay Ampil in Oddar Meanchey province, protested against the private agro-development company they say is bulldozing their property.

On 01 February 2012, about 300 workers burned tyres in front of Moon Apparel (Cambodia) Co. garment factory on the outskirts of Phnom Penh. The workers protested against the alleged firing of five union representatives in the previous week.

On 01 February 2012, more than 100 former Boeung Kak residents gathered in front of the City Hall in Phnom Penh. They demanded more money as compensation for their eviction, claiming they could only afford to buy land but not houses to build, with the amout previously accepted of US$ 8500 of compensation

source: Phnom Penh Post; States News Service (United States)
notes: On 01 February 2012, 50 villagers from Borei Keila blocked traffic in front of City Hall to demand that Phnom Penh Municipal Governor order the developer Phanimex Co. to compensate them for the demolition of their homes. When two of the women villagers removed their clothing in protest, the police arrested five villagers and beat another two unconscious. Some rioters also fought with police and security guards.

On 1 February 2012, 50 villagers from Borei Keila gathered in front of City Hall to demand that Phnom Penh Municipal Governor order developer Phanimex Co. to compensate them for the demolition of their homes. When two of the women villagers removed their clothing in protest, the police arrested five villagers and beat another two unconscious.

On 31 January 2012, more than 100 villagers were blocked by nearly two dozen police and military police as they tried to march to provincial hall in Bavel, Battambang. The villagers were protesting against the arrest of two residents, accused of stealing property. There were no reports of violence.

On 26 January 2012, more than 300 villagers from two districts protested in front of the provincial court in Chbar Mon, Kampong Speu over two land disputes. The villagers demanded the release of a mother of seven, jailed in December 2011 after she had been summonsed to the court over one of the disputes. The villagers were from Treng Trayoeng commune in Phnom Sruoch district and Omlaing commune in Thpong district.

assoc_actor_1: Boeung Kak Communal Group (Cambodia); Borei Keila Communal Group (Cambodia); Dey Krahorm Communal Group (Cambodia); Women (Cambodia)
notes: On 24 January 2012, about 300 former Dey Krahorm residents protested to mark the three-year anniversary of the eviction at the site where they lived in Phnom Penh. The group, joined by Boeung Kak and Borei Keila communal groups, took off their shoes and placed them together to spell 'development', before marching a 50-metre long protest banner to the National Assembly.

On 23 January 2012, hundreds of workers protested in front of Shimano Cambodia Co Ltd factory, in Samroang Tong district, Kampong Speu. The striking workers demanded the reinstatement of a disabled administration chief who had been removed from his position and shifted to another place within the factory.

On 21 January 2012, villagers from Tnort Chum commune in Krakor district, Pursat, protested in front of Pheapimex Group's office. The villagers attempted to prevent the company from clearing their land.

On 20 January 2012, hundreds of workers protested in front of Shimano Cambodia Co Ltd factory, in Samroang Tong district, Kampong Speu. The striking workers demanded the reinstatement of a disabled administration chief who had been removed from his position and shifted to another place within the factory.

On 18 and 19 January 2012, more than 400 villagers blocked National Road 76A in Kratie province for 24 hours. The villagers, from Pir Thnu commune, protested against the shooting of four villagers on 18 January by securty guards hired by the agricultural development firm TTY, involved in a long -running land dispute with the villagers.

On 19 January 2012, nearly 200 garment workers were blocked by 30 police officers after trying to march to the Ministry of Labour, in Phnom Penh. The workers, from Kwei Yang factory in Kandal province, were on strike in response to the dismissal of seven union leaders.

On 18 and 19 January 2012, more than 400 villagers blocked National Road 76A in Kratie province for 24 hours. The villagers, from Pir Thnu commune, protested against the shooting of four villagers on 18 January by security guards hired by the agricultural development firm TTY, involved in a long -running land dispute with the villagers.

On 18 January 2012, four villagers were shot with AK-47s after hundreds of villagers attempted to keep security guards from clearing their cassava fields, in Pir Thnu, Snuol district, Kratie province. The security guards were working for agricultural development firm TTY, involved in a long -running land dispute with the villagers.

On 16 January 2012, more than 200 villagers protested outside a makeshift office owned by Pheapimex company in Krakor district, Pursat. The residents called for their rice fields not to be cleared by the company.

On 16 January 2012, Thai and Cambodian troops were involved in a brief clash at Phu Ma Khua mountain in the disputed border area, near Preah Vihear Temple, in Kantuot commune. About 20 Thai troops were patrolling in the Phu Ma Khua area when they met the Cambodians. The move caused panic among tourists and residents.

On 16 January 2012, more than 100 protesters from Svay Chrum village in Preah Vihear protested in Phnom Penh. The group was blocked by more than 20 police officers from walking to the prime minister's home. The villagers protested against the National Authority of Preah Vihear, as they destroyed their homes to create space for government offices.

On 13 January 2012, a Chinese man was shot to death in broad daylight in Kralanh village, Kbal Trach commune, Krakor district, Pursat province. Authorities were investigating the possibility the killing was motivated by revenge, as the man was the supervisor of a cassava plantation owned by Pheapimix Company, involved in a land dispute with 25 families.

On 12 January 2012, more than 50 villagers from Svay Chrum village, in Preah Vihear, gathered to protest outside Wat Botum pagoda in Phnom Penh. The villagers urged Prime Minister Hun Sen to intervene in an ongoing land dispute with provincial authorities.

On 12 January 2012, a group of family relatives of detainees travelled to Prey Speu Correctional Centre in Chaom Chao commune, Phnom Penh. The group, formed by husbands and fathers of the women and children detained after a protest on 11 January, gathered to plea for their release.

On 11 January 2012, residents of the Borei Keila community in Phnom Penh protested over a forced eviction. 24 women and six children were arrested and held at Prey Speu social affairs rehabilitation centre. The villagers' homes were destroyed the previous week to make way for a commercial real estate project backed by local developer Phanimex Co.

On 11 January 2012, more than 400 striking workers protested outside the Chea Ly garment factory in Dangkor district, Phnom Penh. Workers had begun the strike to demand that the company remove a Chinese manager, and they also demanded the payment of overdue paychecks.

On 11 January 2012, more than 100 residents from two villages blocked National Road No. 2 in Phnom Penh and burned tyres. The villagers, from Srey Snom and Kraing Svay villages in Dangkor district in Phnom Penh, protested against Khutdyvathana company, which they said was digging up dirt from a nearby property.

On 6 January 2012, a deputy police chief was killed by a landmine while patrolling in a forest at the Cambodia-Thailand border, in Choam Ksan district, Preah Vihear. The official died instantly when he triggered a small mine with his hand while on patrol with soldiers.

On 06 January 2012, 50 villagers from Svay Chrum village, in Preah Vihear, gathered to protest outside Wat Botum pagoda in Phnom Penh. The villagers urged Prime Minister Hun Sen to intervene in an ongoing land dispute with provincial authorities.

On 05 January 2012, residents of the Borei Keila community in Phnom Penh protested over a forced eviction, gathering outside the United States, French and British embassies to call for intervention in their case. Their homes were destroyed to make way for a commercial real estate project backed by local developer Phanimex Co.

On 04 January 2012, residents of the Borei Keila community in Phnom Penh protested over a forced eviction by marching to the US embassy. Their homes were destroyed to make way for a commercial real estate project backed by local developer Phanimex Co. Police moved in to disperse the crowd, but no violence occurred.

On 03 January 2012, about 60 animal slaughterhouse operators from Rolea Ba'eir district, Kampong Chhnang, protested against what they claim is extortion by the provincial director of the veterinary department. The protesters claimed they were forced to give money to receive their business licenses.

On 03 January 2012, more than 400 striking garment workers protested outside Kwei Yang Co Ltd, in Ang Snuol district, Kandal province. The workers had nine demands for the factory's management, including the review of a monthly health bonus. The protest ended after an agreement was settled between managers and workers.

On 3 January 2012, residents of the Borei Keila community in Phnom Penh clashed with police over a forced eviction, leaving a dozen people injured. The villagers used bricks and crowbars to confront the group of men hired to provide security for developer Phanimex, the company responsible for demolishing the nearly 300 homes in the area. More than 500 police officers accompanied the demolition process, and fired warning shots and used sticks and electric batons to keep residents at bay.

On 2 January 2012, about 50 rioting residents, some of whom wielded bricks and crowbars, prevented more than 10 local officials and security guards from dismantling 27 houses in Borei Keila community, Phnom Penh. Residents claimed the officials and guards were trying to force people to move to resettlement areas.

On 31 December 2011, more than 200 striking garment workers protested outside Kwei Yang Co Ltd, in Ang Snuol district, Kandal province. The workers had nine demands for the factory's management, including the review of a monthly health bonus.
Property destruction: On 30 Dec 2011, about 300 armed soldiers and military police officials dismantled the homes of more than 100 families in Kantuot commune, in Choam Ksan district, Preah Vihear.

On 28 December 2011, more than 100 Boeung Kak lake residents protested in Phnom Penh after a group of Daun Penh district police officials warned residents to stop rebuilding their homes. The villagers prevented the officials from confiscating their tools.

On 21 December 2011, about 50 villagers converged to a building where authorities were evicting a man from his home, in Borei Keila community, Phnom Penh. The villagers broke down a door which had been locked by the government agents, who fled the scene.
On 20 December 2011, about 60 villagers protested in front of the Battambang provincial court, to ask for the release of a villager who was beaten and arrested by authorities the day before.

On 20 December 2011, about 150 villagers protested outside Kampong Speu provincial court, to show their support to a woman who was being trial over a land dispute. The court decided not to arrest her, fearing the villagers' reaction.

On 20 December 2011, about 100 villagers protested in front of the National Assembly in Phnom Penh, holding a 230-metre krama, a traditional Cambodian scarf. The krama, containing thumbprints of villagers, was submitted as a petition against the passage of laws they claimed would undermine their rights.

On 19 December 2011, a man was beaten by police officers and later arrested, in Ratanak Mondol district, Battambang. The incident occurred after about 30 villagers scuffled with the police to rescue two representatives who were being detained due to a land dispute.

From 16 to 18 December 2011, about 200 villagers from Yeav village in Kampong Cham commune protested against Chhun Hong Rubber Better Company. The villagers demanded the company to stop clearing their farmland.

From 16 to 18 December 2011, about 200 villagers from Yeav village in Kampong Cham commune protested against Chhun Hong Rubber Better Company. The villagers demanded the company to stop clearing their farmland.

From 16 to 18 December 2011, about 200 villagers from Yeav village in Kampong Cham commune protested against Chhun Hong Rubber Better Company. The villagers demanded the company to stop clearing their farmland.

On 16 December 2011, about 30 workers from footwear manufacturer Huey Chuen protested in front of the Labour Ministry in Phnom Penh. The workers were protesting being shifted to a new factory about two kilometres from the one they work at Dangkor district.

On 15 December 2011, Cambodian troops fired shots at a Thai navy helicopter near the border between the two countries, in Mondol Seima district, Koh Kong. The helicopter was on a mission to supply a border post in Trat province. There was no injuries. According to authorities, the incident was the result of a misunderstanding.
On 15 December 2011, nearly 100 vendors protested outside Tuol Kork market, in Phnom Penh, after authorities dismantled their stalls without just cause.

On 14 December 2011, police clashed with nearly 100 Borei Keila community representatives in Phnom Penh. The villagers were protesting over the amount of compensation they had received for a land dispute with Phanimex Company.
On 13 December 2011, more than 100 striking workers set fire to tyres outside Shinglecom Cambodia garment factory in Dangkor district, Phnom Penh.

On 12 December 2011, about 200 people gathered to protest in Phnom Proek district, Battambang, against the measuring of disputed land by government officials and Suon Mean Sambath Company. A fight over a confiscated camera led to armed guards opening fire with AK-47s and seriously injuring three people.

On 08 December 2011, more than 200 workers protested outside Shinglecom Cambodia garment factory in Dangkor district, Phnom Penh. They demanded the reinstatement of a representative of their recently formed union, and for the improvement of work conditions.

On 07 December 2011, villagers clashed with the security guards from Horizon Agriculture Development Co, in Krasaing village, Snuol commune, Kratie province. The villagers were attempting to prevent Horizon Agriculture Development Co from bulldozing their cassava plantations.

On 7 December 2011, the police clashed with about 50 villagers hired by businessmen to guard land, in Boeung Tram village, Ampil Pram Doeum commune, in Battambang. They burned seven cars and two excavators, and also injured one police officer.

On 07 December 2011, about 50 villagers from Lor Peang village, in Kampong Chhnang, protested outside the Supreme Court in Phnom Penh. The villagers had been involved for decades in a land dispute with the company KDC International.

On 06 December 2011, about 200 villagers from two communes (Koh Sdach and Tham Sar) blocked National Road 48 in Koh Kong province to draw attention to their land dispute with the Union Development Group. The police attempted to drive their trucks through, but no violence occurred.

On 06 December 2011, about 100 villagers were allegedly threatened by soldiers brandishing AK-47s, in Krasaing village, Snuol commune, Kratie province. The villagers were attempting to prevent Horizon Agriculture Development Co from bulldozing their cassava plantations.

On 4 December 2011, seven men severely beat a judge at a restaurant in Sen Monorom town, Mondulkiri province. The attackers, suspected of being illegal loggers, dragged the victim into a car and dumped him on the side of a road.

On 03 December 2011, striking workers from Cambo Handsome 1 garment factory protested outside the home of Prime Minister Hun Sen, urging him to intervene in their dispute. They demanded the reinstatement of three union leaders, and better working conditions.

On 02 December 2011, striking workers from Cambo Handsome 1 garment factory protested outside Wat Botum in Phnom Penh. The workers also gathered outside the home of Prime Minister Hun Sen, urging him to intervene in their dispute. They demanded the reinstatement of three union leaders, and better working conditions.
On 1 December 2011, a driver and five farmer workers were injured in Veal Veng district, Pursat province when their truck drove over an anti-tank mine, exploding the device.

On 30 November 2011, about 50 villagers from Kampong Speu protested outside the Appeal Court in Phnom Penh. The Appeal Court delayed a hearing into a land dispute between the villagers and a local NGO in Treng Trayoeng commune's village 3 in Phnom Sruoch district.

On 29 November 2011, striking workers protested outside the Cambo Handsome garment factory in Phnom Penh. The workers were protesting against the suspension of three union leaders. The police blocked the protesters from marching from the factory to the Ministry of Labour, injuring at least 20 people.

On 27 and 28 November 2011, villagers protested in Thma Puok district, Banteay Meanchey province, in an attempt to stop a private company from clearing their land and to ask for intervention by local authorities.

On 28 November 2011, villagers from Boeung Kak Lake community gathered in front of Phnom Penh's City Hall to protest the loss of their land to a Chinese-Cambodian company. Some villagers scuffled with authorities, and four women were injured and another four were detained.

On 28 November 2011, more than 100 striking workers protested at Cambo Handsome 1 garment factory in Phnom Penh, after blocking a street into Prey Sar market. They called on the company to withdraw charges against a union leader, accused of stealing T-shirts from the factory.

On 27 and 28 November 2011, villagers protested in Thma Puok district, Banteay Meanchey province, in an attempt to stop a private company from clearing their land and to ask for intervention by local authorities.
On 27 November 2011, striking workers protested outside the Cambo Handsome garment factory in Phnom Penh. The workers were protesting against the suspension of three union leaders.

On 26 November 2011, nearly 2.000 workers protested at Dangkor district hall, in Phnom Penh, after the arrest of a union leader from the Labour Friendship Union at Cambo Handsome Ltd garment factory. The unionist was released following the protest.

On 24 November 2011, the wife of a deputy police chief and an 18-year-old woman were seriously injured by a grenade in Paoy Paet town, Banteay Meanchey. The grenade was planted on the doorstep of their home. A military official was arrested in connection to the crime.
On 24 November 2011, hotel workers protested outside the Angkor Village Hotel and Resort, in Siem Reap city, to call for the reinstatement of workers who had been unlawfully sacked for unionising.

On 23 November 2011, hotel workers protested outside the Angkor Village Hotel and Resort, in Siem Reap city, to call for the reinstatement of workers who had been unlawfully sacked for unionizing. The police ended the protest and detained two unionists.

On 22 November 2011, villagers from Borei Keila community clashed with the police during a demonstration in Phnom Penh. Police officers beat at demonstrators, who in turn threw objects at the officers.

On 21 November 2011, about 300 villagers from Kandal province delivered petitions to embassies in Phnom Penh. Afterwards, the villagers, involved in land disputes with private companies, marched to the provincial hall and called for Prime Minister Hun Sen to help them.

On 17 November 2011, more than 100 Borei Keila villagers protested against Phanimex Company in the streets of Phnom Penh. The protesters, holding banners and a pig's head, set tyres on fire before marching to the office of the company, to claim a resolution to their land dispute.

On 10 November 2011, about 300 villagers broke down barricades and entered the grounds of rubber firm CRCK, in Prey Lang Forest, Kampong Thom. The police confronted the villagers. The villagers intended to expose illegal logging in the forest. Location coded: Sandan district, where a considerable part of the forest is located.
On 03 November 2011, about 400 villagers from Meak Bei village in Prek Kak commune, in Kampong Cham, protested after workers from a private company attempted to clear their houses with excavators.

On 02 November 2011, about 15 villagers from among 386 families from Borei Keila community continued to protest outside Prampi Makara district hall, in Phnom Penh. The group urged the government to intervene in a contentious land dispute with Phanimex Company.

On 01 November 2011, a group of 100 people protested outside Sihanoukville Municipal Hall. The group, who is facing eviction from their shelters near Sihanoukville Autonomous Port, demanded a resolution before they are forced to move.

On 01 November 2011, about 50 villagers representing 386 families from Borei Keila community protested outside Prampi Makara district hall, in Phnom Penh. The group urged the government to intervene in a contentious land dispute with Phanimex Company.

On 29 October 2011, a man accused of being a sorcerer was killed in Kong Pisei district, Kampong Speu province. Two men were arrested a few hours after the crime in Kantuoth village, Teuk La'ak commune.

On 27 October 2011, 77 families in Snuol district, Kratie province, continued to protest and block a private company from clearing their cassava trees. The villagers, from Khyoem/Khsuem commune, are involved in a land dispute against Dai Nam company.

From 19 to 26 October 2011, nearly 80 families in Snuol district, Kratie province, protested in an attempt to prevent a private company of clearing their cassava trees. The villagers, from Khyoem (Khsuem) commune, blocked 10 excavators from clearing farmland.

On 19 October 2011, 85 residents, representatives of 32 families living in Chamkarmon district, staged a protest in Tonle Bassac commune, Phnom Penh. The demonstrators asked for Prime Minister Hun Sen to intervene on their behalf against the Thai Bun Roong company, which they claim is forcing them to sell their land at below market value.

On 18 October 2011, more than 200 residents of Boeung Kak lake area gathered outside Phnom Penh Municipal Court to protest. They demonstrated while four villagers, who had filed complaints after their homes were demolished, responded to summonses for questioning.

On 17 October 2011, about 250 villagers protested in Srayong commune, Preah Vihear province, against alleged land-grabbing by rubber firm Siladamich Company. Their path was blocked by company security guards and police, but no clash was reported.

From 16 to 17 October 2011, nearly 50 vendors from Boeung Trabek Plaza in Chamkarmon district, Phnom Penh, protested to demand that their landlord further discount rent because they were not attracting enough customers.

On 17 October 2011, Boeung Kak lake residents protested at a site where homes were destroyed in September, in Daun Penh district, Phnom Penh. They appealed to Prime Minister Hun Sen to intervene in their land dispute case.

From 13 to 16 October 2011, nearly 200 villagers from O'Ampril village gathered to protest in front of Anlong Veng commune office, Oddar Meanchey. They claimed they had been illegally refused the right to register to vote by their commune chief.

From 16 to 17 October 2011, nearly 50 vendors from Boeung Trabek Plaza in Chamkarmon district, Phnom Penh, protested to demand that their landlord further discount rent because they were not attracting enough customers.

From 13 to 16 October 2011, nearly 200 villagers from O'Ampril village gathered to protest in front of Anlong Veng commune office, Oddar Meanchey. They claimed they had been illegally refused the right to register to vote by their commune chief.

From 13 to 16 October 2011, nearly 200 villagers from O'Ampril village gathered to protest in front of Anlong Veng commune office, Oddar Meanchey. They claimed they had been illegally refused the right to register to vote by their commune chief.

On 12 and 13 October 2011, striking garment workers protested outside the Meroson Cambodia Co Ltd factory, in Dangkor district, Phnom Penh. The workers had several demands, including the reinstatement of three employees allegedly fired for joining a union.

On 13 October 2011, former Boeung Kak lakeside residents protested in Freedom Park, Phnom Penh. The villagers, who accepted compensation after facing forced eviction, criticized a recent television portrayal of their living situation. They also requested additional government compensation.

On 12 and 13 October 2011, striking garment workers protested outside the Meroson Cambodia Co Ltd factory, in Dangkor district, Phnom Penh. The workers had several demands, including the reinstatement of three employees allegedly fired for joining a union.

On 11 October 2011, striking workers continued to protest outside the M&V garment factory in Kampong Chhnang city. They demanded the reinstatement of 20 employees allegedly fired for attempting to establish an union at the factory.

On 11 October 2011, about 50 students continued to protest outside the Elton International School, a Korean Language Institute, in Kampong Cham city. They claimed the school had cheated them out of money by making false promises of scholarships and overseas jobs.

From 07 to 10 October 2011, striking workers continued to protest outside the M&V garment factory in Kampong Chhnang city to demand the reinstatement of workers. On 10 October, there was a brief clash between rioters and the police, as the groups started to push each other.

On 10 October 2011, about 50 students protested outside Elton International School in Kampong Cham city. They claimed the school had failed to get them jobs in South Korea or pay the US$1500 scholarships promised to each student.

On 10 October 2011, hotel workers and supporters protested outside the Angkor Village Hotel and Resort in Siem Reap city. The hotel continued to refuse to reinstate 67 workers fired between July and August, despite an Arbitration Council ruling saying they were unlawfully dismissed.

From 07 to 10 October 2011, striking workers continued to protest outside the M&V garment factory in Kampong Chhnang city. They demanded the reinstatement of 20 employees allegedly fired for attempting to establish an union at the factory.

On 09 October 2011, nearly 200 vendors from Tonob market in Phnom Penh protested for a second day outside Prime Minister Hun Sen's house in Takhmao town, Kandal. They asked for the PM's intervention in what they said was the sudden closure of the market.

From 07 to 10 October 2011, striking workers continued to protest outside the M&V garment factory in Kampong Chhnang city. They demanded the reinstatement of 20 employees allegedly fired for attempting to establish an union at the factory.

On 08 October 2011, vendors from Tonob market in Phnom Penh protested outside Prime Minister Hun Sen's house in Takhmao town, Kandal. They asked for the PM's intervention in what they said was the sudden closure of the market. District police reportedly attempted to confiscate the protestors' motorbikes, and one man was injured when he attempted to take his motorbike back.

From 07 to 10 October 2011, striking workers continued to protest outside the M&V garment factory in Kampong Chhnang city. They demanded the reinstatement of 20 employees allegedly fired for attempting to establish an union at the factory.

On 06 October 2011, striking workers protested near the M&V garment factory in Kampong Chhnang. They demanded the reinstatement of 20 employees allegedly fired for attempting to establish an union at the factory.

On 05 October 2011, hotel workers and supporters protested outside the Angkor Village Hotel and Resort, in Siem Reap city, to demand the reinstatement of workers. Police armed with riot shields entered the hotel, but no violence occurred.

On 03 October 2011, about 200 villagers from Boeung Kak lake community staged a peaceful protest at Freedom Park, Phnom Penh. The villagers, who had accepted compensation after facing eviction, complained that those who had rejected the deal had now been offered on-site relocation.

On 03 October 2011, nearly 100 vendors from Boeng Trabek Plaza, in Chamkarmon district, Phnom Penh, protested to demand that the company running the plaza reduce their rent by 80 per cent. They claimed the plaza had been attracting too few customers.
On 01 October 2011, more than 100 Tonob market vendors in Russei Keo district, Phnom Penh, protested against a sudden and unannounced closure of the market.
On 29 September 2011, a teenage boy was killed and a young man was seriously wounded while playing with cluster bombs they found in a field while tending cattle in Dangkor district, Phnom Penh.

On 27 September 2011, one man was killed and five others injured in a grenade attack at the family home of a provincial director, in Kampong Chhnang. The police suspected the grenade attack was an act of revenge.

On 21 September 2011, armed villagers from Meanchey village, Sre Cha commune (Snoul district, Kratie), blocked a road to protest against district officials and a Vietnamese company who they believe wanted to cheat them of their farmland.

On 21 September 2011, more than 100 striking garment workers protested outside Hung Wah (Cambodia) Garment Manufacturing factory, in Chaom Chao commune, Phnom Penh. The workers demanded the dismissal of a supervisor they accused of denying them the right to take sick leave, after a mass fainting episode in July.

On 18 September 2011, about 500 villagers from six districts in Kratie's Snoul district protested on National Road 7. They blocked the road near Svay Chreah commune in a bid to find a solution to their land dispute with two Vietnamese rubber companies.

On 16 September 2011, a group of protesters from Boeung Kak Lake area clashed with anti-riot police in Phnom Penh. The group was beaten by the police with electric batons and shields, as they tried to break a cordon. An activist was beaten unconscious and taken to hospital. The villagers had been evicted from their homes despite an order from Prime Minister Hun Sen setting land aside for their use.

On 15 September 2011, member of 50 families from Lor Peang village, Kampong Tralach district, protested outside the Kampong Chhnang provincial court. They accused the company KDC International of taking their farmland.

On 15 September 2011, nearly 400 garment workers protested outside Zhen Yun factory in Russei Keo district, Phnom Penh. They went on strike and protested for not receiving annual bonuses or appropriate overtime pay.

On 15 September 2011, about 70 hotel staff of Angkor Village Hotel and Resort protested outside Siem Reap court. The court heard charges of illegally demonstrating, inciting criminal acts and defamation against union members.
On 12 September 2011, families from Boeung Kak lake community protested in Phnom Penh over the decision of authorities to cut them out of the on-site relocation deal.

On 08 September 2011, about 150 villagers in Krasaing commune, Romeas Hek district (Svay Rieng), blocked bulldozers belonging to a private company that was attempting to clear a community forest. Mittapheap Company was awarded a 1,230-hectare economic land concession to plant rubber trees in the forest.

On 08 September 2011, more than 30 villagers from Boeung Kak Lake district protested in Phnom Penh. They demanded authorities to solve their land dispute, as a Chinese-Cambodian company owned by a politician from the ruling Cambodian People's Party buried their homes in sand to build a luxury residential area.

On 08 September 2011, about 1,882 workers protested outside Supertex garment factory in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh. The striking workers stopped they protest after it was announced that the company and the Ministry of Labour would pay out the compensation they demanded.

On 01 September 2011, more than 100 villagers from Kandal province gathered in front of the Kandal provincial court. They demanded a resolution to their long-standing land dispute with the Heng Development Company.

On 30 August 2011, villagers from Boeung Kak lake community protested at Daun Penh district's Srah Chak commune office in Phnom Penh. 47 families had been cut out of the Boeung Kak compensation deal, which promised land titles for villagers who had to be relocated for a development project.

On 26 August 2011, more than 300 villagers gathered in Phnom Penh to protest against a plan to relocate them from their land in order to make way for rubber plantations. The villagers claimed they had lived on the land since 1979.

On 25 August 2011, more than 150 villagers from Chamkar Leu district, Kampong Cham, gathered at Freedom Park in Phnom Penh. They protested against a plan to relocate them from three villages they say they have lived in since 1979 to make way for a rubber plantation.

On 24 August 2011, more than 200 workers from the Shimano footwear factory in Samraong, Kampong Speu, continued to protest and burn tyres for the third day. The striking workers demanded that their employer reinstate three sacked union representatives.
On 23 August 2011, seven Cambodians were injured by an explosion of an anti-tank mine in a rubber plantation, in Slor Kram Commune, Svay Chek district in Banteay Meanchey province.

On 22 and 23 August 2011, more than 200 workers protested and burnt tyres outside Shimano Footwear factory in Samrong Tong district, Kampong Speu. The striking workers demanded the company to reinstate three union representatives, who they claim were fired earlier with no justification.

On 23 August 2011, about 200 protestors from Boeung Kak lake community burnt tyres in Phnom Penh. The group of around 42 families were threatened with exclusion from an onsite housing deal. The villagers accused municipal authorities of betraying them.

On 22 and 23 August 2011, more than 200 workers protested and burnt tyres outside Shimano Footwear factory in Samrong Tong district, Kampong Speu. The striking workers demanded the company to reinstate three union representatives, who they claim were fired earlier with no justification.

Movement of forces: On 20 August, Cambodian troops of Brigade No. 9, stationed at the foot of Chak Chreng area, near Preah Vihear temple, Kantuot commune, were pulled back to their barracks in Choam Khsant district of Preah Vihear province.

On 18 August 2011, more than 100 villagers protested in Phnom Penh against the destruction of the country's Prey Lang forest. The group of villagers, which included Kuy indigenous people, were joined by monks and environmental activists. The villagers were detained and questioned by Phnom Penh officials.

On 15 August 2011, more than 30 residents of an Australian-run orphanage protested in the facility, in Norea commune, Sangke district, Battambang. The students protested against the new policy which required residents aged 18 or older to be reintegrated into their communities.

On 11 August 2011, more than 100 villagers living near Sihanoukville blocked National Road 4. They protested against tycoon Kith Meng's proposed lakeside ecotourism development, which they fear will rob them of land they have farmed for decades. Police officials moved the protesters to the side in order to reduce traffic jams.

On 10 August 2011, five boys were injured, four of them seriously, after a 60-millimetre shell they had been playing with exploded near the Peam Chaing rubber plantation in Preah Theat commune, Tboung Khmum province. In the news article, location mentioned is in Kampong Cham province. However, in 2013 part of the province was split, creating Tboung Khmum province.

On 08 August 2011, representatives of 168 families from Kampong Cham's Memot district protested at the provincial governor's home in Kampong Cham. The protesters wanted an intervention on their behalf in an ongoing land dispute with Memot Rubber Plantation.

On 8 August 2011, a Thai soldier (identified as Nikorn Moonha) was killed after stepping on a land mine while on patrol near Ta Khwai Temple at the Thai-Cambodian border, near Surin's Phnom Dongrak District. Location coded: Ta Krabey temple, located near Ta Khwai temple.

On 08 August 2011, about 300 garment workers protested in front of Nugget Textile factory, in Meanchey district, Phnom Penh. They demanded the factory to pay a transportation fee, build a daycare centre and allow pregnant women to leave work 15 minutes early.
On 07 August 2011, more than 200 factory workers gathered at Freedom Park in Phnom Penh. The protestors urged the government to cut taxes on petrol.

On 03 August 2011, more than 30 female workers continued their protest outside the Cambrew headquarters in Phnom Penh. The women were protesting against the company's refusal to pay them overtime for working on Sundays.

On 2 August 2011, dozens of children students from an Australian-run orphanage protested in Norea commune, Sangke district, Battambang. They claimed they were not getting enough food and could not afford school fees, and accused the staff of corruption.

On 2 August 2011, more than 30 female workers continued their protest outside the Cambrew headquarters in Phnom Penh, burning tyres. One woman was hospitalized after reportedly being struck by a company minivan and another three fainted from smoke inhalation. The women were protesting against the company's refusal to pay them overtime for working on Sundays.

From 28 July to 01 August 2011, more than 30 female workers continued to protest outside the Cambrew headquarters in Phnom Penh. The women were protesting against the company's refusal to pay them overtime for working on Sundays.

From 28 July to 01 August 2011, more than 30 female workers continued to protest outside the Cambrew headquarters in Phnom Penh. The women were protesting against the company's refusal to pay them overtime for working on Sundays.

From 28 July to 01 August 2011, more than 30 female workers continued to protest outside the Cambrew headquarters in Phnom Penh. The women were protesting against the company's refusal to pay them overtime for working on Sundays.

From 28 July to 01 August 2011, more than 30 female workers continued to protest outside the Cambrew headquarters in Phnom Penh. The women were protesting against the company's refusal to pay them overtime for working on Sundays.

From 28 July to 01 August 2011, more than 30 female workers continued to protest outside the Cambrew headquarters in Phnom Penh. The women were protesting against the company's refusal to pay them overtime for working on Sundays.

On 27 July 2011, more than 30 female workers protested outside the Cambrew headquarters in Phnom Penh using drums and loudspeakers. The women were protesting against the company's refusal to pay them overtime for working on Sundays.

On 27 July 2011, about 20 armed police arrived violently suppressed a protest outside the Zongtex Garment Factory in Dangkor district, Phnom Penh. About 500 workers were protesting against the dismissal of four of their representatives without any reason in the past week. At least three women were slightly injured.

On 26 July 2011, more than 30 female workers protested outside the Cambrew headquarters in Phnom Penh using drums and loudspeakers. The women were protesting against the company's refusal to pay them overtime for working on Sundays.

On 25 July 2011, villagers entered their fourth day of protest in Krasaing commune, Romeas Hek district, Svay Rieng. The villagers protested against Metapheap company, which was granted a concession to turn a forest into a rubber plantation.
On 25 July 2011, more than 30 women gathered for almost five hours in front of Angkor Brewery's head office on Norodom Boulevard, in Phnom Penh. The women demanded a salary increase.

From 22 to 24 July 2011, about 100 residents from 10 villages protested in front of the office of Metapheap company in Krasaing commune, Romeas Hek district, Svay Rieng. The company was granted a concession to turn a forest into a rubber plantation.

From 22 to 24 July 2011, about 100 residents from 10 villages protested in front of the office of Metapheap company in Krasaing commune, Romeas Hek district, Svay Rieng. The company was granted a concession to turn a forest into a rubber plantation.

From 22 to 24 July 2011, about 100 residents from 10 villages protested in front of the office of Metapheap company in Krasaing commune, Romeas Hek district, Svay Rieng. The company was granted a concession to turn a forest into a rubber plantation.

On 21 July 2011, a Cambodian solider was reportedly killed and another was injured during a clash with Thai soldiers at the border area near Trapaing Prasat district, in Oddar Meanchey. A spokesman for the Council of Ministers claimed that reports of an armed clash were 'not accurate'.

On 20 July 2011, more than 40 families protested for the second straight day over a land dispute in Kien Svay district, Kandal province. The protestors, from Prek Tanup and Kampong Svay villages in Kampong Svay commune have accused a businessman of stealing 38 hectares of their land through false contracts.

On 19 July 2011, more than 40 families protested over a land dispute in Kien Svay district, Kandal province. The protestors, from Prek Tanup and Kampong Svay villages in Kampong Svay commune, have accused a businessman of stealing 38 hectares of their land through false contracts.

On 19 July 2011, police armed with guns, electric batons and shields cracked down on a protest of about 300 people at the Supertex garment factory in Phnom Penh. At least two workers were injured. The protesters were demanding their unpaid wages since the factory closed.

On 12 July 2011, Thai soldiers opened gunfire at least twice and also lobbed grenades in the Thai-Cambodia border, near Ta Moan temple in contested territory in Oddar Meanchey province (Cambodia). The Thai side claimed that the incident was caused by drunk soldiers. The Cambodian side did not retaliate, but soldiers were kept alert.

On 11 July 2011, about 60 residents from Boeung Kak lake community gathered across what remains of the lake in Phnom Penh and burnt tyres. The residents demanded on-site relocation housing, as construction for the development project in the area had officially began.
On 9 July 2011, a teenager died when a mine exploded in Ratanak Mondol district in Battambang. The man ran over the mine in a tractor while ploughing a field for his boss.

On 8 July 2011, a reporter from Resmey 7 Makara newspaper was allegedly beaten by a timber broker in Siem Reap city, after he took pictures of the man's truck, which he believed was transporting illegal lumber.

On 07 July 2011, about 150 representatives of 384 families from Borei Keila community protested outside Prime Minster Hun Sen's house at Ta Khmao town. They demanded the company Phan Imex to fulfill a compensation agreement, rejecting a land offer.

On 07 July 2011, about 200 villagers from Boeung Kak lake community protested outside the Phnom Penh Hotel near City Hall in Daun Penh district, Phnom Penh. The protesters submitted a petition after their request for onsite resettlement was rejected by municipal authorities. Two villagers were arrested after they scuffled with police officers.

On 6 July 2011, a 35-year-old tractor driver was seriously injured in an anti-tank mine explosion in Thma Puok district, in Banteay Meanchey. The farmer had ran over the mine with his tractor while clearing a plantation, injuring his arm and leg.

On 03 July 2011, more than 300 protestors were blocked by police from marching to Prime Minister Hun Sen's Phnom Penh residence. The protesters were demanding their former employer, June Textile workers, to respect an arbitration council ruling to pay them severance pay. No violence was reported.
On 2 July 2011, a 22-year-old farmer was seriously injured when his tractor struck an unexploded ordnance while he ploughed a field in Kamrieng district, Battambang.
On 28 June 2011, a 37-year-old man was killed when his tractor detonated an anti-tank mine, in O'Kondorl village in Santepheap commune, Sampov Loun district, Battambang.
On 24 June 2011, two souvenir sellers were beaten with electric batons by officials from Apsara Authority, outside Banteay Srey temple in Siem Reap.

On 22 June 2011, police violently pushed about 30 villagers from Borei Keila community who were protesting outside Prime Minister Hun Sen's house in Takhmao town. The villagers protested against a relocation scheme.

On 21 June 2011, nearly 100 villagers from 114 families in Kandal province protested in front of the provincial court in Ta Khmau to request the release of a villager arrested in connection with a land dispute with a former deputy provincial governor.
On 20 June 2011, two men were seriously injured after hitting an unexploded ordinance, known as a DK75, at a construction site in Sre Or village in Odong district, Kampong Speu province.

On 20 June 2011, one man died and another was injured when an unexploded ordinance detonated in Chbar Mon town, Kampong Speu province. The man had found two pieces of UXO at a construction site and had thrown one against a tree, causing it to detonate.

On 20 June 2011, villagers from Boeung Kak lake community protested outside Prime Minister Hun Sen's house in Ta Khmao. The villagers, involved in a land dispute, protested against a relocation scheme.

On 19 June 2011, more than 1,000 villagers from Kratie and Mondulkiri provinces blocked National Road 76 in Pi Thnu commune. The villagers demonstrated to request that the Sovann Vuthy Company stop clearing land in the commune.

On 15 June 2011, about 500 villagers from two provinces gathered in front of the Kampong Chhnang Municipal Hall. The villagers, from Krakor district in Pursat and Boribor and Teuk Phos districts in Kampong Chhnang, asked provincial authorities to prevent the Pheapimex Company bulldozing their land before the compensation process was finalized.

On 15 June 2011, security guards confronted about 1,000 garment workers who were protesting outside Kampong Speu provincial court in Chbar Mon. The group demanded the release of a union representative who was arrested after a scuffle with another employee.

On 14 June 2011, more than 300 workers from the Sang Vo garment factory gathered to protest in front of Kampong Speu provincial court. They demanded the release of a union representative who was arrested after a scuffle with another employee.

On 13 June 2011, a 29-year-old man was critically injured when a landmine exploded in Banteay Meanchey province. The man was looking for bamboo shoots in Boeung Tasrey village of Thma Pouk district's Kouk Romiet commune.

On 13 June 2011, more than 1,300 garment workers protested outside Supertex Ltd factory in Phnom Penh's Meanchey district. The workers feared the Taiwanese owner of the factory had sold off company assets and fled without paying them wages.

On 10 June 2011, families living in Ploch village in Trapaing Chor commune (Oral district, Kampong Speu) protested against a relocation offer. The villagers had been involved in a land dispute with a sugar company owned by the wife of ruling party senator Ly Yong Phat.

On 9 June 2011, a violent clash occurred between about 250 armed residents of Damnak Raing and Phnom Touch communes and 300 police and military police officers, in Stock Slat village, Kampong Speu province. One villager was shot and a policeman beaten unconscious, and a total of 11 people were injured.

On 07 and 08 June 2011, more than 100 residents from four villages in Kampong Thom province continued to protest in front of the provincial governor's office. They requested the release of a community representative who was arrested in connection with a land dispute with private company Doung Heng Sengsuna.

On 07 and 08 June 2011, more than 100 residents from four villages in Kampong Thom province continued to protest in front of the provincial governor's office. They requested the release of a community representative who was arrested in connection with a land dispute with private company Doung Heng Sengsuna.

On 06 June 2011, more than 100 residents from four villages in Kampong Thom province marched to the provincial governor's office. They requested the release of a community representative who was arrested in connection with a land dispute with private company Doung Heng Sengsuna.

On 2 June 2011, a 43-year-old man was killed in Kandieng district, Pursat, after he allegedly provoked villagers with threats of black magic. The man was beaten to death and found near his home in Damrei Sar village of Koh Chhum commune.

On 02 June 2011, vendors from Kratie town, who lost their markets stalls in a fire, demonstrated outside the Prime Minister's home in Phnom Penh. About 400 stalls at Kratie town's market were burned down in a blaze that vendors think was deliberately lit.

On 1 June 2011, a commune official member of the Sam Rainsy Party was beaten to death in Chhoeu Teal commune, Kien Svay district, Kandal, as he returned home from patrolling the area. Police believed the incident was a robbery, but the opposition party claimed the killing was politically motivated. Three suspects were arrested.
On 29 May 2011, a tractor driver was seriously injured when he ran over an anti-tank mine in Slakram commune's Boeung Snou village, Svay Chek district, Banteay Meanchey.

On 28 May 2011, a district military police commander and his three subordinates attacked two men, shooting one of them, in Samrong Tong commune, Kampong Speu. The men, charcoal vendors, refused to pay a bribe at a road checkpoint in in O'Korki village.

On 25 May 2011, more than 500 villagers from Serei Meanchey commune, Sampov Luon district, Battambang province, gathered to protest against a land concession of more than 4,000 hectares that they claim will push them off their farmland. The villagers were joined by Sam Rainsy Party lawmaker Mu Sochua.

On 25 May 2011, about 200 villagers from four provinces protested at Freedom Park in Phnom Penh, against land concessions the government has granted in Prey Lang forest. The villagers handed officials a petition signed by more than 30,000 people.

On 25 May 2011, about 100 workers and activists gathered outside June Textile, in Phnom Penh. They had planned to march to Freedom Park and to government buildings, but were blocked by the police. The former workers had been demanding severance payments since the factory burned down in March.
On 24 May 2011, a man brutally killed his neighbour over a property dispute in Tang Krang commune, Batheay district, Kampong Cham. The suspect escaped from the scene.

On 22 May 2011, a 22-year-old man was severely injured when an UXO exploded, in Damrei Slap commune, Kampong Svay district, Kampong Thom. The man, who had spotted the UXO in a rice field while tending to his water buffalo, was tinkering with the device, assuming that it had previously detonated.

Four teenagers were slightly injured when a mine exploded, in Mong Russey district, Battambang. The teenagers had discovered the Khmer-Rouge era shell in a field and tried to burn it. Date coded: date of news article.
On 19 May 2011, about 270 of villagers from communities along the Sesan river protested in Pong commune, Ratanakkiri, to protest against the planned US$700 million Lower Sesan II dam.
On 18 May 2011, representatives of more than 200 families protested outside Kampot provincial hall against the closure of a road by Kamchay hydrodam developer in April.

On 16 May 2011, villagers protested against local development firm Cheat Amphiwat Co Ltdm for its plan to create a 6,000-hectare plantation across provinces. Villagers were from Thma Puok district, Banteay Meanchey and Banteay Ampil district, Oddar Meanchey. Location coded: Thma Puok.

On 14 May 2011, three Cambodian deminers died by explosions of unexploded ordinances (UXOs) in Kompong Speu. The deminers were storing the UXOs at a warehouse before they are designed to be destroyed later. Location coded: capital of the province.
On 9 May 2011, a 25-year-old man was seriously injured when an anti-tank mine exploded in Rotanak Mondul district, Battambang. The farmer was clearing land with a tractor when the device exploded.

On 08 May 2011, around 100 police officers, armed with anti-riot shields, electric batons and guns violently dispersed a crowd of 2,000 garment workers, mainly composed of women, who blocked the road near Phnom Penh's airport. The workers protested the loss of their jobs following a fire at the factory on 30 March.

On 8 May 2011, around 100 police officers, armed with anti-riot shields, electric batons and guns violently dispersed a crowd of 2000 garment workers who had formed a roadblock near Phnom Penh's airport. The workers protested the loss of their jobs following a fire at the factory on 30 March, as they claimed the severance pay was insufficient. 8 workers were severely injured and required hospitalization.

On 04 May 2011, about 800 vendors from Battambang town's Phsar Natt market protested for lower rent outside the town's provincial hall. The group requested that provincial governor help decrease the rent on their stalls following a recent 10 percent price increase.

On 3 May 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed again at the border, in the contested territory near Ta Krabei temple and Ta Mon temple in Oddar Meanchey province (Cambodia). One Thai soldier was killed during that fight that began late on Monday and ended early Tuesday.
On 2 May 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed again at the border in the contested territory near Ta Krabei temple and Ta Mon temple in Oddar Meanchey province (Cambodia).

On 1 May 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed again at the border,in the contested territory near Ta Krabei temple and Ta Mon temple in Oddar Meanchey province (Cambodia). A Cambodian soldier was killed.

On 30 April 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed for the ninth straight day at the border, in the contested territory near Ta Krabei temple and Ta Mon temple in Oddar Meanchey province (Cambodia). Nearly 100.000 people were displaced on both sides of the border since the clash began on 22 April.

On 29 April 2011, approximately 100 police officers and 2,000 villagers had a confrontation during the villagers' demonstration against the clearing of their land at the National Road 76 in Kev Seima district (KS, Mondulkiri).

On 29 April 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed for the eighth straight day at the border, in the contested territory near Ta Krabei temple and Ta Mon temple in Oddar Meanchey province (Cambodia).

On 28 April 2011, nearly 500 residents from five villages in Svay Chreah commune, Snuol district, Kratie, protested against Kou Keang Kratie Rubber Company. The villagers, including those from the Steang ethnic minority, requested the company to stop clearing their farmland for rubber plantations.

On 28 April 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed for the seventh straight day at the border, in the contested territory near Ta Krabei temple and Ta Mon temple in Oddar Meanchey province (Cambodia). One Thai soldier was killed.

During the week of 24-30 April, a clash broke out between Apsara Authority officials and residents, during a raid in Angkor Archaeological Park in Khnar Sanday, Siem Reap. Villagers were brandishing sticks and knives, while the police threaten the villagers with guns in their hands.

On 27 April 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed for the sixth straight day at the border, in the contested territory near Ta Krabei temple and Ta Mon temple in Oddar Meanchey province (Cambodia). One Thai soldier and one Thai civilian were killed.

On 27 April 2011, about 200 vendors from Doeum Kor market in Tuol Kork district in Phnom Penh protested for the district governor to find them a new venue. The vendors had received a notice stating they would be evicted in 15 days to 'create public order' in the area.
On 26 April 2011, more than 100 families gathered to prevent local authorities seizing land on behalf of a former provincial governor, in Kandal province's Kien Svay district.

On 26 April 2011, three farmers were killed and other three were injured when an anti-tank mine detonated in Trapaing Prasat district, Oddar Meanchey province. The accident occurred when the anti-tractor where the victims were riding ran over an old mine.

On 26 April 2011, clasesh between Cambodian and Thai troops spread around the constested area of Preah Vihear Temple, in Kantuot commune. Thailand said nearly 26.000 people had been evacuated, while in Cambodia nearly 22.000 people were displaced.

On 26 April 2011, clasesh between Cambodian and Thai troops spread around the constested area of Preah Vihear Temple, Kantuot, bordering Si Sa Ket province in Thailand. Thailand said nearly 26.000 people had been evacuated, while in Cambodia nearly 22.000 people were displaced.

On 26 April 2011, figthing continued in the border area near Pa Nom Dong Rak district of Thailand's Surin province, in the contested territory near Ta Krabei temple and Ta Mon temple in Oddar Meanchey province (Cambodia). One Thai civilian was killed and two wounded.

On 25 April 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed for the fourth consecutive day at the border area near Pa Nom Dong Rak district of Thailand's Surin province, in the contested territory near Ta Krabei temple and Ta Mon temple in Oddar Meanchey province (Cambodia). One Cambodian soldier was killed and one was injured.

On 24 April 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed for the third consecutive day at the border area near Pa Nom Dong Rak district of Thailand's Surin province, in the contested territory near Ta Krabei temple and Ta Mon temple in Oddar Meanchey province (Cambodia). One Thai soldier and one Cambodian soldier were killed.

On 23 April 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed for the second consecutive day at the border area near Pa Nom Dong Rak district of Thailand's Surin province, in the contested territory near Ta Krabei temple and Ta Mon temple in Oddar Meanchey province (Cambodia). Three Cambodian soldiers and one Thai soldier were killed during the fight. Thousands of villagers were evacuated from nearby areas on both sides.

On 22 April 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed at the border area near Pa Nom Dong Rak district of Thailand's Surin province, in the contested territory near Ta Krabei temple and Ta Mon temple in Oddar Meanchey province (Cambodia). Three Thai soldiers and three Cambodian soldiers were killed. At least 13 Thai soldiers were injured.

On 21 April 2011, Cambodian police beat protesters, including elderly women, with electric batons, during a demonstration in Phnom Penh. The group demonstrated against their forced relocation from a Boeung Kak Lake area to make way for a commercial development. 11 people were arrested. According to police, the demonstrators threw bricks and bags of urine at them.

On 16 April 2011, one villager was beaten and others were allegedly threatened with AK-47 rifles by five representatives of an NGO, in Kantuot commune, Choam Ksan district, Preah Vihear province. The villagers, from Prum Vihearthor Techo village, had been embroiled in a land dispute with Drug and AIDS Research and Prevention Organisation (DARPO).

On 13 April 2011, a farmer was killed after a commune police officer allegedly opened fire at a dance party during a Khmer New Year celebration, in Punley village of Peamro district's Baborng commune, Prey Veng.

On 11 April 2011, a 12-year-old was injured after an unexploded ordinance detonated in Sompov Loun commune in Battambang province. The girl was hit by a rock after an excavator accidentally touched the UXO, exploding the landmine.

On 11 April 2011, more than 90 former employees of the now bankrupt Tack Fat garment factory protested outside the Ministry of Social Affairs, in Phnom Penh. They demanded payment of a negotiated severance package.
On 5 April 2011, a 31-year-old man was killed when an old landmine exploded as he planted chili plants in Prek Phnov commune, Sen Sok district, Phnom Penh. Two other workers were injured.
On 04 April 2011, about 300 workers protested outside the Ever Glory garment factory, in Russei Keo district, Phnom Penh. The striking workers demanded the reinstatement of two workers.

Property destruction: On 31 March 2011, about 200 armed military police and police descended upon Tuol Sangke commune's Tuol Kork village, in Phnom Penh. They demolished the homes of forty-two families, enforcing a Supreme Court ruling in favor of a former Funcinpec minister, who allegedly owned the land.

On 30 March 2011, residents of Boeung Kak lakeside protested in Daun Penh district's Srah Chak commune, in Phnom Penh. They expressed disappointment after a meeting between representatives of villagers and Phnom Penh municipal governor failed to reach an agreement over a land dispute.

On 28 March 2011, at least eight female garment workers were injured in clashes with riot police, who used shields and electric shock batons to end a riot over a factory closure, in Phnom Penh. Around 1,000 workers were rioting outside the Tack Fat Garment Factory, burning tyres and briefly blocking National Road 2. About 50 people were injured.

On 25 March 2011, villagers from the Boeung Kak lake area protested outside City Hall in Phnom Penh to demand a resolution to their land dispute. Police armed with riot shields and electric batons suppressed the protest, and hit and temporarily detained one woman.
On 24 March 2011, two police officers allegedly beat a suspect to compel him to confess to his involvement in a street fight in Preah Sihanouk province coded at Sihanoukville city.
On 21 March 2011, more than 200 Boeung Kak residents gathered outside City Hall in Phnom Penh, to await the municipality's ruling to their alternative development plan.

On 17 March 2011, villagers from 96 households in Tram Kak district, Takeo province, staged a non-violent protest. They blocked employees belonging to an unknown private company from destroying Tuol Ang Yeay Pov, a protected sacred hill.

On 17 March 2011, sixty-six people representing 73 families from Kampong Speu province gathered at Prime Minister Hun Sen's villa in Ta Khmao town, Kandal province. The villagers, locked in a land dispute with petrol conglomerate Sokimex, asked for intervention after provincial officials prepared to evict them.

On 11 March 2011, a reporter member of the League of Cambodian Journalists (LCJ) was allegedly beaten by a logger in his house in Konchon Ron village, Prasat commune, Varin district, in Siem Reap. The reporter had taken photographs of the man's logging operations.
During the week of 6-12 March, a 55-year-old man and his two sons were injured by a piece of unexploded ordnance while tilling their vegetable garden in Samlout commune, Samlout district, Battambang.

On 09 March 2011, about 100 vendors from Prek Pnov market, in Sen Sok district, protested in front of the Appeal Court in Phnom Penh. The court had ruled to overturn a municipal court decision on a demarcation wall separating Prek Pnov from a neighboring market.

On 06 March 2011, about 100 villagers protested and threatened to burn TTY Corporation Co Ltd company' s tractors, in Sre Khtum commune, Keo Seima, Mondulkiri. The villagers accused the private firm of encroaching on their land and clearing an area belonging to 63 families.

On 6 March 2011, a 52-year-old farmer was killed when he stepped on an anti-personnel mine, Samlout district, Battambang. The landmine exploded when he and his wife were clearing land in their corn and cassava fields.
On 5 March 2011, a 51-year-old farmer was killed when an unexploded piece of ordnance was set off while he was ploughing his farmland in Malai district, Banteay Meanchey

On 01 March 2011, about 34 villagers from Koh Kong's Kiri Sakor district protested against a Chinese development firm. The company attempted to clear the villagers' land during the week without providing any compensation.
On 28 February 2011, a man was severely injured after his tractor hit an anti-tank mine, in Phnom Proek district, Battambang.
On 28 February 2011, a 14-year-old girl was severely injured and had one leg amputated after stepping on a landmine while walking through farmland in Samlot district, Battambang.
On 28 February 2011, an anti-tank mine explosion injured one man while he was driving in his tractor in Samrong commune, Banteay Meanchey's O'Chruv district.

On 27 February 2011, Daun Penh district police violently suppressed a protest of about 200 people in Phnom Penh. The protesters demanded an alternative plan for the Boeung Kak lake development project. Three activists were arrested, while 10 others suffered injuries from beatings.
On 24 February 2011, a man was seriously injured and his tractor destroyed by an UXO explosion, in Banteay Meanchey. Location coded: capital of the province.
On 24 February 2011, Cambodian soldiers fired three shots in the border area assumed in Kantuot commune, Preah Vihear province into Sisaket province (Thailand).

On 24 February 2011, two Thai soldiers were seriously injured after stepping on landmines while patrolling Phu Ma Khua (near Preah Vihear Temple) along the Cambodian border in Kantuot commune (Preah Vihear province, Cambodia).
On 19 February 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops briefly exchanged fire during a patrol in the border area in Kantuot commune, after dogs accompanying them began fighting.
On 19 February 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops briefly exchanged fire during a patrol in the border area, after dogs accompanying them began fighting. Coded as for Preah Vihear province.

On 16 February 2011, Cambodian troops continued the attack to a Thai outpost near the Preah Vihear temple (Kantuot) in the disputed border, shooting with machine guns, mortar rounds and rocket-propelled grenades (RPGs). Thai troops returned the fire. The event occurred near Pralanpad-lak pass in Kanthalalak district of border Si Sa Ket province.
On 15 February 2011, Cambodian soldiers launched an attack on an operational base of Thai soldiers at Phu Ma Khua in the disputed area of Preah Vihear temple in Kantuot. One Thai soldier was injured.

On 14 February 2011, more than 200 villagers from Tras commune, Svay Rieng province's Romeas Hek district, blocked a rubber company from clearing their land for a fourth consecutive day. The villagers had been involved in a land dispute against Peam Chaing Rubber Company.

On 15 February 2011, Cambodian soldiers launched an attack on an operational base of Thai soldiers at Phu Ma Khua in the disputed area of Preah Vihear temple (Kantuot commune, Cambodia). One Thai soldier was injured.

On 14 February 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed in the disputed border area near Preah Vihear temple in Kantuot,, at Chong Don Ai Pass in Si Sa Ket's Roung subdistrict. One Thai soldier was injured.

On 14 February 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed in the disputed border area near Preah Vihear temple (Kantuot commune in Cambodia), at Chong Don Ai Pass in Si Sa Ket's Roung subdistrict. One Thai soldier was injured.

On 16 February 2011, Cambodian troops continued the attack to a Thai outpost near the Preah Vihear temple, Kantuot commune, in the disputed border, shooting with machine guns, mortar rounds and rocket-propelled grenades (RPGs). Thai troops returned the fire.

On 13 February 2011, police used electric batons to physically confront protestors, in Tras commune, Svay Rieng province's Romeas Hek district, injuring 10 people. The villagers had been blocking a rubber company and police from accessing and clearing their cassava farms for the third straight day.

On 12 February 2011, about 100 villagers in Svay Rieng province's Romeas Hek district blocked a rubber company and police from accessing and clearing their cassava farms. The villagers, from Tras commune, are involved in a land dispute against Peam Chaing Rubber Company.

On 11 February 2011, about 100 villagers in Svay Rieng province's Romeas Hek district blocked a rubber company and police from accessing and clearing their cassava farms. The villagers, from Tras commune, are involved in a land dispute against Peam Chaing Rubber Company.

On 09 February 2011, thirty families from Dangkor district's Andong village protested in Phnom Penh against attempts by local authorities to demolish their temporary housing. They claimed authorities came to dismantle their homes, made with leaf and fabric walls, in order to build new brick homes and charge them for the houses.

On 5 February 2011, Thai and Cambodian soldiers exchanged heavy fire on the disputed border, killing one Thai soldier. The fighting occurred near Preah Vihear Temple, in Kantuot commune. Four Thai soldiers were injured. At least 3000 people from Thailand and 1000 from Cambodia fled their homes.

On 4 February 2011, Thai and Cambodian soldiers exchanged heavy fire on the two countries' shared border, killing two Cambodian soldiers, a Cambodian civilian, and a Thai civilian. The fighting occurred near the disputed border in Preah Vihear Temple, Kantuot. Six Thai and at least four Cambodian soldiers were injured. Five Thai soldiers were captured. Residents in several villages along both sides of the border were evacuated.

On 6 February 2011, violence erupted again in the Thai-Cambodian border, near Preah Vihear Temple, in Kantuot commune, ending a ceasefire agreed the day before. About 14 Thais were injured, and a Thai soldier later died from the injuries (on 08 February).

source: AP; The Australian; Thai News Service
notes: On 7 February 2011, Thai and Cambodian troops clashed for a fourth straight day, near the Thai-Cambodian border around Preah Vihear temple, in Kantuot commune. One Thai soldier was killed. During the four-days clashes, Thai newspapers suggest 64 Cambodian soldiers were killed, while Cambodian news reported that at least 30 Thai troops had died, but independent sources said 7 people were killed.

On 03 February 2011, ninety-three families from Chroy Changvar and Prek Liep communes protested in Phnom Penh. The residents had received a letter prohibiting them from rebuilding houses removed for the expansion of National Road 6A.

On 31 January 2011, a police officer shot three fishermen in Boeung Ta Nhov lake in Kraing Yov commune, Sa'ang district, in Kandal. One man was killed and another one was seriously injured. The officer, who was later arrested, attempted to stop the three fishermen from using illegal nets.

On 24 January 2011, 50 vendors from Moang market, in Battambang province, protested in front of Moang Russey district hall. They called for authorities to intervene after market security officials evicted them.

On 18 January 2011, two men were seriously injured when a B-40 rocket exploded at their home in Chakrei commune's Damnak Ksan village (Battambang province's Phnom Proek district). The men were attempting to break the rocket to make a large blade from the metal when the rocket detonated.

On 17 January 2011, residents of Svay Chrum village near Preah Vihear temple (Kantuot commune) protested while military and police dismantled their homes to make way for Preah Vihear National Authority and UNESCO offices. Villagers claimed authorities attempted to arrest protesting residents.

On 17 January 2011, about 50 villagers from Boeung Kak community gathered outside the Chinese Embassy in Phnom Penh. They attempted to deliver a petition to embassy officials, but were blocked from reaching the gates by 40 military police officers.

On 15 January 2011, about 30 villagers protested in Thma Da commune, Veal Veng, in Pursat province. The villagers managed to halt the clearing of land for a casino project along the Thai border. They allege MDS, a local firm owned by tycoon Try Pheap, began encroaching on their farmland.

On 14 January 2011, a photographer from The Phnom Penh Post was beaten and briefly detained by district police at the Boeung Kak lakeside in Phnom Penh. The journalist was photographing the demolition of homes in the area.

On 12 January 2011, nearly 30 villagers representing 184 families living near Boeung Trabek, Phnom Penh, protested against local authorities they claim are destroying their aquaculture crops in order to build a reservoir. The villagers gathered at the lake to express their concern and stop earth moving machines.

On 09 January 2011, about 300 Boeung Kak residents protested at Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh. The villagers, facing eviction due to a development project, released 99 swallow birds and 99 balloons representing freedom, peace and the 99-year City Hall lease that initiated the project.

On 8 January 2011, an accused sorcerer was killed in Ta Sal commune, Oral district, Kampong Speu. The man, Sieng Soeun, 51, had his throat slit by unknown assailants, as he was walking home after drinking palm sugar juice with his friends.

On 04 January 2011, about 20 families living in Klaing Saing village in Russei Keo district gathered outside the Russei Keo commune hall, in Phnom Penh. They protested against the bulldozing of their land for the construction of a riverside park backed by petrol conglomerate Sokimex.

On 03 January 2011, about 200 residents from Boeung Kak area participated in a protest at Freedom Park, in Phnom Penh. They called for Inner Mongolia Erdos Hung Jun Investment Co, a Chinese firm which reportedly invested tens of millions of dollars in the area, to intervene in the dispute with the local company that is developing the lake.

On 29 December 2010, approximately 50 fishers from Kampong Klaing commune in Srok Sotr Nikum (Siem Reap) protested illegal fees that were being collected from them by local military police and fisheries personnel. The fishers had intended to protest at the Siem Reap provincial hall but were blocked by the district authorities.
On 29 December 2010, a soldier was injured when he stepped on a landmine in Thma Da (Veal Veaeng, Pursat). The soldier was helping his wife find trees when he stepped on the mine.

On 29 December 2010, approximately 50 persons protested outside City Hall in Phnom Penh. The protesters demanded the municipal authority's help after 200 families in Prek Pra commune were given two weeks to relocate.
On 28 December 2010, 40 families protested the clearing of forest and farmlands for the development of acacia and cassava plantations in Ansar Chambak commune (Krakor, Pursat).

On 28 December 2010, 18 families protested outside City Hall in Phnom Penh. The residents opposed their upcoming displacement in order for a access road to be built. They were also dissatisfied with the compensation being offered.

On 24 December 2010, approximately 300 villagers continued protesting for the third day by standing in front of bulldozers in Om Laing (Thpong, Kampong Speu). The villagers said that the land is being illegally grabbed by a company owned by a politician.

On 23 December 2010, villagers in Om Laing (Thpong, Kampong Speu) continued protesting the alleged illegal grabbing of their land by a company owned by a politician. This was the second day of protest.
On 23 December 2010, vendors protested a proposed rental increase outside the PC Market in Mean Chey (Phnom Penh).
On 22 December 2010, villagers in Om Laing (Thpong, Kampong Speu) began protesting the alleged illegal grabbing of their land by a company owned by a politician.
On 20 December 2010, 2 persons were killed and 6 others injured when an anti-tank mine exploded in Sampov Loun district (Battambang). The explosion occurred after an excavator ran over the mine.

On 20 December 2010, approximately 100 residents from Boeung Kak Lake (Village 7) protested in Phnom Penh. The residents demanded the intervention of the Prime Minister to stop the filling of the lake as their homes were being flooded by the process. Two villagers were knocked to the ground when their banner was destroyed by a worker which instigated a clash with police.
On 19 December 2010, 2 people were killed and 6 injured in Chheu Teal (Sampov Loun, Battambang) when a land mine exploded. A man was using an excavator to dig a hole when it triggered a mine.

On 16 December 2010, approximately 100 families from Borei Keila, (Prampi Makara, Phnom Penh) protested outside their homes. The residents opposed the start of construction around their homes before compensation with the development company was finalized.
On 15 December 2010, 4 children were seriously injured when a landmine exploded while they were playing with it in Phnum Proek (Battambang).
On 15 December 2010, 4 children were seriously wounded when a land mine exploded while they were playing in the forest close to their home in Chakrei commune (Phnom Proek, Battambang)

Around 15 December 2010, residents of Boeung Trabek protested in front of the Prime Minister's house in Phnom Penh. Residents alleged that families were displaced and farmland lost due to the construction of a canal.
On 14 December 2010, over 100 vendors protested at Tuol Kork market in Phnom Penh to demand that the market operators reconnect the water and electricity.

On 12 December 2010, approximately 50 representatives of 116 families from Pi Thnou commune in Snoul District protested in front of the home of the Land Management Minister in Kratie province. The residents are facing eviction from their land for the planned construction of a rubber plantation.
