On 10 December 2010, over 100 taxi drivers protested in front of the Provincial Hall in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk). The drivers demanded that motorbike rentals and hotel bus service for foreigners be discontinued.

On 6 December 2010, approximately 250 villagers accompanied 12 fellow villagers to court in Krakor town (Krakor, Pursat). The villagers were summoned for inciting protests among other charges. The large group of villagers did not think the court would be just and as such they came out to show their support.
On 6 December 2010, residents of Boeung Trabek lakeside protested in front of the Prime Minister's house in Phnom Penh. The protesters alleged that they lost farmlands due to a drainage project.
On 6 December 2010, residents of Boeung Trabek lakeside burned tyres near the lake in their community in Phnom Penh, to protest the alleged loss of farmlands due to a drainage project.

On 5 December 2010, over 80 vendors from the Heng Ly market in Tuol Kork district protested in Phnom Penh. The vendors demanded that the owner of the market reconsider his recent stall rental price increase decision.
On 1 December 2010, approximately 300 residents protested outside the provincial hall in Serei Saophoan (Banteay Meanchey) to demand that the local water company lower their prices.

On 20 November 2010, approximately 200 workers from a garment factory in Teuk Thla commune in Sen Sok protested outside the military police headquarters in Phnom Penh to demand the release of a union leader. The union leader was detained for alleged drug smuggling.

On 19 November 2010, a military police officer killed a villager in Malai (Banteay Meanchey). It is reported that the officer fired into the air after the villager failed to stop his tractor. A bullet ricocheted and killed the villager.

On 17 November 2010, 14 people were killed in Battambang when their tractor ran over an anti-tank mine. It is reported that the group of farmers were returning home from harvesting chilies when the land mine exploded.
On 17 November 2010, approximately 500 garment workers in Russey Keo district in Phnom Penh continued protesting the firing of 4 workers who were elected as union leaders.
On 16 November 2010, approximately 500 garment workers in Russey Keo district in Phnom Penh continued protesting the firing of 4 workers who were elected as union leaders.

On 16 November 2010, approximately 80 families from O'Tres commune in Stung Hav district protested at Freedom Park in Phnom Penh. The villagers demonstrated to raise awareness and request the intervention of officials in a land dispute with a company in the district.

On 15 November 2010, approximately 300 persons protested outside the provincial hall in Serei Saophoan (Banteay Meanchey). The residents of Sisophon district demanded that a local water company reduce its rates.
On 15 November 2010, approximately 500 garment workers in Russey Keo district in Phnom Penh protested the firing of 4 workers who were elected as union leaders.

On 13 November 2010, a man was killed and another person injured when police fired shots at the ground in Bakan (Pursat) after being followed by a group of 50 people. This occurred after the police had arrested a local man at a dance party.

On 12 November 2010, workers at a garment factory in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk) continued protesting outside the factory to demand better working conditions and the reinstatement of their union leader. A court order forced more than 700 of these workers to return to work the following day.

On 11 November 2010, workers at a garment factory in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk) continued protesting outside the factory to demand better working conditions and the reinstatement of their union leader.
On 10 November 2010, hundreds of residents of Krakor (Pursat) protested the clearing of forest and farm land to be used for acacia and cassava plantations.

On 10 November 2010, workers at a garment factory in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk) continued protesting outside the factory to demand better working conditions and the reinstatement of their union leader.

On 10 November 2010, over 40 trainee teachers protested in front of the National Institute of Education in Phnom Penh to draw attention to their removal from their course due to accusations of fraud by the Ministry of Education.

On 9 November 2010, workers at a garment factory in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk) continued protesting outside the factory to demand better working conditions and the reinstatement of their union leader.

On 8 November 2010, workers at a garment factory in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk) continued protesting outside the factory to demand better working conditions and the reinstatement of their union leader.

On 7 November 2010, workers at a garment factory in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk) continued protesting outside the factory to demand better working conditions and the reinstatement of their union leader.

On 7 November 2010, representatives of villagers in Boeung Kak Lake (Phnom Penh) protested the resumption of sand pumping which had previously caused flooding of their homes. Police, military and security guards dispersed residents.

On 6 November 2010, workers at a garment factory in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk) continued protesting outside the factory to demand better working conditions and the reinstatement of their union leader.
On 5 November 2010, 3 men were injured when an anti-tank mine exploded in Battambang province. The men were riding in a trailer pulling corn when it drove over a mine which caused it to explode.

On 5 November 2010, workers at a garment factory in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk) continued protesting outside the factory to demand better working conditions and the reinstatement of their union leader.

On 4 November 2010, workers at a garment factory in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk) began protesting outside the factory to demand better working conditions and the reinstatement of their union leader.

On 3 November 2010, over 100 villagers from Memot district protested in front of the provincial court in Kampong Cham City (Kampong Cham). The villagers demanded the release of a woman arrested for poisoning her husband.

On 3 November 2010, approximately 200 garment workers protested in front of the Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Phnom Penh. The workers demonstrated against lawsuits that were filed relating to protest action taken by workers in August.

On 2 November 2010, a man was killed and 3 others injured in Phnum Proek (Battambang) when an anti-tank mine exploded. A soldier was driving a tractor when it ran over the mine and caused it to explode.
On 1 November 2010, approximately 60 persons protested against the clearing of land by a development firm in Veal Veang (Pursat).

On 31 October 2010, approximately 65 persons were detained, photographed and questioned by the police in Siem Reap City (Siem Reap). Villagers from several districts in the province were on their way to Krong Siem Reap to highlight several grievances to Hillary Clinton during her visit to Cambodia. The villagers were released after signing a document to show that they would stop protesting.

On 27 October 2010, approximately 100 persons protested outside the Cambodian-Friendship Hospital in Phnom Penh. The UN Security General was visiting and they wanted to draw attention to the eviction of residents of Boeung Kak lakeside. It was reported that an activist involved with the protest was beaten unconscious by police.

On 26 October 2010, a man and his son were killed when a bomb exploded in their home in Rolea B'ier (Kampong Chhnang). It is reported that the man planned on recycling three bomb pieces when one detonated. A woman was seriously injured in the explosion.

On 25 October 2010, six persons were injured and taken to hospital when they were assaulted by a mob of villagers in Banteay Meanchey province. The group was partying and behaving in a manner considered rude by the villagers who later assaulted them.
On 25 October 2010, approximately 50 families protested at a Cambodian Red Cross ceremony in Serei Saophoan town (Banteay Meanchey). The protesters questioned the relief supply distribution process.

On 25 October 2010, protesters gathered in front of the United Nations Development Programme office in Phnom Penh to request the intervention of UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon into alleged land grabbing. The aim of the protest was to protect their property from being taken without adequate compensation by the Government.

On 24 October 2010, approximately 100 representatives from 5 communities in Phnom Penh gathered in front of the UNDP office (Phnom Penh) to solicit the intervention of the UN Secretary General in their on-going land disputes. Residents demanded to meet with him during an upcoming visit.

On 20 October 2010, approximately 100 vendors briefly clashed with police when they gathered outside the Prime Minister's home in Phnom Penh. The vendors requested a two-year delay of their eviction from their stalls near Olympic Stadium.
On 14 October 2010, approximately 100 vendors protested in front of the Prime Minister's house in Phnom Penh. The vendors demanded that their stalls be kept open during the development of the area.

On 13 October 2010, 50 residents protested in Phnom Penh to demand that the municipality address the high flood levels. There were reports of violence when the police blocked protesters from accessing the City Hall. However, there were no reports of serious injuries and no reports of protesters being violent.

On 30 September 2010, an explosion occurred in the Phnom Trop hill area in (Krong Pursat, Pursat). The Cambodian troops said a grenade was thrown on them by Thai troops. While Thai troops said that it was old ammunition that exploded. No injuries were reported.

In the week of September 30, 2010, a group of residents of Srah Chak commune in Duan Penh (Phnom Penh) set fire to tyres near equipment used to fill the Boeung Kak lake. The residents were protesting because their homes were being affected by mud from the lake filling process. Later when the group attempted to take their protest to the Prime Minister's home they were blocked by police and a scuffle ensued.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (Cambodia); Military Forces of Cambodia (1993-)
notes: On 29 September 2010, a group of vendors and military police clashed with another group of vendors at the Psar Leu market in Siem Reap City (Siem Reap). Banana vendors who were evicted months earlier returned to claim their market space, which resulted in a clash. There were no injuries reported by officials.

On 27 September 2010, approximately 2000 workers of a rubber firm in Busra (Pech Chreada, Mondulkiri) protested outside the company. Workers said their wages were being short-changed as the company was not paying the agreed daily wages.

In the week of September 27, 2010, approximately 60 Boeung Kak lakeside residents protested at two locations in Phnom Penh. The residents opposed the notice to vacate their homes and the low compensation being offered. While protesting, it is reported that residents were assaulted by private security guards employed by the company who wanted them to vacate the land.
On 23 September 2010, a soldier was injured when he stepped on a land mine along the Thai border in Anlong Veng (Oddar Meanchey).
On 21 September 2010, over 300 villagers blocked National Road 5 and protested in front of the district hall in Krakor (Pursat). The villager claimed that a local company had cleared their farmlands.
On 21 September 2010, over 200 residents gathered in front of the provincial court in Kandal Steung (Kandal) to support 2 representatives who were being questioned about a land dispute.
On 20 September 2010, over 7,000 garment workers at two factories in Kandal province protested the suspension of union representatives. This followed multi-day strikes the previous week.

On 20 September 2010, a soldier was killed and another injured when a grenade launcher exploded in Thma Puok, Banteay Meanchey. The explosion occurred after the soldiers accidentally placed a wooden pole on the grenade left from the 1980s.
On 20 September 2010, garment workers at unspecified factories in Phnom Penh protested the suspension of union representatives. This followed multi-day strikes the previous week.
On 18 September 2010, garment workers clashed with the police during a demonstration against a ban on 26 activists from returning to work in Kandal province, leaving at least 5 workers injured.
On 18 September 2010, garment workers in Phnom Penh clashed with police while protesting the suspension of union representatives in response to earlier strikes.

On 16 September 2010, between 80,000 and 200,000 garment workers continued a multi-day strike for the fourth day to protest the revised minimum wage in Phnom Penh. The protest was paused after the Government invited the unions to a negotiation meeting. There were no reports of violence.

In the week of September 15, 2010, approximately 400 residents of Pech Changvar commune walked to the district hall in Kampong Chhnang city to protest the digging of a channel that was affecting their fields. The residents were initially traveling in vans but they were stopped by police and were not allowed to ride in the vans to the city.
On 15 September 2010, between 80,000 and 200,000 garment workers continued a multi-day strike for the third day to protest the revised minimum wage in Phnom Penh. There were no reports of violence.

source: AFP; Clean Clothes Campaign; Morning Star News
notes: On 14 September 2010, over 80,000 garment workers continued a multi-day strike for the second day to protest the revised minimum wage in Phnom Penh. There were no reports of violence.

On 13 September 2010, over 60,000 garment workers started a multi-day strike to protest the revised minimum wage in Phnom Penh. There were no reports of violence, but police arrested three people and confiscated microphones.

On 10 September 2010, an unidentified gunman shot at Forestry Administration officials while they were removing illegal logs from a car. The officials have been focusing on stemming illegal logging. No injuries were reported.
On 10 September 2010, a man was killed in Veal Veang (Pursat) when a mine exploded while he was cutting tees.

On 8 September 2010, approximately 30 persons from Phsar Chhnang commune protested outside the provincial court in Kampong Chhnang City (Kampong Chhnang). The protesters said that their fishing equipment were destroyed by police and fisheries officials.

actor1: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Forestry Officials
notes: In the week of September 6, 2010, a child was injured when forestry officials demolished the homes of 30 families in Commune 1, Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk). The forestry official says the land is part of a protected area.

On 5 September 2010, approximately 300 villagers protested at the provincial court estimated to be located in Kandal Steung (Kandal). The protesters demanded the release of a representative involved in a land dispute with a development company.
On 3 September 2010, construction workers continued protesting on Monivong Boulevard (Phnom Penh) to demand a pay increase.
On 2 September 2010, construction workers continued protesting on Monivong Boulevard (Phnom Penh) to demand a pay increase.
On 1 September 2010, construction workers staged a protest on Monivong Boulevard (Phnom Penh) to demand a pay increase for overtime work.

On 31 August 2010, approximately 300 villagers gathered at the electricity company in Anlong Veng (Oddar Meanchey). The villagers complained about an increase in the price of electricity and demanded that the company reinstall their old electricity meters.

On 30 August 2010, approximately 40 residents of Boeung Kak lakeside gathered in Wat Botum in Phnom Penh to deliver a petition to the Prime Minister. The villagers are facing eviction from their homes in Boeung Kak lakeside.

On 29 August 2010, 4 persons were killed and 3 others injured in a bomb explosion in Phnom Kravan (Pursat). It is reported that a man was using an unexploded bomb as a microphone and it exploded when he threw it and it hit a wooden floor.

On 29 August 2010, 4 civilians were killed, and 3 others injured when a leftover B-40 rocket launcher exploded in Rovieng (Phnom Kravanh, Pursat). It is reported that a villager was using the explosive as a pretend microphone when it fell and detonated.

On 27 August 2010, villagers blocked National Road 48 in Sre Ambel (Koh Kong) to demonstrate and draw attention to a land dispute where 34 families could be evicted. A motorist angered by the traffic caused by the blockage clashed with protestors injuring four.

On 25 August 2010, approximately 300 farmers from Omlaing commune protested in Thpong, Kampong Speu. The farmers who are in a land dispute with a sugar company, were promised that a meeting would be held to resolve the dispute. It is alleged that company representatives broke this promise.
On 25 August 2010, a boy was killed in Banan (Battambang) when a cow stepped on an anti-tank mine. The explosion killed the boy and two cows.

On 25 August 2010, 2 villagers were beaten unconscious by workers hired by a businessman in Koh Kong. The villagers attempted to block workers from accessing what they claim to be their land, and in response two women were physically assaulted. It is reported that military police officers and 10 other civilians stood and watched while the assault occurred.

On 25 August 2010, approximately 100 residents of Boeung Kak lakeside protested at City Hall in Phnom Penh. The residents demanded that the filling of the lake be halted as it was flooding their homes.

On 23 August 2010, residents of Prek Chik village were allegedly beaten by police in Sre Ambel (Koh Kong). The villagers who are engaged in a land dispute tried to block the police from destroying their crops on the instruction of the company owner of the land.

On 23 August 2010, approximately 300 villagers from Omlaing commune blocked National Road 52 in Thpong (Kampong Speu) to prevent sugar company workers from clearing their farmlands and tearing down their homes.

On 22 August 2010, workers of a garment factory in Mean Chey district (Phnom Penh) continued protesting in front of the factory gates to demand better working conditions. Workers protested both day and night.

On 21 August 2010, workers of a garment factory in Mean Chey district (Phnom Penh) continued protesting in front of the factory gates to demand better working conditions. Workers protested both day and night.

On 20 August 2010, workers of a garment factory in Mean Chey district (Phnom Penh) continued protesting in front of the factory gates to demand better working conditions. Workers protested both day and night.

On 19 August 2010, workers of a construction company in Meanchey (Phnom Penh) continued their protest outside the company's office for a fourth day to protest the dismissal of 60 workers for trying to form a trade union.
On 19 August 2010, workers of a garment factory in Mean Chey district (Phnom Penh) protested in front of the factory gates to demand better working conditions. Workers protested both day and night.
On 18 August 2010, workers of a construction company in Meanchey (Phnom Penh) continued their protest for a third day to protest the dismissal of 60 workers for trying to form a trade union.

On 17 August 2010, over 100 villagers protested in front of the provincial court in Kampong Cham City (Kampong Thom). The villagers were demanding the release of a resident of Trea commune in Stoung district who was arrested in connection with a land dispute.

On 17 August 2010, workers of a construction company in Meanchey (Phnom Penh) continued their strike outside the company's office to protest the dismissal of 60 workers for trying to form a trade union.
On 17 August 2010, workers of a garment factory protested at the factory in Mean Chey district (Phnom Penh) to demand better working conditions.
On 16 August 2010, workers of a construction company in Meanchey (Phnom Penh) went on strike outside the company's office to protest the dismissal of 60 workers for trying to form a trade union.

On 10 August 2010, 13 NGO workers with the Cambodian Disabled Survivors' Association were arrested by soldiers in Kampong Speu province for allegedly building roads on land belonging to the army. While detained it is reported that the workers were beaten and shocked with electric batons. They were released 4 hours later.

On 10 August 2010, a group of 50 NGO workers gathered in Kampong Speu province to protest the detention of 13 NGO workers. It is reported that during the protest soldiers fired shots in the air to try and disperse the protesters.

On 9 August 2010, approximately 100 villagers were violently removed from a disputed piece of land in Stueng Trang (Kampong Cham) by police and military police officers. The officers who were hired by the development company fired shots in the air and then used electric bantons on villagers who were farming the land. Three persons were injured.

On 8 August 2010, approximately 50 villagers from Battambang province gathered in front of the Prime Minister's house in Phnom Penh to draw attention to their land dispute. Police personnel forcibly broke up the protest and loaded them on to buses. Five persons were injured.
On 8 August 2010, a group of persons protested in Phnom Penh to draw attention to their long standing dispute with a military police official.
On 29 July 2010, approximately 100 persons gathered in front of the provincial court in Chbar Mon (Kampong Speu) to protest the possibility of losing their land to a sugar company.
On 29 July 2010, approximately 3000 garment workers continued protesting outside PCCS Garment Ltd factory in Sen Sok (Phnom Penh) against the firing of a union representative.

On 27 July 2010, 100 police clashed with 3000 garment workers who were protesting the suspension of a union official in Phnom Penh. It is alleged that the police beat workers in order for them to resume working. Conflicting reports indicate that 9 workers were injured, however the police deny that there were injuries.
On 25 July 2010, approximately 1000 workers protested low wage increase in front of the National Assembly in Tonle Bassac (Chamkarmon, Phnom Penh).

In the week of July 21, 2010, 2 people were killed and another 3 injured when a police officer opened fire in Phnom Penh Thmey (Sen Sok, Phnom Penh). The event occurred after one of the victims and the police officer argued over unspecified reason.
On 20 July 2010, garment factory workers protested the dismissal of a union representative in front of the factory in Phnom Penh.
On 19 July 2010, approximately 20 parents protested Grade 9 exams results in Banteay Meanchey province.
On 19 July 2010, garment factory workers protested the dismissal of a union representative in front of the factory in Phnom Penh.
On 17 July 2010, an alleged thief was beaten close to death by a security guard and a mob of locals in Tuol Kork (Phnom Penh) after he attempted to steal a motorbike.
On 16 July 2010, garment factory workers protested the dismissal of a union representative in front of the factory in Phnom Penh.
On 15 July 2010, approximately 256 families protested in Phlout Leu village, Trapeang Chour (Aoral, Kampong Speu). The familes held a sit-in prevent the sugar company from clearing the disputed land.
On 15 July 2010, garment factory workers protested the dismissal of a union representative in front of the factory in Phnom Penh.

On 13 July 2010, approximately 160 persons inclusive of disabled veterans continued protesting in Phnom Penh to pressure the authorities to grant them the land concessions that they were promised. After the protest ended, 5 disabled veterans where arrested on their way home.
On 12 July 2010, approximately 160 persons inclusive of disabled veterans protested in Phnom Penh to pressure the authorities to grant them the land concessions that they were promised.

On 8 July 2010, a soldier with the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces Battalion opened fire on residents of Kampong Treas (Kroch Chhmar, Tboung Khmum). Three persons were killed and four injured in the attack. No motive was given.
On 4 July 2010, 65 families protested on a disputed piece of land in Baray, Kampong Thom. The families said that a provincial deputy governor has been illegally trying to force them off their land.

On 4 July 2010, a group of soldiers opened fire on approximately 60 farmers who were working on disputed land in Samlout (Battambang). It is reported that the soldiers also beat the farmers injuring two, one seriously.

On 2 July 2010, a clash occurred between police/provincial officials and residents of Kien Svay (Kandal). The residents attempted to block the police and provincial officials from enforcing a court ruling over disputed land in Prek Treng village of Samrong Thom commune. It was reported that some residents were beaten and arrested but was later released when the residents blocked the police truck.

On 1 July 2010, approximately 10 soldiers fired on 60 farmers who were farming on a disputed piece of land in Samlout (Battambang). Afterwards soldiers allegedly beat those who refused to stop farming, injuring two persons.

On 28 June 2010, approximately 50 families from Anlong Veng (Oddar Meanchey) protested in front of Wat Botum in Phnom Penh to draw attention to their lack of infrastructure. The families who were recently relocated said that they no longer had access to farmland, clean water, schools and health centre.

On 23 June 2010, approximately 50 villagers of Om Laing commune protested outside the office of a company the villagers are engaged in a land dispute with. The villagers demanded the release of a farmer that was earlier arrested for trying to stop company employees from clearing his land.

On 21 June 2010, approximately 130 families from Chhlong district protested in front of the Kratie Provincial Court in Kracheh (Kratie). The villagers demanded the release of a man arrested for burning his house to the ground.
On 21 June 2010, approximately 2000 garment workers protested in front of a garment factory in Dangkor district (Phnom Penh) to demand the reinstatement of 7 union representatives.
In the month of June 2010, villagers from Phreah Rong and Chungrok villages in Pursat province protested outside the National Assembly in Phnom Penh to draw attention to an on-going land dispute.

On 15 June 2010, over 200 protesters gathered at Wat Botum in Phnom Penh to see the Prime Minister and raise their concerns about land disputes that are impacting thousands of villagers. After two hours they were dispersed by police.

On 14 June 2010, police removed approximately 100 residents of Kampong Cham province from a park near Wat Botum in Phnom Penh. The residents were in the park to draw attention to a land dispute with the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces.
On 14 June 2010, approximately 3000 workers at a garment factory in Dangkor (Phnom Penh) protested to demand the reinstatement of 7 union representatives.

On 8 June 2010, the Military troops of Thailand and Cambodia clashed near a disputed area in Trapaeng Prasat (Oddor Meanchey). Both groups exchange gunfire for a few minutes. No fatalities were reported.
On 7 June 2010, 68 families protested outside City Hall in Phnom Penh to demand that officials provide land for them to rebuild their homes at the site of a fire in Boeung Kak 2 commune.

On 6 June 2010, approximately 200 residents of Chong Koh village in Koh Oknhatey commune protested along the Mekong river in Kien Svay (Kandal). The residents opposed the dredging of sand in the river which threatens their farm land.

On 3 June 2010, villagers of Russey Keo district protested outside the Prime Minister's house in Ta Khmau City (Kandal). The villagers feared their homes will be negatively affected by a planned road expansion.

On 2 June 2010, a former Cambodian minister led approximately 50 supporters in a march in Phnom Penh. This followed her defamation conviction by the Supreme Court in Phnom Penh. The police briefly stopped the march and then allowed it to continue.

On 2 June 2010, approximately 150 disabled veterans protested in front of the Prime Minister's house in Phnom Penh. They requested that the Prime Minister provide them with 4000 hectares of protected land in Kratie.

On 1 June 2010, a man was killed and 12 others injured in a grenade attack in Anlong Veng (Oddar Meanchey). It is believed that a dispute may be the motive for the attack. Three men were subsequently arrested.
On 1 June 2010, vendors of O'Russei market protested outside the Prime Minister's house in Pnom Penh. The vendors opposed a recently implemented market upgrade charge.

On 31 May 2010, 100 villagers tried to protest the confiscation of 5 tractors at the Provincial Hall in Krong Battambang (Battambang). Police scattered the protesters and told them to select 6 persons to represent the group.
On 31 May 2010, approximately 500 vendors from O'Russei market protested outside the Prime Minister's home in Phnom Penh. The vendors disagreed with a new daily market upgrade charge.

On 28 May 2010, approximately 150 residents of Kandal Stung and Takhmao districts protested plans to develop their farm lands by a development company. The villagers reported that the police violently broke up the protest that was staged in front of the Prime Minister's house in Phnom Penh and arrested 6 persons. The use of violence was denied by the military police chief.

On 25 May 2010, a group of military police, provincial police and soldiers burned the houses of more than 100 villagers in O'Ampil village in Anlong Veng district (AV, OM) after the villagers refused to leave following an eviction notice.

Property destruction: On May 25, 2010, 50 police and Environment Department workers destroyed the homes of approximately 100 families in Anlong Veng (Oddar Meanchey) after an on-going land dispute. The police dismantled some homes and burnt others.

On 24 May 2010, approximately 200 villagers from Romeas Haek district accompanied a resident that was summoned for a previous protest to the Svay Rieng provincial court in Krong Savy Rieng (Savy Rieng). The villagers are engaged in a land dispute with a rubber company in the province.

On 24 May 2010, approximately 50 villagers of Chong Khneas commune protested at the Siem Reap Provincial Hall in Siem Reap City (Siem Reap). The villagers opposed the destruction of their fishing nets and wanted officials to allow them to use finer nets.
On 21 May 2010, approximately 40 residents of Boeung Chhuok village who are slated to be evicted protested outside the Prime Minister's house in Ta Khmau City (Kandal).

In the week of May 20, 2010, vendors from Ban Lung market protested outside the Prime Minister's house in Phnom Penh. The vendors alleged that they were being charged high and illegal fees by the market owner.

On 20 May 2010, in Siem Reap, approximately 100 vendors protested outside the Apsara Authority office because they were prevented from selling their goods near Bayon Temple and they were losing income.

On 19 May 2010, approximately 100 residents of Ta Ches commune, Kampong Tralach district continued protesting in front of the provincial governor's office in Kampong Chhnang City (Kampong Chhnang). The residents who are engaged in a land dispute requested permission to plant rice on the land. This is the third day of protest.

On 19 May 2010, representatives of 35 families from Kilometre 6 commune in Russey Keo (Phnom Penh) gathered at the district hall to protest an eviction notice that accused them of illegal occupation of a land in Tuol Kork village.

On 18 May 2010, approximately 100 residents of Ta Ches commune, Kampong Tralach district continued protesting in front of the provincial governor's office in Kampong Chhnang City (Kampong Chhnang). The residents who are engaged in a land dispute requested permission to plant rice on the land. This is the second day of protest.

On 18 May 2010, approximately 200 villagers protested in front of Wat Botum in Phnom Penh to demand that the Prime Minister intervene in a land dispute. The villagers from Koh Kong province were not pleased with the compensation being offered.

On 17 May 2010, approximately 100 residents of Kampong Tralach district protested in front of the provincial governor's office in Kampong Chhnang City (Kampong Chhnang). The residents who are engaged in a land dispute requested permission to plant rice on the land and asked that 7 persons currently jailed in connection with the dispute be released.
On 17 May 2010, 5 persons were injured when a man used an axe to hit a bomb until it detonated in Mongkol Borey (Banteay Meanchey).
On 17 May 2010, a woman was injured when she bit a bomb she found near her home in Steung Treng province.

On 17 May 2010, over 100 villagers representing 2000 families in Snuol district, Kratie province were prevented from gathering in front of the Prime Minister's house. The villagers who were protesting the destruction of their farm lands by an agricultural company, moved their protest to Wat Botum (Phnom Penh). They were later removed by police.
On 15 May 2010, three commune police allegedly beat and administered electric shocks to a person in their custody in search of a confession in Tnoat Chum commune (Baray, KT).
On 14 May 2010, a soldier based in Thma Puok (Banteay Meanchey) was seriously injured when he stepped on a land mine while searching for bamboo shoots.
On 14 May 2010, a villager from Svay Chek (Banteay Meanchey) was seriously injured when a land mine exploded while he was out hunting.
On 11 May 2010, 500 residents of Santuk (Kampong Thom) protested the closure of a dam in their district in 2009, which they believe is the reason for the flooding of their farmlands.

On 9 May 2010, approximately 600 residents of Om Laing (Thpong, Kampong Speu) gathered to prevent employees of a company involved in a land dispute from clearing their land. There were approximately 100 soldiers stationed on the property.

On 5 May 2010, approximately 110 villagers from Prey Pdao commune in Takeo province protested in front of the National Assembly in Phnom Penh. Villagers were protesting the alleged violence by the police against the previous day's protesters.
In the week of May 4, 2010, a boy was injured when a bomb he was playing with exploded in Kampong Cham.
On 4 May 2010, approximately 200 residents of Svay Rieng province travelled to the home of the Senate President in Kamchay Mear (Prey Veng) to protest the detention of a community representative.

On 4 May 2010, a group of villagers in Srok Prey Kabbas (Takeo) protested the construction of a road that would destroy existing fences. The villagers said that three of them were beaten by police but this was denied by officials.

On 4 May 2010, approximately 87 workers at a garment factory in Mean Chey district protested in front of the Ministry of Labour in Phnom Penh. The workers alleged that they were prevented from working or earning a salary for most of April because they were not assigned shifts.

On 3 May 2010, approximately 200 residents protested in front of the district police office in Romeas Haek (Savy Rieng). The residents demanded the release of representatives who were arrested in connection with an earlier land dispute protest.
On 2 May 2010, approximately 100 residents of Tras commune gathered in front of a rubber company in Romeas Haek (Savy Rieng) to request the reopening of a road that had been cut off for 5 days.
On 1 May 2010, 5 plantation workers were killed and 9 injured by an explosion in Sala Krau (Pailin). The explosion occurred when they drove over an anti-tank mine.

assoc_actor_1: CCAWDU: Coalition of Cambodian Apparel Workers Democratic Union; CLC: Cambodian Labour Confederation; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 1 May 2010, the president of the CLC and CCAWDU led several thousands of workers to stage a demonstration in Phnom Penh city (PM, PP) demanding industry concessions from the government including a raise of minimum wage and implementation of health care and pension systems.

assoc_actor_1: CCU: Cambodian Confederation of Unions; CITA: Cambodian Independent Teachers' Association; Labor Group (Cambodia); Teachers (Cambodia)
notes: On 1 May 2010, in a 300-strong march led by the president of the CCU and CITA, demonstrators scuffled briefly with police due to a disagreement over the route of the march. They were demonstrating to advocate for industry concessions from the government.

On 29 April 2010, protesters gathered at the Provincial court in Siem Reap City (Siem Reap) to demand the release of a man who was arrested for illegal logging. The protesters said that government officials had sold the land to them.

On 27 April 2010, approximately 30 Boeung Kak Lake area villagers protested in front of the senate in Phnom Penh. The protesters wanted to draw attention to an on-going land dispute that could result in close to 4000 families being evicted from their homes.
On 26 April 2010, a man from Chamlan Romeang Lea village in Samlout (Battambang) was killed by an unknown group of people in an attacked that is believed to be linked to land disputes in the area.

On 26 April 2010, approximately 50 villagers of Boeung Kak lake gathered in front of City Hall in Phnom Penh. The villagers opposed the approval of development plans for a project before the 4000 families presently on the land finalized compensation.

On 21 April 2010, over 100 residents of Thmei commune in Sen Sok district protested outside the Prime Minister's house in Phnom Penh. The residents opposed a planned drainage system that they believe would negatively affect 600 families.

On 20 April 2010, approximately 600 villagers from Om Laing commune continued blocking National Road 52 to protest an on-going land dispute and what they claim to be inadequate efforts by the company to resolve the disagreement.

On 19 April 2010, approximately 300 persons from Om Laing (Thpong, Kampong Speu) protested near the site of a piece of disputed land in the commune. The aim of the protest was to prevent further clearing of the land. In the evening, approximately 400 villagers continued protesting, blocking a section of National Road 52.

On 17 April 2010, the Military troops of Thailand and Cambodia clashed near a disputed area in O Smach (Samraong, Oddar Meanchey). There was a brief pause between two periods of fighting. There were no reported fatalities or injuries.

On 8 April 2010, over 80 families from Choeung Ek commune in Dangkor district protested outside Wat Botum in Phnom Penh. The villagers requested the Prime Minister's intervention in settling a land dispute between themselves and other villagers.

On 7 April 2010, villagers from Kiri Vong district staged a land-dispute protest in the capital Phnom Penh. The residents claimed a NGO planted acacia trees on their land. The protest was broken up by police.

On 6 April 2010, approximately 100 market vendors protested outside the market in Banan (Battambang). The protest related to the attempted forced eviction by the police and military police. The vendors were previously given notice to vacate the site and that deadline had passed.

On 6 April 2010, vendors protested near Psar Leu market in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk). The vendors are unhappy with restrictions that have been implemented to manage traffic in the area because their businesses are being negatively impacted.
In the week of April 5, 2010, a boy was killed and another injured when a bomb they were playing with exploded in Kampot province.
On 5 April 2010, approximately 300 villagers continued protesting for a second day in Kandal Steung (Kandal). The villagers are engaged in a land dispute with a private company.

On 5 April 2010, 5 families from Prek Tanuo village in Chakangre Leu commune protested at City Hall in Phnom Penh. The families are facing eviction and alleged that commune officials threatened to destroy their homes if they did not accept the offered compensation.
On 4 April 2010, a village advocate was shot and injured by a group of unknown persons in Samlout (Battambang). There have been ongoing land disputes in the area.

On 4 April 2010, approximately 400 persons blocked the National Road 2 in Kandal Steung district, Kandal province. The residents protested that clearing equipment was sent days earlier to a contested rice field. Conflicting reports indicate that the military police had used violence to disperse the protesters by beating some with batons.

On 4 April 2010, residents in Prampi Makara (Phnom Penh) assaulted two men with rocks and staves. The men were suspected of earlier stealing a mobile phone. The police intervened and ended the assault.

On 29 March 2010, representatives of 160 families protested in front of the office of the Cambodian Veterans Association in Kampong Cham. The villagers alleged that the association is forcing them off their land.
On 28 March 2010, in Phnom Penh, over 100 teachers and parents gathered to protest the length of skirts worn by female students in school.

On 26 March 2010, approximately 500 persons blocked a section of National Road 4 in Kampong Speu province to demand the release of 2 community representatives. The representatives were arrested on charges stemming from a land dispute with a sugar company owned by a CPP senator.

On 25 March 2010, a group of protestors travelling from Thpong district, Kampong Speu province to join an ongoing demonstration to oppose the arrest of 2 community representatives were attacked by police. It is reported that 10 persons were injured when police attacked the group with batons, damaged their tractor and set-up check points to stop their progress.

On 25 March 2010, a mob of approximately 400 persons attacked and killed two alleged thieves and wounded another at the police station in Dangkao (Phnom Penh). The police had earlier arrested the three alleged thieves who were accused of stealing a motorcycle from two women.

On 25 March 2010, a mob of villagers in Dangkor in Phnom Penh municipality, killed two suspected thieves and injured another. The group of approximately 400 villagers attacked the men with sticks, knives, stones and poles.
On 22 March 2010, approximately 250 residents of Boeung Kak marched to City Hall in Phnom Penh to demand that the authorities give them a list of all registered properties in the lakeside area.

On 22 March 2010, approximately 50 promotion workers protested the firing of 30 workers allegedly because of their age and looks. The workers protested in front of the Angkor Beer company office on Norodom Boulevard in Phnom Penh.
On 21 March 2010, 3 children in Koas Krala commune (Battambang) were seriously injured when bombs they found and were playing with exploded.
On 19 March 2010, police and villagers attacked one another in Odongk district (Odongk, KS) when the authorities attempted to evict the villagers from a plot of land with force.
Property destruction: On 18 March 2010, a group of villagers torched the office of the Phnom Penh Sugar Company in Om Laing (Thpong, Kampong Speu). This event follows an unspecified land dispute.

On 18 March 2010, 400 villagers and 150 police clashed during the execution of a court order to evict 100 families from land in Phnum Touch commune, Odongk district, Kampong Speu province. It is reported that police attacked villagers when they refused to leave, and villagers used rocks and other objects to attack the police. Over 10 villagers and 14 policemen were injured.

On 18 March 2010, 22 families from Boeung Kak 1 commune in Tuol Kork district protested at the Phnom Penh Municipal Hall in Phnom Penh to demand compensation to relocate from their land for a planned road.
On 17 March 2010, two boys were killed and 10 adults injured when a grenade was thrown in a house in Chamkar Leu (Kampong Cham). It is believed that the attacked is connected to a business dispute.

On 16 March 2010, approximately 100 villagers protested in front of the local offices of a sugar company in Thpong district, Kampong Speu province. The residents of Om Laing commune reported that 11 excavators had impinged on 2 hectares of land in their community.
In March, a soldier seriously assaulted a Reaksmey Kampuchea journalist for allegedly taking unfavorable photographs of gambling in the Paoy Paet area (PP, BM).

On 7 March 2010, police clashed with a group of residents in Kraya commune (Santuk, Kampong Thom) after about 40 farmers tried to access their old farmland to plant cassava. Three men sustained injuries when police fired on the group who are former residents of a disputed piece of land in Kraya commune. Villagers were demanding farmland that was promised during the relocation process.
In the month of March 2010, a man attacked and injured two persons with a cleaver in Kandal province. The attacked was motivated by a land dispute.

In the month of March 2010, villagers in Romeas Haek (Savy Rieng) protesting a land dispute with a rubber company clashed with workers. It is reported that villagers detained a company representative and some were accused of destroying police property.

On 10 March 2010, approximately 60 residents of Boeung Kak lake protested in front of the Prime Minister's house in Phnom Penh. The residents demanded land titles for their property as they feared they would lose their land to a real estate development project. The police later moved the protesters to Wat Botum.

On 9 March 2010, a man was killed and his wife and daughter injured when a bomb exploded in Phnom Kravanh (Pursat). It is reported that the civilians were using the bomb to catch fish after it was found in a field.

On 8 March 2010, villagers evicted in 2009 from disputed land attempted to return to their former farmland in Kraya commune (Santuk, KT) and allegedly attacked police guarding the plantation with knives. Police opened fire on the villagers and wounded three.

actor2: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Forestry Officials
notes: On 7 March 2010, Oddar Meanchey province forestry officials claimed that persons from a group of 200 military families shot at them when they attempted to remove the families from a protected forest area. Coded at Samraong city.
On 7 March 2010, a group of 40 villagers farming inside a concession area was fired on by police guarding the plantation at Kraya commune (Santuk, Kampong Thom). Three persons were shot and injured.

On 6 March 2010, a villager was killed by a soldier in Anlong Veng (Oddar Meanchey). It is reported that the soldier stopped the villager who was transporting wood and demanded payment. He shot the villager when he refused his demand.

On 6 March 2010, community forest monitors and soldiers clashed in Samraong (Oddar Meanchey). The clashed occurred when the monitors attempted to ask the soldiers and their families to remove their settlement from protected forest areas. It was reported that 10 monitors were assaulted.
On 5 March 2010, approximately 58 families in Battambang province protested the construction of a tower. The residents opposed the tower due to its health risks.

Non-Violent Activity: On 4/3/2010, the Military of Cambodia fired 200 rockets at an airfield in Kampong Chhnang, 110 miles from the Thai border. The Cambodian government and military denied that this rare public test of rockets is a show of force but in light of the border tensions between Thailand and Cambodia this event has potential significance.

On 4 March 2010, approximately 80 persons gathered outside the Provincial Hall in Sihanoukville (Preah Sihanouk province) to request that the authorities provide land for them to relocate. Presently, the villagers are accused of living on public land.

On 3 March 2010, 5 villagers of O Smach (Samraong, Oddar Meanchey) were seriously beaten by armed soldiers. This followed an earlier scuffle after a group of soldiers accused a group of persons of interfering with their motorbike. The soldiers returned a few days later and beat the group with belts and sticks.

On 1 March 2010, villagers marching to the Prime Minister's residence in Takhmao were blocked by police in Dangkor (Phnom Penh). The villagers are protesting the alleged seizure of their farmland. It is reported that scuffles occurred when villagers tried to cross the police barriers and police detained eight persons.
On 28 February 2010, over 1000 persons continued protesting in Om Laing, Thpong district, Kampong Speu province over their possible eviction for a sugar company to develop the land.
On 27 February 2010, over 1000 persons protested in Om Laing, Thpong district, Kampong Speu province over their possible eviction for a sugar company to develop the land.
On 18 February 2010, 45 staff members of Angkor Chum district hospital in Angkor Chum district, Siem Reap protested the alleged cruel treatment by the operational district director.
On 17 February 2010, 3 Thais who are thought to be illegal loggers were injured in the border area in Choam Khsant (Preah Vihear) when they stepped on separate land mines.
On 16 February 2010, several hundred vendors protested their planned eviction in front of the Siem Reap Provincial Hall in Siem Reap city.
During the week of February 15, 2010, taxi drivers protested raised parking fees at a market in Thma Puok (Banteay Meanchey).

On 15 February 2010, approximately 100 villagers from Daek Phleung village in Samrong Tong district protested in front of the provincial governor's office in Kampong Speu. The villagers demanded the dismissal of the village chief due to alleged corruption.
On 10 February 2010, 3 boys were seriously injured in Koas Krala (Battambang) when the mine they were playing with exploded.

actor1: Police Forces of Cambodia (1993-) Prison Guards
notes: On 5 February 2010, two persons reported that they were beaten while in custody of Svay Chrum district police as they tried to obtain a confession from them for a crime they did not commit.

On 4 February 2010, approximately 200 villagers from Kandal Steung district attempted to protest in front of the Kandal Provincial Headquarters. The villagers are involved in a price dispute with a local electricity supplier and were quickly turned away from their protest location by the police.
On 2 February 2010, 12 civilians returning from the forest were fired on by Thai military in O Smach (Samraong, Oddar Meanchey). One man was seriously injured.

On 2 February 2010, approximately 100 residents of Boeung Kak lake village 3 protested outside City Hall in Phnom Penh to demand the construction of a drainage system in the area as waste water was flooding their homes.

On 29 January 2010, the Military troops of Thailand and Cambodia exchanged gunfire near a disputed area in Veal Veaeng (Pursat). One person was killed in the exchange. Reports are conflicting as to whether the person who died is a Thai soldier or a civilian.

On 27 January 2010, approximately 100 market vendors protested their pending eviction from the Pouk market in Pouk district, Siem Reap province. A group of police officers were at the market to dismantle their stalls and forcibly evict the vendors. However, local officials stopped the forced eviction when the vendors started demonstrating.

On 27 January 2010, over 120 families protested outside their apartment in Borei Keila commune, Prampi Makara district, Phnom Penh. The residents will be forced to leave due to an agreement between a development company and city officials.

On 26 January 2010, 4 villagers were injured in a clash between staff members and residents in Prey Nob (Preah Sihanouk). It is reported that 40 villagers were engaged in a 3-day land protest when they were attacked by staff members of the company that was given the land.

On 25 January 2010, over 40 villagers engaged in a land dispute protested in Prey Nob (Preah Sihanouk). Workers of the company involved in the dispute were also present at the location. This event is part of a 3-day protest.

On 24 January 2010, over 40 villagers engaged in a land dispute protested in Prey Nob (Preah Sihanouk). Workers of the company involved in the dispute were also present at the location. This event is part of a 3-day protest.

On 24 January 2010, the Military troops of Thailand and Cambodia clashed in Kantuot (Choam Khsant, Preah Vihear) allegedly after Thai troops entered Cambodia territory. It is reported that two Thai soldiers were injured in the battle.

On 24 January 2010, approximately 200 former residents of Tonle Bassac commune, Chamkar Mon district, Phnom Penh marched to their former residence to remember their violent eviction a year earlier. The residents also raised concerns about their relocation site which is 20 kilometers from the city centre.

assoc_actor_1: FTUWKC: Free Trade Union of Workers of the Kingdom of Cambodia; Labor Group (Cambodia)
notes: On 22 January 2010, approximately 100 workers, 12 opposition legislators and the leader of the Free Trade Union of Workers marched in Phnom Penh to mark the 6th anniversary of the murder of a former Free Trade Union of Workers leader. They peacefully called on the government to arrest the real murders or nationwide strike action will be taken. Although security was present they did not engage with the gathering.

Defusal: In the week of January 21, 2010, a K58 mine bomb was discovered by cleaners in Paoy Paet (Ou Chrov, Banteay Meanchey). It is reported that the bomb was placed along with bags of rubbish by an unidentified man. The bomb was taken and destroyed by the Cambodian Mine Action Authority.

On 19 January 2010, approximately 100 persons protested in front of the Pursat Provincial Court in Krong Pursat (Pursat). The protesters demanded the release of a man suspected of robbery who they believe was wrongfully arrested.
On 18 January 2010, vendors from Chhouk market in Kampot province protested in Phnom Penh. The vendors said that stalls built on the market's parking lot were reducing the number of customers.
On 15 January 2010, workers at a shoe factory in Phnom Penh protested the firing of 3 union leaders. It is reported that 4 workers were injured when police tried to disperse protesters.
On 14 January 2010, workers at a shoe factory in Chaom Chau (Phnom Penh) set fire to tyres in protest against being excluded from a meeting to negotiate the termination of an employee walkout.
On 13 January 2010, workers at a shoe factory in Chaom Chau commune, Por Senchey district, Phnom Penh continued protesting the firing of union leaders.
On 12 January 2010, workers at a shoe factory in Chaom Chau commune, Por Senchey district, Phnom Penh continued protesting the firing of union leaders.

On 11 January 2010, a grenade was launched into the home of Ampov Prey's (Kandal Stueng, Kandal) commune chief. The police believe the attack may be connected to the chief's land dispute decisions. No injuries were reported.
On 11 January 2010, workers at a shoe factory in Chaom Chau commune, Por Senchey district, Phnom Penh continued protesting the firing of union leaders.

On 11 January 2010, members of 13 families protested in front of the district headquarters in Phnom Penh to demand more compensation and a guaranteed relocation site upon eviction. The families are residents of Boeung Kak 1 commune in Tuol Kork district and are slated to be evicted by month end.
On 10 January 2010, two commune officers beat a civilian in Kandal province, coded at Ta Khmao city, over an earlier public dispute, that resulted in the victim later dying from his injuries.
On 10 January 2010, workers at a shoe factory in Chaom Chau commune, Por Senchey district, Phnom Penh continued protesting the firing of union leaders.
On 9 January 2010, workers at a shoe factory in Chaom Chau commune, Por Senchey district, Phnom Penh continued protesting the firing of union leaders.
On 8 January 2010, 900 workers at a factory in Phnom Penh protested the firing of union leaders.
On 5 January 2010, residents of Boeung Kak protested outside the commune office in Phnom Penh to demand that the government clear the sewage from their community.
On 3 January 2010, approximately 100 villagers protested at the site of an on-going land dispute in Kandal Steung (Kandal) and removed pole markers.

On 3 January 2010, a Cambodian man was shot by Thai soldiers near the Thai/Cambodia border in Banteay Meanchey province. The man reported that he was collecting plants in Dangkrek mountains when he was shot.
